name: Puhemies.
text: – The first item on the agenda is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Ukraine and relations between the European Union and Russia. (2014/2841 (RSP))

name: Guy Verhofstadt (ALDE). -
text: Mr President, it is always the same here in the Parliament. We ask for Baroness Ashton, and once again she is not present. I know that she is somewhere else. I think that she sees world affairs as only being one thing – Iran. I do not think that she is aware of any other problem in the world. It is a shame that every time, for nearly five years now, when we ask for Baroness Ashton, she is never there – even for important matters, such as Ukraine, relations with Russia, and the uncertainty surrounding the Association Agreement, where we have no explanation. In the next five years, we must not accept an attitude from the new High Representative like the one we have seen from Baroness Ashton. I want this made clear at the beginning of this debate. (Applause)

name: Rebecca Harms (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mr President, Mr Olli Rehn, I would like to thank The Commissioner for his work and for his work. Nothing against you! However, I also miss Martin Schulz as President of the European Parliament in this debate this morning. Martin Schulz has agreed with us on the Fast Track Procedure for the ratification of the Association Agreement as a whole. Martin Schulz wanted the two parliaments to be interconnected with video. He should also listen to the criticism of the current state of the ratification agreement and then hold this meeting with us. I find that the absence of Ashton and the absence of Martin Schulz are intolerable.

name: Štefan Füle
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - Mr President, those who criticise the European project should realise that the benefits of the freedoms that we enjoy are not self-evident for everybody on our continent – peace with our neighbours, absence of threats to our sovereignty, open borders, democracy, rule of law, and prosperity. These achievements, which we tend to take for granted, are the long-standing aspirations of the people of Ukraine. For many, they correspond with a future based on European values which, as Europeans themselves, they share. They have paid a high price in the process since last November, and I am proud to be here today so that we can together take a historic step in Ukraine’s political association and economic integration with the European Union.  Much has happened since we were preparing for the Vilnius Summit one year ago. Crimea, part of the sovereign territory of an independent Ukraine, has been illegally annexed by Russia in an act we will never recognise. Furthermore, the territorial integrity of Ukraine is being further challenged by rebels in the East, who are supported through the direct military involvement of Russia. Many hundreds have been killed in military action among people who had been living as peaceful neighbours only a year ago, but aggression does not pay. On the contrary, it has further united the Ukrainian people behind the aspiration for a better future for their country.  There is no time to rest. Much remains to be done. The fragile ceasefire will need to be turned into a genuine peace. The courageous move by President Poroshenko offers a real opportunity for lasting peace, but there are many challenges. Direct fighting on the ground has become sporadic and prisoners are being freed, but unfortunately incidences of shelling and shooting continue. Russian troops are still in Ukraine; armed forces are using the ceasefire to redeploy and resupply; and large parts of the border remain outside of the control of the authorities, allowing a continuous flow of militants, arms and equipment into Ukraine from Russia. What can we do? Our approach is threefold. Firstly, we continue to give our full and active support for a sustainable political solution. Secondly, we are maintaining pressure on Russia through a gradual increase of individual and economic sanctions to try to make it alter its course of action and move towards a solution. And thirdly, we continue our support for Ukraine’s sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity, and to help it overcome the difficulties it faces. My colleague Commissioner Oettinger is sparing no efforts to facilitate an agreement between Russia and Ukraine ensuring a fair price for gas deliveries and security of supply to the European Union. We have also engaged with Russia to discuss the effects on the Russian economy of the implementation of the association agreement – including the DCFTA – with a view to clarifying concerns and, where appropriate, identifying solutions. The deal reached on Friday by my colleague Commissioner Karel De Gucht is good news for de-escalation, and it has the potential to be a game-changer in the ongoing crisis. I will discuss this further in the next debate this morning. You are aware that the European Union adopted a new package of restrictive measures with regard to Russia last week on the basis of the mandate of the European Council of 30 August. This was done in response to the increased inflow of fighters and weapons from the territory of the Russian Federation into Eastern Ukraine and the aggression by the Russian armed forces on Ukrainian soil over the past weeks, and in order to reinforce the effectiveness of existing measures. The new package includes, firstly, more individuals who are responsible for undermining the territorial integrity of Ukraine, and secondly, economic and financial sanctions with regard to access to capital markets, defence, dual-use goods and sensitive technologies. We have always stressed that our restrictive measures are reversible and scalable; therefore, by the end of September, the Member States will carry out a comprehensive review of the implementation of the peace plan and, in the light of the review, and if the situation on the ground so warrants, the sanctions may be amended, suspended or repealed – in whole or in part – depending, of course, also on developments in Crimea. We have already expressed our strong support for the peace deal agreed in Minsk; its implementation is a key to success. We need to learn from recent experience, from the failed attempts in Geneva and Berlin earlier this year, to pass from words to deeds in reaching a political solution, and to respect the ceasefire agreed in June. We call on the Russian Government to pass from verbal pledges to the implementation of commitments this time around and to ensure a genuine and a comprehensive implementation of the peace plan. As I have said, the implementation of the ceasefire agreement and the road map will be important for all further decisions on sanctions. Today it is difficult to see if and how successfully European Union relations with Russia can continue under the label of the so-called strategic partnership. In the short term, much more effort is needed to reach a comprehensive conflict resolution in Ukraine, and Russia must show that it takes its commitments seriously. Russia should prove in deeds its respect for international law and for the territorial integrity and sovereignty of its neighbours. As for the medium and long term, the European Union and Russia will need to further build their relations on shared interests with a view to engaging in dialogue, particularly in the fields of trade and investment, energy, science, cooperation in solving international crises and in responding to global challenges. In any case, the solution to the conflict in Ukraine will be the litmus test for launching a dialogue on the development of the huge untapped potential of the European Union’s future relations with Russia. We must avoid creating a lasting rift on our continent. We must also reflect on how we can jointly work on a vision of cooperation on the European continent, where all countries can take advantage of economic opportunities from Lisbon to Vladivostok.  Our European House is being destroyed; the time has come to rebuild it with all European partners involved, not leaving anyone outside of this process. The relationship between the EU and Russia played a central role; the relationship between the European Union, the customs union and, in the future, the Eurasian Union will have an important role to play.

name: Elmar Brok
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I believe that today is an historic moment, that the treaty with Ukraine will be ratified at the same time in the Rada and in the European Parliament, and that we are saying that, even after Tuesday's agreement, this treaty will not be changed at all. It doesn't change a word, there's an asymmetric implementation. The fact that this has been recognised in this way no longer gives Russia the justification for taking action against this Treaty and of using it as an alibi to take action against Ukraine. I believe that we should make this very clear that this Treaty, in its wording, applies in all parts, unamended. It must also be clear that this agreement can no longer be torpedoed. I believe that it is equally important that the Ukrainian President and the Ukrainian Government propose today in the Rada a series of reform possibilities of anti-corruption, decentralisation and other things that will make it possible to initiate a sensible process within Ukraine too, thereby implementing the Poroshenko peace plan accordingly. This, too, is an important measure. It must also be said that the energy package, which is once again under negotiation, comes to a reasonable solution, that Russia must no longer be allowed to use energy and energy prices as a political weapon. I hope that an agreement will be reached there. Now we come to a third area – that is the Russian invasion of Ukraine. The annexation of Crimea under international law, the lack of sufficient respect for the ceasefire, the talk about Novorossiya, which gives the impression that we want to annex other areas, that Russian soldiers have been involved in and engaged in hybrid warfare in Ukraine with tanks, official battalions, and that, as Commissioner rightly said, we want to see action rather than words, and that this has never been respected in Russia since the Geneva agreements. As long as that is not the case, we will persevere with the sanctions and, if nothing happens, we will possibly issue further sanctions, because it must be clear to Russia that international law is valid and that Ukraine's territorial integrity is safeguarded.  Commissioner, you have rightly said that we are prepared to partner with Russia. It is in our interest to have a good relationship with Russia and Russia with us. But this can only be done under the conditions of respect for international law. I believe that this must be clear. I believe that the acceptance of current Russian policy in some parts is simply unacceptable to us, because we should see that this Europe is formed on the basis of the law and the rules that no country is entitled to govern in the internal affairs of another country by pressure and by attacking such countries.  This must also be clear, that this applies not only to Ukraine, but also to Moldova, including to matters of Georgia and other countries, but also, in particular, to safeguard our own countries. Now I am glad that a NATO renaissance has taken place in Newport. Europe's collective security also depends on NATO. That is why Poland and the Baltic States must be adequately protected. It should also be clear that we are entering a new era, that we are finally implementing a European foreign, security and defence policy in order to ensure in this way that the territory of each european state must have the same quality and that no one can be disadvantaged. Everyone must know that they have the solidarity of the other in order to ensure a peaceful Europe on this basis.

name: Gianni Pittella
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioners, unfortunately, as we know in Ukraine, more than three thousand people have died in recent months. Many more people were injured. Hundreds of thousands of civilians are fleeing.  The principle of international law of the inviolability of borders has been broken and dialogue between partner countries has been replaced by escalation of violence and the imposition of diplomatic sanctions. These are the elements of a crisis of great importance to Europe. We must be able to respond fully and firmly, not only because this crisis will have an impact on our security, but also because what is at stake is the future of relations with our neighbours, with whom we share the main interests. With this responsibility and with this firmness, we must ask ourselves, this Parliament, the Member States and the High Representative for Foreign and Security Policy this question: does Europe need a new Cold War? We Socialists and Democrats say no, but we also wonder whether Europe should allow anything to prevent a new Cold War. We Socialists and Democrats say no. We believe that not everything can be allowed and insist on respecting the right of Ukrainians to decide their fate as well as on defending the principle of territorial integrity.  Peace and prosperity in our neighbourhood should be the objective, and we still want to believe that this objective is shared with Russia. At the same time, the defence of international law is a duty for us, and legality is the single framework for developing future peaceful relations. The recently declared ceasefire is a positive step forward, but it is fragile. We need to maintain dialogue with Russia in order to make the ceasefire effective and to assist those affected by the conflict. Sanctions cannot always replace the search for a diplomatic and political solution. We call on the High Representative, in the future too, to facilitate dialogue between Ukraine and Russia and to maintain open channels of communication with Russia in order to take concrete steps towards a peaceful solution to the crisis. Among these passages I would like to mention: one, the withdrawal of all military forces from Ukraine; two, to ban the entry of fighters and weapons into eastern Ukraine; three, the commitment of the rebels in the negotiations for a comprehensive political solution. We are sure that Russia can convince the rebels, because another conflict on russia's borders would be unacceptable. Let us therefore give peace a chance, a chance. Taking into account the situation on the ground, the European Union must be ready to phase out sanctions and, if the assessment is positive, to re-establish good relations with Russia. I would also stress that the crisis in Ukraine should not hinder cooperation with Russia in other areas where our interests coincide. I am thinking of the fight against international terrorism in Syria and Iraq, the need to stabilise Afghanistan and the fight against the spread of weapons of mass destruction in important regions such as Iran. The European Parliament had no news, and was surprised at the decision to postpone the implementation of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement, which we are voting on here today, until December 2015. Many problems could have been avoided if the current consultation process on the implementation of the agreement had been agreed earlier. The delay in implementing the agreement should not be seen in a Cold War logic as a victory for Russia, but as a concession to build peace. I will conclude by saying that we are giving peace a chance, and I want to reiterate that. We work for peace and prosperity and we work together, all together, for these goals.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, having just returned yesterday from Kiev, I feel that the need for supporting Ukraine against the aggression it is facing from Russia is clearer than ever. It is clear also to my group, the ECR, that in response to Ukraine’s ambitions to move in a westward, democratic, Euro-Atlantic direction, Russia is revisiting its imperial past – refusing to accept that its large neighbour in the 21st century is an independent sovereign nation that has the right to take charge of its own destiny. The refusal of Russia to accept this and to work within this internationally accepted legal paradigm should concern us all as democrats. This is not a case of an isolated conflict in a faraway land, but rather it is part of a wider struggle in which democratic nations on our own doorstep are fighting off the revanchist and irredentist ideals of a Putin-led authoritarian and revisionist regime that boasts of a nuclear arsenal. The West has already stood by as countries such as Georgia, Armenia and Moldova have suffered as a result of these ideals. We must not allow Ukraine to become another precedent. It is for this reason that Member States within the EU and NATO should begin to take proactive, rather than reactive, steps in this conflict, sending a message to President Putin that there is hard-power substance behind our rhetoric. Commentators from across the world have noted now the necessity for Russia of militarily acquiring a land corridor to the Crimea. In this regard we should also note the presence of 50 000 Russian troops at the ready on the borders. It has been suggested that one Member State of NATO is already arming the Ukrainian army in anticipation of this further act of aggression. So today I call on other Member States to do the same and allow Ukraine to acquire the means to defend itself. We are making the right move today in this House by simultaneously voting to ratify the Association Agreement and the deep and comprehensive free trade agreement (DCFTA) with Ukraine’s Verkhovna Rada. Europe, including, I have to say, my own country, has for too long relied on the dominance of Russian energy and finance. We must now look to diversify away from these dependencies and to have a coordinated EU plan for external energy security, just as we have successfully united the entire European Union in the support of tough economic sanctions against Russia for its blatant acts of aggression.

name: Petras Auštrevičius
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioners, the present situation in Ukraine remains very, and increasingly, complicated. We are witnessing a war going on and war crimes being committed in Europe. This has deconstructed the European security system and exposed Ukraine to undeclared aggression from Russia. The pretext for Russia’s military action against Ukraine was the choice – by the free will of the Ukrainian people and the country’s new leadership – of a European perspective to create new and more transparent governance, to fight corruption and to develop a free-trade exchange with the European Union. Is that a crime or a danger for the existing system? Who can presume to sit in judgment and decide to impose a harsh situation on neighbouring countries? Many of us were taken by surprise by the announcement on 12 September that the implementation of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement was being postponed for 15 months. It is as if a young couple’s parents had decided after the wedding to postpone the honeymoon for 15 months. Notwithstanding the format of trilateral talks, we have to respect the autonomy of EU decision-making, the competence of EU institutions and EU procedures. We should be asking the question: is this not ultimately a recognition of the EU’s inability to impose a necessary level of sanctions against Russia, and the continuation of a self-imposed policy of restraint? Finally, colleagues, by accepting the ‘three seas’ policy of the High Representative and, I am sorry to say, the Italian Presidency, we simply support a ‘no voice, no action’ policy line. I find that most regrettable, and I hope our ratification today of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement will be a necessary step in the right direction. Let us vote together for Europe’s future and for a democratic and European Ukraine.

name: Georgios Katrougkalos
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, I have just come back from two visits to Kiev, where I followed the trial for the ban on the Communist party of Ukraine. This was a show trial clearly reflecting the rise in political influence of neo-fascist elements. I have witnessed with my own eyes the failure of EU policies in the area. Ukraine is a deeply divided country with a very weak civil society and political parties which are little more than a façade for the business projects of oligarchs. We have been engaged in a bras de fer and a trade war with Russia, which is poisoning Ukraine’s internal political life and, at the same time, harming European farmers and the European economy. Instead of a policy of dividing, we should opt for one of reconciliation, giving the Ukrainian people a chance to avoid a civil war and to decide freely on their future, with full recognition of fundamental human rights and respect for European values. There is still time for peace and democracy in Ukraine.

name: Rebecca Harms
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. I have worked with many Ukrainians for at least ten years on this moment of ratification of an agreement between the European Union and Ukraine, and I simply have to admit now that I do not know at this moment whether I should be happy, whether to laugh or to cry. I am very cold because I do not agree at all with the line taken by the European Commission and the Council on the trade agreement. In order to understand this, we need to re-establish what the Association Agreement in Ukraine stands for. That is not what the Ukrainians wanted. The Ukrainians wanted membership of the European Union, and from the outset there were many who saw the Association Agreement as an instrument of the European Union to keep Ukraine a little far away. The fact that this association agreement exists today is not thanks to Mr Barroso, Mrs Ashton, Mr Füle, Mr De Gucht, Merkel, Hollande or others. The fact that we can and want to ratify this today has to do with the fact that the citizens of Ukraine have fought for freedom and democracy. We did not take this as seriously as we should have taken seriously. It is President Putin who has taken this democracy movement the most. It was Putin who decided when his puppet regime was no longer tenable, when he took Yanukovych out of the game, that he would have to go so far against freedom and democracy in Ukraine that he was even ready to invade Crimea. In the meantime, he is prepared to wage a war, a war that will never be declared, which is taking place on the territory of Ukraine, but which is directed against freedom, democracy and European values as a whole. Ladies and gentlemen, the worst thing in this situation of compromise is self-deception, ongoing self-deception. The emperor's new clothes, I thought, Mr Füle, in your speech. My impression is that we must now do everything we can to ensure that the one who has bet on the military solution – Putin – does not get what he wanted with the military solution, while we have not been able to find a way to protect our Ukrainian friends from this readiness for war from Russia. I think that is very difficult. We have relied on this fast-track procedure for ratifying the Association Agreement. Mr Brok, I do not understand you. Are you naive? Or do you really believe that it is already certain that the trade agreement will enter into force unchanged in January 2016? I have read who has taken action against it. I have to tell you that the only one I trust at the moment and who has tried to explain his real-political approach to me is Pavlo Klimkin, the Foreign Minister in Kiev. We have an incredibly difficult road ahead of us. Everything is in question in this trade agreement. And we will only get what Ukraine needs if we really dedicate ourselves now to Ukraine, if we do everything we can to ensure that political, social and economic reforms take place. We are paying at the moment, we are taking money in our hands so that Putin gets his big foot in the door. I don't know if we'll get him out of there. Because we, as Europeans, have let ourselves be lied to by Russian diplomats and Russian politicians. One last wish: the orientation alone towards oligarchs and the old established politicians in Ukraine must not continue in this way. I recommend that all colleagues seek the conversation with many more Ukrainians, so that we know how our actions work and so that we finally understand what this country really needs. Winter is going to be tough. And even that is not even settled that we can do it with Oettinger's weak ideas. Ladies and gentlemen! If the Commission were not already ...... (Interjections) (The President cut off the speaker) (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Elmar Brok (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, Mrs Harms, I would like to thank Mrs Harms for her work on this I agree with almost everything you have said here. But we are ratifying today. We should retain the power of interpretation through our own ratification. If we ratify this Treaty, it will be ratified as it is and cannot be changed. This will do the same today the Rada. Everything else is outside the text of this Treaty.  If we ratify today, the Treaty will remain as it is. This sovereignty of interpretation should not be taken away from us by our own insecurity, because this is highly unwise and means the next gateway. That is why we are saying that we are ratifying this today, and that this cannot be changed by anyone; there may be exceptions to the implementation.

name: Rebecca Harms (Verts/ALE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr Brok, I would like to thank Mr Brok for his work, It will not surprise you: I will recommend to my group today that it approve the association agreements. But I am not doing this because I believe the Dud in the Commission, or because I have confidence in President Hollande, who wants to deliver Mistral, but at the same time blocks the trade agreement with Ukraine. I am doing this because, in this situation, this is the only chance to strengthen the backs of wise minds such as Pavlo Klimkin and others in Ukraine in their hopeless and yet supportive situation.

name: Nigel Farage
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, amongst the long list of foreign policy failures and contradictions in the last few years, including of course the bombing of Libya and the desire to arm the rebels in Syria, has been the unnecessary provocation of Vladimir Putin. This EU empire, ever seeking to expand, stated its territorial claim on the Ukraine some years ago. Just to make that worse, some NATO members said they would like the Ukraine to join NATO. We directly encouraged the uprising in the Ukraine that led to the toppling of President Yanukovych; that led in turn to Vladimir Putin reacting; and the moral of the story is: if you poke the Russian bear with a stick, do not be surprised when he reacts.  Now just to continue with that, today we are rushing through, at undue speed, an Association Agreement with the Ukraine, and as we speak there are NATO soldiers engaged in military exercises in the Ukraine. Have we taken leave of our senses? Do we actually want to have a war with Putin? Because if we do, we are certainly going about it the right way.  Perhaps we ought to recognise that the West now faces the biggest threat and crisis to our way of life that we have seen for over 70 years. The recent beheadings of the British and American hostages graphically illustrates the problem, and we have our citizens from our own countries engaged in that struggle too. In the war against Islamic extremism, Vladimir Putin, whatever we may think of him as a human being, is actually on our side. I suggest we grow up. I suggest we recognise the real threat facing all of our countries, communities and societies, stop playing war games in the Ukraine and start to prepare a plan to help countries like Syria, Iraq, Kenya, and indeed Nigeria, to try and help them to deal with the real threat that faces us. Let us not go on provoking Putin, whether we like him or not. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Ioan Mircea Paşcu (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Sir, in your considered opinion, which is better: to have Russian soldiers fighting a war on the territory of Ukraine, or to have NATO troops exercising in response to that on the territory of Ukraine?

name: Nigel Farage (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – The point I was making is that there should be a huge degree of guilt in this House about what provoked all of this in the first place. We saw Western Ukrainians waving European flags, rioting, setting fire to things and effectively staging a coup d’état which brought down the Ukrainian President, leading to this instability. Yes, you are the guilty people and you refuse to accept it.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI). -
text: Mr. President! In the direction of all those ladies and gentlemen who are calling here for even more sanctions and provocations, may one thing be written in the register: they all carry out these power games on the backs of the people. It is they who are suffering, not politicians, who are debating it and are constantly ramping up a scenario that is problematic enough.  Let me express my appreciation to Ukraine. Ukraine is part of the European family of nations, and I myself was chairman of the Austrian-Ukrainian Parliamentary Friendship Society for six years. We have always worked to bring Ukraine closer to Europe, because it is part of the European family of nations. But from the day that both Russian and American mercenaries were active here in Ukraine, a process has been initiated which is an unfortunate one and which touches all the people here in a very unpleasant way. Those who are now calling for it and saying that the Russians are here, that is right: do not forget that there are also at least 400 Blackwater mercenaries in Ukraine. My request to you is to stop sanctions, stop provocations and find a way of reason here, a tripolar process of peace-building between the Russians, the Americans and Ukraine.

name: Jacek Saryusz-Wolski (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking We are facing a conflict at stake not only in Ukraine's sovereignty, but also in our security, security in Europe and the stability of an order based on democracy and the rule of law. Ukraine faces a dual challenge: reforming the state whose agenda is association, and protecting its borders and territorial integrity from Russian aggression, invasion and war. Ukraine must feel real support: otherwise, if we leave it alone with Russia, it will bow to its pressure. The ratification and full implementation of the Association Agreement today is therefore crucial. Only consistent political pressure, Russia's political isolation, increasing economic sanctions can prompt Russia to withdraw and cease military action in Ukraine. The first step is a ceasefire, but let us recall that this was also intended to mean the withdrawal of foreign troops – Russian troops – from Ukrainian territory.  The States of the Union should support Ukraine in its military activities and efforts, m.in. by supplying weapons, in its efforts to protect its sovereignty and independence. The concessions made so far by the Union have not resolved the conflict, on the contrary, they are seen by Russia as a weakness and an incentive for further aggressive steps and a progressive invasion. I am afraid that the postponement of the entry into force of the trade part will also share the same fate – it will encourage Russia to take further aggressive steps. Russian aggression reinforces the need for our common and solidarity-based foreign policy and the strengthening of the military and defence capabilities of the European Union and NATO. Narrow, mercantile interests must not paralyse our European policy.

name: Knut Fleckenstein (S&D). -
text: Mr. President, dear colleagues! This Parliament has always been committed to the sovereignty of Ukraine. That is why we have always had a clear stance against the annexation of Crimea and all the disguised steps taken by Russia to destabilise its neighbour. This will continue to be the case in the future. The ceasefire, even if it is not observed in some places, is a first step. It may allow for a political solution, but it is not yet one. We do not confuse this. Further steps must follow. The Ukrainian President has shown the way. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which It is not a question of draging Ukraine on one side or the other, so to speak. We must be concerned with supporting Ukraine on its path to political and economic reform, on its path to democracy and the rule of law and prosperity. For that is what drove the citizens of Kiev to the Majdan. That is why we are voting today in favour of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement, because it opens up new opportunities for cooperation between both partners. That is why we also support the consultations between the EU, Ukraine and Russia on the compatibility of free trade agreements with the EU and trade with Russia. Better to learn late than never. But the late timing of these talks is extremely annoying. Like travelling preachers, we have called for this over and over again. The fact that there is only now serious talk leaves a devastating aftertaste and is a sign of poverty for us. I very much hope that a different, faster way will be chosen with regard to the treaties with Moldova and Georgia. Ukraine needs economic modernisation. We support them, now and also through the future free trade agreement. But Ukraine also needs good relations with its neighbours in both the east and the west.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Two years ago, in an interview with a NATO High Representative about the threats in the Königsnem region of Kaliningrad, I heard that the Russian threat had evaporated. "Has evaporated" – this was exactly the phrase used. I think that in the current situation we can no longer afford to misjune, naivety, illusions and pretend that such threats, not only for Ukraine, but for my whole region, for the free world, is not there.  Mr Farage, I would like to thank you for your I think the policy of salami and pretending that if we throw some sort of russia's cool down, we will be satisfied and we will be able to deal with other things is a fundamental mistake.  Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. I will admit that I regretted your affirmation of the Eurasian Union. This is Vladimir Putin's demand and we should be careful at the moment what signals and gestures we are conveying to the Russian side. Very consistent diplomatic sanctions need to be put in place.  I am pleased with the ratification of today's simultaneous and common, but I believe that the Association Agreement in its commercial part should enter into force immediately.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE). -
text: Mr President, first of all, I find it highly regrettable that Baroness Ashton is not among us. I wonder what better, at the end of her term of office, she has to do than to be present at such a serious, highly sensitive and important debate as this. With all due respect to you, Commissioner Füle, that is also how I would like to interpret the very general remarks that you have made, because otherwise, given what happened just a few days ago, I find them somewhat inappropriate. I regret that the leader of the ‘Advocates of Mr Putin’ group here in Parliament is not present, but let me remind you of the fact that I come from a country which in 1938 faced a serious threat and that, due to an agreement reached in a city not far from the Czech Republic, basically we were left alone. You might say that this is an inappropriate comparison but what we face today is, first of all, the ratification of an important agreement, in fact the same type of agreement that I had the privilege to be a part of when we were negotiating with the European Communities in 1990-91. I am still fully aware of how important it has been economically, and how important it was politically and psychologically. Today I could say that the Ukrainians are in a similar situation, but no they are not: they are in a worse situation. In 1990-91 we were basically surfing an unstoppable wave. Ukraine today is still in very unsafe waters. I do not need to remind you that we are facing a situation which constitutes aggression, a breach of international law, with thousands of people killed, Russian forces in Ukraine, and other measures characteristic of certain services in Russia. I find it highly regrettable that, just a few days ago, it was agreed in trilateral talks, i.e. in the presence of the Russians, that the implementation of the trade agreement would be postponed. If I look at the international press what does it say? Russia has 2 400 amendments to the draft agreement. Do we really think that one year from now Russia will not still have 2 400 amendments: that Russia will finally be satisfied with the fact that we are concluding this agreement? No. I think we have given up on certain standards and certain values. I think that we have failed. I must say that on the sanctions, on the foreign policy side, we have done well, but we have made an enormous mistake in the presence of the Russian negotiators. That has to be rectified. I hope that we will ratify the agreement in full today.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, Mr Teliska, I too come from a country to which, at the end of the 1930s, the so-called democratic powers left alone. But let's not be hypocrites. I don't know whether to laugh or cry by listening to certain things that are said here. I'll choose to laugh. There's a rap group in my country that has a very funny song that says "let the USSR come back". In the end, it seems that the USSR is going to be brought back to us, again, by NATO, just as it brought us to the fundamentalists. Do you remember, ladies and gentlemen, when Rambo was fighting Bin Laden in Afghanistan? There has been talk here of freedom and democracy. But this has nothing to do with freedom and democracy. It has to do with geopolitics. And the question we have to ask ourselves is whether we assume that European foreign policy is going to be a pawn on a chessboard run by the United States or whether we are going to be serious enough to have a foreign policy of our own that does not put Europeans at risk.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (EFDD). -
text: Despite the efforts of the Ukrainian State and its leader, Piotro Poroshenko, the European Union and other states, despite the fragile ceasefire that saves thousands of people' lives, the struggle for the territorial integrity of the Ukrainian state, including Crimea, and the fight for the right of the Ukrainian state and its citizens to freely choose and live as they wish, continue and do not seem to end soon. Vladimir Putin and the surrounding environment, intoxicated by imperial ambitions, continue the war without regretting the lives of either his or the Ukrainian citizens, even without hiding the presence of a regular Russian army. Attacks on the Baltic States also begin under the guise of the alleged defence of the rights of Russian-speaking people. In this situation, the concentration and unity of all our countries is particularly important, without selling russia military equipment, including aircraft carriers, through economic sanctions and focusing on russia's economic or energy blackmail, which may be stronger. I am referring to Russia's attempts to reduce gas supplies and the ban on the export of foodstuffs from the Countries of the European Union. We must understand and, together, help farmers in European countries, who suffer the greatest losses as a result of such things. I am talking about Lithuania, which is precisely the country, and I am talking about other countries whose farmers need such support. Dear colleagues, let us understand that only through joint efforts and focus can we make the aggressors understand that the rules of the 21st century are no longer established by them.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am in favour of Russia and I am against sanctions against Russia and Putin.  I asked a question about the Malaysian plane as well, because it used to be said that it was a Russian missile, but now bullets are being fired which may be Ukrainians. In my opinion, Europe makes demented choices against Russia. Hundreds of millions of Europeans are paying for it, simply because you have to defend America from their interests. I believe that we must cooperate with Russia, because otherwise this Europe, which is already inverted against illegal immigrants, because it is unable to find a solution to illegal immigrants, against Islamists, because it is unable to find a solution on the Islamists, and it is doing so now with Russia. It's shameful. There are no Eurosceptics or Pro-Europeans here, there are only 'Euro-idealists' here, who do not do the interests of the European people and do not have the interests of those who have companies, economies that work with Russia. In Italy there are many entrepreneurs who are struggling with your demented choices, and I want to say in this shirt that I am pro-Russia, and that if the Ukrainian people, a part of the Ukrainian people, decides in a referendum to stay with Russia, because the people are sovereign and the governments in this case do not.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE). -
text: Mr President, today is a historic day for our relationship with Ukraine. We are ratifying the Association Agreement with this country. When I vote, I will have in mind that for their country's proximity to Europe, some Ukrainians have given their lives. We would hold their memory if we did not support the full implementation of the agreement.  In the context of the crisis in Ukraine, relations with Russia are a real test for the Union's foreign policy. Unfortunately, we're a long way from passing the test. Let's just think about what's happened lately. Ten days ago it was decided to strengthen sanctions on Russia so that, immediately afterwards, several member countries would delay the implementation of the decision. Last week we decided to ratify the Association Agreement simultaneously, but on Friday we learned that its implementation will be delayed as a result of Russian blackmail.  For the European citizens we represent, the whole process is incomprehensible. They want, as the recent GMF poll shows, Ukraine's rapprochement with Europe and are for tough sanctions against Russia. These expectations are deceived. Europe has not reacted coherently to its greatest security threat since the fall of the Iron Curtain. Moscow was our strategic partner; He's not at the moment. I know it's hard to take this position, but we have to do it, in order to really represent a smart policy in relation to Russia.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D). -
text: Mr President, I start by saying to the Commissioner that in diplomacy sometimes one has to take quick decisions. However, when there are those who seek to divide us, to come to that decision on Friday without consultation was one that clearly has caused consternation in this House. I am sure you will have heard that. Like several of my colleagues, I express the wish in this debate for the peace talks to continue; for Russian troops to be withdrawn, and for the decisions that have been taken in the Council about the sanctions to be supported. But I do not apologise for using my speech as a Member of the European Parliament to say how proud I and we were to vote simultaneously with the Verkhovna Rada, the Ukrainian Parliament, to ratify the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement. It is an act of huge symbolism which holds out the hand of friendship to the people of Ukraine when there are attempts to divide us. It is a sign of our absolute unity. It is the democratic mark of the right of sovereign countries and of their peoples to decide their own futures. To those on the fringes of this House who say they admire Putin and who in this debate seek to oppose the agreement, it shows our Ukrainian friends that we have extremists in the European Union too. Perhaps they and all of us when we come to vote will remember the thousand people who gave their lives in the Euromaidan so that this Association Agreement could come forward.

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR). -
text: The Russian leader, Mr Putin, likes to show with all kinds of animals, such as horses, tigers and leopards. That way, everyone has to believe that Putin is a very strong man who can handle anything.  I call on Mr Putin to show that he really can handle something, and by that I mean this: until now, investigators have not been able to go to the place where flight MH17 crashed. To date, no investigation has been carried out and access to the site of the disaster has been blocked by separatists. The latter have even started to remove plane metal!  Putin needs to show he can really handle something. Let him stop those separatists out there and get them out! Then research can be done and justice can be done. Then the killers of all the occupants of MH17 can be apprehended and taken to court. That is what is needed now, Mr President!

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, I think that only real political myops could not see that pushing Ukraine into turmoil, into a trend of annexation to Western mechanisms and the European Union would lead nowhere else but to Russia's annexation of Crimea. As harsh as it sounds, I repeat that only politically myopish people could not see it. And unfortunately, even between this Parliament and the Council it seems that there are people who felt that they could act as the European Union, as a great empire that can play a role in changing the structures of the world. On the contrary, I believe that the European Union must work towards democracy and freedom and not play a role that replaces old tendencies of empires. We're in a truce process. In order to support and lead to peace, we need to see how we can contain the issue of sanctions. That's real politics.

name: Daniela Aiuto (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on 17 July, there was the accident on Malaysia Airlines Flight MH17 in which two hundred and ninety-six people died and, I would remind you, eighty children. Since the immediate beginning of the investigation, it has been established that this is not just a plane crash, but a real military attack. Neither the Dutch Committee of Inquiry in its preliminary report nor the experts of the EASA and Eurocontrol at the hearing in the Committee on Transport on 3 September were able to clarify what had happened.  How is it possible that the EASA was not aware of ukraine's security provisions on the danger of flying over that area? Ladies and gentlemen, do you think it is possible that there is no clear responsibility, given the countless bodies that should protect European citizens? Let's talk about the safety of all of us. We must demand complete clarity on this matter, because in addition to the question of security, there are others of an economic, political and social nature. We talked about it yesterday. Many companies, including in Italy, are now collapsing as a result of sanctions applied both by the European Union and also by Russia, and are therefore completely exasperated. There is a risk of the total collapse of entire sectors: agri-food, we talked about it yesterday, but also textiles, transport, not to mention the energy sector, given the European Union's heavy dependence on Russia. Now, ladies and gentlemen, given that Europe does not need gas, but needs heat, is it not the case, is it not time for the European Union to review its energy policies seriously, becoming self-sufficient and focusing definitively on renewable sources?

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI). -
text: Mr President, despite the fact that Ukraine has not carried out the necessary reforms to its legislation – it has reached an agreement on the production of mutant products – and, in general, is not ready to join the European Union, there is an attempt to speed up its integration processes. At the same time, the European Union is ready to announce new strict measures against Russia. This policy was expected to provoke russia to take countermeasures that would significantly and adversely affect the daily lives of millions of European citizens. These measures will also greatly affect the Greek economy, which has already been destroyed by the austerity measures imposed on it, and the Greek people, among others, suffer from the unaffordable taxation imposed on it by the Greek government. The peoples of Europe must not become scapegoats for a policy which, in fact, does not serve their interests but satisfies the aspirations of international economic operators seeking to manipulate the international economy in order to achieve political influence. The solution to the problem in Ukraine is not the European Union's confrontation with Russia, but the conduct of frank negotiations from which agreements will be reached that will be beneficial to all parties involved. This is the direction in which we must turn if we are really interested in the well-being of the peoples of Europe.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE). -
text: Mr. President, as president-elect of the European Parliament delegation to Ukraine, I want to send a message of support and solidarity to our friends in Ukraine who have very clearly chosen Europe. This choice also implies our responsibility, responsibility at a time when Ukraine is facing aggression by Russia, when its territorial integrity is threatened.  Today's ratification of the association agreement is a really historic development in ukraine-European Union relations and I think that this new framework in which we as a European Parliament will also play an important role through the parliamentary accession committee will help Ukraine's reform agenda in the years ahead.  I want the trade part of the agreement to enter into force as early as possible - one neighbouring country cannot set another's path and development.  In this regard, I want a ceasefire to be implemented, president Poroshenko's peace plan respected, and I am sure that Croatia's recent experience in peaceful reintegration of the occupied territories can be a very useful move even in the future months of resolving the Ukrainian crisis.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, it is quite clear that the affair in Ukraine is a complicated one, as are the responsibilities. Of course, Russia is not allowed to invade a country, as it has done with Crimea and in the eastern region of Ukraine, and it is therefore right to respond to this violation, just as it is right that Europe should make its own reflections and choices in order to resolve the problems and not to deepen them. We need a political solution, but on what basis? I believe that the political solution needs two important coordinates. The first concerns the territorial integrity of Ukraine, the second is the awareness that with today's approval of the Association Agreement we cannot see this agreement as a kind of key to paving the way for a possible enlargement of the European Union to Ukraine. This issue is not on the agenda and it would be a serious mistake to leave a trace of it in our debate. I believe that it is within these two coordinates that a political solution must be sought and I hope that the Commission will be able to work in this direction beyond the itching of some countries.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI). -
text: Mr President, to deal with anybody, one must understand him. Let us try to understand Russia. First, the Russian Federation is the legal successor of the Soviet Union. From their point of view, they see constant aggression from NATO, which has swallowed the German Democratic Republic, then the Comecon countries, then the Baltic States, and now the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation is trying to subdue Ukraine and perhaps install its missiles there. They are defending themselves against a strong aggressive power. Second, Russians remember that a Marxist anti-American government was installed in Grenada in 1983, and that Ronald Reagan then sent in troops and ousted the elected government. There was no general outcry of indignation from democrats. Third, Russians are good chess players. They would know that NATO does not want Ukraine. Thus NATO has sent the strongest signal possible to his Excellency Vladimir Putin that he can do whatever he wants with Ukraine. The European Union does not have any troops. We can only tease the bear. The bear lies at the border of Ukraine – not of Poland or France. We can do this in safety, but please think of the Ukrainians. We shall vote against.

name: Daniel Caspary (PPE). -
text: Mr. President! In view of the great nonsense that we are hearing today from a number of speakers on the far right, I am very grateful that we can all live in a liberal, democratic European Union today. We should all celebrate today as a major step in the fact that our neighbours in Ukraine have also chosen to work more closely with us economically and politically in elections, in votes. We have always said that it is not either-or, but there is nothing in our way that Ukraine can have very good relations with both neighbours – with all our neighbours. Commissioner De Gucht thinks it is a pity that the free trade agreement section can now enter into force only one year later. However, if we want to help Ukraine, we should do everything we can to ensure that our unilateral measures, which we have been in force for some time now, namely that Ukraine can send its goods and products to Europe duty-free and quota-free, will continue to be maintained in the future. I would ask you to take the necessary steps to ensure that we can continue to provide this support to the Ukrainian economy until the free trade agreement finally enters into force. Ukraine deserves it!

name: Ioan Mircea Paşcu (S&D). -
text: Mr President, there was a marked asymmetry between the unlawful actions of Putin’s Russia in Ukraine and the EU’s response, both militarily – see the hybrid war being waged in Ukraine – but also politically. Putin’s Russia has imposed on us again, trying to achieve the strategic objective of keeping control over Ukraine through a series of well-calculated tactical moves in an attempt to prevent a strategic response on our part. We accommodated that game because, willingly or not, we lost sight of the big picture in an attempt to salvage a very lucrative relationship with a key commercial partner, ignoring the fact that Putin’s Russia long since ceased to see us similarly.  The EU should therefore salute tactical moves like the ceasefire agreed in Minsk on 5 September, while remaining aware of Putin’s Russia’s strategic design and its implications for its eastern members who have been strategically reassured by NATO at the last summit, a fact which should be mentioned.  The EU should do so aware that the wave of violent deaths, the wave of violent change of borders initiated by Putin’s Russia in the East, may meet a similar peaceful wave initiated in the West should Scotland decide to break away.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, even as you are about to adopt the partnership agreement with Ukraine, I want to tell you that, in the face of history, you cannot say that you did not know.  You cannot say that you did not know that, for twenty-five years, the United States has been seeking to integrate Ukraine and Georgia into NATO in order to cut those countries off from Russia. You cannot say that you did not know that Ukraine is a country torn between East and West and that it would have taken from the beginning to work with Moscow to make Ukraine an interface between the Union and Russia, so that Ukraine would be federal and neutral. Who can believe that the European Union defends peace when we know that its representative in Moscow is Lithuanian and that in Kiev he is Polish?  When Russia has turned to China and Washington has distanced us from a natural strategic and energy partner, if, moreover, this policy of tension and sanction has not led, before, to the folly of war, well I ask you, ladies and gentlemen, will you finally ask yourself where the true interest of the peoples of Europe is?

name: Le Président. -
text: Congressman, I'm Polish too.

name: Sandra Kalniete (PPE). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Europe is a soft power but this does not mean that it should be defenceless and trade sophisticated arms to aggressive regimes on its borders. It would be both highly symbolic and practically important to cancel definitively the sale of Mistral-class warships to Russia and purchase them instead for use in EU-related missions. I believe that delaying the provisional application of the Association Agreement with Ukraine, under pressure from Russia, weakens Ukraine’s link with the EU. It is an ominous sign of what the end game might be in Russia’s war against Ukraine’s European choice. Be aware that the world has not changed in a few months. Some of us might like to hope that after a few months we could get back to business as usual with Russia, but unfortunately, for years to come, Russia will be not a strategic partner for Europe but rather a strategic challenge. We will have to take united action in the face of that challenge.

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari (S&D). -
text: Mr President, it is indeed disconcerting and dangerous that relations between the European Union and Russia have deteriorated so drastically and rapidly. In fact, this has happened throughout the beginning of this millennium, but now, of course, this interference in Ukraine's sovereignty escalated relations.  Europe's borders must not be changed, that is clear. Talk has hardened, that's dangerous, too. The New Times (Russia) newspaper wrote on 6 May 2005 that the commission had not been allowed to take part in the investigation. When Finland is annexed to Russia, Finland will become Hong Kong of Russia. Such a great promise. Of course, in Russia, too, people talk about what is said and what is written, and not everything is the voice of the Kremlin. But yes, this hardened rhetoric is extremely dangerous.  The task of these sanctions is to force the parties to the negotiating tables. That's why they're important. What complicates the economy most at the moment, not only is sanctions, but also the fact that we do not know what President Putin is thinking, it is not really known what the next step is in Russia, whether it is Transnistria or what it is.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI). -
text: From the outset, the European Union has been one-sided in its handling of the Ukrainian-Russian conflict. Snow white is the new Ukrainian leadership, which has had the support of the United States and its secret services, and the blacks are those fighting for their self-determination and Russia – a more nuanced approach is needed. It should be acknowledged that the future of Ukraine is a matter of national security for Russia. In a speech here yesterday, it was also said that, like Ronald Reagan's 'Star Wars' programme, we must bring Russia to its knees. It should be acknowledged that ingesting a pole world order is not in the european Union's interest. We need a Ukraine that ensures the self-determination of ethnic groups, including regional self-determination, even in the form of a confederation. Russia is our dominant economic partner, the embargo is not going to work. A balanced, moderate relationship is the only way to bring peace.

name: Michael Gahler (PPE). -
text: Mr. President! Seventy-five years after the Hitler-Stalin Pact, I am grateful to be part of the successor state that has learned from this low point in history. There is no domestic or intergovernmental conflict in Europe that justifies gun violence. Enforcing the right of the strongest in 21st-century Europe by force of arms is a deeply Stalinist approach. We respond peacefully: with sanctions that make Russia realise that it can only lose its policy. And we are responding by ratifying the agreement with Ukraine.  This is our message to the people there – not only in Kiev, but also in Donetsk, Luhansk, Mariupol and Simferopol: we support your struggle for freedom and the rule of law at home and your orientation towards integration in democratic Europe. But I also say to all those responsible in Ukraine: this is your last chance for real internal reforms. I hope you take advantage of this opportunity! Slava Ukraini!

name: Ana Gomes (S&D). -
text: Mr President, it is time for the European Union to be effective in solidarity with the Ukrainian people and in defending international law and peace. Russian aggression against Ukraine is undeniable and intolerable beyond Crimea. Russia must assume its increased responsibilities as a permanent member of the UN Security Council, respecting the ceasefire and enabling political dialogue in Ukraine, without interfering in the democratic choice of ukrainians to determine who governs them and the alliances with which they govern themselves, such as the association agreement that this Parliament and Verkhovna Rada will ratify today.  In order to be effective, the Union must commit itself to compliance with economic, financial and defence sanctions, ensuring that dual-use equipment does not escape the arms embargo, and must support democratic governance in Ukraine, including its ability to invest in the diversification of energy sources, alternatives to Russia's dependence, which must also strategically impose itself on the Union itself.  The sanctions are reversible, whether Russia understands it and understands that we in the European Union do not want war, not even cold, but we do not stand idly by in the face of what Putin instigates and leads in Ukraine, calling into question European and global security.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I welcome the rapid use of the European Union Association Agreement with Ukraine. Thus we send a clear message of support to the country at this critical time. In the 21st century we cannot go back to periods prior to the Helsinki Act itself, which, forty years ago, recognized the right of each State to choose the organizations and alliances to which it wanted to be a party. We cannot go back to anachronisms, such as spheres of influence, or illegal practices, such as the use of force and the violation of sovereignty and territorial integrity. The adoption of the Agreement with Ukraine is consistent with the values of freedom, peace and respect for the sovereignty of countries. These are the values with which we identify with European countries, and which Russia should share. The agreement is against no one. Trilateral conversations have been launched for months to clear problems in their application. It would be appropriate, by the way, Commissioner, to know more about what happened at Friday's meeting: the scope and reasons for the decisions taken. And I'm done. In the last twenty years we have wanted to build a relationship of trust and partnership with Russia in the European Union. But the indispensable framework of this relationship is respect for international law, which Russia is unfortunately forgetting.

name: Kati Piri (S&D). -
text: Today we are ratifying an association agreement between the EU and Ukraine. At the same time, our Ukrainian colleagues are confirming the same agreement in Kiev. A year ago, no one could have imagined what this agreement would be and how it became a symbol of freedom and self-determination. Cynics will argue that the symbolism of this joint signing is a provocation to Russia and that we are intervening in the Russian sphere of influence. I totally disagree with that. For me, the signing of this agreement is an expression of a sovereign people who can choose their own future. That does not allow itself to be forced to make choices under the threat of military or economic violence by the large neighbour. And the choice of the Ukrainians is for a free, democratic and prosperous Ukraine.  Commissioner, can you clarify to us whether delaying the implementation of the Association Agreement was a sovereign decision of Ukraine or has the EU given Moscow a veto over a bilateral agreement? What are the implications for Georgia and Moldova?

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE). -
text: Mr President, we need first of all to face reality. This is not a matter of incursions by some Russian troops into Ukrainian territory: war and aggression are going on, and war crimes are being committed. So, if we rely on a truce we face a dilemma. Last week, some Member States appeared to rely on a truce simply in order to have an excuse to delay further sanctions. The question is whether we need reliable sanctions to secure genuine peace – not merely a truce – because Mr Putin will certainly not dismantle his neo-imperialist agenda by himself. Last week Mr Chizhov, his Ambassador to the EU, told Euronews that Crimea’s belonging to Ukraine was a historic aberration which had been rectified. I have not heard any comments, but if we continue in this way then tomorrow Mr Putin will declare that the restoration of independence to the Soviet-occupied Baltic States was an aberration which has to be rectified. I fully agree with my colleague Ms Kalniete that, following the annexation of Crimea, arms deals between Western firms and Russia are still operational and that they should be stopped, including the Mistral warship deliveries.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D). -
text: Mr President, given that the peace process in the region has begun and tension is low, and bearing in mind that imports from Ukraine amount to EUR 14 billion while European exports to it amount to EUR 24 billion, it is clear that the trade agreement with Ukraine is necessary and that it should remain high on the European trade agenda. However, I would like to know to what extent the consequences of any new sanctions have been calculated and weighed, given that, in addition to agricultural products, tourism has also been affected and, at the same time, Europe's energy security is at stake. I would therefore like to be further informed whether and to what this move is the right one at this time and what we should expect in the coming period.

name: Esther de Lange (PPE). -
text: If one thing has become clear in this debate, it is that the summer of 2014, the annexation of Crimea, Russian troops in Ukraine and the downing of MH17, in which 298 people lost their lives, including nearly 200 of my compatriots, force the European Union to grow up very quickly. Because 70 years of peace and prosperity is, of course, a success, but on the other hand, that success threatens to lull us to sleep. And the big concessions that sit here on the far left and the populist right in this house are sleeping on.  This makes them the greatest threat, not only to our neighbouring countries, but also to the entire European Union as such. That may be their underlying agenda, by the way, I think, but I say loud and clear here: not with us! We are not going to draw ukraine in the same way that Russia, not that, but in Ukraine, people are fighting and dying in order to live in peace and according to European values. We support these people. And so we reach out and ratify this association agreement.  And so, the European Commission, and with that I conclude, we will see whether the postponement of the implementation of this agreement will indeed bring about the turn that you promised, Commissioner, and is not part of a concession policy that will destroy everything that we stand for.

name: Marju Lauristin (S&D). -
text: Mr President-in-Office, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank you Indeed, the fact that we can adopt an Association Agreement between the European Union and Ukraine is a very strong sign of support for those Ukrainians – especially I would stress to the young generation of Ukraine – who, at the cost of their lives, have been prepared to fight for Ukraine's approach to Europe, for recognising Ukraine as a European nation, as a European society, as a European country.  At the same time, however, we should see at all times the wider context in which russian aggression is currently taking place, russia's fight against such developments. This context is actually linked to Russia's new geopolitical strategy, which we should analyse, not really be blue-eyed and naïve and think that we can proceed in our own way, whereas Russia is actually actually acting differently. The way Russia operates very dangerously resembles what happened between 1938 and 1939. I fully agree with Mr Telička on this. Another example of this is the current provocation, which took place on the Estonian-Russian border, where the Russian security forces actually kidnapped an Estonian defence police officer and planned a demonstration process in Moscow in the same way as the late 1930s processes that took place in Moscow. I think we need to be vigilant. We must be united against all such incidents, all such provocations.

name: David McAllister (PPE). -
text: Mr. President, dear ladies and gentlemen! For me, there is a very crucial question: what can the European Union actually do to ensure that the Minsk 12-point plan is implemented? The answer for us, of course, can only be: act and negotiate. The dual approach of imposing painful sanctions on the one hand and political efforts on the other is the only sensible way to deal with Moscow. However, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union should not be blinded by Russia's commitments. Too often, Moscow has presented negotiating solutions that have not been implemented afterwards. The twelve-point plan and the associated signals from Russia to contribute to a peaceful solution to the conflict are, of course, to be welcomed. But the fact is that the twelve points have not even been implemented in the initial. There is no stable ceasefire so far, there is no osce monitoring of the ceasefire on the Russian-Ukrainian border, and there has been no full withdrawal of Russian soldiers from the region. Therefore, the twelve-point plan is certainly a way of finding a solution, but it is not yet the solution. Only by balancing decisive action and diplomacy can we, as the European Union, actually achieve the twelve points being implemented and the Ukraine crisis not to become a deadlocked conflict in the middle of Europe. That, too, should be the message of the day today.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D). -
text: Mr. President, by voting positively on this agreement, we are first and foremost showing support for something necessary, but at the same time resisting something inadmissible in international relations. This is a key contribution to removing dilemmas about ukraine's future. It is not and must not be an important part of a post-Soviet space in an effort, but a country in the regular process of joining with the European Union.  Our support for the association agreement is a signal that the European Parliament sees Ukraine as a partner capable of implementing reforms. Even if there is enlargement fatigue, there must be no fatigue in supporting the Ukrainian people to gradually achieve their key objective, which is membership of the European Union.  However, the crisis in Ukraine and the crisis in relations with Russia is also a moment of truth for international organisations, especially those whose purpose is to prevent conflicts and establish security. The global security system set up in San Francisco in 1944 and adapted in Helsinki in 1975, primarily designed to prevent conflicts between states, needs serious reform.  A new security deal for the 21st century should perhaps be negotiate in Kiev on the basis of a persistently unfolding tragedy.

name: Ελένη Θεοχάρους (PPE). -
text: Commissioner, I can only welcome the firm commitment of many of the MEPs who have spoken today to the need to apply international human rights law and peoples' self-determination, both in terms of this challenge and in terms of future potential challenges in the Baltic Republics, for example. A colleague quite rightly said that we cannot allow intruders to set policies. However, I cannot help but point out, Commissioner, the selective implementation of this attitude and this policy. Given that for forty years a State has held a Member State of the European Union and we, instead of punishing it, instead of imposing sanctions on it as we owe it and as we are doing today in Russia, we caress it, so that the Prime Minister of that country is now illegally in my country, in occupied Cyprus and, you should know, that this monster has been raised by us with the policy of two measures of both stations.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE) -
text: The Ukrainian crisis has caught us unprepared for political and security challenges. However, the annexation of Crimea, Russia's invasion of eastern Ukraine and Russian propaganda need clear and rapid political responses. We need to redefine our policy towards Russia and see it as it is and not what we would like to see. We must be united, otherwise there will be a crisis of values, from which we will find it difficult to find a way out. It is dangerous to promote the interests of their countries beyond the values of a peaceful order in Europe. This can leave deep scars on European politics. We have talked about the situation in eastern Ukraine that we should not allow it to create another frozen conflict. Unfortunately, it is already becoming a reality. Reaching a ceasefire in Ukraine will not be easy. However, we should be attentive to what price we will have to pay for it.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE). -
text: Mr President, Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioners for their excellent work and for the work she has The association agreement that we are ratifying today in Ukraine and in the European Parliament strengthens Ukraine's sovereign rights and independence. But it does not yet create peace in freedom and justice in the region. Yes, we all hoped – 25 years after the fall of the Iron Curtain, after overcoming the violent division of Europe – that war in Europe would be impossible. But those who ignore state sovereignty have crossed borders. We have war in Europe. Ukraine, Russia and the Member States of the European Union are members of the Council of Europe. They are all members of the United Nations. International law is being broken. Human rights are being violated. Anyone who violates the law must be punished! Anyone who wants negotiations must ensure a ceasefire! Anyone who wants to renew the political dialogue between the EU and Russia should work for a common business basis. So far, we have only in Crimea. Unfortunately, when it is asked about the situation in eastern Ukraine, the cause of the decisions taken on 12 September, we do not yet have this common basis for business in the awareness of Europe and between Russia, Ukraine and Europe. Let us play our part in this.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I must say that I am deeply concerned about the situation we are experiencing, concern about the serious economic crisis we are experiencing, but even more so about the international situation. Europe, the European Union, was born precisely on these two pillars, prosperity and peace, indeed I would say peace and well-being, and today they both seem to be in crisis. Perhaps we are also waking up from an illusion in which we have lulled ourselves for so long. We thought they were forever acquired assets and perhaps we did not do enough to protect them in past years, when they were not in danger. Today, I believe, we are also experiencing delays in this respect. Certainly, in the situation that has arisen in Ukraine, we have not been as effective as we could have been, we have not been as timely as it would have been if we were. However, I feel that I am concerned, because I would not like to see – war is done in two, peace is also made in two, but sometimes the tone here is becoming really worrying – I would not like to see the very high, invisible but real walls rise again, which would hurt the world, globally. Europe must rediscover its dimension of dialogue, it must strengthen diplomacy, it must open dialogue, it must build bridges.  I ask the Commission – unfortunately I do not have time – what is being done, for example, by going into practice, to compensate for those sectors such as agriculture that are deeply affected. Have you then carried out analyses to see what would happen with further sanctions and possible countermeasures on the Russian side? We are very concerned. I repeat, peace and well-being are closely linked, we cannot build peace by giving up slices of well-being.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I support the measures as outlined by the Commissioner and also, of course, the sanctions. The problem with sanctions is that they can be disproportionate and can affect some Member States more than others, particularly different sections of society such as agriculture. I would ask the Commission to look beyond sanctions, particularly at major events like conferences, World Cups etc. fixed for Russia, and set a date by which, if we do not have a resolution to these problems, they should be moved out of Russia. In that way only Russia would suffer. There would be no need for boycotts – because if we continue like this there will calls for boycotts – and I think a firm message would be given to Russia that there are other ways than sanctions to make them hurt, to bring them to the table and to ensure that international law is observed. I would ask the Commissioners would they consider bringing that to discussions. I think it would perhaps be more effective than sanctions in the long term.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we obviously have an obligation to defend international legality and to seek to correspond, as far as possible, to Ukrainian claims to bring the European Union closer to the European Union, but this does not allow us to devalue the complexity of the problem, much less should lead us to the adoption of anti-Russian rhetoric with very harmful consequences for international security.  As has been said by several colleagues, Russia is a strategic partner and should also be seen as a strategic partner of the European Union, and it is enough to look at history to understand the need to maintain this relationship.
