Furthermore, Russia is also a partner, or should be, and has been, in resolving some of the major international conflicts that we are facing today. And so what i think we have is to achieve the best possible balance here, a balance based on firmness, on supporting legitimate Ukrainian claims, but also by betting on constant diplomatic action to foster a good relationship with Russia.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking It was a very interesting debate. There have been many interesting comments here, but unfortunately it is forgotten that this conflict is already going on for many, many months. Here we have heard calls for action – in the eyes of many Europeans, the actions taken by the European Parliament and other EU institutions are erratic, weak, reactive, the initiative belongs to Russia, in a sense it can be said that Putin wins in this conflict. I am afraid that, unfortunately, next year we will be in a much more difficult situation and debate in a similar way, again we will hear calls for more effective action – and perhaps then it will no longer be about Crimea and not about eastern Ukraine, but about Kiev. It seems to me that we, as the European Parliament, should consider what to do one step earlier, what stronger measures to take to ensure that this black scenario does not come true.  Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR). –

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE). -
text: There are things on which we can quickly agree in this House and reach a consensus. One is that the association agreement with Ukraine is fair and should be supported. I'm going to support him myself. The second thing is that we are living in a time when the people who elected us are very concerned and are watching with concern about whether we are able to conduct dialogue and debate in the European Parliament, which will strengthen what they care most about – peace, to development, to transcending poverty, to efficiency when it comes to the problems that arise in their lives.  I am afraid that today's debate has shown that we have not actually learned much from history that many people are closer to the language of the Cold War than to the language of some common, inclusive thinking. I think that the European Parliament must be someone who contributes his share to such thinking.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, I am impressed by the belligerence I hear in this Parliament, bellicose words which shake the bonfire of conflict and the danger of war. Some Members of the PPE Group were talking about a large-scale Russian invasion: I would like to see the evidence, because the only evidence I have seen is a civilian satellite — perhaps it is the same evidence that they used to carry out the illegal invasion of Iraq. Who's interested in not good neighborhood with Russia? Because it is not good neighborhood to give a letter of nature to a violent change of government with neo-Nazi elements; nor is NATO expansion or missile shield expansion or sanctions good neighborhood, which they did not want to apply with more than six hundred children killed in Gaza. Using a trade agreement as a weapon is also not a good neighborhood. Ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, leave the bellicose soflamas; stop playing the game for those who don't want a Europe with normal relations with their neighbours; stop tying fire in Europe with gasoline of American interests.

name: Heidi Hautala (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mr President, honourable Members, in the middle of this crisis and war which touches all of Europe and the European order, I regret to share with you the news that the Finnish Government – the government of my country – is about to take a decision on Thursday to license a Russian nuclear power station provided by Rosatom, which is an integral part of the Russian Government. I believe that this goes directly against the spirit of our policy on Russia, and I would like to draw your attention to this decision. I really hope that the Finnish Government will still reconsider the decision because it would be very regrettable.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, what we have heard today over and over again is talk about sovereignty, independence and democracy, the legitimacy of borders and people having their own freedom. And yet what we are actually talking about is people being freed from Russian tyranny in order to be moved over to the rules of the EU. Freedom is not to choose who rules you, whose sets of laws you have: freedom is to make your own laws. In this debate that we have had today, person after person has tried to ask questions to properly debate this issue, and due to time and the way this place works we have not even been able to do that properly. There is no way that this place can properly discuss individual freedoms and the rights of peoples – it is not appropriate, it is not fit for purpose to do this. So I say that we need to think again about these very important issues. This place is not appropriate for these things.

name: Karel De Gucht
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, although there was a discussion on the political aspects of the relationship between ourselves and Ukraine and the interference of Russia, a lot of questions have been put about the DCFTA and, more precisely, the agreements or proposal for an agreement on Friday with respect to delaying the provisional application. What is it really about? It is a process; and I have to say that I am very surprised that you are surprised about this process, because it started on 11 July when there was a first trilateral meeting, asked for not by us but by the two other parties concerned, and the Russians put on the table a number of remarks and questions and observations with respect to the DCFTA. That resulted in technical consultations over the month of August, with the agreement to meet again on 12 September at ministerial level. Then there was the summit meeting in Minsk on 26 August, where Catherine Ashton, Günther Oettinger and myself represented the European Commission. Explicit reference was made to the meeting on 12 September and President Poroshenko even said that he was going to postpone the ratification until that very date. That is why we met, Mr Auštrevičius, to make possible the ratification of this agreement by Ukraine. That is why we have been doing this and when you look closely at the agreement that we reached on Friday, what does it really say? On the one hand, it says that we are going to prolong the autonomous trade measures, which means that the advantages that we grant to Ukraine can continue. I think this is very important, because what you really need in Ukraine is economic growth and development. That is what you really need. If you want to find a lasting peace there, that is what you need. If you want to strengthen the position of the Ukrainian people that is what you need, economic growth, and we continue that. On the other hand, the Russians have been asking to cut out 2 400 lines from the agreement, that is about one fourth of the agreement on the tariffs. They are claiming that the technical barriers to trade are disadvantageous to them and they say that SPS cannot go ahead as it stands at this moment in time. Solutions exist for the SPS, because we could very well have an equivalence on the Ukrainian market between SPS in Russia – GOST rules – and our own rules. You could have that. For technical barriers to date, it is a programme that still has to be put into practice. And the 2 400 tariff lines: yes, of course, if you make a DCFTA that gives an advantage with respect to tariffs. But we are ready to do exactly the same with Russia! We have been insisting with Russia for years, about having a DCFTA with them! It is not that we are doing anything against them, but that is what they want to do. To find the solution for that, we have postponed the provisional application for one year, leaving open the possibility for either party – either party meaning Ukraine or the European Union – to put possible changes on the table. Just putting them on the table, you know: we have not agreed to any change. And, by the way, we could not do that. The only ones who could do that, honourable Members, once you have ratified the agreement, is you; because it would mean that you would have to change the treaty with Ukraine before you can change anything in it. I do not have the feeling that Parliament is really ready to do that. So what we have been doing is creating the conditions for ratifying today. That is what we need today. Once this ratification happens, this is a new fact. It is not only a political fact, it is a legal fact, it is a judicial fact. It means that you have an agreement, that you have a treaty, and that you can only change it by a new treaty. I have always understood that that is what you wanted, which is why I do not understand the remarks you have been making today. If you really want to put yourself in a difficult position with Russia, if you really want to give them the upper hand, then you have to follow the line you have been voicing here, that this is a bad agreement, that in fact we should delay ratification of the agreement. Allow me to say that to do so would be a historical mistake. What we have been doing is creating the conditions for ratification of this very, very important treaty. That does not concern only Ukraine: it concerns the whole Eastern Neighbourhood. It is about whether or not we are in a position to continue this policy and make it a success.

name: Štefan Füle
text: , Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/ High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - Mr President, honourable Members, there was a lot of wisdom, as always, during this debate – though rather more populist slogans than I have been used to hearing over the past five years, and some outrageous remarks too, from your side, such as the implication that the nationalities of our Heads of Delegation in our partner countries determine the policy of the European Union. What a nonsense! I would like to make four points. The first, in response to your request that we should learn more about Russia, is that we understand Russia. The 1975 Helsinki Act clearly stipulates that borders may not be changed through military force. Under the 1990 Paris Charter, it is reiterated that ‘within the framework of international law, all the participating States have equal rights and duties. They will respect each other’s right to define and conduct ... its relations with other States in accordance with international law and in the spirit of the present Declaration’. The Budapest Memorandum of 1994 guarantees the Ukrainians total integrity and sovereignty. All of that was violated and destroyed by one European country. In 2008, in the context of the NATO-Russia Council in Bucharest, Vladimir Putin said that Ukraine was an artificial country – yet someone here is blaming EU policy for the problems there! I cannot follow that logic. My second point is in response to the call I heard for us to ‘grow up’ and to recognise a real threat. What is a real threat? I always thought it was when someone starts to violate the rule of law and international law, because those are the bases of our wellbeing. We have agreed that our commitments to law and to order will determine not only the way we treat each other but also how we treat our neighbours. This is predominantly what we base our security on. By the way, Catherine Ashton is not here not because she wants to avoid a debate with the European Parliament but because she is also dealing with Russian diplomats on the very complex Iranian issue. She is doing everything possible to prevent the Iranian issue becoming a hot topic for debate here. And she is moving in the right direction, in part thanks to constructive cooperation with the Russian diplomats. So our insistence on Russia living up to its commitments vis-à-vis international law and the rule of law does not prevent us from working with Russians on other important hot topics around the world. My third point concerns self-deception. The problem is that the same people who have always called for us to respect the sovereignty of third countries’ decisions are now questioning our own policy, which is based on that. The thing which needs to be very clearly underlined is that there has been a Ukrainian request to postpone the provisional application of the economic part of the Association Agreement – and that was also underlined in the discussion that President Barroso had with President Poroshenko and Prime Minister Yatsenyuk. The reasoning was logical and understandable. The economy and financial system of Ukraine face a huge test because of the events in the east, not to mention the impact of the illegal annexation of Crimea. They expressed the wish to have more time to prepare for accepting the tariffs being negotiated. In today’s ratification of the Association Agreement by the Verkhovna Rada, in parallel to the ratification providing consent, this body clearly underlines the commitment of Ukrainians to the text being negotiated. Another thing needs to be underlined to which no one has really referred, and to all of you who spoke in favour of peace prevailing, I would like to make this point clear. The Russians have their troops on Ukrainian territory and they have also made it absolutely clear, repeatedly, on the record, that once the Association Agreement is ratified by the Verkhovna Rada, on that very day – rather than later when they might face economic or trade difficulties, although we do not share that opinion – they will not only repeal the Commonwealth of Independent States Free Trade Agreement with Ukraine, but will also adopt further restrictive economic measures against it. So, in addition to the military threat and possible escalation, we have also been facing the threat of a full-scale economic and trade war. We have the ratification of the agreement which, as described by my colleague, has been negotiated over four years. We will have the provisional application of the political part. We will have the continuation of reforms, because we asked that question and, in the discussion that President Barroso had with Prime Minister Yatsenyuk on Saturday, we agreed on a number of elements: we will go ahead with the structure provided for in the Association Agreement; we will have the Association Council, the committee and various subcommittees; and we will start our work. The European Agenda for Reform, as agreed with the Ukrainians, is very much about the implementation of the Association Agreement and it will go ahead. Implementation of the action plan, which was also adopted today by the Verkhovna Rada, operationalising the Association Agreement, goes ahead. Our preparations for the donors’ conference at the end of this year – to focus both on the implementation of the Association Agreement and on the reconstruction and rehabilitation of the east of Ukraine – go ahead. The mandate and focus of the Ukrainian Support Group, which has started its work already, remain the same, and the coordination mechanism provided for by the Ukrainians for the implementation of the Association Agreement will go ahead. There is no a delay as a result of Russian blackmail. Now, the last point: a number of you spoke of dividing lines – we are being accused of creating dividing lines through the Association Agreement – and I believe the time has come to prove that the Association Agreement is actually one of the building components of what could, in future, be a European economic free zone from Lisbon to Vladivostok. Whether or not some of you call the Eurasian Union a project of Putin, it is a matter of reality. It means that not only Russia but also Belarus and Kazakhstan, and very soon Armenia too, will have their views on the Association Agreement with Ukraine and its impact on those countries; it means that they too will have views on cooperation with the European Union. Not only do we all stand to benefit, but we will be able to eliminate the danger of creating a dividing line if we start to work together, because if we missed this aspect, thus undermining the importance of the regulatory framework, then by just ignoring the Eurasian Union we would be the ones contributing to the new dividing line in Europe. I believe the agreement should be a part of this much bigger picture, in which all these important initiatives and steps are being put together.

name: Przewodniczący. -
text: Motions for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure shall be published at a later date. I close the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 18 September 2014 at 12.00. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Lorenzo Cesa (PPE)
text: in writing. The situation in eastern Ukraine is becoming increasingly worrying, violence has grown exponentially, causing three thousand deaths and a great many injuries. Despite the signing of the Minsk Protocol on 5 September, in which a ceasefire was agreed, fighting continued. The European Union cannot and must not remain indifferent to these constant violations of international law that threaten the lives and security of millions of people. The persistence of these tensions makes the situation dangerous not only for the inhabitants of Ukraine, who are most directly affected, but also for all of us European citizens. Last August, in fact, the Russian Government adopted a list of products from the Union, the USA, Norway, Canada and Australia that will be banned for a year on the Russian market. The European Union will suffer the heavy consequences, because Russia is the second largest export market for our agricultural products. The European Commission must therefore urgently take all necessary measures to support producers affected by these restrictions. In concrete terms, I hope that the Union will use extraordinary funds to deal with a crisis that is not only sector-based, but above all political!

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The situation in Ukraine transports us to some of the darkest pages in The history of Europe. The rise to power of assumedfascist forces, following the coup d'état, was blessed by the European Union, the US and NATO – complicit in provocations, instigating violence, violating fundamental freedoms and rights, crimes perpetrated by ultranationalist and fascist forces. The interests that these forces serve, as in the past, are clear. Take the recent privatisation of the public gas company, approved in an illegitimate parliament. The EU-Ukraine association agreement, which the country's legitimate authorities, in exercising their sovereign right, did not want to sign, is now signed with the coup authorities. An agreement with very high costs for the Ukrainian economy and for the people of this country – which was prevented from ruling on it in a referendum, as proposed by the Communist Party of Ukraine, which has since been removed from parliament and the subject of a judicial process for its illegalisation. As for the slight rhetoric of democracy and human rights, which is so dear to the EU, we are therefore talking. Meanwhile, in conjunction with the US and NATO, the aggressive policy of siege of Russia – which threatens security and peace in Europe – continues.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: in writing. – The Ukrainian conflict has been the most severe security crisis in Europe in decades, entailing regional and even global impacts. To end the conflict in Eastern Ukraine and stabilise the Ukrainian economy is, without doubt, of the utmost importance. As every sovereign country is free to decide about its future, Russia does not have the right to put Ukraine under pressure. Hence the international community needs to react determinedly to contribute to a political and diplomatic solution. We must help Ukraine both financially and politically to master these huge challenges so that it can remain a unified and independent country. It is urgently required that Member States act unanimously as one European Union and thus develop a true common foreign, security and defence policy, including a common energy policy, which takes account of the regional and global challenges of the 21st century.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. – Russia is the second largest market for agricultural products from the European Union. 10% of all EU exports of fruit, vegetables and milk, as well as one third of meat exports, go to Russia. In financial terms, EUR 5 billion is at stake for European producers. In Austria alone, agricultural exports to Russia fell by 12% to EUR 1.55 billion in the first half of 2014. In total, Austrian agricultural exports have so far been affected by the Russian embargo, with around EUR 100 million. The Austrian Economic Research Institute expects economic damage of €775 million as a result of the EU-Russia sanctions. It is not enough for the EU to provide €125 million for fruit and vegetable growers and €60 million in promotion. The sanctions have led to an unacceptable situation for European producers: one of the largest markets is breaking away, while domestic demand is weakening, and only today the OECD has massively lowered its growth forecasts for the current and the coming year. What Europe needs now is political leadership for a solution to the Ukraine conflict and, above all, a swift end to sanctions.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. I reject this European Parliament resolution on Ukraine. For although the situation in Ukraine has eased somewhat, headless and ill-conceived demands are being made. Ukrainian citizens should be able to enter the EU without a visa – as if Ukraine had criminality and corruption under control. The EU should end nuclear security cooperation with Russia – as if we were no longer concerned with Chernobyl risks. EU states are to cancel the South Stream pipeline and other energy agreements with Russia – as if the electricity came out of the socket. The strategic security partnership with Russia is to be ended – as if Russia were no longer a nuclear military power. And alternative solutions are not even named. The last few weeks have opened up a glimmer of hope. It must not be jeopardised by reckless measures which, in the long term, can also cause serious damage to us. I condemn the illegal annexation of Crimea and any covert or open support for violent attempts at secession. Nevertheless, Ukraine's borders are inviolable, but not immutable. Ethnic groups should be able to decide on their nationality in fair, free, democratic self-determination. Minorities must be granted adequate rights. The establishment of the german-Danish border after the First World War and the referendum in Scotland show that conflicts can also be resolved peacefully.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing.– If EU security is at stake, foreign policy takes precedence over trade policy. Everyone in general certainly agrees that if someone violates the Constitution or international rules, we must stand up to defend democracy.  Today, we are taking steps to ensure this security for the EU. However, we should know whether these actions lead to an objective and what we will cause. If we have launched sanctions against Russia, we must recalculate all the impacts and also count on retaliation. If sanctions or retaliation lead to EU countries losing markets, losing employment and someone else taking up the vacant space, then that is not a thoughtful procedure. As regards the impact of Russia's retaliatory measures, which have banned the import of certain types of food, we must immediately: - prevent the destabilisation in the EU that the food surplus that has arisen can cause us - to help us find new markets and outlets - to provide concrete compensation for affected farmers, the number of which has already exceeded one million today.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. Mr President, I would like to thank the I believe that the sanctions already imposed and future sanctions against Russia are more than misguided and unfounded. I am even going a step further and strongly opposed unilateral interference by the European Union in the conflict between two sovereign states. The European Union cares less about establishing the rule of law and respect for human rights in Ukraine, and certainly not about the urgent problems of high youth unemployment in Europe. It directs its foreign policy, for whatever reason, primarily on American interests and, incidentally, can also distract from the wrong measures in the still present euro crisis. And the role of the victim is once again the European population. On the one hand, it seems that no one has thought about the counter-sanctions that are to be expected: the European taxpayer will have to pay more than before in order not to freeze in the coming months. On the other hand, the peoples of the tax-paying European nations will also have to reach deep into their own pockets for the association agreement with Ukraine. They will have to explain this to future generations.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. – I consider the adoption of an association agreement with Ukraine to be the best way to contribute to the peaceful resolution of the military conflict in Ukraine. I see this act as a first step towards stabilising the situation and, at the same time, confirming the well-known principle that democratic states seek to resolve conflicts peacefully in the first place, and totalitarianism extends to violence and aggression. The association agreement will not only bring about the mutual opening of markets and the liberalisation of tariffs, but is also an important expression of the solidarity of the whole democratic Europe with the struggling Ukraine. While Russian aggression in Crimea and eastern Ukraine has brought chaos, destruction, loss of life and economic decline, the Association Agreement will strengthen the Ukrainian economy, force its elites to behave more responsibly and give its people more freedom. Anchoring Ukraine in the European economic and political area will prevent the war that is taking place there from being turned into the frozen conflict that we see in Tsnstersk, Abkhazia and South Ossetia. I do not think that Ukraine is before the break-up, as some politicians and Members say. Its citizens have been proving for months that their wish is a united, strong and, above all, democratic Ukraine. It is our duty to do everything we can to help them achieve this goal. Moreover, it is also in the clear interest of the European Union and our citizens to have stable and reliable neighbours.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. During the 7th parliamentary term of the European Parliament, I raised at least 25 times the issue of the sale of Mistral-type French ships, its cynical basis and negative importance for The security of Europe. I already pointed this out when President Sarkozy announced his intentions. I am pleased that a large number of colleagues have come to the same view today, and I also call on others to recognise this and influence France to cancel the transaction. Of course we shall show solidarity with France. We cannot ignore the costs that have already been incurred. The right thing for the EU would be to buy out the ships together with France and hand them over as a so-called seed to an EU fleet within the framework of the EU's common security and defence policy. Ceterum censeo – France will bitterly regret if these ships are handed over to Russia ... and even more – France should already regret the decision to allow the vladivostok ship to sail out of the port of St. Lazare with Russian crew. During their learning journey, the Russian sailors can sail astray and end up, for example, in the port of Sevastopol.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – (6) It is quite clear that the US, NATO and the EU do have enormous responsibilities in the situation in Ukraine, since they have been complicit in the provocations, the instigation of violence, the violation of freedoms and rights and the crimes of the ultranationalist and fascist forces that were the perpetrators of a coup d'état, itself promoted by the EU. Nothing has been said on the restriction of individual freedoms by the Ukrainian government in the Plenary of the EP, nor is it written on the official websites of the European Parliament or the European Commission. In the last two months, the Ukrainian Ministry of Justice has begun legal proceedings with a view to the illegalization of the Communist Party of Ukraine, a party significantly represented in the Ukrainian Parliament. This is an administrative action of which not only state institutions but also the Nazi-fascist-oriented Svoboda Party are authors; it is the staging of a trial to ban the Communist Party of Ukraine. But what does it matter to the EU if this coup government serves its economic and geopolitical interests? History repeats itself and brecht said that first they took the Communists, but then they took the others.

name: Presidente. -
text: The next item is the joint debate on the recommendation of the Committee on Foreign Affairs on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, of the one part, and Ukraine, of the other part, with the exception of provisions concerning the treatment of third-country nationals legally employed as employed persons in the territory of the other Party (13613/2013 – C8-0105/2014 – 2013/0151A(NLE)) (Rapporteur: Jacek Saryusz-Wolski) (A8-0002/2014), and – the recommendation of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs on the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement, with regard to the provisions relating to the treatment of third-country nationals legally employed in the territory of the other Party (14011/2013 - C8-0106/2014 - 2013/0151B(NLE)) (Rapporteur: Mr Mas's Committee on Economic and : Claude Moraes) Please respect the deadlines absolutely during this debate because at noon we will be in direct contact with the Parliament of Kiev, so I cannot accept either blue card or catch-the-eye. I also call on my former fellow Commissioners to respect absolutely the time limit set, as well as all the rapporteurs and all those who will speak, otherwise I will have to cut you off, not out of disrespect for you, but because we cannot disrespect the Parliament in Kiev.

name: Jacek Saryusz-Wolski
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, I am hereby submitting to the European Parliament the legislative proposal to ratify – to give consent to – the Association Agreement between the European Union and the Ukraine, ten years after the Orange Revolution, which deceived so many hopes, one year after the failure in Vilnius to sign the Association Agreement and 10 months after the beginning of the heroic and victorious Euromaidan, which was a sign of the wish and will of the Ukrainian nation to make its European choice. The European choice of Ukraine, through this ratification today, will be institutionalised in the form of an Association Agreement and will in future bind the European Union and the Ukraine together. During the past 10 months, Ukrainian citizens proved to be committed to European values and willing to fight for the country’s democratic development. Ukrainian society has paid the highest price for their European aspirations, grieving the deaths of numerous people, suffering territorial occupation by Russia and experiencing a deteriorating economic situation. The European Union was extending assistance to the Ukrainian State. From the EU side the EU has assisted Ukraine economically and politically and with this ratification it gives Ukraine the strongest sign of support.   Economic support on the Union’s side is substantial, with a financial package amounting to up to EUR 11 billion, and it also covers political support, which is embodied in the creation of the Support Group for Ukraine in the European Commission, the organisation of the International Donors Conference and efforts towards establishment of the technical assistance plan in a number of areas, from constitutional to judicial and administrative reform. This ratification is a milestone in Ukraine-EU relations. The ratification of the Association Agreement follows the signing, in two sequences in March and June, of this agreement and it is such a milestone in spite of the regrettable proposal on delayed implementation of the Agreement which was recently discussed.  The ratification of the Association Agreement is a success for both Ukraine and the European Union. Today’s vote on ratification, which will happen at 12 noon simultaneously in two European cities, Kiev and Strasbourg – the capital of Europe and the capital of Ukraine – and by two democratically elected parliaments, both chambers seeing each other on the big screens, by the Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine and the European Parliament, the highest legislative directly elected and democratic body of the European Union. It is a strong symbolic message to Ukrainian society and the proof of sharing the common European values and destiny.  This gesture is even more necessary today than it seemed to be some time ago, in the face of the increasing pressure, invasion and warfare directed against Ukraine by Russia. We need to restore the credibility of this relationship in the face of external threats. An Association Agreement is not the definitive goal of Ukrainian-European Union relations. Ukraine and the European Union have a common future in front of them and this future must be protected from external Russian pressure, to become a reality. What can be done? The only way for the Union to effectively stop those threats and stop Russia questioning this relationship is to introduce increasingly heavy sanctions, until the cost for Russia becomes too high for it to sustain its policies. We need to enhance and accelerate financial and economic assistance to Ukraine and contribute to increasing the military capabilities of Ukraine. Ukraine should be assisted in protecting its territorial integrity and in introducing the agreed necessary but difficult reforms at the same time and in parallel. The Association Agreement to be ratified today will be protected from any changes which might be requested by any third counry. We start and embark on the new European future for Ukraine. Ukraine: welcome to this new relationship with the European Union.

name: Claude Moraes
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, Mr Saryusz-Wolski has spoken with some passion and a lot of knowledge about the position in Ukraine, as have many colleagues in the foreign affairs debate.  It falls to the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs – where the decision was split – to take responsibility for Article 17, the legal migration and neighbourhood aspects of this Association Agreement, which are nevertheless very important aspects. We were very conscious of this and take very seriously our responsibility to have a vote in parallel with the Kiev Parliament. Although our responsibilities are less than those of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, the seriousness with which our committee voted yesterday, swiftly, in a vote without debate – and I understand that many of our members were concerned about the lack of debate in committee – nevertheless shows they were acutely aware that this parallel symbolic vote, as Mr Saryusz-Wolski described it, was an extremely important signal to the people of Ukraine. I want to specifically say why that is. In the last parliamentary term I was also one of the rapporteurs responsible for neighbourhood policy. We have heard in the last debate on foreign affairs why neighbourhood policy must be consistent. Despite all the sufferings of the Ukrainian people that we have heard of, we need to be consistent in our neighbourhood policy. Neighbourhood policy is an extremely important indicator that we will maintain our undertakings to the Ukrainian people and we will not deviate from that. So the Civil Liberties Committee will maintain its policy and our vote yesterday, by some majority, was the signal of that. I do not want to take up the time of the plenary too much because we want that vote to coincide at 12.00, but I would just like to say that we will take our steps seriously under Article 17 and I will conclude my remarks there.

name: Karel De Gucht
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, many questions have been put about the agreement, or the proposal for an agreement, reached last Friday in Brussels between Ukraine, the European Union and Russia. What does it really mean? It means, on the one hand, that we are going to prolong the autonomous trade measures vis-à-vis Ukraine. So they will continue to be able to export onto our European markets as if the agreement were already in force. Let me point out that, since June when we decided on the autonomous trade measures for the first time, exports by Ukraine to the European Union have increased by 15% in just a couple of months. So this is a very effective tool. It is up to the Council of Ministers to change the decision on provisional application, and with respect to the autonomous trade measures it depends on codecision by the European Parliament and the Council whether or not these autonomous measures are prolonged. This is a decision to be taken by you and by the Council of Ministers in a very democratic process. With regard to provisional application, which is the other side of the mirror, the question of whether we have free access to the Ukrainian market, and whether we can continue with sanitary and phytosanitary standards (SPS) and with the technical barriers to trade, is in the hands of the Council of Ministers. There is currently a decision on provisional application, and the Council will have to change that. We are going to make a proposal to them to do so for definite periods of time – specifically until the end of next year. Why have we been working to make the agreement that was reached on Friday? Some have said it is non-effective, a sign of weakness or a mistake. The reason we have been doing it, Ms Harms, and the result of the long process which started in July, is to make ratification possible. Without this agreement on Friday, there would no ratification today. And what are the results of that ratification? There are at least three. First, it gives new economic opportunities to Ukraine to export into the European Union and to have economic growth. If we really want Ukraine to become a fully-fledged democracy and part of the European House, what you will need there is economic opportunity, growth and jobs. And that, by the way, is the reason why these people protested in the Maidan: because they want freedom and they want economic growth. When the Soviet Union split apart, the per capita income in Ukraine was a little bit higher than it was in Poland, and now the per capita income in Poland is four times higher than that of Ukraine. That has been the result of Poland becoming a member of the European Union. Secondly, ratification establishes a bond between Ukraine and the European Union which is very important because that is what the people really want. They want to establish this bond with the European Union, and once the ratification has taken place it is no longer merely a matter of words. It has become a legal relationship: it has become a treaty. Of course, the Member States will have to ratify it. Six have done so already and it will be very wise for the other Member States to do this as soon as possible. Ratification establishes a bond between Ukraine and the European Union which will be very difficult, if not impossible, to undo because it establishes a treaty. At the moment, what Russia is trying to do in Ukraine is to create a new frozen conflict in the east of the country. That is what they are trying to do – just as happened in Moldova with Transnistria, just as happened in Georgia with Abkhazia and South Ossetia, and just as happened in Nagorno-Karabakh. At that moment in time we, as the European Union, are saying ‘OK, we will make a treaty with you, we will make this bond with you.’ This is a legal bond and we are not going to undo it, but rather we will make further discussion possible and will ensure that the elections on 15 October take place under acceptable conditions. We are ready to make a sacrifice – yes, an economic sacrifice – and delay the provisional application of the agreement for a very limited period of time. That is what this is about and I am sure that is what you are going to vote for in half an hour’s time.

name: Tibor Szanyi
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Hungary neighbouring country, and we see and feel very much of this whole conflict up close. Nevertheless, as a Hungarian man and as a Hungarian politician, I would just like to congratulate the European institutions, including the European Parliament, for finally choosing the path of action, not inaction, compared to many other similar cases. Nevertheless, let us not forget that the result of this current process, the deepest reason why we stand where we stand, is, after all, nationalism. Unfortunately, there is also a lot of nationalist effort in Europe. We must not only befriend Ukraine, but also oppose nationalist aspirations within the European Union.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Today we are providing an incentive to achieve a free and economically stronger Ukraine. If we are to provide a buffer against a destructive policy of destabilisation by the Kremlin, this step is necessary, both for our security and for Ukraine's. But of course, change can never be imposed from the outside. Change always comes from within. The systematic underlying weaknesses of Ukraine's democratic institutions are a constant driver for those who want to destabilise the country. Without real reforms in the judiciary, without decisive anti-corruption measures, without the dissolving of the oligarch system, which comprises the Ukrainian political class, in short, without changing the system itself that has characterised Ukraine for years, this agreement will not withstand future foreign policy. And that change, after all, was what the Euromaidan movement was all about.  I hope that my colleagues in the Council will realise this. We are on your side, but we are taking this moment to give the Ukrainians confidence in politics.  In the meantime, Commissioner, I would like to call for concrete help. Dozens of severely wounded soldiers need urgent professional medical attention in our hospitals. Hundreds of thousands of refugees need help. Reconstruction in the east, the liberated areas, must begin urgently. I hope that the European Union can help here quickly. Long live Ukraine.

name: Kaja Kallas
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all I would like to strongly welcome the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement. I hope that the European Parliament will give its consent with a large majority. The armed conflict in the eastern Ukraine has resulted in over 3000 military and civilian casualties, but it has also resulted in major economic costs, including the cost of rebuilding the eastern regions. Ukraine needs a political and negotiated resolution of the conflict. For that it is necessary that the Russian Federation withdraw all its troops from Ukraine. It also needs EU support. I believe this agreement is a great opportunity for EU-Ukraine economic relations, for the economic development of Ukraine, but it is also a great opportunity for Ukraine to further consolidate its efforts to strengthen the rule of law, fight against corruption and guarantee compliance with human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Commissioners, I would like to thank the Commissioners for their excellent work and for the work she has done. My group is critical of today's ratification with the current postponement of the entry into force of Chapter V of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement.  Two reasons: it has already been stated that nothing will ultimately change in the agreement, and at the same time the announced year will be used to bypass shock therapy in Ukraine. Who, please, would seriously explain here that the high social costs of association for Ukraine would no longer be due in a year's time? In Ukraine, we do not even have a parliament at the moment that could draft legislation to that end, because new elections are scheduled. In fact, we are in substance again when we ratify the EU-Ukraine free trade agreement of 2012 or on the eve of Vilnius.  The EP is supposed to nod off here today, which has not been analysed and not discussed against the rules, neither in the EP, in the EU, nor in Ukrainian society, and certainly not with partners such as Russia. The message is clear: the citizens will foot the bill and we are a willing instrument.  That is why my group is calling for the Association Agreement not to be voted on today and for a roadmap to be presented to the EP in the short term on how the overall complex of EU-Ukraine-Russia economic relations should be regulated transparently for all.

name: Yannick Jadot
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, Commissioner, I hope that in just over half an hour this Parliament will vote by a large majority for this association agreement. This is an extremely important signal of solidarity and support at an extremely difficult time for Ukrainians. There is an economic component to this agreement. It brings Ukraine closer to the Community acquis, subject to democratic conditionality, which is very important.  I hope that a large majority will emerge. Of course, it will not include all groups. The far right continues to prefer Putin's corrupt dictatorship to democracy and the right of peoples to self-determination.  Beyond that, we are in a somewhat complicated situation because we learned last Friday that the conditions for the implementation of the agreement had changed. Ten days ago, the Committee on International Trade met in the presence of the European Commission and we were absolutely not alerted to the fact that possible changes in the conditions of implementation, including the trade agreement, were being negotiated. And, because you are being questioned this morning, half an hour before the vote, we are beginning to understand the reasons that may have led to changes in the implementation and perhaps the content of the agreement.  Did any members of the European Council intervene? Under what mandate was such a postponement negotiated? Was it Russia that intervened and, because of its military occupation of part of Ukraine, imposed this postponement? We don't know, but we're still going to vote.  There is a real problem here, Commissioner. That there is a staging of the vote of this Parliament and the vote of the Ukrainian Parliament at the same time, all this is very good. But this European Parliament must be able to judge this agreement seriously. As it stands, we have not been able to do that. You're ruining this deal a little bit.

name: James Carver
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the timing of this agreement is despicable. We have an intermittent ceasefire coming and going in Eastern Ukraine and this procedure is being rushed through here so that the European and Ukrainian parliaments can send a joint symbolic signal towards Russia. Usual procedures for amendments have been strictly limited in terms of time for submission, and they were only in English. Parliamentary procedures have not been adhered to. The Committee on International Trade was unable to submit an official position on the trade aspects of this agreement. So much for democracy. The consideration of this agreement has been rushed through in the name of political posturing and risks prolonging and possibly even intensifying both the conflict in Eastern Ukraine and tensions with Russia. You people simply do not understand the meaning of the word diplomacy. Quite frankly, you are trying to extinguish a bonfire that you lit, with gasoline.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D). -
text: For the peace and well-being of all the people in Ukraine – that is what we are working towards. To support sovereignty, for a political solution, to break aggression and to economic recovery. By approving the Association Agreement, we assume active responsibility for the modernisation of the country, political and economic reforms. So that European money is really given to those who need it most – pensioners, small entrepreneurs, families with children. I am particularly pleased that we have also included mobility in the agreement. We are removing another barrier to Ukraine's entry into a visa-free regime, and that is what people feel most tangible to strengthen people-to-people contacts.  Dear colleagues, the ratification of the agreement is proof that we care about the thousands of innocent victims who had to die. That's our debt. That today we stand on the side of those who suffer the most in Ukraine.

name: Timothy Kirkhope (ECR). -
text: Mr President, through this agreement we are offering Ukraine the greatest tool the EU has at its disposal: access to our single market in all senses. Such an agreement will not only improve our ties with our eastern neighbours, it will also provide Ukraine with the impetus to make reforms: reforms to improve transparency, tackle corruption and improve the economy. Reforms will not happen overnight and they will not happen without pain but in the long run Ukraine will be able to take her rightful place as a Western country, with open and stable markets, capable of standing on her own two feet. In Europe this Association Agreement means not only that we gain the partnership of a long-standing and, one might say, long-suffering friend but also that we will gain a stable marketplace in which our producers and our businesses can fully engage. Of course, in order to open our markets to each other we must also ensure that some fundamental norms and standards are put in place. That is what this agreement seeks to do, and especially to ensure that basic rights are maintained for all workers coming to and from Ukraine. Today marks a new chapter in EU-Ukraine relations, a process that will be to our mutual benefit, and no one should get in the way of that.

name: Miloslav Ransdorf (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, I would like to agree with what Viktoria Shilova of the Anti-War movement said that the Ukrainians had exchanged the government of thieves, which was for Yanukovych, for the government of murderers, which is for Poroshenko.  It must be said that today's economic situation is catastrophic, that the National Bank of Ukraine is currently in a state of technical default, that 35 mines are closed in eastern Ukraine and that Ukraine will not have enough energy coal in 3 weeks. There is an energy crisis and that is an issue that is also important to us in the European Parliament, as well as the fact that there are hundreds of companies waiting for a sensible economic programme that European businesses could offer them. I believe that we should go down this path and realise that we should form a group in support of Ukraine in the European Parliament. This means not the support of those who rule there today, where a third of the fascists are actually in government, but in support of the Ukrainian people and for Ukraine to go in a sensible direction. Elections are therefore a great opportunity and it will not be an easy task. We should try to oversee the election, because there are 32,006 constituencies.

name: Barbara Spinelli (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that any treaty with the Ukrainian Government needs a more in-depth debate. Parliament has given itself too little time. These are the points that should be clarified before any agreement is reached in the middle of the civil war. Russia cannot be provoked at the same time by including Ukraine in NATO. The Government of Kiev, which is considered illegal by half the Ukrainians, should be asked to disband the far-right and neo-Nazi militias under the Interior Ministry in Kiev immediately. The Russian people in eastern and southern Ukraine must be protected, otherwise we are giving Putin every reason for an invasion. We should be seriously discussing sanctions against Russia, which I believe to be a wrong policy, indeed a non-political one.

name: Karel De Gucht
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, honourable Members, today you are going to ratify the Association Agreement with Ukraine. This is an historical fact but I think it is also the beginning of a process, the process of anchoring Ukraine in a democratic process, establishing the rule of law in that country, helping the Ukrainians to ban corruption and bringing them economic prosperity, and also contributing to their sovereignty, their sovereignty which is presently under pressure from Russia. The Commission, the present one and also the next one, will follow up this process very closely. It will follow it very closely with respect to the agreement that we reached on Friday and, for example, if Russia is not respecting the conditions of the postponement of the provisional application of the Agreement by imposing trade measures on Ukraine, we will propose to the Council to change their decision on provisional application. We will look very clearly into the political process, making sure that we do not end up with a Ukraine which is constantly destabilised by the establishment of a new frozen conflict in the east of the country. And we will make sure that the necessary financial help, political help, economic help is given to Ukraine so that they can develop towards sovereignty, democracy and independence.

name: Štefan Füle
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - Mr President, I am also speaking a little bit on my own behalf. Over the past year we have witnessed how the Ukrainian people have struggled for freedom, democracy and the rule of law, values at the core of the European Union. Europe stands with countries willing to engage on this path, and this is what our relationship with Ukraine is all about. We want to support Ukraine to become a more democratic, prosperous and rule-governed country. Ukraine deserves the same opportunities that were afforded to my country and other countries in Eastern Europe after 1989. This was precisely the aim of our Association Agreement on which negotiations have been taking place for more than five years and which you are about to ratify. Honourable Members, Ukrainians count on your clear support in the vote later this morning. Let us send them a strong signal from Strasbourg to Kiev.

name: Jacek Saryusz-Wolski
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, I am certain that in a few minutes this House will, with a great majority, ratify the Association Agreement between the European Union and Ukraine, thus sending a strong signal of support and solidarity. The Association Agreement can provisionally enter into force immediately after reciprocal notification by both sides of the ratification and it will mean work in secret by Commissioner De Gucht as to how to make it half enter into force – politically but not economically. After ratification the Association Agreement – and this is the formal statement of the rapporteur and of the forthcoming resolution – cannot be changed by one word or one comma. We have to do all we can in order to prevent it being stopped or derailed. Our Moscow sources say that a letter demanding changes to the text has already been sent to Commissioner De Gucht from Russia. I believe that with our ratification we are completely closing the gate to such possibilities and that we are acting in accordance with all the elements of our resolution, which is to be put to the vote on Thursday, that demand further, more audacious, extended and enhanced action by the European Union to assist Ukraine in its economic and political process and also in the defence of its territorial integrity and, ultimately, of the dignity of the Ukrainian nation.

name: Presidente. -
text: I would like to thank all Members for understanding the importance of respecting speaking time during this debate. I would also like to thank Commissioners Füle and De Gucht for their contributions to meeting the timetable. (The sitting was suspended for a few moments) Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing.– Ukraine's current foreign and domestic political events deserve particular attention from Europe, as Ukrainian citizens have paid a heavy price for European orientation. The creation of peace, stability and the security of the population in Ukraine is currently a priority and all assistance must be given to Ukraine, and it is therefore important to ratify the Association Treaty. This is also important in order to really start the process of democratisation, the rule of law and the conditions for equality of law for national minorities in Ukraine in the country's domestic political life. I hope that by the forthcoming parliamentary elections, constituencies favourable to nationalities living in one bloc will already be established and that their representatives will be able to obtain a mandate, which the Central Electoral Commission (CVK) has not done illegally in the event of an early election scheduled by the end of September. It is important to emphasise this, because when we contribute to the Association Treaty between Ukraine and the EU, a rule-of-law Ukraine that respects the rights of minorities can be a real partner for the European Union.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE)
text: Writing. – Today's ratification of the Association Agreement is a symbolic and historically important step in EU-Ukraine relations. This is a step in the right direction. The EU has long had a clear policy towards Ukraine based on respect for its free and sovereign decisions. The Association Agreement is the result of a long-standing negotiation process confirming this policy. This has been confirmed today by both the European Parliament and the Ukrainian Verchovna Council. I believe that this agreement will bring economic benefits for Ukraine and will provide an incentive for further reforms. I consider the arguments that are made against the ratification of this agreement to be scum and inaccurate and are often the result of Russian propaganda. The European Union is interested in Ukraine being our partner – both commercial and political. With today's ratification, we are sending a signal that we want to achieve this objective. The tense situation that reigns in Ukraine is not the result of this agreement, but of Russia's aggressive policy towards its neighbours. I firmly believe that such a policy will not last long.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. – We hear voices from Member State governments that sanctions against Russia are inefficient. The Hungarian Prime Minister says we're going to shoot ourselves in the leg. There are two problems with this statement, and the EP must therefore strongly reject it. The first problem is that the claim is not true. The Moscow Stock Exchange is falling, the ruble has fallen to historic lows against both the euro and the dollar, with $51 billion in capital fleeing the country. All this proves that these are real, strong, effective sanctions. On the other hand, it is true that sanctions also harm European economies, but they are much smaller than what Russia suffers. Russia needs us Europeans more than the other way around. International law, the protection of the Ukrainian people who have been victims of territorial aggression and respect for European core values are more important than the temporary problems caused by sanctions. More than that, it is important that the EU cannot credibly criticise a non-Community state until it has resolved the problems of fundamental rights within its own borders. Unfortunately, the Hungarian example has shown that there could be a reorganization of the rule of law and democratic rights after EU accession. Unfortunately, the EU is currently powerless to act in the interests of democratic fundamental rights. A community-wide solution must be found as soon as possible. Only then can we pursue a credible foreign policy in relation to Russia.

name: Laurențiu Rebega (S&D)
text: in writing. – This crisis is of a political nature, so it is inadmissible for agricultural producers to be one of those most affected by the European Union's political relations with the Russian Federation. I believe that not only community support measures for vegetable and fruit producers need to be supported, as they lose impressive amounts on a daily basis, but also that encouraging consumers to consume these products significantly can be a short- and long-term solution. One solution may also be to support producers and facilitate access to already open extra European markets - such as the Chinese one - and I agree with openness to Canadian and American markets. I am optimistic that the European Union will strike a balance between political sanctions against the Russian Federation and the european Union's protection of the interests of agricultural producers.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. – Today, in Strasbourg, the European Parliament approved by a majority vote the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement, including the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Agreement (DCFTA). The moment was a historic one, given that, at the same time, the agreement was also ratified by the Ukrainian Parliament. The agreement requires a liberalized political and trade association. The political component brings Ukraine one step closer to the EU, while the economic aspect provides reciprocal, free access to the market, substantially integrating the markets of the two parties, abolishing import duties and prohibiting other trade restrictions.  As a Member of the European Parliament, on behalf of Romania, a neighbouring country to Ukraine, I would like to stress the importance of this agreement, which is a clear sign of solidarity and appreciation from the EU towards the Ukrainian people in its struggle for democracy, for a prosperous future in a country where the principles of democracy are respected. Ukraine needs good neighbourly relations with both the West and Eastern Europe. Following the vote in the European Parliament and the Ukrainian Parliament, the agreement will be applied provisionally, but the exact date will be confirmed by the Council. In order to enter into full force, the agreement must be ratified by the 28 Member States.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: in writing.– Mr President, colleagues, bulgaria is also among the countries affected by the Russian food embargo. So far, the calculations are for BGN 10.5 million of our total agricultural exports. The ban on imports of agricultural products deprived all producers of access to the second largest market for European goods. Today, they expect solidarity from Brussels in the form of urgent and adequate measures to make up for their losses and protect them from new ones.  Unfortunately, the secondary effect of the embargo can prove even deeper and more devastating for some industries, including job losses where agriculture is the sole livelihood of the population. Farmers are among the most affected by the political crisis between the EU and Russia, but it is not right for them to pay this high price themselves.  In this regard, I find the eur 125 million compensation envisaged to be extremely insufficient and call for their increase. However, this should not be done solely with funds from the CAP Crisis Fund, which was foreseen for crises in the internal market caused by drought, floods, low harvests or diseases, and this is not the case. Therefore, we need to make up for losses from Russian restrictions from other feathers, as well as push for more cap funds in 2015.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – The European Parliament and the Supreme Rada in Kiev today simultaneously approve the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement. If at the beginning of last week this political gesture was viewed with confidence, today it is overshadowed by the decision to postpone the implementation of the Free Trade Agreement between Kiev and the EU. We must avoid the celebration of simultaneous ratification of the agreement because internal pressures in Ukraine, as well as external ones, risk turning the Association Agreement into a drawer document, which is not applicable or unenforceable. The EP and the EU institutions must take priority over the application of the Association Agreement, in particular its commercial component.  Twenty-five years after the fall of the Iron Curtain, we might think that Europe has finally left behind the experience of totalitarian regimes, the lack of democracy and respect for international treaties, but the realities of the east of the continent show us otherwise. That is why I believe that there is a need for more consistency and coherence in the policy of the EU and the Member States in relation to Ukraine with regard to the sanctions policies applied to the Russian Federation, in strengthening the EU-NATO relationship and for better coordination with the measures of the recent North Atlantic summit. Our goal is peace and stability in the region and maintaining the level of ambition of the Eastern Partnership objective.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: In writing.- Months ago, I wrote and talked about the Kremlin's geostrategic plans that go much further than Crimea. Putin does not respect world order, territorial sovereignty, international law and fundamental human rights. I was looking forward to implementing the trade agreement with Ukraine. By delaying his entry into force, we have in some ways once again bowed to Putin. We, too, are to blame for Russia's military intervention in Ukraine and the expansion of its territory, because in 2008 we did not guarantee it a secure future in the North Atlantic Treaty. I'm sure Putin can't win this war in the long run. If it continues on its trajectory, Russia will be an isolated country and a major economic and social catastrophe in a few years. But the consequences will also be severe for us, and they will be even worse if we hesitate with more decisive sanctions and all-round assistance to Ukraine.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: The next item on the agenda is voting time. Ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would ask you to take a seat. Please take your seats! As you know, we have organised a live switch with the Ukrainian Parliament for the forthcoming vote. You see the members of the Ukrainian Parliament here on the screens. (Applause) There may be delays in transmission. You have to assume that what we are saying and doing here may arrive in Kiev with a delay of about 30 seconds to a minute, or vice versa. If you want to clap for 30 seconds at the end of my speech, we will bridge the time delay. Ladies and gentlemen, President Poroshenko, I would like to thank President Poroshenko for his excellent work. I do not think I am exaggerating when I say that we are experiencing a historic moment. The European Parliament here in Strasbourg and the Verkhovna Rada in Kiev will immediately ratify the Association Agreement between the European Union and Ukraine. The fact that two parliaments in free self-determination are voting on this Treaty at the same time today is free democracy in free self-determination; this is the opposite of managed democracy. (Interjections and applause) The ratification of this Treaty, which has remained unchanged since the first days of the peaceful demonstrations on the Majdan, is a golden hour of democracy, especially in view of what we have seen in recent months. I would like to ask you: a few months ago, who could have imagined that borders in Europe would once again be shifted by force, that the security architecture that we have painstakingly built up in this continent, especially after the end of the Cold War, would be called into question? Who would have thought it possible for the law of the strongest to re-enter Europe? We stand for the strength of the law! Ladies and gentlemen! The fear of war has returned to Europe. What has happened and is happening in Ukraine concerns us all. I would therefore like to repeat here, particularly in conjunction with my colleagues in Kiev, that the European Parliament has always defended Ukraine's territorial integrity and sovereignty, and we will continue to do so. (Applause) We will therefore do so so that the dream of the people of Ukraine, the dream of the people who fought on the Majdan, so that the demands of the Ukrainian people can become a reality. We are fighting for a democratic Ukraine, for a constitutional Ukraine whose constitution and electoral law have been reformed, a country that wants to crack down on corruption, in which human rights are respected and, above all, the rights of minorities are protected. We support a Ukraine whose economy is thriving, where the social divide is closing and all people have a good future. The day on which this Ukraine becomes a reality will be the day when the promise of the peaceful revolution on the Majdan is fulfilled. We – and I believe I am speaking on behalf of the overwhelming majority of Members of the European Parliament – will support the Ukrainian people in fulfilling this dream of The Majdan. That is why this vote is taking place today. (Applause) Before we proceed to the vote here, I have the great honour of giving the floor to the President of Ukraine, Petro Poroshenko, who will now speak to us from Kiev, beyond the distance and thanks to modern technology. After that, the vote will take place and, after the vote, I will sign the European Parliament's letter of transmission to the Council before your eyes in order to initiate the formal process for the final procedures. The President of Ukraine, Mr Poroshenko, now has the floor. (Applause)

name: Petro Poroshenko
text: President of Ukraine. - Mr President, honourable Members, first of all I would like to thank you for your applause and for the support for Ukraine that you have just demonstrated. I would like to say that the atmosphere here in the Verkhovna Rada reminds me very much of the atmosphere we had here in 1991 when we gained our independence. Who is ready to die for Europe? That is the question that is now posed by researchers who research the influence of Europe on the creation of a state. It is something that is quite natural, to give one’s life and to die for one’s country. The first 100 Ukrainians who died in February and the 872 who died in the east died not only for Ukraine; they died so that Ukraine could take its place in Europe. Starting from the Second World War, no other nation has paid as high a price for the right to be European. Tell me, please, who will dare close the door of Europe to Ukraine after this? Who will be against the prospect of membership in the European Union towards which we are taking today our first, but most decisive, step? Over seven years – ever since the EU-Ukraine Paris Summit – we have been preparing the text of this Association Agreement. I would like first of all to thank everybody who took part in this process – the diplomats, the experts, and most of all the citizens who very decisively supported us on our European course. Last autumn we thought that everything was absolutely ready for signature, because the whole country was resolutely in favour, and the arguments of those who were against appeared extremely feeble, but on 29 November 2013 in Vilnius we were all waiting for this signature. The necessity of signing this agreement then and now is also very evident for Ukrainians. Ukrainians revolted against what Yanukovych did in turning the express train to face eastwards. I am convinced that our vote today will demonstrate this very clearly. The internal or external forces that try to stop our progress have already been defeated. You know that this agreement, which was signed in June 2014 in Brussels and is being jointly ratified today, is going to be a feast – not only for us Ukrainians, but for all of united Europe, because without Ukraine there is no united Europe. We did not cede to any blackmail. We endured, and I want to underline that in the text of this agreement no paragraph, no comma, no word will have been changed, and that is the text which I will sign today. I shall ask the Ukrainian Government tomorrow to make this agreement enter into force tomorrow. Friends, implementation is very easy. It is freedom of speech; it is the no-visa regime; it is the investment climate; it is democracy. All of that is a way of implementing our agreement. We have no right to wait any longer. Our last negotiations in Brussels allow us to enlarge upon even what this agreement foresees. We will have preferential treatment until the end of 2015. European products will come into the Ukrainian market under the international agreements in the framework in force today. Ukraine will be able to compete with other countries and other producers. I also want today to thank the European Union for the incredible support that they have given us in these very difficult times. On the other hand, our European partners want only one thing in exchange: reform. Please do not delay. Neither the war, nor the political situation can be excuses to not proceed with reform. I am convinced of the fact that the national plan for reform for 2020 will be presented. We will do this together, not each and every one of us thinking of ourselves: it is the President, the Government and the Parliament that must work together and we will go on the path to victory. If anybody tries to open an inner front against this, we will not allow it. Moreover, these reforms foresee Ukraine becoming a very important centre for anti-corruption laws. I will propose anti-corruption laws in the framework of a bureau or of a committee for this. This is what we have taken upon ourselves as part of the ratification and implementation, and I think that this will be the best way to say that we have already started.  In the 1920s, Mykola Khvylovy – a great Ukrainian author – said: give us Europe! We understand Europe as a psychological category which allows us to move forward towards progress. Today we are making steps on this new path of return. The start was difficult, but we will win. Glory to Ukraine! Glory to Europe! Honourable friends, this will be a historic moment now when, together with the European Parliament, we will take a decision. (Applause)

name: Der Präsident. -
text: Ladies and gentlemen! We now come to the voting process. A roll-call vote has been requested. Before we take this vote, I would like to make another point. I believe that in the history of parliamentarianism there has never been a vote by two parliaments to ratify an international treaty together on two sides at the same time. I believe that this is a one-off process – and a process of which we should be proud. (Applause) That is why, ladies and gentlemen, we shall now proceed to the vote. Colleagues have made advance payments: you have seen the result of the vote from Kiev. I am now opening the vote on the EU association agreement with Ukraine, on the Saryusz-Wolski report.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: Ladies and gentlemen! You have seen that President Poroshenko, on the other hand, has already signed and signed the entry into force of the agreement. I am now signing Parliament's letter of transmission that we have ratified this agreement, in which I call on the other EU institutions to put this agreement into force immediately. I am doing this before your eyes so that you can see that it is happening immediately. (The President signed the letter of transmission) (Applause) That concludes the vote.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we voted against the ratification of these agreements. Ukraine is currently torn between East and West, as we see tragically every day. Let us not forget that this crisis is directly the result of the signing or not of the agreements we are discussing today, since it began with the volte-face of President Yanukovych, then overthrown by a coup d'état. Why then throw oil on the fire by signing this agreement instead, on the contrary, trying to calm things between the two sides.  The association between the UNION and Ukraine aims, in particular, to promote, preserve and consolidate peace and stability. For now, you end up with exactly the opposite result. On the other hand, how do you want to implement a free trade agreement with a country in which there is a civil war on about a third of its territory?  Finally, it is rather worrying, damaging and alarming that no impact assessment has been carried out since this agreement carries many risks, both for European employees, and therefore for French employees, and of course for Ukrainian employees.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI). -
text: Mr President, we voted against this agreement because an association agreement at the moment is to prepare for war. It is, in fact, to accentuate the division between East and West when we should work for unity and for peace. It means respecting, on the other hand, the Ukrainian people by voting against it. Faced with its false economic hopes - gas and electricity already more expensive, water that has increased by 50%, destruction of jobs and rising unemployment - western aid will never be enough to rebuild a divided and destroyed country and our Parliament is lying to Ukraine by making it look for aid commensurate with economic difficulties. Ukraine will find itself even more impoverished and the compensations of the West will never live up to expectations. The Ukrainian people will soon feel betrayed by the West. Finally, democracy in Ukraine is more fragile than ever in the hands of corrupt oligarchs, clearly fascist elements that sow hatred and racism. Parliament is being manipulated by NATO.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE). -
text: Mr. President! I voted in favour of the Association Agreement because, for me, it is not the end of a story, but the beginning of a new story, and it could also be overridden in this way: by working together to create trust.  Anyone who reads the agreement carefully and looks at the prospects knows that it is not only a prospect for the European Union and for Ukraine, but it could also be a perspective, if you like, in the trialogue between Ukraine, between the European Union and Russia. I repeat, the motto could be: through joint work, through trade, to build trust. That is why I was able to vote in favour of the agreement by a majority of this House.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI). -
text: As a Hungarian person, of course, I did not vote – because I could not vote with good heart – for an association agreement between the European Union and a country – Ukraine – which is a country that constantly and increasingly tramples on the human rights of nearly 200 000 Hungarian people.
