Hungarians in Transcarpathia live in fear, Hungarians in Transcarpathia are fleeing. This Association Agreement states that the parties must respect human rights and the rights of indigenous national communities must be respected. Ukraine is doing less and less. I do not usually politicize party politics here, but my heart was broken when my fellow Fidesz members stood and applauded this disgraceful association agreement. And it was squeezed even when the elected representative of the Hungarians in Transcarpathia did not speak in this debate.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, an Association Agreement is a half-way house between a trade agreement and EU membership. This is Ukraine’s second attempt at an Association Agreement. The first attempt led to the overthrow of the democratically elected pro-Russian President and the current civil war which we have now in the Ukraine. With Putin uttering his rhetoric, where is this going to end? The Ukraine is a buffer zone between NATO and Russia; the EU has taken away this buffer zone, potentially putting NATO tanks on the border with Russia. What you are doing today is throwing petrol onto the bonfire which the EU lit. Putin is not the biggest threat to our civilisation. The biggest threat is Muslim extremists. This is for political reasons, and poking the Russian bear is very dangerous. For this reason UKIP voted against this agreement.

name: Klaus Buchner (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mr. President! The agreement contains statements that many do not perceive; that is no wonder, with around 1 200 pages on which we have now voted. I refer specifically to Article 89 in the section on trade. It states that the laws in Ukraine must be amended in such a way as to introduce investment protection and the so-called arbitration procedures. Investment protection means that Ukraine cannot introduce new social and environmental laws that affect the profits of European investors. Note: a dismantling of democracy. Arbitration proceedings can result in billions of dollars in fines that ruin the Ukrainian economy or at least cause serious damage to it.  If we conclude the agreement with these agreements, the Ukrainian people will very quickly realise that we have sent them a Trojan horse. Confidence in Europe is being lost and our relationship with each other is being permanently disrupted. I stress that an agreement with Ukraine is absolutely necessary, but please do not use these passages in this form.

name: Tatjana Ždanoka (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mr President, I voted against consent to the Agreement. I regard this Agreement as a badly prepared, extremely irresponsible and especially politicised decision. In three days we will be celebrating a very important anniversary: just 51 years will have passed since a similar agreement with Turkey – and  where is the EU now in our relations with that country? I recommend that we remind them of that – those naïve, naïvely dreaming people in Ukraine who hope for a fast advance on the question of their country’s membership of the European Union, for a free visa regime, just promised irresponsibly by Mr Poroshenko. We are inviting new inhabitants to enter the House of the EU which now needs to be profoundly rebuilt; and therefore our decision is completely irresponsible.

name: Neena Gill (S&D). -
text: Mr President, I voted in favour of the Saryusz-Wolski report because I believe that strengthening the relationship between the EU and Ukraine at this crucial juncture is critical. Ukraine is a close neighbour whose security, stability and prosperity are increasingly affecting the EU, as recent events have demonstrated. I firmly believe that it is the interests of citizens from both sides that we make this strong commitment to supporting Ukraine in its effort to implement deep-rooted and sustainable economic and political reform while cooperating closely on security across the region. I also believe that this agreement is instrumental in fostering a political solution to the crisis in Ukraine which respects the country’s sovereignty and territorial integrity. Commissioner De Gucht has now announced that the entry into force of the deep and comprehensive free trade agreement (DCFTA) between the EU and Ukraine, a key part of this Association Agreement, will be delayed in an effort to avoid further escalation of the tensions with Russia. I appreciate that such a step might be necessary to contribute to de-escalation of this conflict, however, I would also like to underscore the fact that the decision by Ukraine to enter into this agreement with the EU is a sovereign one and we should not lose sight of the vital imperative of defending firmly Ukraine’s right to make such sovereign choices.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, I voted against this agreement on trade between the European Union and Ukraine, because I believe that this agreement is particularly disadvantageous for Ukraine. I am clearly in support of free trade, but Ukraine is committed to adopting the whole acquis, all regulations of the European Union. This treaty divided Ukraine politically, it divided it in November, it caused the Maidan movement, because what was advantageous for the western part of the country – trade without tariffs with the European Union – was also disadvantageous for the east of the country, because in this part it will become more difficult to trade with Russia and other countries of the former Soviet Union. I would therefore be in support of a free trade agreement, but I am sorry that Ukraine must adopt the whole one-off acquis, which is particularly harmful to the poorer countries of the European Union and will be all the more damaging to a country like Ukraine.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted outright against the EU-Ukraine partnership agreement because of the political implications of signing it for that country and the region. In fact, it was the signing of this partnership agreement that led to the coup d'etion in Ukraine, encouraged by the US and the EU itself against the legitimate president, Yanukovich.  In no way am I going to support an association agreement with an illegitimate government that emerged from a coup d'éerous, which also has fascist members in it. An association agreement, on the other hand, which is used by the EU as a weapon against Russia. The EU, rather than promoting its trade interests, should promote an immediate cessation of hostilities and a comprehensive peace agreement for Ukraine.

name: Andrus Ansip (ALDE)
text: Writing. - I today supported the ratification of the Association Agreement between the European Union and Ukraine.  Few EU policies have had as important and long-term consequences as this issue, so it is also important to keep the focus and clear objective in relations between Ukraine and the EU. On the Part of the European Union, this is an opportunity for the Ukrainian people and an invitation to closer communication. The European Parliament must direct EU policy and support the Ukrainian people and their elected President, and fully support the ratification of the Association Agreement, not only but also as soon as possible.  Apart from the events of recent months, it is clear that Russia is not hiding its objectives and has used military force to achieve its political objectives – no concession or delay has brought the expected result, but has encouraged the Russian leadership to take even more aggressive steps.  The fact that there is a truce today and Russia is ready for negotiations is the result of clear political steps and increasing sanctions by the EU and our allies. Apart from the sacrifices made by Ukraine in the name of its association with the European Union, the least the EU can do is to ratify this treaty and make sure that it is fully implemented.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. - The ratification of the Association Agreement is an important sign of solidarity towards Ukraine. Negotiations on the Association Agreement began in 2007 in a sign of increased cooperation between the EU and Ukraine. This partnership must not be abandoned even after Russia has occupied territory contrary to international law. Through this agreement, the EU Member States and Ukraine are pursuing the objective of mutually reducing import duties. However, Ukraine, the EU and Russia agreed in trilateral talks that the economic part of the agreement would not enter into force until the end of 2015. This was done to counter Russia's concern that EU goods would enter the Russian market via Ukraine. The ratification of the Association Agreement, however, supports, above all, the democratic construction of Ukraine. The agreement calls for the implementation of reforms and respect for the rule of law. It is a motivation to adhere to and develop principles of the rule of law, even in times of external threat, in order to meet European standards. It was precisely for these objectives of the rule of law, the fight against corruption and the development of democracy that Ukrainian citizens protested on the Majdan from the end of 2013, after the then Ukrainian President Yanukovych announced that he would not sign the Association Agreement with the European Union.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. - In full coherence with the "general" association agreement between the European Union and Ukraine, the aim here is to give a legal framework to workers from third countries legally employed on the territory of the other party. This will contribute to the necessary rapprochement between the Union and Ukraine and thus to the political and socio-economic stabilisation of ukraine.

name: Heinz K. Becker (PPE)
text: Writing. - I voted in favour of the association agreement between the European Union and Ukraine because it is the promise made to the Maidan freedom fighters. Many people, especially young people, stood up last year and demonstrated for the Association Agreement. Some have paid for this with their lives. We owe it to these people that Europe stands by its promises. The Association Agreement strengthens Ukraine's sovereignty, but does not yet create peace in freedom and justice in the region. It will therefore continue to be necessary to talk to Russia and to maintain dialogue.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This association agreement between the EU/Euratom and Ukraine, which is to replace the previous Partnership and Cooperation Agreement and which covers more than 30 sectors ranging from the economy to transport and supported by general principles such as respect for democratic principles, is mainly aimed at creating a vast free trade area that will further accentuate the dumping of which the EU is already a victim. Thus it will be a first step towards Ukraine's future and possible accession to the European Union even as the EU budget is constrained. Finally, in view of the current humanitarian, military and political crisis in eastern Ukraine, any such initiative aimed at an agreement with the EU can only increase tensions and conflicts with Russia. That is why I opposed this agreement.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I did not support the Saryusz-Wolski report with my vote because I believe that this agreement once again demonstrates the EU's indifference and lack of capacity to give immediate answers to Italian agriculture affected by the Russian embargo.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I voted in favour in the vote on the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement. However, I have several serious objections to the procedure itself, including the application of a so-called urgency procedure in which the European Parliament quickly votes through the agreement without being able to deal with or discuss it. It is not responsible to represent the citizens in this way. The agreement must also be approved by the Ukrainian Parliament with a quick procedure just weeks before national elections are held in Ukraine. That is not taking the democratic process seriously. A key element of the agreement is a deep and comprehensive free trade area, with far-reaching consequences for the economy as well as on social, environmental and food standards. Due to the 'emergency procedure' used, the competent Parliamentary Committee on International Trade has not been able to deal with the part of the agreement constituted by the FREE Trade Agreement. This unfortunately does not surround the agreement with a proper political debate, as should have been the case.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. - I voted in favour of this recommendation because the Association Agreement between the European Union and Ukraine is the first of the next generation of association agreements signed with the Eastern Partnership countries. The Association Agreement aims to accelerate the development of political and economic relations between Ukraine and the EU. This is a very important historical moment and the fact that the European Parliament, despite the tense political situation, has not withdrawn and ratified the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement. In view of the historically close relations between the European Union and Ukraine and the ever closer ties, as well as the current political situation in the European neighbourhood, the European Parliament aims to strengthen and expand relations, democracy and the development of civil society in this Association Agreement.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Although I in substance support the non-discrimination principle in the context of employment, I have voted against this report in order to voice my rejection of the undemocratic way this file was brought forward – without any substantial or public debate in committee or plenary. An agreement which was at the very root of the escalation of the current EU-Ukraine-Russia conflict should not be rushed through Parliament without any proper political scrutiny. Pushing through an association agreement at this time only serves to escalate the conflict in an increasingly fragile situation. Europe’s citizens are already paying the price for this conflict, and this would only see it intensify. For the sake of our farmers and others who are paying the price for the deepening conflict between Russia and Ukraine, we cannot vote for this association agreement’s progression in any form.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted against because the EU's policy towards Russia is wrong. Instead, we should bring the Russian Federation closer together and not follow foreign-imposed policies that only benefit the US. We are suffering severe damage from the EU's sanctions policy. No more sanctions on Russia, no more American puppets!

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. - The signing of the agreement creates a comprehensive political association and economic integration between the EU and Ukraine and provides free mutual access to the market, representing a clear and strong signal of support for Ukraine's European path. I support Ukraine's efforts in the process of democratisation to preserve its territorial integrity, and I also believe that we must provide them with economic and political assistance in order to build a state of law and a prosperous economy.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) Today I voted in favour of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement, which includes a comprehensive and in-depth free trade area (DCFTA).  This agreement will establish a stronger political link and economic integration between the EU and Ukraine and provide free and reciprocal access to markets. Thanks to this ratification, Ukraine's European choice will be institutionalised and its political, social and economic future will be linked to the future of the EU. Ukrainian society has paid the highest price for its European aspirations, in terms of human and economic losses. With this ratification, the EU recognises this sacrifice and offers Ukraine concrete and tangible support.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Although I in substance support the non-discrimination principle in the context of employment, I have voted against this report in order to voice my rejection of the undemocratic way this file was brought forward – without any substantial or public debate in committee or plenary. An agreement which was at the very root of the escalation of the current EU-Ukraine-Russia conflict should not be rushed through Parliament without any proper political scrutiny. Pushing through an association agreement at this time only serves to escalate the conflict in an increasingly fragile situation. Europe’s citizens are already paying the price for this conflict, and this would only see it intensify. For the sake of our farmers and others who are paying the price for the deepening conflict between Russia and Ukraine, we cannot vote for this association agreement’s progression in any form.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. - When starting a common path it is always better to do it on a solid basis: the association agreement between the European Union and Ukraine was concluded at an inappropriate time, both from an institutional and economic point of view.  The situation of conflict and the continuing uncertainty about certain responsibilities, both on the one hand and on the other, would be sufficient reasons to prolong a more than due reflection on the future of a country such as Ukraine to complex and varied realities such as the single market and the European Union. We know that this agreement has more political than substantive significance and serves more than anything else to give a signal, but the price of this signal is paid by ordinary citizens who suffer the consequences of imposing sanctions that do not take into account the double-edged liaison between the Russian and European economic realities. In such a complex scenario, we need reflection and dialogue between the two parties in conditions of peace and stability, only in this way can decisions of a strategic sense be taken, especially in a country such as Ukraine, which has been in need of a series of structural reforms for years.

name: Lorenzo Cesa (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I expressed with great conviction my firm YES to the ratification of the Association Agreement between the European Union and Ukraine. For the first time in history, two parliaments have voted at the same time on an agreement that will sanction deep political association and mutual economic integration. Today, the parliaments of Strasbourg and Kiev have come together ideally, expressing a strong desire for dialogue and cooperation. This is not just a formal act but a significant moment, which will set the course for intense cultural and commercial exchange. The political provisions will bring Ukraine closer to the European Union, opening up new channels of political dialogue and establishing basic rules for cooperation in strategic areas such as energy, transport and education. Today is a day of celebration for the democracy of the Ukrainian people and the People of Europe!

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. - It was exciting to participate in this vote at the same time as the Verkhovna Rada. This was an historic vote not only because of the role of technology that made the moment itself suggestive, but also because my intention, in voting in favour, was to take a step that would bring an end to misunderstandings with Russia. It is now up to Ukraine to take the necessary steps to secure peace, particularly in terms of concessions to regions that have the greatest affinity with Russia. I am concerned that the self-determination of peoples, peace and the conditions for prosperity prevail.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - I support the Agreement between the European Union and Ukraine because I believe that we have a responsibility to support peoples who fight for freedom and democracy and who want to strengthen their ties with the European Union.  Negotiation of this agreement began in 2007 and was concluded in 2012. Russian pressure and the withdrawal of the deposed Ukrainian government led to two more years being lost. I also believe that this agreement can be a model for negotiations with other Eastern Partnership countries. I hope that the EU will be firm in its implementation and will not give in to moscow's blackmail, which in practice seeks to reduce these agreements with the states that Russia considers to be in its strategic orbit to an futility.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of this agreement ratified today at the same time by the European Parliament and the Ukrainian Parliament. A fine sign of democracy that enshrines the Union's support for this country and, with the creation of a free trade area, the basis for cooperation in areas such as energy, transport and education. It is now essential for Ukraine to implement those important reforms that make democracy a reality, through the fight against internal problems, especially corruption. Respect for the rule of law and human rights remains a fundamental condition for the EU and today, with this agreement, I believe that we have taken a step in this direction. We hope to see the fruits of this choice soon.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – This agreement signifies the choice of the people of Ukraine to foster within their country European values. This choice deserved my vote.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. - (IT) I think it is imprudent to vote on a free trade agreement, which will start in 2016, between Europe and Ukraine.  Considering that part of Ukrainian territory is the scene of clashes over the dispute in certain regions and that the number of people killed, according to the UN, between regular troops and pro-Russian rebels, is 2 086 victims, including 20 children; since as of 26 July there were 1129 calculated deaths, again by the United Nations, the current moment testifies to the serious resurgence of the civil conflict without an international awareness. For these reasons, I am abstaining from voting on this act on a occasion such as ukraine, which is currently very unclear.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted outright against the EU-Ukraine partnership agreement because of the political implications of signing it for that country and the region. In fact, it was the signing of this partnership agreement that led to the coup d'etion in Ukraine, encouraged by the US and the EU itself against the legitimate president, Yanukovich.  In no way am I going to support an association agreement with an illegitimate government that emerged from a coup d'éerous, which also has fascist members in it. An association agreement, on the other hand, which is used by the EU as a weapon against Russia. The EU, rather than promoting its trade interests, should promote an immediate cessation of hostilities and a comprehensive peace agreement for Ukraine.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. - For more than twenty years, Europe has been proposing a free trade agreement with Ukraine, a country directly bordering the EU. From the point of view of regional cooperation, the Association Agreement is an important step. Ukraine is becoming the 'most favoured nation' for Europe, since it is now able to apply free trade conditions on an equal terms to those enjoyed by its trading partners under GATT. This is an important step from an economic and commercial point of view, of course, but it is becoming more politically important at the moment. Indeed, the Association Agreement, in addition to marking the importance of the market economy, underlines the EU's support in defending democratic values and human rights. It is through the protection of Ukraine's independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity that important results can be achieved with a view to peace and stability throughout the European continent. Europe can do so much for Ukraine. Ukrainian citizens need support and they must not feel alone, they must know that they can count on us. Euromaidan is an important signal to which we cannot remain indifferent. Young pro-European Ukrainians have the right to be heard by a Europe that guarantees democratic principles.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. – The simultaneous vote of the European Parliament and the Verkhovna Rada in favour of the Association Agreement and Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area represents a milestone not only in the relations between the EU and Ukraine but also a strong and positive signal to the next country in line, Moldova. The ratification acknowledges the important reform efforts and ambitions of the Ukrainian authorities for democracy, stability and prosperity as well as the legitimate aspirations of its people for even closer cooperation with the Union. The Agreement signed by Ukraine and Moldova is not an end in itself. It constitutes the starting point of a new framework within which to advance and deepen relations even further; one more building block of a process which will foster enhanced political association and economic integration bringing these two countries closer to the EU while also  delivering concrete benefits to citizens and responding effectively to their demands and their needs.  Today I voted yes to recognise the tremendous efforts made by the Ukrainian people, to send a clear and encouraging message to Moldova and to reiterate that the EU and this House stand ready to provide all the support needed on this crucial path.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this agreement, as a European citizen who values the contribution Ukraine can give to the economic wellbeing of our Union, and the talent that it can contribute to our continent. I also want to believe that the integration between the European Union and our Ukrainian neighbours can go even further. Meanwhile, I welcome the ceasefire in eastern Ukraine and ask both sides to respect it. We should also support talks between Ukraine and Russia, and help Ukraine regain stability and implement crucial political and economic reforms.

name: Diane Dodds (NI)
text: in writing. – I very much welcome the principles that underlie this Association Agreement – namely support for the rule of law and the protection of Ukrainian sovereignty.  And upon these principles it is right that the EU engages with Ukraine to support its political reforms, to encourage free trade, and to cooperate on matters of security and defence that are currently very salient given the context of actions by Russia in the east of the country. Indeed, at a time when the Russian import ban continues to have ramifications for the dairy sector in my constituency, Northern Ireland, I also share the view that continued political discussions are vital in seeking de-escalation in tensions between the two countries. We must accept, however, that the first step in this process must be the withdrawal of Russian forces and resources from separatist militants – to establish a secure border and international monitoring.

name: Bas Eickhout (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. - We ultimately voted in favour of the Association Agreement with Ukraine. We want to support and help the Ukrainian people in the fight for true democracy, against war and violence, and for the preservation of sovereignty. We support the sanctions against Russia because the leaders of that country are indeed behaving unsuspently. The peace talks must continue and deserve our support. However, we must dare to face up to the situation. We are being dragged into a geopolitical game that is heavily mediated by the simultaneous and perhaps hasty vote in the EP and the Ukrainian Parliament. Although this agreement is to be put to the vote today, it is already being said that it will not enter into force until 1 January 2016. Why the rush to approve them now? Are we not in danger of becoming in the situation of another 'frozen conflict' at the EU's borders? We are also particularly uncomfortable with the content of the 1200 pages that are on the ballot. How will these agreements affect our models of society? What is the real agenda behind this agreement? Are we putting Ukraine on the right path or is it being used for a larger geopolitical conflict? Voting against now would be irresponsible, given Ukraine's desire and our desire to support Ukraine. But in the coming months, we will be holding our hearts as this conflict develops and whether it will allow us to go down the path of peace.

name: Georgios Epitideios (NI)
text: Writing. - I voted against the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement because in my opinion this is done at a time earlier than planned. Ukraine is not yet ready to join the EU as it does not meet the criteria set out in the Copenhagen Agreement. Furthermore, this Agreement, together with Ukraine's acquisition of atomic energy capabilities and the new measures against Russia announced by the EU, runs counter to the interests of Russia, which is expected to react with new countermeasures. This development will have a direct and significant impact on the economies of the EU Member States and in particular on the damaged Greek economy.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. - Ukrainian citizens have paid a very high price for their European ambitions. They have suffered a historic death toll, they have seen their territory occupied and their economy is devastated. However, they are always committed to European values, fighting to the end to defend them. Ukraine is a neighbouring state of the European Union with which we have established important relations for our economy. The European Union must respond to external pressures to ensure not only its territorial integrity, but also that of the neighbouring states with which it cooperates. The EU-Ukraine agreement is another step towards protecting European interests. For the reasons set out above, I voted in favour. I hope that this agreement will help to promote peace and create conditions conducive to closer economic and trade relations that will lead to the gradual integration of Ukraine into the EU internal market.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This recommendation strengthens relations between the EU and the forces that have illegitimately taken power in Ukraine. We are facing another step in the process of open US and EU interference in Ukraine's internal situation, promoting destabilisation, actively supporting fascist and neo-Nazi political and paramilitary forces and inciting the exacerbation of tensions, divisions and divisions in this country. Of the agreements ever signed between the EU and third countries, this is one of the farthest goes, aiming at the full harmonisation of Ukrainian laws to EU rules and rules, an agreement that sweeps all areas of Ukrainian society, with a clear prejudice to the Ukrainian people, without being called upon to rule, in particular in a referendum, as proposed by the Communist Party of Ukraine , which is currently the target of a persecution by the coup power, aiming at its illegalization. An agreement with consequences deeply harmful to the interests of ukrainian workers and people, national interests and sovereignty of Ukraine, signed with a government weeks away from going to elections, aggravated by the kiev authorities' application of the serious package of submission and austerity imposed by the US, IMF and EU troika.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. - I abstained on the grounds that I consider the accelerated procedure for the association agreement with Ukraine to be unjustified and not reflecting the current internal political situation in the country.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. - The association agreement between the EU and Ukraine confirms the EU's unholy foreign policy choices. This agreement will fuel tensions and hostilities with Russia regardless of the real needs of the Ukrainian people and European citizens.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. – Ukraine does not have a clear position on the issue of GMOs (genetically modified products) as it accepts subsidies on the terms of the IMF and the World Bank, which go to large agro-enterprises which will lead to the country's opening up for genetically modified crops. We are voting against trade and corporate ties between the EU and Ukraine for these reasons, because of the risks involved. As far as actions are concerned, it is not possible, to satisfy political interests, to accept a shift to dangerous forms of energy (Atomic Energy) but to Alternative Energy Sources and Green Development.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. – I have chosen to vote in favour of the report on the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement, with the exception of the treatment of third-country nationals legally employed as workers in the territory of the other party. The Agreement will establish closer ties in areas such as workers’ rights, visa liberalisation, justice and business regulations. It also puts a strong emphasis on the values and principles of: democracy and the rule of law, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, good governance, the market economy and sustainable development.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the ratification of the Association Agreement; in my view it is a success for both Ukraine and the European Union. Today’s vote on the ratification, simultaneously in two European cities, Kiev and Strasbourg, voted by two democratically-elected parliaments – the Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine and the European Parliament, the highest democratically-elected legislative body of the European Union – is a strong symbolic message to Ukrainian society and proof of the sharing of common European values and a European destiny. This gesture is even more necessary today in the face of the increasing Russian pressure, invasion and warfare directed against Ukraine.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - The EU-Ukraine Association Agreement adopted by the EP is a support for the independence and unity of Ukraine. The agreement deals with both political and economic aspects of cooperation. Political support will m.in areas such as energy and transport. The Agreement with Ukraine is also a commitment to carry out a number of reforms and to respect democratic principles and human rights. The agreement also introduces a free trade principle, which will allow for deeper integration of the Ukrainian market into the EU.  In the absence of an effective solution to the Russian-Ukrainian conflict, Ukraine's integration into the EU offers an opportunity to protect against further Russian expansion. The history of the EU itself shows the importance of broad economic cooperation for peace. There is no doubt that the stability of the EU's eastern border is in the common interest of the EU and Ukraine. Despite the strong support of Members in the vote – 535 were in favour – the agreement has yet to be ratified by the 28 Member States. So far, only four countries have ratified it.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Voted against the ratification of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement, with the exception of the treatment of third-country nationals legally employed as workers in the territory of the other Party, because in this context of internal conflict as well as the current weakness of the ceasefire, the appropriate conditions for such an agreement are not met , which could become an element that rekindled tensions between East and Kiev. Moreover, such ratification has been raised without the existence of a deep and democratic debate which would be appropriate for such a long-standing agreement.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the ratification of the comprehensive free trade agreement between the European Union and Ukraine, which echoes the citizen's commitment to democratic change for which men and women have fought, some of whom have lost their lives. We send a strong signal to Ukraine in its efforts at political and economic reform, but also a message to Russia to respect Ukraine's territorial integrity and sovereignty. Through this agreement, Ukraine will move closer to the EU through new channels of political dialogue and a framework for cooperation in areas such as energy, transport and education.  I hope that this agreement will help to remedy the widespread corruption that plagues all levels of decision-making and hinders the improvement of the living conditions of the population.  Another important point of the agreement is the obligation for Ukraine to reform and respect democratic principles, human rights and the rule of law.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I see today’s voting as a fruitful result of the Eastern Partnership summit meeting in Vilnius, Lithuania. It is unfortunate that the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement can only be signed after a lot of losses in Maidan and Eastern Ukraine. I believe that the ratification today is a strong symbolic gesture, which shows our support for Ukrainians that made a European choice almost a year ago. Today is a historic day for Ukraine as well as for the European Union, which enables us to share the same values and move towards a common future. Nevertheless, the EU has to be united and stand together with Ukraine to be able to deal with the increasing pressure coming from Russia. We have to look at today's political crisis as an opportunity to move forwards, search for new markets and decrease our dependence on Russia.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. - I voted against this EU-Ukraine Association Agreement because I believe that this process has taken place in a hurry, without a vision and without clear consultation with the citizens of Ukraine. The European Union's attitude towards Ukraine has major geopolitical consequences and, in my opinion, this is the main reason for the escalation of the conflict in Ukraine. This requires a careful approach and this association agreement is more likely to backfire. International security, human rights and democracy are at all times more important than short-sighted trade policy.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - I voted in favour of the Association Agreement with Ukraine. The ratification of this agreement on an accelerated basis is undoubtedly a clear signal that the European Union is on Ukraine's side and supporting it in its pro-European and independence efforts. Unfortunately, Ukraine's European choice is occupied with the highest price you can pay. I believe that, in this situation, it is Europe's duty to do everything it can to mitigate the terrible consequences that this country suffers. The Association Agreement together with the Free Trade Area Agreement is an important example of this, but it should be borne in mind that, in addition to macroeconomic support, humanitarian aid is the most urgent at this point. The recent increase of EUR 2.5 million in this aid by the EC is undoubtedly very important, but the needs remain enormous.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. - On Tuesday 16 September, the Ukrainian parliament made the decisive choice to ratify, unanimously, the association agreement with the European Union. At the same time, the European Parliament also ratified the agreement, marking a rapprochement with the Kiev authorities. If this approach is described by some as historic, it should not make us lose sight of the stakes of this rapprochement. While this approach in form marks recognition and support for Ukraine's independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity, it does not resolve the conflict that has claimed more than 2,700 lives since its inception. What about this agreement, which has been stripped of its essential marrow, namely the commercial component, which has been postponed until the end of 2015? There is certainly the political signal. But I fear that these few lines are merely a screen to mask the appalling impotence of Europe, which fails, because of the antagonistic interests within it, to speak on an equal footing with its interlocutor and nevertheless a Russian partner.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Voted against the ratification of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement, with the exception of the treatment of third-country nationals legally employed as workers in the territory of the other Party, because in this context of internal conflict as well as the current weakness of the ceasefire, the appropriate conditions for such an agreement are not met , which could become an element that rekindled tensions between East and Kiev. Moreover, such ratification has been raised without the existence of a deep and democratic debate which would be appropriate for such a long-standing agreement.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. - I voted No because it is a long-awaited agreement that creates a European perspective for Ukraine. It is also the European Parliament's contribution to peacemaking in Ukraine. I add to this that within the ALDE group I have publicly advocated the need to lead European best practice in the protection of ethnic and linguistic values in Ukraine, as this is also a crucial element for stabilising the situation in Ukraine.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of the association agreement between the EU and Ukraine. This agreement is the first step towards deepening political and economic relations between the European Union and Ukraine and the first agreement of its kind, by its ambition. Given the events of the Maidan and the current context, the validation of this agreement was a no-brainer and an act of support for Ukraine. The Agreement was approved by a very large majority. I welcome this historic vote which took place in a duplex with the Ukrainian Parliament.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I am pleased that the European and Ukrainian Parliaments have jointly ratified the Association Agreement between the European Union and Ukraine, despite the European Union's decision to postpone the entry into force of its economic component. This Agreement, whose perspective is at the origin of the Maidan events, is in favour of closer political relations and trade between the European Union and Ukraine. This is a historic vote, which reminds us that the European Parliament has always defended the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Ukraine.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the EU-Ukraine association agreement. It is important that both parliaments gave their approval to exactly the same text that was prepared for the 2013 November Vilnius summit. Nothing was changed in it. I see it as a clear sign that both the EU and Ukraine are by now committed to join in the European space of role of law and reforms. However, there will be a disappointing delay in implementing the agreement which was decided unexpectedly only on 12 September. Having secured the role of a third partner, Russia can also have wide scope to interfere in bilateral EU-Ukraine relations, introducing its own terms. It also means Russia has a chance to continue destabilisation of Ukraine. On the other hand, those in Ukraine who are hesitant about starting radical structural reforms could see the delay as a suitable excuse to neglect their commitments, as happened after the Orange Revolution. However, I am glad that the European Parliament with an overwhelming majority demonstrated its commitment towards Ukraine and its European choice.

name: Jan Keller (S&D)
text: in writing. – Today, with my vote, I expressed my opposition to the conclusion of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement. In my opinion, the vote on this agreement should have taken place only after the October parliamentary elections in Ukraine. It is not possible to invoke the democratisational impact of this agreement if we do not know what political forces will prevail in these elections. In this respect, the European Parliament should not issue a blank cheque to any country.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. – I welcomed and supported the simultaneous ratification with the Ukrainian Parliament of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement. It opens up new possibilities for co-operation between the EU and Ukraine, and allows the EU to support Ukraine with its ambitious political and economic reform efforts. It also sends a clear signal of solidarity with the Ukrainian people and of support for its desire for a democratic and prosperous future, within a democratic country.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. - I support the implementation of the EU - Ukraine Association Agreement, first of a new generation of agreements with Eastern countries and aiming at the acceleration of the deepening of political and economic relations between Ukraine and the EU. I support the desire to strengthen and widen relations in an ambitious way.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of Mr Beazley's recommendation. Jacek Saryusz-Wolski. as the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement (AA) will be the driving force with which Europe aims to strengthen relations with Ukraine. But given today's complex and troubled situation, the ratification of the agreement defined last June takes on deeper meanings, also representing an important signal of democracy and support for the Ukrainian people. I hope that the Ukrainian Government will be able to start a serious reform process from tomorrow.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. - I voted against the free trade agreement with Ukraine because a decision of this magnitude cannot be taken either in haste, by an illegitimate assembly, or under external pressure. The decision to submit this free trade agreement to the Ukrainians was made without actually explaining the content of this agreement to its people, without consultation, without studies on its impact. It was endorsed on the Ukrainian side by the same assembly that passed the emergency laws against protesters in Maidan Square, with parliamentary elections scheduled for 26 October. For the Ukrainian economy, however, there was no urgency to sign this agreement, since Ukrainian products already benefit from present-day tariffs and this agreement will not be implemented until the end of 2015. By refusing to wait for the new parliamentary elections, the Ukrainian government has placed itself above the hard-paid Ukrainian people's sovereignty in Maidan Square. By this eagerness, he has re-entered the struggles of influence between his neighbors that have caused so much suffering to the Ukrainian nation. Ukraine must be able to choose its own path, under calm conditions, respecting the sovereignty of its people, and with neighbours who respect its own.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - I supported the ratification of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement because it is an important step towards ukraine's rapprochement with the European Union. This is the culmination of many months of turbulent events in Ukraine. My conviction was reinforced by President Poroshenko's statement that the Ukrainian government would draw up an economic development plan and that he would personally start the fight against corruption. I am aware of the complexity of the situation in Ukraine. Great diplomatic efforts are needed, including on the Russia-EU line. The act of ratification itself does not solve the problem.

name: Paloma López (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted outright against the EU-Ukraine partnership agreement because of the political implications of signing it for that country and the region. In fact, it was the signing of this partnership agreement that led to the coup d'etion in Ukraine, encouraged by the US and the EU itself against the legitimate president, Yanukovich.  In no way am I going to support an association agreement with an illegitimate government that emerged from a coup d'éerous, which also has fascist members in it. An association agreement, on the other hand, which is used by the EU as a weapon against Russia. The EU, rather than promoting its trade interests, should promote an immediate cessation of hostilities and a comprehensive peace agreement for Ukraine.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - Colleagues, Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. Ukraine is a geopolitical partner of the European Union. It is the second largest European country after Russia, with great wealth and an absorbent market. Until 25 years ago, most European countries knew nothing about Ukraine, and now almost all European media are turned to the region, underlining its strategic importance for the EU economy.  We also see how ukrainian civil society is growing in strength, how many changes have taken place in the last few years. We, as Europeans, should support the political transition of our neighbours, because only by being aware of their objectives are citizens able to change reality and, consequently, reform their country. I therefore voted in favour of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. - I voted in favour because Ukraine's move towards Europe and the Association Agreement between Ukraine and the EU are a good thing. The "Harmony" party in the Latvian Parliament in its time also voted in favour, because, despite recent events, it will also enable Ukraine to introduce European rules on several aspects, as well as to strengthen the true democracy in the Ukrainian state rather than fictitious democracy.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because the current regulation for relations between the European Union and Ukraine needed to be updated. This vote was on the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement (AA), which is the first of a new generation of Association Agreements with Eastern Partnership countries. The Association Agreement aims to accelerate the deepening of political and economic relations between Ukraine and the EU, which I welcome if there is popular support for this by the people of both countries.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) In line with this Parliament and with the Ukrainian Parliament, which voted in favour of the agreement at the same time, I consider today's vote to be a real page in the history of the European Union. The association agreement strengthens the political partnership and collaboration in the fields of energy, transport and education between the European Union and Kiev in a particularly delicate international context. With this vote, we intend to give Europe's full support to Ukraine's territorial integrity in the hope that the conflict with Russia will be resolved quickly and peacefully.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The war has returned to Europe, to the very borders of the European Union. Moreover, it is a war that is not only cruel, but also useless. Fratricidal war. I stress another aspect of the conflict. Just three weeks ago, the presidents of Russia and Ukraine, the leaders of the European Union and the Eurasian Economic Union met in Minsk. Direct negotiations have begun between kiev's new power and rebels in eastern Ukraine. The first agreements were born, which allow for the cessation of bloodshed, the exchange of prisoners, the reform of Ukraine's constitutional system.  Politicians in the 21st century should address even the most dramatic divisions in society and between them by acting, not by firing, not by anti-government coups. No physical violence. Moreover, the war in Ukraine is an example of a war that cannot solve anything. By killing people, can you eliminate Ukraine's ethnic divisions, eradicate the country's wild social divisions, stop the decline of the economy, or break up the church? War will only deepen these differences, no matter what happens. There can be no winner in a fratricidal war – everyone loses in it! We will probably not find agreement in assessing the very poor work of the Commissioners in the preparation of the Association Agreement, we will not agree on how great a danger to democracy the emergence of oligarchs poses, we probably have different views on the implementation of the association agreement. Let's not look for the culprits, let's look for a path to peace in Ukraine. For these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. - I have today rejected the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement because not only are foreign policy reasons against the introduction of the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area (DCFTA) with Ukraine, but there are also economic concerns. These include the fact that Russia and its customs union are currently the largest buyer of Ukrainian exports. However, Russia will impose an import duty of 7.8% on 98% of Ukrainian products in order to protect its own market from European products. This is estimated to result in a loss of €165 billion for Ukraine over the next ten years. In addition, Ukraine will have to make an enormous effort to ensure that its companies can become competitive on the European market and thus become competitive, since the DCFTA not only allows duty-free access to the internal market, but also requires compliance with European standards in this regard.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. - Parliament is asked here to approve the Council's ratification of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement. The EU extends its empire to its neighbours by including them in its free trade area. Combined with economic sanctions against Russia, Ukraine's main economic partner, this European annexation of the Ukrainian market will worsen the collapse of this economy, especially in the industrial east of the country. The first part of this agreement (political component) was signed in March 2014 at the beginning of the Ukrainian crisis and the second (economic) in June, which contributed to further destabilizing the region. This aggressive free trade is a factor of war. Moreover, the emergency procedure imposed in an authoritarian manner by Martin Schultz prevents a proper examination of the terms of this agreement. Linking the Ukrainian state to the fate of the EU and NATO goes against its entire history and against its interests and the sovereignty of its people. I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. - The signing of this agreement reflects a historic moment at a very important stage in Europe's life. Today, at the same time in the EP and the Ukrainian Parliament, and after the speeches of the two Presidents, this trade agreement between the EU and Ukraine was voted on and approved. It is good to note that against this agreement were only the GUE and the far-right neofascist. The signing of this agreement comes at a difficult time for Ukraine, which has already been deprived of part of its territory and is fighting pro-Russian separatists in the easternmost regions of its country.  The EU could not leave Ukraine to its fate, the widening of the conflict is a real risk, but what is at stake here is also the EU wanting peace and at the same time promoting it. A trade agreement cannot be a risk, nor can it be seen as a provocation. Ukraine as a sovereign country must be able to sign partnership agreements whenever and with whomever it wants. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this recommendation as it gives its consent to the establishment of a political and economic association agreement between the EU and Ukraine. More specifically on the trade aspect of this agreement (the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Agreement – DCFTA), this will provide for a mutual opening of the markets and the gradual approximisation to the EU norms. This agreement will also ensure that, through tariff liberalisation alone, Ukraine’s economy is expected to be boosted by around EUR 1.2 billion per year.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I am pleased that an association agreement has finally been signed between Ukraine and the European Union. Today we can only welcome this step, but this is only the first step in a long process aimed at Ukraine's political stability. We will give our full support to the reforms undertaken by the Ukrainian government in order to uphold European values.  The Ukrainian people have paid a heavy price. The political relay must take place. Civil society must be included in this process so that it is truly democratic. It is a matter of listening to Ukraine and its people so that such a crisis does not happen again.  Dialogue with Russia also remains crucial. Easing tensions with Moscow in a trilogue involving all parties involved is necessary if we are to go further in the process of political reconstruction.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. – I fully support the agreement because I strongly believe that it is an important step towards further economic and political integration between Ukraine and EU. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. - This agreement is a major step in the history of the European Union's external relations. I wanted to support him. The ratification gave rise to a unique and strong moment: the European Parliament and the Ukrainian Parliament proceeded to vote simultaneously and in video link. The agreement demonstrates a strong commitment and demonstrates Europe's willingness to assert itself on international issues. In substance, the text will contribute to the development of Ukraine through economic cooperation. Finally, this agreement creates the conditions for common prosperity.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted for the Association Agreement with Ukraine because I believe that the European Union must remain open to both the countries of the East and the Countries of the South. Ukraine and especially Ukrainian citizens, regardless of nationality or ethnicity, have the right to a European path, and I hope that, in this respect, Romania will always be a support in acquiring this ideal. I believe that the european Union's aim is to show the world that Europe can be an area of peace, economic development and democracy, and I call on all European states to follow this path, however difficult. With this association agreement, Ukraine has new development prospects that will certainly enable it to achieve its objectives and establish a peace relationship with its neighbours. The association with Ukraine brings into the common European space a number of values and traditions that have marked European history and are elements specific to European culture.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. – I today rejected the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement because not only are there strong foreign policy reasons against the introduction of the DCFTA [deep and comprehensive free trade agreement] with Ukraine, but there are also economic concerns. These include the fact that Russia and its customs union are currently the largest customers of Ukrainian exports. However, Russia will impose an import duty of 7.8% on 98% of Ukrainian products in order to protect its own market from the flood of European products. This is estimated to result in a loss of €165 billion for Ukraine over the next ten years. In addition, Ukraine will have to make an enormous financial effort to enable its companies to become competitive on the European market and thus to become competitive, since the DCFTA not only allows duty-free access to the internal market, but also requires compliance with European standards in this regard.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The prospect of signing an association agreement between Ukraine and the EU and its refusal by former President Yanukovych, combined with Russia's proposal to sign an agreement for the creation of the Eurasian Union, has triggered protests in Kiev resulting in civil war and extreme tension in relations between the West and Russia. These joint proposals by the European Union and Russia to Ukraine have led to the exacerbation of nationalist conflicts and the division of Ukraine into several warring camps. The signing of this agreement risks further plunging Ukraine into division.  The obligation for the European Union to present and sign this association agreement as soon as possible is the result of a catastrophic management of its own diplomatic and trade relations with both Ukraine and Russia. By my vote against, it was to signal my opposition to this European interference and over-bidding which resulted only in the splitting into two or three parts of a country.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. – The Association Agreement between the EU and Ukraine will definitely mark a turning point for Ukraine. Finally, the will of the people of Ukraine has been recognised. With our support, the European Parliament has given consent to an agreement which should have been signed already back in 2013, when the then President Yanukovych unilaterally changed the agenda for his country. I hope this agreement means the start of many reforms Ukraine will have to endeavour to bring about in the next years, but most importantly, that we share with Ukraine our fundamental values of democracy, human rights, peaceful co-existence, human dignity and the rule of law. Even though full implementation will take some time, until the ratification process is concluded and trade barriers are finally lifted, our commitment to the citizens of Ukraine stays untouched: the future for the people of Ukraine is European.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - As president of the delegation for cooperation with Ukraine, I supported the simultaneous ratification of the Association Agreement in the European Parliament and Verhovna Radi. The political symbolism of the Association Agreement is important to support the European path chosen by the Ukrainian people.  In its current respect, the agreement will serve as a guide for the Ukrainian Government in the area of legislative alignment with the acquis of the European Union and full economic reforms in a number of sectors. For the European Parliament, it is particularly important that from November the provisional application of the part of the agreement concerning the Parliamentary Association Committee, whose main objective will be to support ukrainian counterparts in upgrading and implementing reforms, starts. I expect the conditions for applying the free trade section to arrive soon.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: in writing. – I strongly supported the Agreement on the Association of the European Union and Ukraine. I consider this moment to be historical without any exaggeration. A hard-fought Ukraine decided to conclude an association agreement, clearly demonstrating its European identity. As a Czech, I understand well how important pro-Western orientation is to the peoples of our region. It was also an honour to support this document as an MEP by voting.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation on the Association Agreement between Ukraine and the European Union, because in view of the events, the European Union must demonstrate that it is a strong ally of Ukraine. There is an urgent need for effective cooperation between the European Union and Ukraine, especially since the pre-existing legal situation was a dead end. Thus, this agreement establishes a long-term course of action in order to curb Russia's expansionist policies and assert Ukraine's sovereignty. Only Russia's respect for this state of events would restore new cordial relations.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the report of my colleague Jacek Saryusz-Wolski which enabled the European Parliament to approve the Association Agreement between the European Union and its Member States on the one hand and Ukraine on the other.  Given the political and economic context of Ukraine, the approval of the agreement by the European Parliament is a strong signal sent by the European Union which continues to fulfil its neighbourhood policy and spread its values.  The approval of the agreement took place simultaneously and via videoconference between the Ukrainian Parliament and the European Parliament. The agreement will strengthen economic and political ties between the European Union and Ukraine.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Voted against the ratification of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement, with the exception of the treatment of third-country nationals legally employed as workers in the territory of the other Party, because in this context of internal conflict as well as the current weakness of the ceasefire, the appropriate conditions for such an agreement are not met , which could become an element that rekindled tensions between East and Kiev. Moreover, such ratification has been raised without the existence of a deep and democratic debate which would be appropriate for such a long-standing agreement.

name: Judith Sargentini (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. - We ultimately voted in favour of the Association Agreement with Ukraine. We want to support and help the Ukrainian people in the fight for true democracy, against war and violence or for the preservation of sovereignty. We support the sanctions. Russia because the leaders of that country are indeed behaving unsusedly. The peace talks must continue and deserve our support. However, we must dare to face up to the situation. We are being dragged into a geopolitical game that is heavily mediated by the simultaneous and perhaps hasty vote in the EP and the Ukrainian Parliament. Although this agreement is to be put to the vote today, it is already being said that it will not enter into force until 1 January 2016. Why the rush to approve them now? And are we not in danger of ending up in the situation of another 'frozen conflict' at the EU's borders? We are also particularly uncomfortable with the content of the 1200 pages that are on the ballot. How will these agreements affect our models of society? What is the real agenda behind this agreement? Are we putting Ukraine on the right track with this agreement or is it being used for a larger geopolitical conflict? Voting against now would be irresponsible, given Ukraine's desire and our desire to support Ukraine. But in the coming months, we will be holding our hearts as this conflict develops and whether it will allow us to go down the path of peace.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted outright against the EU-Ukraine partnership agreement because of the political implications of signing it for that country and the region. In fact, it was the signing of this partnership agreement that led to the coup d'etion in Ukraine, encouraged by the US and the EU itself against the legitimate president, Yanukovich.  In no way am I going to support an association agreement with an illegitimate government that emerged from a coup d'éerous, which also has fascist members in it. An association agreement, on the other hand, which is used by the EU as a weapon against Russia. The EU, rather than promoting its trade interests, should promote an immediate cessation of hostilities and a comprehensive peace agreement for Ukraine.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. – I welcome today’s vote on the ratification of the EU-Ukraine association agreement. This vote is a clear sign of solidarity with the Ukrainian people and of support for their desire for a democratic and prosperous future, within a democratic state.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. - I voted in favour of the association agreement with Ukraine for a number of reasons. Ukraine consists geographically of two parts, which are divided by the River Dneper. Historically, the left side of the river was called the "left bank" and the right side of the "right bank". One part has always drawn more to Russia and the other to Europe. This was also evident in 2004 during the famous Orange Revolution. Statistics show that 78% of ukraine's population is considered ethnic Ukrainians, and up to 17% proudly report to the Russians. At the end of 2004, Ukrainians experienced their Orange Revolution. Ukrainians have experienced totalitarianism, corrupt politicians and oligarchs alike. I see the Association Agreement as a start, but ukraine's move in the right direction. Nevertheless, the country has a long way to go, at the end of which there is to be a free referendum. I believe that Ukrainians have the right to decide freely where they want to belong. I emphasize that freely. No pressure, no war. Ukraine is not a cake to cut, it is our partner. I am pleased that we have sealed the signing of the Association Agreement today. In addition to the political partnership, its main contribution is the pursuit of freedom of expression, visa-free travel, an atmosphere of democracy and mutual free access to the market. I ask people to pray for this country tested by a bloody conflict.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. - The European Union's accession treaty with Ukraine is indeed a major and significant step in mutual relations and represents a historic moment for the whole of Europe. Taking into account previous enlargements and especially the rich experience of the Republic of Croatia in lengthy and difficult membership negotiations, I would like to point out that the European Union must also lead a coherent policy in this process and insist on fulfilling and reaching all the highest European values. Ukraine's political accession to the European Union and economic integration must depend on progress in the implementation of this Agreement and on Ukraine's track record of ensuring respect for common values. Ukraine must implement the political, socio-economic, legal and institutional reforms necessary for the effective implementation of all these Agreed Objectives Agreement. As this Agreement particularly emphasises cooperation in the fields of environmental protection, energy security and commitment to sustainable development that stands at the heart of European values, I support its ratification, as I deeply believe that cooperation in these areas is crucial for the prosperity of all our citizens. I would also like to stress that by implementing the objectives of this Agreement, the European Union must continuously take into account Russia's positions so that a prosperous future for citizens is secured on both sides of the borders.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing - We approve the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement at a time when Ukraine is divided and divided by war. Innocent mothers and children are suffering and dying, starving entire regions of south-eastern Ukraine. I believe that the signing of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement last November only helped to do so. The diplomacy of eu leaders failed in the negotiations because political issues were at the forefront and eyes were turning on the country's economic, national and human rights problems. Today, when approving the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement, I expressed my agreement with a positive vote because, as an MEP living in the east of Slovakia, I believe that Ukraine belongs to a common Europe. There are new challenges ahead for Ukraine, the road to the EU will not be short or easy, but I believe that the conflict will stop and intensive negotiations will begin to maintain peace and save Ukraine's economic collapse so that they can fulfil the terms of the association agreement.

name: Barbara Spinelli (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted against this Association Agreement because I believe that any agreement with the Ukrainian Government needs a much more in-depth debate than is happening. Our Parliament has given itself too little time to deal with issues that are inescapable, in the midst of civil war.  These are the points that I believe should be clarified before any agreement, in the present situation of war and international tension: • The States of the Union cannot at the same time provoke Russia, having consequently included Ukraine in NATO.  • To the Government of Kiev, which half of ukrainians consider illegitimate, the Union should call for the immediate dissolution of far-right or neo-Nazi militias such as the Azov Battalion, which is now under the Interior Ministry in Kiev. • Russian populations in eastern and southern Ukraine must be protected, otherwise we give Vladimir Putin every reason for armed intervention. As a matter of principle, the edict outlawing the Ukrainian Communist Party must also be revoked.  • We should seriously discuss sanctions against Russia. In fact, a non-political

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. – I am voting against the agreement because the European Union must sever all relations with Ukraine and turn to the Russian market. Furthermore, I do not want Ukraine to implement nuclear programmes.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. - I voted in favour of the Association Agreement with Ukraine. I want to support and help Ukraine in the fight for true democracy, against war and violence and for the preservation of sovereignty. I support the sanctions because the Russian leadership is behaving in a disused manner. Peace talks must continue. We are being dragged into a geopolitical game that is heavily mediated by the simultaneous and hasty vote in the EP and the Ukrainian Parliament. Although this agreement is up for the vote today, it may not enter into force until early 2016. Why the rush to approve them now? Are we not in danger of creating another 'frozen conflict' at the EU's borders? And what to say about the content of the 1200 pages on the ballot? How will they affect our models of society? What's the real agenda? Are we putting Ukraine on the right track with this agreement or is it being used for a larger geopolitical conflict? Voting against now is irresponsible, given Ukraine's desire and our desire to support Ukraine. In the coming months, we will be holding our hearts as to how this conflict develops and whether we are on the path of peace.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - I support the European Parliament's resolution on the conclusion of the Association Agreement between the European Union and Ukraine and see this as a correct and necessary step to assist Ukraine in the current difficult situation. The Association Agreement comes as the continuation of ever-better EU-Ukraine relations and replaces the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, which has so far been in force. The resolution clearly supports Ukraine's European path and its approach to the EU internal market. The resolution sends a strong signal of support for Ukraine's territorial integrity and its growing role in the security of the whole of Europe. Ukraine has shown its will to move closer to modern Europe so far, and the task of all of us is to enable it to make the transition to a modern European society as easy and successful as possible, as it deserves. This resolution is a step in that direction. The association agreement envisions a number of measures that will strengthen human rights and democratic principles. The difficult current situation of Ukraine is well known to us from the near Croatian past, when all external assistance was welcome to us, so it is necessary to provide assistance in the best possible way. We are sending a message of responsibility, the trade part of the agreement should enter into force as soon as possible, and I fully support President Poroshenko's peace plan.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: in writing. – Today's vote must be a clear response to the current situation in Ukraine, whose citizens are already exposed to the consequences of blackmail through Russian gas. Ukrainian schools have introduced a 6-day working week in the premonition of the impossibility of sesuring teaching in the winter months, and Ukrainian households are already without hot water. The European Union must now offer a clear perspective for future cooperation, thus contributing to the european union's perceived people of Ukrainian cities and municipalities as a responsible partner who is ready to respond adequately and thus contribute to addressing the current situation. I believe that the conclusion of an association agreement between the European Union and Ukraine is an absolutely necessary and positive step that will expand the possibilities for supporting Ukraine in the long term.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community and their Member States, on the one hand, and Ukraine, on the other, to the exclusion of the provisions relating to the treatment of third-country nationals legally employed on the territory of the other party. We therefore ask that these provisions come into force immediately.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: Writing. - The Ukraine-EU Association Agreement is the first constructive step taken by the European Union since the crisis in Ukraine began.  Ukraine is on the brink of a humanitarian catastrophe and urgently needs help. By signing the Treaty, Europe will make certain moral and political commitments tomorrow, and thereby give the Ukrainian people hope for an improvement. However, it is now more of a political decision, because the association, as such, will not be talked about until a short time later.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I am very happy to have voted in favour of this Association Agreement and I am sure the Parliament will speak with a very strong majority in favour of it. This is an historic moment. The European Parliament has always defended the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Ukraine and will continue to do so through this vote. Through this ratification, Ukraine’s European choice will be institutionalised and will bind the futures of the EU and Ukraine together. Ukrainian society has paid the highest price for its European aspirations, grieving for the deaths of numerous people, suffering territorial occupation by Russia and experiencing deteriorating economic conditions. With this ratification, the EU gives Ukraine the strongest sign of support.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted outright against the EU-Ukraine partnership agreement because of the political implications of signing it for that country and the region. In fact, it was the signing of this partnership agreement that led to the coup d'etion in Ukraine, encouraged by the US and the EU itself against the legitimate president, Yanukovich.  In no way am I going to support an association agreement with an illegitimate government that emerged from a coup d'éerous, which also has fascist members in it. An association agreement, on the other hand, which is used by the EU as a weapon against Russia. The EU, rather than promoting its trade interests, should promote an immediate cessation of hostilities and a comprehensive peace agreement for Ukraine.

name: Johannes Cornelis van Baalen (ALDE)
