text: Written. - Hans van Baalen (ALDE-VVD) supports the Association Agreement between the European Union and Ukraine. In connection with the opening of the parliamentary year in the Netherlands (Throne Speech), he was not able to attend the final vote on the Association Agreement in Strasbourg.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. - The European Parliament has adopted the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement as a major emergency. This agreement is based solely on free trade and will weigh heavily on the Already struggling Ukrainian economy.  The President of the European Parliament, Martin Schulz, makes this subject a direct communication operation with Mr Pietro Poroshenko and the Ukrainian Parliament, making the Ukrainian President a champion of pacifism and the fight against corruption, forgetting in passing that two representatives of the extreme right sit in his government. It's like going back to the Cold War: with the Russian villains on one side and the nice Ukrainians on the other.  The situation in Ukraine is dramatic. No one should put oil on the fire. It is a very sad sight that has been given to the European Parliament. The gue/NGL parliamentarians voted against the agreement and continue to call for a real political dialogue that emphasizes the interests of the people and not the will to dominate one another.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The AA is a bad deal for workers from Ukraine and EU countries. By removing customs barriers and subjecting economies, groups and businesses with different capacities to so-called free competition will translate, as painfully we know, into ruin for SMEs and unemployment for thousands of workers. We propose trade agreements not based on the elimination of tariffs and the imposition of neoliberal reforms. Rather, we propose social and environmental criteria and solutions that lead to mutual advantages, with respect for the sovereignty of each country.

name: Hermann Winkler (PPE)
text: Writing. - I abstained from the vote because I have the impression that, at this stage, this decision does not contribute to the resolution of the conflict between Ukraine and Russia, but exacerbates it. Ukraine is deeply divided and, in this difficult situation, we should refrain from doing anything to reinforce this and to give the impression of pulling Ukraine on one side. The much-needed peace process can only succeed with the involvement of Russia. Simultaneous coordination between the EP, the Ukrainian Rada and the Russian Parliament would be ideal for this.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This recommendation is another chapter in the process of interference by the majority of the European Parliament in the unstable situation in Ukraine. Once again, they try to have extreme relations, not taking responsibility in the situation of near-civil war so that they push a country with the support and active participation of the US and NATO.  The question here is NATO's objective of expanding to the border of the Russian Federation at any cost, based on the geopolitical use of a sovereign country to secure the political, economic and military dominance of a region. This resolution ignores it and is another step towards the brutal and open interference of the US and the EU in Ukraine's internal situation, which promotes destabilization by actively supporting fascist and neo-Nazi political and paramilitary forces, inciting the exacerbation of dangerous tensions in this country. This agreement aims at full harmonisation of Ukrainian laws to EU rules and rules, sweeps all areas of Ukrainian society, with a clear prejudice to the Ukrainian people, without being called upon to comment. An agreement with consequences deeply harmful to the interests of workers and the Ukrainian people, national interests and sovereignty of Ukraine, signed by a government without democratic legitimacy.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I voted in favour of this report because I think it is a small step for the European Union and Ukraine, but a big step for all of us, a big step for peace and stability in Ukraine.  I know what we experienced as Czechs after the adoption of a similar agreement, and I also remember the sceptical debate within the so-called old States of the European Union, which said that it would threaten security, stability, it would have negative connotations for us, the newly arrived countries of the European Union. No negatives have materialized, ladies and gentlemen. I therefore believe that, even in the case of Ukraine, it will not come to life and that, indeed, this agreement will lead to the prosperity of the European Union and to the prosperity of Ukraine.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE). -
text: Mr President, at a time when Mr Putin is probing our weakness and trying to redraw the borders of Europe with military force, at a time when the people of Ukraine are subject to an invasion with military force, I think it is very important that this Parliament has united with a strong majority to show our support. I have voted in favour of the Association Agreement with Ukraine wholeheartedly. It is very important economically, but it is also an important political signal that we do not accept this way of acting in Europe. Their problem, their fight for freedom, for sovereignty, for territorial integrity, is our common European fight. I do regret that both the left and extreme right have turned their back by voting against this agreement in a large majority . I think it is unacceptable; it goes against the European values we all stand for.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted outright against the EU-Ukraine partnership agreement because of the political implications of signing it for that country and the region. In fact, it was the signing of this partnership agreement that led to the coup d'etion in Ukraine, encouraged by the US and the EU itself against the legitimate president, Yanukovich.  In no way am I going to support an association agreement with an illegitimate government that emerged from a coup d'éerous, which also has fascist members in it. An association agreement, on the other hand, which is used by the EU as a weapon against Russia. The EU, instead of promoting its trade interests, should promote an immediate cessation of hostilities and a comprehensive peace agreement for Ukraine.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. - It is essential at present, in view of the events we all know, to develop increased political and economic cooperation with Ukraine. This association agreement, which will bring the European Union and Ukraine closer together, goes in this direction and should help to stabilise the democratic transition, in particular by promoting the socio-economic development of the country and the strengthening of its institutions.  The European Union is thus acting as an important step in promoting the necessary regional geo-political stability.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. Any attempt at association in view of the current situation can only increase tensions and this part of the agreement is at the base already distorted since 3 European countries will not participate and will not be subject to it. These are the United Kingdom, Ireland and Denmark.  Other countries, including France, will have to comply with this provision, which is in fact aimed at easing the issuance of visas and gradually and in a timely manner introducing a visa-free regime (particularly with regard to the mobility of workers), i.e. increasing the immigration of Ukrainians to the Member States of the European Union. That is why I also objected to this provision of the agreement.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted against the report by Mr Beazley. Mr Moraes, since it forms part of the general association agreement between the EU and Ukraine, and I believe that, at the moment, it is giving the pulse of a europe that is soothing Russia, is putting our entrepreneurs affected by the Russian embargo in crisis.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Although I in substance support the non-discrimination principle in the context of employment, I have voted against this report in order to voice my rejection of the undemocratic way this file was brought forward – without any substantial or public debate in committee or plenary. An agreement which was at the very root of the escalation of the current EU-Ukraine-Russia conflict should not be rushed through Parliament without any proper political scrutiny. Pushing through an association agreement at this time only serves to escalate the conflict in an increasingly fragile situation. Europe’s citizens are already paying the price for this conflict, and this would only see it intensify. For the sake of our farmers and others who are paying the price for the deepening conflict between Russia and Ukraine, we cannot vote for this association agreement’s progression in any form.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) This measure is complementary to the other agreement. They have the basic spirit in common, and so I also voted in favour of this agreement. However, it was appropriate to deal with this matter in a different legal forum because of the implications that this may have on internal security and social issues.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted in favour of the EU-Ukraine agreement on the part on workers' rights (Moraes report). The agreement states that there must be no discrimination against workers from third countries. It's important. However, I would like to underline my criticism of the urgency procedure used, in which the European Parliament quickly votes through the agreement without being able to deal with or discuss it. It is not responsible to represent the citizens in this way. The agreement must also be approved by the Ukrainian Parliament with a quick procedure just weeks before national elections are held in Ukraine. The whole procedure therefore has a lightning character over it that does not take the democratic process seriously. The agreement could have been improved if both the European Parliament and Ukrainian MEPs had been allowed to deal with it as usual.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. - I voted in favour of this recommendation on the free movement of workers from Ukraine. This notice lays down specific rules concerning equal treatment of third-country nationals legally working in the territory of the other Party to the agreement.  The Association Agreement between the European Union and Ukraine is the first of a new generation of association agreements signed with the Eastern Partnership countries. The Association Agreement aims to accelerate the development of political and economic relations between Ukraine and the EU.  In view of the historical relations between the European Union and Ukraine and the ever closer ties, as well as the current political situation in the European neighbourhood, the European Parliament supports the conclusion of the agreement and the wish to strengthen and expand relations decisively and innovatively with this Association Agreement.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Although I in substance support the non-discrimination principle in the context of employment, I have voted against this report in order to voice my rejection of the undemocratic way this file was brought forward – without any substantial or public debate in committee or plenary. An agreement which was at the very root of the escalation of the current EU-Ukraine-Russia conflict should not be rushed through Parliament without any proper political scrutiny. Pushing through an association agreement at this time only serves to escalate the conflict in an increasingly fragile situation. Europe’s citizens are already paying the price for this conflict, and this would only see it intensify. For the sake of our farmers and others who are paying the price for the deepening conflict between Russia and Ukraine, we cannot vote for this association agreement’s progression in any form.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. - I voted against the agreement. Ukraine is pursuing the wrong foreign policy towards Russia, provocation and bombing of civilian populations.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - (IT) Today I voted in favour of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement, which includes a comprehensive and in-depth free trade area (DCFTA).  Bearing in mind the important historical relations between the European Union and Ukraine and the current political situation in the European neighbourhood, I am convinced that this axis is strategic and makes it possible to strengthen the european Union's international positioning.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - I support the Agreement between the European Union and Ukraine because I believe that we have a responsibility to support peoples who fight for freedom and democracy and who want to strengthen their ties with the European Union.  Negotiation of this agreement began in 2007 and was concluded in 2012. Russian pressure and the withdrawal of the deposed Ukrainian government led to two more years being lost. I also believe that this agreement can be a model for negotiations with other Eastern Partnership countries. I hope that the EU will be firm in its implementation and will not give in to moscow's blackmail, which in practice seeks to reduce these agreements with the states that Russia considers to be in its strategic orbit to an futility.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of this agreement ratified today at the same time by the European Parliament and the Ukrainian Parliament. Of particular importance are the rules establishing greater movement of workers, a visa-free regime and the time schedule for transposing European legislation into Ukrainian domestic law. This support from the Eu ropean Union must now be the lever through which Ukraine must commit itself to improving its internal democracy, bringing it ever closer to that of Europe and its Member States.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – Voting in favour of the EU-Ukraine association agreement as regards the treatment of third-country nationals legally employed as workers in the territory of the other party is another way of supporting the Ukrainian European choice.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. - The EU-Ukraine Association Agreement is the first in a new generation of association agreements with Eastern Partnership countries. The deepening of political and economic relations between Ukraine and the European Union must be speeded up. It must be the EU's task to strengthen and extend relations in an ambitious and innovative way. It is essential that Ukrainian workers legally employed in the territory of a Member State must be subject to the laws, conditions and procedures applicable in each Member State, and the European Union must not be subjected to any discriminatory treatment. I can therefore only vote in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted outright against the EU-Ukraine partnership agreement because of the political implications of signing it for that country and the region. In fact, it was the signing of this partnership agreement that led to the coup d'etion in Ukraine, encouraged by the US and the EU itself against the legitimate president, Yanukovich.  In no way am I going to support an association agreement with an illegitimate government that emerged from a coup d'éerous, which also has fascist members in it. An association agreement, on the other hand, which is used by the EU as a weapon against Russia. The EU, instead of promoting its trade interests, should promote an immediate cessation of hostilities and a comprehensive peace agreement for Ukraine.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution, as it is a continuation of the primary vote on the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement. I believe that within the context of the current political situation within a European neighbourhood we must strengthen relations with Ukraine and widen our relations with the country. Additionally, the Association Agreement seeks to protect third-country nationals legally employed in the territory of another party, thus abiding with the European Charter of Fundamental Rights (Article 15.3).

name: Georgios Epitideios (NI)
text: Writing. - I voted against the part of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement which refers to the treatment of third-country nationals legally employed as workers in the territory of the other Party because, in my opinion, the possibility of third-country nationals moving freely to EU countries would contribute to the loss of jobs by nationals of European countries. The already very high unemployment rate in countries, especially the European South, combined with this development, will have a direct and significant impact on the economies of the EU Member States and especially on the Greek economy, taking into account that the unemployment rate in my country is in the order of 30%, and youth unemployment is 60%.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. - Ukrainian citizens have paid a very high price for their European ambitions. They have suffered a historic death toll, they have seen their territory occupied and their economy is devastated. However, they are always committed to European values, fighting to the end to defend them. Ukraine is a neighbouring state of the European Union with which we have established important relations for our economy. The European Union must respond to external pressures to ensure not only its territorial integrity, but also that of the neighbouring states with which it cooperates. The EU-Ukraine agreement is another step towards the protection of European interests. For the reasons set out above, I voted in favour. I hope that this agreement will help to promote peace and create conditions conducive to closer economic and trade relations, leading to the gradual integration of Ukraine into the EU internal market.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This report refers to the long-awaited and long-promoted EU-Ukraine Association Agreement (AA). Remember that the refusal of his signature by the former President of Ukraine at the Vilnius Summit led to repayable acts of interference by the US, NATO and the EU (including many Members of this Parliament), which led to the coup d'état that deposed him and the seizure of power by nationalist forces, of a supposed neo-Nazi and fascist nature, whose action led to the intensification of the deep national and class divisions that already existed , leading to aggression on those in the east of the country resisted the authoritarianism of illegitimate power.  The AA is a poisoned gift for workers from Ukraine and EU countries. Removing much of the customs barriers, subjecting economies, groups and companies with different capacities to said free competition, will cause workers to be further pressured to lower wages and social rights, and will lead to the disappearance of thousands of SMEs and small and medium-sized farmers, further aggravating the serious economic and social situation experienced by the Ukrainian people. Facilitating or liberalising visas is actually a way to further weaken labor relations, subjecting workers to even greater arbitrariness of companies. We voted against it.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. - I abstained on the grounds that I consider the accelerated procedure for the association agreement with Ukraine to be unjustified and not reflecting the current internal political situation in the country.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. - The association agreement between the EU and Ukraine confirms the EU's unholy foreign policy choices. This agreement will fuel tensions and hostilities with Russia regardless of the real needs of the Ukrainian people and European citizens.  Article 10 of the Directive is applicable to the Article 17 of this Agreement cannot therefore be dissociated from the political assessment of the Agreement in its entirety.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. – I am voting against the European Union's association agreement with Ukraine: as long as the issue of legal and illegal immigrants is not clarified in the EU, we cannot talk about legal workers from third countries.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: in writing. – I supported the resolution as I strongly believe that today’s ratification is a milestone in EU-Ukraine relations, an important and symbolic step showing the commitment of both sides to a successful implementation. Russia aims to undermine and eventually stop this Agreement coming into force. Any delay in the provisional implementation of the EU-Ukraine DCFTA could put a fully-fledged EU-Ukraine Association Agreement at risk. The coming months should be used by the Ukrainian authorities to tackle the necessary modernisation and transformation reforms with a view to advancing the AA agenda. This should be done in parallel with efforts made to sustain the territorial integrity and unity of Ukraine.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - It has been voted in favour of this Report on the treatment of third-country nationals legally employed as workers on the territory of the other Party, because it refers exclusively to the treatment of workers who are nationals of Ukraine and are legally employed on the territory of an EU Member State shall not be discriminated against on the basis of their nationality as regards working conditions , remuneration or dismissal, in respect of nationals of that Member State.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. On Tuesday 16 September, the European Parliament approved the ratification of the Association Agreement, which includes a comprehensive and comprehensive free trade agreement between the European Union and Ukraine. I welcome the vote on this agreement, which is the first agreement based on a political association between Europe and a country of the Eastern Partnership.  It is unprecedented in terms of scale in terms of the number of areas covered and the depth of the accuracy of commitments and deadlines. Its key components include governance and sectoral cooperation in areas such as energy, transport and environmental protection, industrial cooperation, social development and social protection.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - Today, the European Parliament has given the green light to ukraine's Association Agreement to the European Union by a large majority in favour. This is an historic moment because for the first time a simultaneous vote was held in two parliaments, the Ukrainian and the European, for the ratification of an agreement. This agreement will be the first in a new generation of association agreements with Eastern Partnership countries that will allow the deepening of political and economic relations between Ukraine and the European Union.

name: Paloma López (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted outright against the EU-Ukraine partnership agreement because of the political implications of signing it for that country and the region. In fact, it was the signing of this partnership agreement that led to the coup d'etion in Ukraine, encouraged by the US and the EU itself against the legitimate president, Yanukovich.  In no way am I going to support an association agreement with an illegitimate government that emerged from a coup d'éerous, which also has fascist members in it. An association agreement, on the other hand, which is used by the EU as a weapon against Russia. The EU, instead of promoting its trade interests, should promote an immediate cessation of hostilities and a comprehensive peace agreement for Ukraine.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Although I in principle support the non-discrimination principle in the context of employment, I have voted against this report in order to voice my rejection of the undemocratic way this file was brought forward – without any substantial or public debate in committee or plenary. An agreement which was at the very root of the escalation of the current EU-Ukraine-Russia conflict should not be rushed through Parliament without any proper political scrutiny.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. - On Tuesday 16 September, the Ukrainian parliament made the decisive choice to ratify, unanimously, the association agreement with the European Union. At the same time, the European Parliament also ratified the agreement, marking a rapprochement with the Kiev authorities. While the trade component is completely removed from the agreement, its chapter on justice, immigration and security has been set up by negotiators who are certainly in a hurry to give pledges of goodwill to the Ukrainian side despite the crisis of distrust in Europe. The article on the treatment of workers stipulates that Ukrainian nationals working legally on EU territory and Europeans employed in Ukraine should not be discriminated against in relation to nationals of the host country in terms of pay and working conditions.  While this provision seems reasonable to me, I would like to point out that any measure relating to visa liberalisation can only be considered as a hypothesis, and that the examination of the conditions and modalities still needs to be deepened in the light of the humanitarian emergency but also of the capabilities, needs and security imperative of the Member States.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - It has been voted in favour of this Report on the treatment of third-country nationals legally employed as workers on the territory of the other Party, because it refers exclusively to the treatment of workers who are nationals of Ukraine and are legally employed on the territory of an EU Member State shall not be discriminated against on the basis of their nationality as regards working conditions , remuneration or dismissal, in respect of nationals of that Member State.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. - I voted Yes because it is a long-awaited agreement that creates a European perspective for Ukraine in addressing the issue of third-country nationals given the current political situation in the European neighbourhood and the desire to strengthen ties between Ukraine and the European Union.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of the association agreement between the EU and Ukraine with regard to the treatment of nationals employed legally in Ukraine and the EU. The agreement stipulates that Ukrainian nationals legally employed on EU territory and EU nationals legally employed on Ukrainian territory must not be discriminated against on the basis of their nationality in relation to working conditions, remuneration and redundancy procedures. The agreement was adopted by a very large majority, which I welcome.

name: Rina Ronja Kari (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. - Although I support the substance of the principle of non-discrimination in relation to the labour market, I have voted against this recommendation in protest at the undemocratic process surrounding the agreement – without any substantive debate either in the committees or in plenary. A 2 000-page agreement cannot be properly dealt with through an emergency procedure. An agreement linked to the very root of the ongoing EU-Ukraine-Russia conflict should not be rushed through without proper political debate and consideration.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. - I voted in favour because, in fact, this decision is directly linked to the joint ratification of the Association Agreement. The 'Harmony' party also always supported Ukraine's rapproportion with the EU, maintaining good relations with all its neighbours.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the report by my colleague, Mr De Clercq, on be it. Mr Moraes, because I believe that it is the result of a further civilised development of relations between the European Union and its neighbour Ukraine.  The document, which complements the content of the agreement aimed at establishing a deep political and economic association between the two countries, conveys, as well as a clear political significance, a message of openness, of extremely symbolic value.  I find that the dossier, which follows the Council's call for the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement to be divided into two decisions ( one of which regulated precisely the treatment of European and Ukrainian citizens legally employed as employees in the territory of the other party) is characterised by absolute historical consistency.  It is, in fact, a new point of reference for legislation between the parties, at a time when the links between the European Union and Ukraine are becoming ever closer.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE)
text: in writing. - The vote today simultaneously by both the European and Ukrainian Parliaments is an extremely important signal for Russia. Europe is stronger and demonstrates to the Russian Federation that the prosperity of citizens is achieved through cooperation and peace, not by aggression and conflict. The agreement has already been ratified by six of the 28 Member States. This process needs to be completed everywhere as soon as possible to block the rise of Russia, which still poses a permanent and imminent danger to all EU countries. The European Parliament has basically initialled today the guarantee that Ukraine will join the EU as soon as possible and has encouraged it to continue the European path it has chosen and for which many have unfortunately paid with their lives. I am convinced that Ukraine will appreciate Europe's solidarity and make every effort to reform itself where it is needed.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. - Parliament is asked here to approve the aspects relating to the "treatment of third-country nationals legally employed in the territory of the other party" included in the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement.  I am, of course, committed to equal treatment of workers.  But I am firmly opposed to this agreement which annexes Ukraine to the European liberal yoke. I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. - The signing of this agreement reflects a historic moment at a very important stage in Europe's life. Today, simultaneously in the EP. and in the Ukrainian Parliament, and after the speeches of the two Presidents, this trade agreement between the EU and Ukraine was voted on and approved. It is good to note that against this agreement were only the GUE and the far-right neofascist. The signing of this agreement comes at a difficult time for Ukraine, which has already been deprived of part of its territory and is fighting pro-Russian separatists in the easternmost regions of its country.  The EU could not leave Ukraine to its fate, the widening of the conflict is a real risk, but what is at stake here is also the EU wanting peace and at the same time promoting it. A trade agreement cannot be a risk, nor can it be seen as a provocation. Ukraine, as a sovereign country, must be able to sign partnership agreements whenever and with whomever it wants. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. – This recommendation concerns specifically Article 17 of the EU-Ukraine association agreement. This Article contains specific obligations relating to the treatment of third-country nationals legally employed as workers in the territory of the other party. I have voted in favour of this recommendation as it strengthens and widens the relations between the EU and Ukraine, drawing the latter closer to Europe while also further strengthening the close historical relationship and progressively closer links between the EU and Ukraine.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The current situation in eastern Ukraine is crucial for the future of the European Union. If the EU is to weigh in on the world stage, it must send a strong message that it cannot tolerate Russian acts of aggression going unpunished. We cannot remain silent in the face of violations of international law. The signing of the Association Agreement is a positive signal sent to the Ukrainian authorities and people. Positive steps remain to be taken to promote stability and peace in the region.  But it is time for the EU to speak with one voice! The lack of cohesion among European decision-makers on the Russian aggression weakens the determination of the Union. I regret that Russian reluctance has had an influence on the immediate implementation of the treaty, particularly with regard to trade. I regret that we have not been able, given the importance of the situation, to agree on a faster implementation of the agreement.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. – Taking into account the close relationship and closer links between the European Union and Ukraine and the current political situation within the European neighbourhood, I fully support this report which will strengthen and widen relations with the Association Agreement between EU and Ukraine

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. - These provisions concern one particular point of the negotiations concluded with Ukraine: the treatment of nationals. This article does not open up a new law for Ukrainians in Europe or for Europeans in Ukraine. It provides that nationals legally employed under each national law do not suffer discrimination because of their nationality. I have therefore supported this point, which is part of the overall agreement.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. - We voted for the conclusion of the Association Agreement between the EU and Ukraine and we welcome the simultaneous ratification of the agreement by the European Parliament and the Ukrainian Parliament in Kiev. In view of the close historical relations between the EU and Ukraine, as well as the current political situation, we support the desire to strengthen and expand relations in an ambitious and innovative way through this Association Agreement. The main purpose of the agreement is to accelerate political and economic relations between Ukraine and the EU, as well as Ukraine's gradual access to parts of the EU's internal market, including through the creation of a deep and comprehensive free trade area. The overall objectives of the association are to promote a gradual rapprochement between the two parties on the basis of common values; in intensifying political dialogue; promoting, maintaining and strengthening peace and stability at both regional and international level; in creating the conditions for improving economic and trade relations, the ultimate objective being Ukraine's gradual access to parts of the EU's internal market. The agreement will be provisionally applied, but the date will be confirmed by the Council. In order to enter into full force, the agreement must be ratified by the 28 Member States.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The JRC is voting against the EU-Ukraine Association and Free Trade Agreement, which is promoted economically, politically as well as with arms, because it serves the penetration of EU monopolies into new markets, their association with parts of the Ukrainian plutocracy whose interests are best served by their association with the EU. The Agreement imposes heavy commitments to promote capitalist restructurings that further bring the Ukrainian people to their knees, intensifying the exploitation of workers, while reforms in Ukraine's urban political system ensure the uninterrupted profitability and dominance of monopolistic groups. The celebrations of the EU, its allies, THE US-NATO and the reactionary Ukrainian government for the adoption of the association agreement cannot hide the fact that it will make the already dramatic situation of the Ukrainian people even worse. In contrast to the carnage, poverty and oppression experienced today, in the years of socialist construction the Ukrainian and the other peoples of the Soviet Union lived alone in peace and prosperity. This demonstrates the incomparable primacy of socialism, shows that the interests of the peoples are at odds with the imperialist associations of capital, in conflict with the capitalist path of development and the power of monopolies.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. – The Association Agreement between the EU and Ukraine will definitely mark a turning point for Ukraine. Finally, the will of the people of Ukraine has been recognised. With our support, the European Parliament has given consent to an agreement which should have been signed already back in 2013, when the then President Yanukovych unilaterally changed the agenda for his country. I hope this agreement means the start of many reforms Ukraine will have to endeavour to bring about in the next years, but most importantly, that we share with Ukraine our fundamental values of democracy, human rights, peaceful co-existence, human dignity and the rule of law. Even though full implementation will take some time, until the ratification process is concluded and trade barriers are definitely lifted, our commitment to the citizens of Ukraine stays untouched: the future for the people of Ukraine is European.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation on the Association Agreement on the workers' regime in relations between the European Union and Ukraine because it is the essential part of the proper implementation of the Association Agreement as a whole. I consider that the mobility of workers is a prerequisite for any association agreement, of which a clear enforcement structure must be defined, in order to establish optimal commercial relations and avoid abuse.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. - (IT) I have chosen to vote against because the article in question is part of the general association agreement between the EU and Ukraine to which I am against.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - It has been voted in favour of this Report on the treatment of third-country nationals legally employed as workers on the territory of the other Party, because it refers exclusively to the treatment of workers who are nationals of Ukraine and are legally employed on the territory of an EU Member State shall not be discriminated against on the basis of their nationality as regards working conditions , remuneration or dismissal, in respect of nationals of that Member State.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted outright against the EU-Ukraine partnership agreement because of the political implications of signing it for that country and the region. In fact, it was the signing of this partnership agreement that led to the coup d'etion in Ukraine, encouraged by the US and the EU itself against the legitimate president, Yanukovich.  In no way am I going to support an association agreement with an illegitimate government that emerged from a coup d'éerous, which also has fascist members in it. An association agreement, on the other hand, which is used by the EU as a weapon against Russia. The EU, instead of promoting its trade interests, should promote an immediate cessation of hostilities and a comprehensive peace agreement for Ukraine.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. – Today I voted in favour of the EU/Euratom/Ukraine Association Agreement: treatment of third country nationals legally employed as workers in the territory of the other party. I welcome the decision of the European Parliament to give its consent to this important agreement which opens up new possibilities for co-operation between the EU and Ukraine. This is the first of a new generation of association agreements with Eastern Partnership countries. Such agreements allow the EU to support Ukraine in its ambitious political and economic reforms.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. - The European Union Association Agreement with Ukraine is the first such agreement concluded with one of the Eastern Partnership countries and thus represents a historic step forward by the European Union in interstate relations. Since, in accordance with Article 218 of the Regulation, the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union fulfills the necessary procedure, and I consider freedom of movement of people to be one of the highest values of the European Union, I fully support this report. Also, I would like to mention that there are still some restrictions on the employment of workers between the Member States, including in terms of the employment of Croatian citizens. As part of the construction of the European Research Area, and also in line with the objectives of the Agreement covering scientific and technological cooperation, we must pay particular attention to the mobility of researchers and scientists and their facilitated entry, as scientific cooperation is the cornerstone of economic development and the backbone of smart, inclusive and sustainable growth.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. - I voted in favour of the association agreement with Ukraine. I want to support and help Ukraine in the fight for true democracy, against war and violence and for the preservation of sovereignty. I support the sanctions because the Russian leadership is behaving in a disused manner. The peace talks must continue. We are being dragged into a geopolitical game that is heavily mediated by the simultaneous and hasty vote in the EP and the Ukrainian Parliament. Although this Treaty is on the table today, it may not enter into force until early 2016. Why the rush to approve this now? Are we not in danger of creating another 'frozen conflict' at the EU's borders? And what to say about the content of the 1200 pages that are on the ballot. How will they affect our models of society? What's the real agenda? With this Treaty, we put Ukraine on the right path or is the country being used for a larger geopolitical conflict. Voting against it now is irresponsible, given Ukraine's desire and our desire to support Ukraine. In the coming months, we will be holding our hearts as this conflict develops and whether we are on the path of peace.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - Since the decision to join between the European Union and Ukraine is divided into two important decisions, the first of which as an accession treaty, without provisions on third-country nationals legally employed on the territory of the other party, this Decision, which is taken in parallel with the first, relates precisely to the procedures towards third-country nationals legally employed on the territory of the other party , i.e. Ukraine. Given that this Resolution is another step towards strengthening relations between the two sides and a necessary move towards Ukraine's rapprochement and accession to the European Union, the resolution is a very important document by which the European Parliament supports all citizens of Ukraine in their fight for freedom and independence, as equal members of European society. The agreement regulates rights and civil liberties as well as issues of relations towards third-country citizens and allows them to operate normally within the Association Agreement. These issues are the subject of the Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) Committee, which also expresses strong support for Ukraine in the EU rapprochement and accession process, which I also support.

name: Eleytherios Synadinos (NI)
text: Writing. - I am voting against because the European Union must sever all relations with Ukraine and turn to the Russian market. Furthermore, I do not want Ukraine to implement nuclear programmes.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I, of course, like my entire political group, voted in favour of the EU/Euratom/Ukraine Association Agreement. The text also deals with the treatment of third-country nationals legally employed in the territory of the other party. We welcome the positive result of this vote and would like to see the application text as soon as possible.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. - I have today rejected the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement because not only are there strong foreign policy reasons against the introduction of the DCFTA [deep and comprehensive free trade agreement] with Ukraine, but there are also economic concerns. These include the fact that Russia and its customs union are currently the largest customers of Ukrainian exports. However, Russia will impose an import duty of 7.8% on 98% of Ukrainian products in order to protect its own market from the flood of European products. This is estimated to result in a loss of €165 billion for Ukraine over the next ten years. In addition, Ukraine will have to make an enormous financial effort to enable its companies to become competitive on the European market and thus to become competitive, since the DCFTA not only allows duty-free access to the internal market, but also requires compliance with European standards in this regard.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. – This is an historic and very important date. Our vote today has very strong economic consequences but is also highly symbolic! I am very happy to have voted in favour of this association agreement and I am sure the Parliament will speak with a very strong majority in favour of it. This is an historic moment. The European Parliament has always defended the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Ukraine and will continue to do so through this vote. Through this ratification, Ukraine’s European choice will be institutionalised and will bind the futures of the EU and Ukraine together. Ukrainian society has paid the highest price for its European aspirations, grieving for the deaths of numerous people, suffering territorial occupation by Russia and experiencing deteriorating economic conditions. With this ratification, the EU gives Ukraine the strongest sign of support.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted outright against the EU-Ukraine partnership agreement because of the political implications of signing it for that country and the region. In fact, it was the signing of this partnership agreement that led to the coup d'etion in Ukraine, encouraged by the US and the EU itself against the legitimate president, Yanukovich.  In no way am I going to support an association agreement with an illegitimate government that emerged from a coup d'éerous, which also has fascist members in it. An association agreement, on the other hand, which is used by the EU as a weapon against Russia. The EU, rather than promoting its trade interests, should promote an immediate cessation of hostilities and a comprehensive peace agreement for Ukraine.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution in recognition of the shared values that both the European Union and Ukraine share, namely democracy, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, and respect for the rule of law. In addition to these shared values I voted in favour of this resolution to recognise the clear desire shown by the people of Ukraine for a closer and stronger relationship with the European Union.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The adoption of this report is another step towards the implementation of the long-awaited and long-promoted Association Agreement (AA) between the EU and Ukraine.  In this sense, it shows the complete hypocrisy of the European Union which reserves to assess the democraticity of each country according to its interests. Ukraine was not democratic when it refused this agreement with the EU preferring to negotiate with Russia. Now, after the illegal coup d'état and with a government of which fascist parties are part that violate all kinds of leftist opposition, Ukraine, which has already broken into this draconian agreement, has become democratic. Although this parliament banned the Communist Party of Ukraine, whose parliamentary group was composed of 32 Members, from the Chamber. We can only vote against it.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This recommendation is another chapter in the process of interference by the majority of the European Parliament in the unstable situation in Ukraine. Once again, they try to have extreme relations, not taking responsibility in the situation of near-civil war so that they push a country with the support and active participation of the US and NATO.  The question here is NATO's objective of expanding to the border of the Russian Federation at any cost, based on the geopolitical use of a sovereign country to secure the political, economic and military dominance of a region. This resolution ignores it and is another step towards the brutal and open interference of the US and the EU in Ukraine's internal situation, which promotes destabilization by actively supporting fascist and neo-Nazi political and paramilitary forces, inciting the exacerbation of dangerous tensions in this country. This agreement aims at full harmonisation of Ukrainian laws with EU rules and rules, sweeps all areas of Ukrainian society, with a clear prejudice to the Ukrainian people, without being called upon to comment. An agreement with consequences deeply harmful to the interests of workers and the Ukrainian people, national interests and sovereignty of Ukraine, signed by a government without democratic legitimacy.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: That concludes the explanations of vote. (The sitting was suspended at 12.45 p.m. and resumed at 3 p.m.)

name: President. -
text: The next item is the debate on the presentation by the Council of its position on the draft general budget – 2015 financial year (2014/2719(RSP)).  I wish to inform colleagues that for this item we do not have a catch-the-eye procedure and there are no blue cards for these debates, so it is very much just the speakers who are on the list who will be contributing to our debate.

name: Enrico Zanetti
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, it is an honour and a privilege for me to be here to present the Council's position on the draft Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015 formally adopted on 2 September. This is the Second Annual Budget of the European Union under the new Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020. As such, it must be functional, both at the start of the programmes being defined in the various policy areas and at the completion of the 2007-2013 programming measures that are being closed. These are precisely the features that the Council has taken particular into account when defining its position on the 2015 budget, in the awareness of the importance of adequate financial support from the Union for the objectives of growth and employment and for the pursuit of the Europe 2020 strategy. Of course, in taking these objectives into account, the Council has also taken into account the fact that the financing of European initiative programmes must take place in a context of sustainability and budgetary discipline, in line with what the European Union requires of the Member States with regard to national budgets. Having said all that, we believe that the solution identified by the Council adequately interprets the needs for synthesis between these different objectives, and above all allows the European Union to have the necessary budgetary resources for 2015, in order to honour the commitments already made and to start new interventions in the various sectors quickly with a view to sound and efficient financial management. In particular, the size of the appropriations that has been provided to the programmes by measures promoting growth and employment, starting with that of young people, confirms the sensitivity towards these priorities, in line with the conclusions of the European Council of 26 and 27 June last, as well as the allocation of resources reserved for interventions in the other sectors, from communications to research and rural development, to the emergence of immigration, is the result of a specific attention that the Council has also paid to these priorities. This is even though, in adopting its position, the Council considered that, in comparison with the proposal presented by the Commission, savings in expenditure on certain items were necessary and possible.  Necessary, in the sense of the desirability of maintaining adequate margins of resources available for commitments and payments to cope, during the financial year, with unforeseen circumstances and events. Possible, in the sense that the reductions were all based on an in-depth analysis of the programmes, both as regards their real expenditure needs and as regards their possibilities of financial absorption in 2015, and were therefore identified in such a way as not to adversely affect the implementation of the new programmes, nor the implementation and closure of current interventions. In any case, as I will explain later, the Council's position provides for a 2015 budget which, even after these reductions, considered, as mentioned, necessary and possible, shows an increase both in terms of commitment appropriations and payment compared to the 2014 budget. It is understood that Italy, as President-in-Office of the Union, will work with the European Parliament and the Commission to reach agreement on the 2015 budget, trusting in the constructive spirit and climate of cooperation that has always been established between the three institutions in the search for a compromise on the Union's budget. However, let us now turn to the detailed content of the Council's position, a position which provides for total appropriations of eur 144 billion in commitments and one hundred and forty billion euros in payments. With regard to the Commission's budget proposal, the Council has therefore provided for a reduction of EUR 502 million for commitments and EUR 2.1 billion for payments. As I have already mentioned, despite these reductions, both commitments and payments increase compared to the 2014 budget, also taking into account the amending budget 1/2014 already approved; in particular, an increase of EUR 2.4 billion for commitments, equal to 1.71% out of their total, and an increase of EUR 4.6 billion for payments, equal to 3.32% of their total. I think it is significant to stress that the Council's position does not imply any reduction in the EU budget, even if it is compared not only to the 2014 budget currently in force, but also when compared with the sum of the balances of the current budget and the balances of the amending budgets for 2014 proposed by the Commission and on which the Council is still making its assessments.  That is why, as I said earlier, this position combines in a balanced way the need for adequate support for the socio-economic development policies promoted by the European Union with the need for sustainability and budgetary discipline. All the more so when we consider the declaration annexed to the Council's position, in which the Commission is asked to present a draft amending budget as soon as the level of appropriations for payments during 2015 proves insufficient to meet the financial needs linked to the headings most affected by the phenomenon of so-called RALs. It is no coincidence, moreover, that a very broad consensus was reached in the Council on this position with the vote in favour of almost all the Member States.  I shall now refrain from going into the details of the headings by heading, on the understanding that I will of course then be available at the clarification stage, but I repeat that, even at the level of each individual heading, the principle that the Council's position nevertheless implies an increased budget compared to that of 2014 remains valid, precisely for each heading. Let me conclude by summation of the three principles that guided the work done in the Council to examine the draft budget for 2015. Firstly, the need to provide sufficient funding for policies that are closest to the hearts of European citizens, namely the fight against unemployment, especially youth unemployment, investment in research and innovation, support for small and medium-sized enterprises, management of international crises such as the one in Ukraine, management of migratory flows and humanitarian aid.  Secondly, the need to be vigilant on the public finance front, in view of the continuous efforts required of the Member States to contain their budgets. In this respect, particular attention must be paid to keeping administrative expenditure under control, as we trust in the ability of the European administration to seek and achieve a higher level of efficiency. Finally, thirdly, the need to adopt a prudent and reasonable EU budget, with the necessary margins below the various ceilings provided for in the multiannual financial framework to deal with unforeseen circumstances. As I have repeatedly stated in my speech, the Italian Presidency is convinced that the Council's position on the draft budget for 2015 represents a balanced compromise solution, combining the need for adequate budget allocation to meet the various challenges facing the European Union, with the need to consolidate public finances, which concerns the , in addition to national budgets, also the European budget. At the same time, however, I repeat that Italy, as President-in-Office of the Union, will work with the European Parliament and the Commission to reach agreement on the 2015 budget that takes equally appropriate account of the sensitivities and priorities expressed by all three institutions. In concluding my speech, I thank you for your attention, certainly a calm and constructive discussion, and I remain available for this purpose to respond to any requests for clarification and in-depth analysis.

name: Jacek Dominik
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, honourable Members, Ministers, thank you for the opportunity to address you today. Before I start my speech I would like quickly to react to some comments by the Presidency on the EU budget – both the present one and the future one. I want to highlight two figures which may give you a broader picture: the 2014 budget, if finally adopted with all the amendments proposed by the Commission, will still be about EUR 4 billion below the payments actually adopted for the year 2013; and the budget for 2015, if adopted as presented by the Commission, will still be EUR 2 billion below the 2013 budget. So we are still far from a return to the level of expenditure we used to have, and, although there has been mention of some increase in the EU budget for 2015, actually, if you compare the figures, there is a slight decrease in nominal terms. Taking this into account, the Commission has to reiterate its position today that it is disappointed concerning the Council’s reading of the draft budget for 2015. The Council has taken a ‘business as usual’ approach although we are facing an unprecedented situation. The Commission has already expressed its assessment on previous occasions, and now, at this crucial moment of the budgetary procedure, I would like to focus on the main elements. The Commission proposal for the 2015 budget was drafted in a challenging context. The main goal is to contribute to the economic recovery by investing in programmes that foster growth and jobs and allow the implementation of the new legally adopted programmes for 2014-2020 to start. We have been tasked with doing this not least by the European Council, which confirmed these objectives in June 2014. The biggest difficulties, however, concern the payments. First we need to secure adequate resources for financing the political priorities we have agreed under the new financial framework. Second, we need to find a solution and take under control the increasing backlog. We must be able to pay the bills outstanding from the 2007-2013 period and reimburse the Member States and other beneficiaries within a reasonable timeframe. We simply cannot ignore the claims coming in. To achieve these targets, the Commission has proposed to use the maximum available resources for 2015 and the maximum available flexibility provided for in the current financial framework. In line with the political priorities, the Commission has proposed under Heading 1a, competitiveness for growth and jobs, an increase of 5.8% in commitments and an increase of almost 30% in payments, which is needed to cover previous years’ deep reductions. Yet the Council has returned to its tradition and seeks to reduce commitments by half a billion euros and payments by over EUR 2.1 billion, with more than 60% of the cuts affecting Heading 1a, the heading which provides the very resources that should be helping to contribute to growth and jobs, and particularly to tackling youth unemployment. For Heading 1a alone, this is a cut of around EUR 1.3 billion in payments. For research, the reduction by 10% would impact, under Horizon 2020, on around 600 projects, involving more than 7000 participants, of which around 1400 are SMEs. Similarly, for our external policy – in spite of the EU’s commitments and engagement in recent crises, in particular in neighbouring countries – substantial reductions of EUR 384 million are proposed to the Commission’s draft budget. We need the full amount of payments the Commission has proposed, both in 2014 and 2015, and the full use of flexibility arrangements if we want to stabilise the situation. There must be some limit to pushing payments into the next years, over and over again. We must re-emphasise in this context that what the Commission requests for 2015 might suffice only if we keep on track with what is required in 2014. The annual budget is about implementing the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), not changing the political agreement on which it is based. The political priorities have been decided on during MFF negotiations and now we have to find a way to implement them through annual budgets. Against this background of the current experience with a shortage of payment appropriations in 2014, the Commission can only regret the position taken by the Council in its reading of the 2015 budget. The Council acts as if the situation called for a ‘business as usual’ approach, ignoring current priorities and the budgetary situation. It is taking a two-step approach, whereby first a low level of payment appropriations is authorised in the budget, with the understanding that a supplementary amending budget may be needed in the course of the year. That is not a sound budgetary approach: it creates a major liquidity problem for the annual budget. I would appeal to you, the Parliament, to take account of these concerns during the advance preparation for your reading of the 2015 budget. We should work together to break this vicious circle by putting the right amount of resources in the 2015 budget, from 1 January, in order to implement our common priorities, provide the means to address our obligations stemming from previous years’ commitments and curb the global growth of outstanding commitments – the so-called RALS (restes à liquider). I would like to emphasise that the level of payments proposed by the Commission for 2015 can contribute to stabilising the situation with regard to the 2014 payments only if the 2014 payments are also addressed, and Draft Amending Budget No 3 for the year 2014, with the request to use the remaining margin under the payment ceiling of EUR 700 million and to activate the contingency margin mechanism for an amount of EUR 4 billion, is fully adopted. Developments on the revenue side in 2014 provide an opportunity to work in this direction. Exceptional additional revenue from fines means that the additional payment request for 2014 will be at virtually no cost to Member States. This is welcome at a time of tight national budgets. We should seize the chance to try and take control of the situation. Finally, we need to agree that, in order to stabilise the situation, we must use all the flexibility arrangements provided for in the new financial framework to address all the unforeseen needs and to stabilise the payment situation. I look to our interinstitutional meeting on 24 September to help us jointly to find a sustainable approach. I would already like to thank Parliament for its initiative in convening and hosting this meeting, and in particular the Chair of the Committee on Budgets, Mr Arthuis, and the budget rapporteurs for 2014 and 2015, Ms Gardiazabal, Ms Hohlmeier and Mr Deprez.

name: Monika Hohlmeier
text: Rapporteur. - (DE) Madam President, Commissioner, I welcome the Presidency of the Council. Although I am responsible for Parliament itself and the other sections, I would like to begin by saying, with regard to the Commission budget, that I can no longer understand the Council at all. We have defined a multi-year, seven-year financial framework. I have the impression that the Council no longer knows it. We have only recently adopted it, and the Council is deviating from it to such an extent that I can no longer understand the Council.  Secondly, they say that they want to promote investment and growth. Why then is research and innovation being cut back and the area of SMEs that you want to give special support to is also being cut? Why, on the one hand, do we stress that we want to increase humanitarian aid in Syria when, on the other hand, you are fully aware that, unfortunately, you have cut it in the budget? Development aid must be increased, for the reasons around us that we know, but it is still being cut. I have to say quite frankly that, even since the many budget negotiations in which I have been allowed to participate, it has become more and more clear to me that payments and payment obligations are falling apart, that we have more and more invoices and that fewer and fewer payments are made available.  In any way, I would like the Council to slowly reconcile words and deeds in some way. I may be forgiven for being direct, but some of them do not understand it when I hear growth all the time and research is being cut back. Then I no longer know whether the Council is actually enforcing this, which it is personally discussing. With respect to the other sections and the European Parliament, Parliament itself is going to pull the strings. We will not make any additional increases compared to those we decided on in the spring. We already have the Members' Statute included in this: since this requires us to receive tens of billions of euros in the budget as a result of the statute, we have also saved this ourselves accordingly and will consistently stick to a sensible and orderly line here. However, I also have a few comments on the European External Action Service. The European External Action Service also faces the problem of the fact that it is actually a service growing up, but still does not get the funds for it, especially since its resources are then also distributed rather confusingly between the Commission and the European External Action Service. That is why I think it is imperative that we should perhaps set up security rooms so that we can no longer read the speeches of our external representative on You Tube, and that the Council should not make this out.  A second, final point concerns the European Court of Justice. The Council has long decided that it must be extended. We have serious risks to our budget because we have the first complaint because the proceedings are too long. The duration of the procedure is now more than three years, and that means serious financial consequences for the budget. Perhaps the ECJ should finally be given the new judges that have been promised to it for a long time, so that it can return to orderly work.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President, Mr Zanetti, Commissioner Dominik, the truth is that you may be surprised by the coincidence of priorities between this Parliament and the European Council, and then how far away the positions on the budget are because, as you very well explained — and we have long discussed this — one of the great priorities of the European institutions has to be to get out of the crisis , relaunch the economy, generate growth and fight unemployment, especially youth unemployment. Those are the short-term measures. More so in the long term, we can talk about complying with the Europe 2020 Strategy and, above all, getting the European Union competitive in the world in which we live. And for that we have to invest; and I think we have to invest in order to compete, in this world, in knowledge and that is why I believe that the games devoted to research, development, education and aid to small and medium-sized enterprises must be strengthened, as they rightly said. Or we can also talk about infrastructure or even energy, which is one of the great challenges facing the European Union in the future. But when we go into detail and when we look at the funding that the Council wants to devote to these programmes and the one that the European Parliament wants to devote, that is where we see the big difference. Because we, in our reading — and you will see the agreements we will reach in the coming days — will strengthen many of these programmes and, on the other hand, you, in your reading of the Council, cut, for example, 195 million in research and development, 35 million in the Connecting Europe Facility or 75 million in large-scale infrastructure. And we therefore see that there is a contradiction between what the Councils decide — as the Ecofin has said, as the European Councils said in June last year — and what they then do in the European budget. And this about commitments. But if we look at the payments, we're in a much more serious situation. And the problem is that you, with your reading of the budget, not only don't solve the problem, but aggravate it. We ended 2013 with 25 billion euros in unpaid bills and, in this budget, instead of strengthening that line, they want to cut 2.1 billion more. They said cuts are feasible; I think the Commission has made it very clear that these cuts are not being feasible. I am not going to go into the technical details - the Commission has explained very well what the situation is - but I do want to tell you two things: first, cutting the budget on payments is not saving on the budget, because all they are doing is not paying what we are having to do, because they are not complying with the agreements of the financial framework and because worst of all they are delaying the implementation of projects that are vital to the future of the European Union. And to cut I think it is a double error in the European budget, because if they intend to solve national finances by cutting the European budget, it is clear that they will not make it — hopefully only with a small cut in the European budget we could save the state of finance!—. And the problem is that they are denying the added value of the budget and I do not think we are recognising the European project as such. In conclusion, I am simply asking the Italian Presidency, in truth, to look closely at the problem of payments and to examine very thoroughly the possible solutions within the Council. If you really address this problem, you will have this Parliament helping and working side by side to prevent this from going forward.

name: Jean Arthuis
text: Chairman of the Budgets Committee. Madam President, Minister, Commissioner, I would like to point out that the elections of 25 May delivered their verdict with severity and it is little to say to recall how strong Euroscepticism has been. Criticism has peaked as growth is sluggish and unemployment is high, it is reaching desperate levels among young people. As populism rumbles across the continent, the IMF and OECD are concerned about the stagnation of the eurozone.   The real question is whether the European Union budget can remedy this and restore confidence. To answer this question, we need to clarify three prerequisites: first, to prepare the revision of the multi-year financial framework adopted at the end of 2013. It sets spending limits and revenue levels for seven years. Voted before the election, this framework clearly did not attract the support of the electorate. Democracy therefore orders us to prepare its revision. Can we expect some inflections as early as the 2015 budget? Is there no urgency to present a "combat budget" in the face of the volatility of circumstances? Is it reasonable to lock ourselves in a rigid budget tunnel, insensitive to economic situations, as well as accidents of course?  To a large extent, the 2015 credits will settle transactions launched in 2012 or 2013! At a time when Europe is under threat of economic collapse, such inertia deprives the budget of responsiveness. Are we finally ready to implement specific and maximum flexibility as early as the 2015 budget? Secondly, I want to sound the alarm again about the growing gap between commitment credits and payment credits. As of December 31, 2013, the remains to be liquidated are soaring to new heights, unpaid debts are accumulating and increasing: 5 billion at the end of 2010, 24 billion at the end of 2013. And yet the treaties forbid the Union from taking on debt. However, it is a sneaky debt that takes shape and puts operators in difficulty. This vicious circle is irresponsible.  The EUROPEAN Union budget is modest, accounting for just 1% of gross domestic product (GDP). That is why it should be conceived and executed with discernment, method and coherence. I ask the Council to let us know about its plan to take the weight of the past and allow us to get off on the right foot. Finally, what will be the sources of funding for the 300 billion investments announced by the President of the Commission on 15 July? These cannot be transactions that, in any event, would have been financed by the markets. If Europe is to have a driving effect, it means that it has to take on a risk, and this risk-taking is absolutely expression in the budget. Since everyone recognizes the urgency, what will be the budget translation in 2015? The credibility of the President of the Commission is at stake. In conclusion, I would like to express my strong hope that the 2015 budget should not be a mere extension of previous budgets, bearing the mark of a new plank in payment appropriations. Europe is in crisis, Europe is in danger, we have been elected to restore its aplomb and restore confidence to Europeans.

name: Enrico Zanetti
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, with regard to the requests relating to the multiannual financial framework, we know that there is a possibility in the medium term of its revision in the light of changes in the macroeconomic scenario. Clearly, this is not the specific forum in which we can deal with this issue. Here we need to talk about the draft budget for 2015 given the current multiannual financial framework. In this context, I think I can say that we are not going to question the priorities in any way, but we are clearly going to decline them in the implementation phase of budgetary choices with a gradual approach. A gradual approach that starts from two fundamental points.  The first, as I tried to point out earlier, of a Council position that nevertheless brings a 2015 budget of expansion compared to the current 2014 budget and in any case not lower than that which would emerge on the basis of the consideration of the further proposals for amending budgets made in relation to 2014 by the Commission on which, as we know, in relation to that year, the Council's position is still being assessed. However, with regard to 2015, the Council's position is already becoming a starting point which, compared with the previous year, is seen as a point of arrival, therefore no downsizing.  Furthermore, alongside this stake, there is the other, which consists of the declaration annexed to the Council's position, which calls on the Commission to submit amending budgets for 2015 if it is appropriate to submit them, precisely for matters relating to payments. With regard to the issue of competitiveness for growth and employment, so heading 1a, I would like to mention the numbers anyway, because with regard to this heading the Council's position has set commitments at seventeen billion and one hundred, with a reduction therefore compared to the Commission's proposal of three hundred and twenty-four million euros, but nevertheless with an increase compared to the 2014 budget of six hundred and forty million euros , and payments to EUR 14.2 billion, a reduction on the Commission's proposal of EUR 1.3 billion, but nonetheless an increase over the 2014 budget of as much as EUR 2.8 billion.  It is also important, I believe, to stress that absolutely no reduction compared with the Commission's proposal has been provided for under this heading by the Council with regard to resources for small and medium-sized enterprises, for investment in research and innovation through the COSME programme, as well as for the education and development of skills through the Erasmus+ programme, while the appropriations paid for Horizon 2020 and The Connecting Europe Mechanism , on which most of the reductions proposed by the Council for the heading in question have been concentrated, they have nevertheless increased compared to 2014. The CEF programme has an increase in appropriations in payments of almost 60% and Horizon 2020 by more than 30%. After that, the Council is fully aware of the extreme importance of the EU budget and its role in reviving growth and employment, particularly in the current economic crisis. The Council hopes to ensure adequate funding of the European Union's priorities, in particular with regard to youth unemployment, research and innovation funding, as well as support for small and medium-sized enterprises, but, as we mentioned, the Council itself cannot fail to adopt a realistic approach in the preparation of the EU budget, based both on past and present rates of use of the allocations and on the foreseeable absorption capacity of European funding. Having said that, in thanking you, of course, for this interesting and constructive exchange of views, I am sure that a good understanding of our mutual positions will be the necessary condition for reaching agreement on the 2015 budget, and I therefore believe that today's debate is a good starting point. The Italian Presidency will do all it can to reach an agreement, in a constructive spirit, with a view to responding in the best possible way to the expectations of european citizens, because we are well aware that Europe needs a budget that responds adequately to the citizens' demands, and on this I am sure that together, Parliament, the Council and the Commission, will succeed in finding the right ways to achieve this goal.

name: President. -
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. The level of unpayed payments by the European Commission is alarming. Thousands of small and medium-sized enterprises are failing because of the long wait for funding that the EU should provide to help growth and development at a time of economic stagnation.
