Liquidity problems threaten the survival of companies and the functioning of the real economy, leading to an ever deeper loss of confidence in the institutions. It is therefore necessary to unblock and speed up the problem of payments and to reallocate resources in key areas, such as employment, small and medium-sized enterprises, the fight against corruption, immigration and micro-financing, cutting the administrative waste within the European institutions and their consultative bodies. More realistic spending planning would help to avoid constant requests for additional funds through amending budgets within the European budget, which is in stark contrast to the need for Member States to contain their budgets. We need to identify programmes that do not involve added value and that are lacking in efficient performance, in order to be able to free up resources to be committed to growth and employment.

name: President. -
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on structural shortage of payments in the Horizon 2020 budget (2014/2839 (RSP)).

name: Enrico Zanetti
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, Horizon 2020 is the largest framework programme on research and innovation in the European Union to date.  Its budget for the 2014-2020 programming period provides for over EUR 77 billion, representing a real increase of around one third of the funding available for research and investment compared to the allocations of the Seventh Framework Programme for Research under the 2007-2013 programming period. Behind this considerable increase, decided by the Heads of State or Government, there is therefore the political will to increase spending on research and investment, which are essential to stimulate European competitiveness and growth. Horizon 2020 is therefore our common goal and the most important pan-European research programme agreed in the context of the EU 2020 strategy. On the 2014 budget, the Commission, in its proposal for amending budget No 3, provided for an increase in the budget for the research sector of around EUR 230 million, most of which was allocated to the Horizon 2020 programme. The Council's position on this proposal is being defined, in preparation for discussion with the European Parliament and its approval. With regard to the 2015 budget, as I also had the opportunity to point out earlier, the Council adopted its position on 2 September, with some reductions compared with the Commission's proposal for appropriations with regard to the level of payments. This position has just been presented in detail, and I would like to point out in this connection that it must be read as a whole as an effort to mediate between the requirements of adequate support for the various Community policies, especially those oriented towards growth and employment, but at the same time safeguarding budgetary discipline. The Council is convinced that its position on the 2015 draft budget represents a fair balance between these needs while respecting the political priorities defined by the European Council for a more competitive Europe. Furthermore, I would like to point out that, although the budget for horizon 2020 has been reduced in relation to what the European Commission proposed in its draft budget for 2015, it is still increasing by 33%, as we mentioned earlier in relation to the budget currently entered in the 2014 budget. This shows that the Council has not been insensitive to the objectives of this programme. In this respect, it should be borne in hand that heading 1a is the one that proposed the highest increases in the Commission's draft budget compared with 2014, in view of programmes that are still in the start-up phase and for which a smaller spending trend is expected in the early years and gradually growing in the continuation of programming.  At the same time, for other items of expenditure, such as heading 1b, relating to the Structural Funds and the Cohesion Fund, the Commission has highlighted the need to meet expenditure commitments already entered into and reports already submitted by the Member States, for which the Council has therefore really reduced the reductions to a minimum. As you can see, therefore, the exercise has been very difficult, as the situations are complex and heterogeneous and all require attention from the institutions, which are therefore obliged to make choices in a public finance scenario that is certainly not favourable. I am confident that, together with Parliament, we will be able to reach an agreement as soon as possible, in order to give Europe its budget and ensure full operation on all policies, including and indeed starting with Horizon 2020.

name: Máire Geoghegan-Quinn
text: Comhalta de chuid an Choimisiúin. - A Uachtaráin, tá mé buíoch gur eagraíodh díospóireacht thábhachtach den tsórt seo inniu.  Parliament’s decision to include a debate on the structural shortage of payments in the Horizon 2020 budget is very timely, particularly just after the debate we have had already with Commissioner Dominik. Since 2011, research and innovation programmes have suffered from a recurrent and accumulating lack of payment appropriations, and I will return to this in more detail in a few minutes. The situation has deteriorated under Horizon 2020 because the payment ceilings provided for in the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework are tight. This situation has obliged the Commission to put in place drastic measures in order to meet its contractual obligations and to avoid payment delays. Two key measures have been adopted already in 2013: firstly a reduction of the average pre-financing rates for all research grants; and secondly the postponement of calls for proposal closure dates, thus spreading the payment needs to later years. The implementation of these drastic measures has reduced payments by up to EUR 1.5 billion in research programmes for the year 2014. We should not forget that these payment appropriation needs are, in reality, merely being pushed back to 2015 and beyond. Indeed, if current trends continue, such unmet accumulated payment needs would result in more than 40% of Horizon 2020 commitments remaining outstanding in 2020 and without proper payment coverage. However, these measures will no longer suffice to avoid payment delays if the requested payment appropriations are not met. In short, the approach of putting off to the future has reached its limits. Concretely, for 2014 and despite the implementation of these measures, an additional EUR 230 million, requested through Draft Amending Budget 3/2014, is urgently needed before the end of the year for the research DGs to avoid payment delays. In addition to this already challenging situation, I must draw attention to the sword of Damocles that hangs over Horizon 2020 in the 2015 budget. The proposed 10% cut in the Commission’s draft budget for research payment appropriations – representing a EUR 1 billion decrease for the research budget – would lead to a situation where research DGs could fail in their contractual obligations to thousands of research beneficiaries. In practical terms, let me repeat what Commissioner Dominik has already mentioned to you: around 600 collaborative projects under Horizon 2020 would be affected, involving more than 7000 participants, of which around 1400 are SMEs. I believe it is important to clarify one particular issue with regard to this proposed 10% cut in funding. Some would seek to obscure the reality by presenting the situation on Heading 1a as some sort of a huge increase for R&D spending by comparison with 2014. What such a narrative fails to mention is that 2014 constituted a highly atypical year in terms of the scale of the payment appropriations budget for research and innovation. Indeed, in 2014, due to the phasing-in of Horizon 2020, some 15% less has been budgeted by comparison with 2013. The ‘increased spending’ narrative neglects two important factors: the step increase of the commitment profile in the last years of the seventh framework programme (FP7), as FP7 was backloaded; and, secondly, the overall limited availability of payments which we face. Thus, 2014 cannot be used as a valid benchmark for judging the budget trend in 2015. In fact, 60% of our spending in 2014 and 2015 is actually legacy-related payments from FP7, meaning that the full roll-out of Horizon 2020 is, de facto, being pushed even further into the future due to the lack of payment appropriations. In short, an outcome which provided for a cut in spending on the scale originally proposed by the Commission for 2015 would seriously call into question the reputation of the European Union as a reliable funder of research. This is a dramatic situation for a flagship policy that is intended to support jobs, growth and competitiveness.  It is also highly regrettable in the current economic situation, given our collective search for growth-enhancing measures and knowing that research and innovation are crucial to new growth and jobs. Such artificially low investment in research will also negatively impact on other initiatives such as the Digital Agenda, the energy technologies plan and our climate change policies. Such a large cut in 2015 would, moreover, be at odds with repeated affirmations in support of the Europe 2020 Growth and Jobs Agenda, most recently articulated through the Strategic Agenda for the Union in Times of Change. It goes without saying, therefore, that a new boost for jobs, growth and investment cannot be achieved if we continue to reduce planned investments in research and innovation. We are counting on you, the Members of the European Parliament, to give us your active support in addressing this problem by adopting without modification both Draft Amending Budget 3/2014 and the draft budget for 2015 as presented by the Commission.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the "A lot of us have children. And what do we, as parents, understand very well? We understand that the future of our children will be ensured by a good education. It means a lot of time, it means a lot of money for families and society as a whole, but it's an investment, we all understand that it is necessary for our children to grow up and be able to take care of themselves.  If we look more broadly at the European Union, it seems that all the political forces have understood that if we want to see economic growth, new jobs in the future, we need to invest serious money in scientific development. It is long-term money that will bear the long-term benefits. And we worked together with the Council of Europe, with the Member States, in the european Union's multi-annual budget of 7 years, to provide European Union funding for scientific progress. In my opinion, it is completely incomprehensible and totally unacceptable that the Council of Europe - the Member States - now suddenly wants to change this funding by drastically reducing what has been carefully designed and planned for the long term. Colleagues, I call for this change in the Council's position not to be supported. We must keep this funding for science so that we have the growth in Europe in the future, the jobs that we all need. Let's finance science! Let us finance Horizon 2020!

name: Dan Nica
text: on behalf of the S&D group – Cutting payment appropriations has become a structural problem, which threatens to create an impossible budgetary situation at the end of this framework programme if current trends are not corrected.  If the Commission were to receive the necessary level of payment appropriations for Horizon 2020 in the coming years, then the need for payment appropriations for research and technological development would be EUR 7 billion. Unfortunately, given the limited budget that R&D DDs face each year, the estimated necessary budget for the R&D side will be around 16 billion, nine billion more than normal.  Basically, 20% of the budget for Horizon 2020 is postponed for the next MFF.  In order to comply with the MFF ceiling, the Commission significantly reduced the budgetary demand for 2014 in Horizon 2020, and the Council introduced further reductions.  To deal with this situation, all DGs implementing r&D programmes have introduced important measures. The level of project funding has been reduced and, in a number of cases, calls for projects and their deadlines have been postponed to move more payments in 2015. For 2015, the draft budget has already been kept to a minimum. With the abovementioned measures, the Commission would at most be able to cover the payment obligations already outstanding.  However, in July, the Council proposed a further reduction for the 2015 budget of another EUR 1 billion for the entire research budget. If this reduction is adopted, the DGs-General for Research and Development will no longer be able to fulfil their contractual obligations on payments on time, nor in any case future obligations. As already mentioned above, if we continue to push payments for the coming years, the situation will get worse.

name: Ashley Fox
text: , on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, Horizon 2020 is one of the areas of the EU budget which can have a real impact in boosting economic growth. It must be a priority to ensure that it is financed effectively in order to achieve its full potential. The Council and the Commission have reiterated on numerous occasions their desire for the EU budget to promote growth and jobs. If they are to live up to this commitment they must do their utmost to resolve any issues around financing Horizon 2020. I note that the Council is proposing quite a significant cut of nearly EUR 1 billion – i.e. 11% – to payment appropriations for the EU research programme. In contrast, cuts to the cohesion payments amount to just 0.4% and those to agriculture 0.1%. EU research has been disproportionately hit by the Council’s proposals. I understand that the package of cuts is brought about partly by tighter budgetary controls put in place by Member States that are net contributors. I approve of this and I think it is inappropriate for the Commission to blame the Member States for it. The fact that we have to make these cuts is the fault of the whole Commission being unable to manage its budgets effectively. The Commission has been too liberal with commitments without tracking available payments. This has been going on for years and is getting worse. The result of this poor management is that crucial research funding is suffering and this is because of bad budgetary practice in other areas such as structural funds. So, rather than coming to this Chamber and asking the taxpayer for ever more money, I would ask the Commission to come here and explain how it is going to improve its systems to ensure that Horizon 2020 does not suffer. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Madam President, it is interesting to see that we are talking about cutting down budgets – and there are some that are more important than others – but surely the colleague will agree with me that, if you wanted to buy a new car – a beautiful Jaguar which is produced in my constituency – he could look at some of the models, and some of them are more expensive, but he could buy the brand new XE, which is a superb car, more affordable but still valuable and still good value for money. Maybe this is what the European Union needs to learn. Would you agree with me: time to look for more value for money?

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – Well, I agree with my colleague. We should look to value for money, and the very first place we should cut is this travelling circus to Strasbourg. We could save EUR 100 million each and every year by having a single seat, and we could raise EUR 500 million by selling these buildings. Then you could afford to buy a great many excellent Jaguars made in his constituency.

name: Nils Torvalds
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, when somebody in Finland is doing something very stupid he is usually these days asked: do you have all your Moomins in the valley? When I heard Minister Zanetti, I got the feeling that the Moomins in his valley had fled in panic. The Commission made clear that they need all the payments that they have allocated to research and development – and especially to Horizon 2020 – and the implementing rates are good. Now the Council is cutting Heading 1a, with Horizon 2020 being hardest hit, having taken 41% of the cuts in the headings.  Parliament had agreed, together with the Council and Commission, to strengthen the creation of jobs for growth and competitiveness, but to do this they need to strengthen investment in favour of these goals. I am disappointed in the Council due to the fact that its provisional draft budget is one that makes cuts and does not show any support for this agreement. In early 2013, the Council wanted the funding for Horizon 2020 to represent real growth compared with the 2013 level. As late as 27 June 2014, the Council stated that: ‘the credibility of the Union depends on its ability to ensure adequate follow-up on decisions and commitments’ and that ‘the Union needs bold steps to foster growth, increase investments, create more and better jobs and encourage reforms for competiveness’. You should try to get some of your Moomins back into the valley and some of the money back into the budget.

name: Pablo Echenique
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, it is estimated that the Seventh Framework Programme, the predecessor of Horizon 2020, has produced between seven and fourteen euros of industrial added value for every euro invested. Its long-term impact is estimated at an increase of 1% of the Union's gross domestic product, the creation of nearly one million jobs and a one-and-a-half percentage point increase in exports. In this House we can disagree on many things, but I believe that none of us here can deny, or even relativize, the immense importance that the Horizon 2020 programme can have for European science, nor its very clear and proven multiplier effect on our battered economy. However, in its position on the 2015 budget, the Council proposes cuts for Horizon 2020 of EUR 190 million in appropriations and EUR 980 million in payments, literally condemning many of the programmes already initiated. If you want a Europe of Einsteins, Curies, Cajales and Hawkings, if you want a Europe that leads the world — not only scientific, but also technological and industrial innovation and in the creation of sustainable and quality jobs, if you want this Europe and not one that is content to invent, innovenate and manufacture others, the only logical position is to repudiate the unacceptable cuts proposed by the Council, as well as to mobilise the Contingency Margin and the Flexibility Instrument provided for by the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020 to provide the programme with the resources it deserves.

name: Claude Turmes
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, first, I should like to say thank you to the Commissioner – I am here, I am a backbencher now! Thank you very much, Commissioner, for your very courageous and straightforward speech today. Mr Fox’s intervention has already given us a flavour of where this political game will go. Despite the fact that it is the British Treasury and the treasuries of some other rich Member States who cause all these problems, this will be another UKIP and Tory – I think it is more UKIPisation – party strategy. They will blame Brussels for the fact that it is the British Government, it is Mrs Merkel, it is the Austrians and the Danish and the Finnish Governments who are creating the problem here. Colleagues, we will have to win this battle; but, if we want to win this battle, this battle has to leave the Brussels bubble. It has to leave this place. And what is great for us is that it is precisely the universities in the UK who will lose the most, it is the universities in Germany who will lose the most, it is the universities in Sweden and Finland which will lose the most, and in Austria and in the Netherlands. So what we have to do is ask the students of these countries to organise big demonstrations in front of their finance ministries. We have to show who is creating trouble and we have to prevent this from turning into another ‘blame Brussels’ game. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Does my colleague not appreciate the general distrust of this institution throughout the United Kingdom and indeed in other Member States? If I was running a small business as a limited company, I would have to make an annual return. Now the accounts for this place have not been properly audited for 18 years. Does my colleague accept that this is just one sincere criterion for distrust of this organisation? There will be better value version for British students outside of this travesty when the British Government is in a situation where she can spend funds on areas in which she succeeds.

name: Claude Turmes (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – I think it is very difficult to answer questions from UKIP because they rarely speak on the topic, and they always try to continue this anti-Europe game. I think that at the end of the day, maybe next Thursday, we will get an answer to that, and that will be the outcome of the sad story of 10 to 15 years of unfair Europe-bashing from the major newspapers and some of the political parties. So go ahead; we will have to live with the results.

name: Jonathan Arnott
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, as the proverb goes, a tyrannical king once asked a wise man, ‘What shall I do for the betterment of our people?’ The wise man replied, ‘The best thing you could do for your people is to remain in bed until noon so that for this brief period you shall not afflict mankind’.  Horizon 2020 focuses on research to create growth and jobs, but when you are spending more than you earn you have got to cut something. We need research, even if I prefer that to come through the Member States rather than from the EU. But how about starting with EU overregulation? The European Union should operate according to the principle of subsidiarity. Everything that could be dealt with at a local level should be dealt with at a local level.  Last week I visited a charity, the Blyth Resource Initiative Centre, in my constituency. It helps unemployed people back to work. It works with local businesses, provides training and is hamstrung by regulations when it wants to expand. In Redcar, in my constituency, I visited a food bank where even some people who are in employment are now finding need of food parcels and where people who used to run successful businesses now find themselves in similar need. When will this place realise that what business needs is not more EU regulations, but for regulators to follow the lead of the unjust king and stay in bed until midday and give business the chance to recover? That is where the cuts should take place. It is very simple. This place pays lip service to the concept of subsidiarity but throws the principle out every day of the week, without batting an eyelid, while the payments problem represents all of the reasons why the EU does not work, cannot work and will not work.

name: Sophie Montel (NI). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union has demanded that the submitted governments of the Member States implement austerity measures that are hitting the middle and working classes hard and which have in no way boosted economic activity and growth in the euro area. It demanded that these same governments submit a budgetary example by setting them accounting and numerical limits that should not be exceeded or face very heavy fines. It is now clear that the European Union should have started to apply to itself rules of budgetary rigour. The situation of payments has reached a very alarming point, by the admission of the senior members of the Committee on Budgets. The unpaid bills have thus accumulated without the Council obviously being alarmed. How could he have allowed the situation to deteriorate at this level? The European Union is in the process of going into debt and there is indeed a structural deficit and not just a cyclical deficit in payments. This is the responsibility of the EPP and the PES that co-direct.  As in France, where the UMP and the Socialist Party have brought our country to the brink of bankruptcy, where the local authorities led by the right and the left are constantly increasing debt, blowing up operating expenses and increasing the tax burden.  The Horizon 2020 programme, which overall includes excellent projects, is part of a multi-year framework. Given the situation, how can you still commit to seven years? The volatility of the economic situation should make you think, also given your demonstrated inability to set a rigorous fiscal framework. Even more worrying, ladies and gentlemen, is your reasoning. At a meeting of the Committee on Budgets, which I attended last July, Mr Zanni asked a common-sense question. He asked whether the Council could consider re-establishing the situation by saving money. The leading members, the Commissioners in the lead, were offended that all the European Union's projects were vital.  Today, there are some dark cuts that will be made in Horizon 2020's budget, which, let us remember, has excellent aspects. In view of the economic, social and financial situation in the euro area and the more than worrying situation of the remains to be liquidated - more than 200 billion euros - at the end of 2013, we strongly urge you to take drastic savings measures in your projects and programmes and finally to focus on the efficient, the justified and the priority.

name: Janusz Lewandowski (PPE). -
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. The problem we are talking about – the problem of non-payment – is the universal problem of the European budget. We are talking today about research and development shortcomings, but a few months ago we talked about the dramatic humanitarian situation on which hundreds of people in refugee camps in Syria depend. In no other area than research and development (where innovation is concerned), there is no greater gap between declarations and opportunities between promises and resources at our disposal.  I would like to say to all the critics that, at national level, as at European level, budgets are currently scarcity management, but the distinguishing feature of the European budget is that annual tasks, annual ambitions can be quantified, can be expressed in figures called 'commitments'. If there are no payments to cover these commitments, which are agreed jointly by the countries and Parliament, the emptiness of these declarations is revealed, precisely because of this, more acutely than at national level.  The reasons for the current state of affairs are well known and diagnosed: under-payments at a time of crisis, when more than 20 countries were in an excessive deficit procedure, with bills rising at the end of the 2007-2013 programming. This is obvious. Low payment ceilings for 2014-2015, and at the same time new promises called frontloading, precisely concerning the scope of Heading 1. The effect is known, it is also diagnosed. No way out of this crisis is blame game. The way out is an amending budget for this year, solid budgeting for 2015, so that I believe that the Italian Presidency and the next Commissioners responsible for research and development will have their hands full. (The speaker agreed to answer two questions asked by the blue card (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Reimer Böge (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner Dominik rightly said earlier that it is also the task of the annual budget to use and implement the agreement on the multiannual financial framework. The task is not to bring this agreement down regularly and annually. I now ask Mr Lewandowski, who, in his capacity as former Commissioner, was involved in the negotiations on the MFF, whether what the Council is now doing in terms of research and innovation is not contrary to the political agreements that Parliament and the Council have decided to accept, namely to accept the figures on the one hand, but at the same time more flexibility and frontloading, for example ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Janusz Lewandowski (PPE)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the "blue card". – Unfortunately, I must confirm Mr Böge's concerns: indeed, the jointly agreed front loading, which means payments for the period 2014-2015 (we estimate them at almost EUR 3 billion), if compared to the council's cuts, this is nothing compared to the commonly agreed promises in the areas of Youth Employment, Horizon 2020, ErasmusPlus and Cosme. This stands in extreme contradiction to the promises made.

name: Giulia Moi (EFDD)
text: Blue card question. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to know whether the Commission intends to do anything, given that Italy has the Presidency, but given that, according to calculations, of one hundred and twenty billion fraud ... (The President cut the speaker off.) ... the budget would need to be better controlled because, for example, in Italy, sixty billion euros end up in un controlled fraud, out of one hundred and twenty throughout Europe. I would like to ask whether he intends to do anything during the six months of the Italian Presidency.

name: Janusz Lewandowski (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – I am not sure whether this question is addressed to me. However, I can assure you that what we are talking about and what is missing is ‘eligible bills’, audited bills coming from 28 countries. These figures are not invented by the Commission. These are deliveries from 28 countries for accomplished projects and here it is not only a question of economies affecting beneficiaries, it is a question of the credibility of the European institutions.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Mr Representative of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, Horizon 2020 is the European engine for growth and jobs. The focus on knowledge, technology and innovation was central to the proposal made by Jean-Claude Juncker to this Parliament. The words in the European sessions have to correspond to the acts. If that does not happen, the lines of credibility and trust between the institutions will be broken, as the Commissioner rightly said. The Horizon 2020 component associated with research, science and innovation will predictably in the next Commission as responsible for the new Commissioner Portuguese. This new Commissioner is well aware of what it is to cut funding in science, research and innovation. The government of which it has been a part of the last three years has brutally reduced public investment in science and innovation and reduced research grants by more than 50%. I only use this example because it's a concrete example. The result is in sight. With these choices, Portugal regressed in gross domestic product and Portugal regressed into highly qualified employment.  This is a sign of what can happen if the whole Union adopts this strategy. I do not believe that the new Commissioner will want to repeat in the European Commission the policies he has pursued in his country. Ensuring timely payment of commitments is your first test of fire. Here will be its weight with Jean-Claude Juncker and the new Commissioner for the Budget. It is in the interests of the future of the European Union that this burden corresponds to the great importance that these areas have for competitiveness and cohesion.  It is important to be ambitious in the design of the policies associated with Horizon 2020. Increasing human capital, technological capital and creative capital are necessary but not sufficient conditions to ensure growth and job creation in the European Union. We have to be more demanding in transferring these resources to value creation. We need a new industrial revolution, industrialization 4.0, based on clean innovation and the information cloud, based on energy union and based on the new digital agenda. What is at stake is decisive. That we start by failing payments is a bad sign we can't tolerate.  (The speaker agrees to answer a question under the "blue card" procedure in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: It asks according to the procedure "blue card". – Mr Zorrinho wanted to bring national politics here. Forget that we are in the European Parliament, but I will take advantage of the cue that he brought us here and I ask him if he knows that it was in the time of the government of the Socialist Party - that he was part of as Secretary of State for Innovation - that there was the slightest implementation of Horizon 2020 and that, then as the current government, the implementation of Horizon 2020 began to improve , started to grow and have high execution rates.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. – Madam President, of course, my colleague who has been in Parliament for the longest time knows that during the government of which I was very honoured to be a member there was no Horizon 2020. On the other hand, I'm not the one who brought the national issue here, but I want to bring national issues. No commissioner will succeed in Horizon 2020 if there are no good national policies to promote research, science and innovation, we lose good applications and good executions.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR). -
text: Madam President, dear colleagues! It has been said several times that the Horizon 2020 programme is a good programme.  It is specifically geared to the requirements that will be placed on us in the future. But, of course, it is very important that a programme is only as good as it can be implemented in practice. We therefore believe that this programme is not suitable for making cuts there, especially in view of the fact that there are already many commitments made in this area, where it is not yet known exactly how to finance them. However, we, the ECR, also believe that this cannot be used as a vehicle to demand an increase in the overall budget through the back door. Instead, we simply need to focus more on innovative forward-looking programmes in the European budget. We must also, of course, see here again: Horizon 2020 is only a partial aspect of the budget. However, it clearly shows the overall problem here, which is particularly evident in the commitments made which are not financed. That is where we have to start, and that is the very important thing.

name: Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy (ALDE). -
text: I will be honest: after hearing from the Council and the Commission, I did not believe my own ears. Were they talking about the same subject? I have rarely heard such contradictory statements in this House from the Council on the one hand and the Commission on the other. The Council: a loud drumbeat about the wonderful increases in research and development budgets and, Commissioner, with the honest story that is now being irresponsibly cut back on this, using the words 'sword of Damocles', and, to top it all off, the expectation that, if we continue like this, we will be 40% short of payments by 2020. That seems irresponsible to me. After years of very difficult negotiations on the multiannual budget, we have indeed had an increase in that research budget. That multi-annual budget was not the innovative multi-annual budget I would have liked to have seen. As far as I am concerned, the research budget could have been much higher, but it was a step in the right direction. And now the Council is threatening to reverse this with truly irresponsible cuts. Because, let us be honest, we are all talking about growth and jobs, but we will only achieve growth and jobs in Europe if we invest enough in innovation. Only then will we have really solid sustainable growth. So that is not the way the Council wants austerity in this way every time. To refer to my British colleagues: this is really penny-wise and pound-foolish! Does the Council realise, as the Commissioner said, that we are putting thousands of institutions and businesses in difficulty here? Madam President, I am very curious about the Council's response, especially to the comments made by the Commissioner.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL). -
text: A Uachtaráin, caithfidh mé a rá go bhfuil an-imní orm maidir leis an dréachtbhuiséad do 2015 mar go bhfuil níos mó ciorruithe le teacht. Tá an chuid is mó de na ciorruithe ag teacht ó Theideal 1A agus Horizon 2020 agus téann sé seo i gcoinne gealltanas a thug an Chomhairle chun infheistíocht a dhéanamh i bpostanna agus fás agus tógann sé ón mbunaidhm chun infheistiú a dhéanamh i ndaoine.  Maidir le Horizon 2020, ní féidir glacadh leis an ngearradh de 41.4 % go háirithe agus é ag cur tograí cosúil le Marie Curie i mbaol agus é chomh lárnach i dtaobh an idéalachais don taighde. Is sárú é an moladh seo den chreat airgeadais ilbhliantúil 2014-2020.  Tá an neamhshuim atá léirithe ag an gCoimisiún i dtaobh na n-iascairí scannalach. Dʼfhéadfá a rá go bhfuil mórfhaillí taispeánta agus is náireach agus is uafásach iad na ciorruithe atá molta sa doiciméad seo.  Tugadh mandáid dúinn ó mhuintir na hEorpa agus tháinig teachtaireacht shoiléir uathu agus is é sin go gcaithfear bogadh ó na beartais déine. Dá mbainfí úsáid as gnáthchiall agus cleachtas maith gnó bheadh sé soiléir go gcaithfear infheistíocht a dhéanamh chun iarmhéid bainc sláintiúil a chruthú. Tá pionóis á ghearradh orainn mar gheall ar bhotúin ón am a chuaigh thart leis an mbuiséad neamhréalaíoch seo.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE). -
text: What does the Council say in an explanation to our universities, research institutions and others that they have done their jobs and spent money, but we are not going to pay? There will be no payments. What justifications and excuses do they intend to invent that deadlines and promises are not being kept? Perhaps it would be more appropriate, even rather than criticising the Commission, to honestly admit that, despite the incessant and high-flying rhetoric about the importance of innovation and research, heads of state and heads of government do not really care so much about these things.  My colleague Claude Turmes has already made this situation ironic. I'm not going to repeat it. I would just like to express the hope that perhaps Mr Tusk, as President of the European Council, will be able to seize this bull.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, here too we are discussing the problem of payments and cuts in the Union's budget, in this case for the Horizon 2020 programme. We are talking about one of the most important initiatives at European level, some eighty billion for research and innovation. In practice, however, not even a year after its launch, we are already in serious cuts that risk jeopardising the entire implementation of the project.  At this point I would like to ask a simple question: does Europe really believe in the projects it proposes, or is it just propaganda? If, on the other hand, research and innovation are only used as commercials, then the discourse is quite different. I hope that the Commission and the Council will give us a clear answer. If, however, Europe does not believe in research and innovation, at least let the Member States invest in this area, removing these items from the calculation of the absurd constraints imposed by the European Union's Stability and Growth Pact.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI). -
text: Madam President, representatives of the Council and the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. When State Secretary Zanetti tells us today that the overall budget should be used to the best possible way for growth and jobs, and at the same time we hear from Commissioner Dominik that the Horizon 2020 programme is intended to save 10% of the funds, that 600 projects cannot be financed, that 1 400 SMEs and 7 000 people are affected, that is a substantial contradiction in terms. I say to you that by saving on research and development, you will certainly not create growth and employment in Europe. Nor does it correspond to the dimension of the Horizon 2020 programme, which I would like to mention briefly. As has already been said, Horizon 2020 is the world's largest transnational research and development programme with a budget of EUR 80 billion, which is now to be cut. The programme is a priority in the Competitiveness for Growth and Jobs sub-heading in the European budget, with a share of just under 57%. Horizon 2020 provides a common framework for three major objectives: scientific excellence, competitiveness and market leadership, as well as major societal challenges. In all three areas, funding will be cut in the future. We must speak out against this. Innovation, research and development are among the main priorities in the European Union in the Europe 2020 strategy, the strategy for creating growth and jobs. According to the strategy, EU countries are to invest 3% of gross domestic product in research and development by 2020, to create 3.7 million jobs and to increase GDP by 800 billion. Ladies and gentlemen, with a 10% reduction in Horizon 2020, you will certainly not achieve these targets.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Mr Representative of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, research and innovation are priorities of the European Union which we all consider crucial for the objectives of growth and unemployment to be achieved.  The Council has also emphasised this priority, which is, moreover, a commitment established in the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020. However, in the 2015 budget the Council intends to cut EUR 1 335 million for payments for heading 1A, precisely the one containing the main instruments of growth and jobs. Only the cuts applied to Horizon 2020 represent more than 41% of the total cuts adopted by the Council for this heading. This would mean a decrease for Horizon 2020 which would violate the approved Multiannual Financial Framework.  The Council, once again, declares one thing and does another. It states that it intends to strengthen investment in growth and jobs but does not comply with the agreements, the Regulation of the Multiannual Financial Framework does not take on sufficient amounts and amounts with which it has committed itself.  Let us also not forget that research, innovation and smart growth are also present in cohesion policy funds - and in particular in the ERDF and the European Social Fund - and these have been hit even harder by cuts that make it impossible to pay for expenditure already made and what we are talking about is expenditure already incurred. We are not talking about extra money in payments, we are not asking for more money, what we are asking is for the Council to pay what it owes. The Council must be credible, comply with the law, implement the programmes contained in the Financial Framework 2014-2020. It must be an exemplary institution in the background.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, an essential dowry, I would like to say a virtue in politics and in the institutions, and this also applies to Europe, should be coherence, that is to say, a correspondence between our proclamations, our objectives and then the consequent acts that we adopt, otherwise I believe that we ourselves are fuelling mistrust in Europe, in that Europe in which we believe so much. , because we ourselves, let us say, do not live up to our commitments. I say this because if we look at two figures from this budget – I know that they have already been mentioned but repeated iuvant, I hope – if we look at two figures we realise how inconsistency there is in this Council proposal. Well, 70% or 73% of the cuts that the Council makes on the Commission's proposal are all in heading 1a, which has a curious title: 'Competitiveness for growth and jobs', and then 40%, as has been said, focuses on Horizon 2020, which has been a bit of our flagship, and I would like to thank Commissioner Geoghegan-Quinn here for his commitment and support in the effort to increase the research programmes and to set up the European Union's research programmes. In heading 1a there is COSME, there is the Joint Research Centre, which is very important. There are so many significant chapters. In the Horizon section, for example, there are emerging future technologies that are being cut, those that can give Europe and European industry a dominant and, let us say, significant position in international competition. Well, I say this very warmly to the Council: when the previous Parliament accepted the multiannual financial framework, it did so reluctantly during the last parliamentary term, but in the end it accepted that framework. It is now impossible for this more ambitious Parliament, which is also encouraged by an electoral review, to accept conditions that take us backwards.  Back then we were promised front loading, uploading, to say: the first few years we will put more resources because we need a boost for growth. So, here we are faced with a kind of back loading, because commitments are being shifted – I am not talking about the very serious problem of payments. So I say this, in short: it is not the council's usual pretentious position, but it is the coherence that we want to have out of respect for the institutions. I believe that we will make a great alliance with the next Commission to restore the commitments that have been made.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President, Horizon 2020 can be a very important programme for research and innovation that supports small and medium-sized enterprises and promotes new jobs and boosts social development. However, so far it has been shown that access to finance, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises, is very difficult. Synergies between academia and the private sector favoured by the programme often turn research into a tool of large multinational companies which develops on the basis of their own needs and interests and not the interests of society. The proposed reduction in funds is now being added to these. Instead of reducing the funds relating to the militarisation and interventions of the European Union around the world, we choose to reduce the funds that can be used for young people, to ensure stable and regulated work, to support secondary education and the right to work. As a GUE/NGL Group we cannot consent. The European Union must and must invest in research and innovation, in jobs, but also contribute to social development.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD). -
text: Madam President, the Council proposes to limit the subsidies in the Horizon 2020 research support programme, and I support this proposal to reduce it, but probably for reasons other than the Council. Then I'll explain why. I have two reasons for this: firstly, in my view, the programme contradicts one of the main principles enshrined in the Treaties, namely the principle we call subsidiarity. I think it is clear here that the investment in research is best done by the person concerned by the research, that is, a particular company, and it is not for the European Commission to decide at all. Secondly, there has been a cliché here several, perhaps a thousand times today, that we need investment in research to support growth, employment. Why do I say it's a cliché? That's probably true, but it's very important who invests in research. I think companies are supposed to invest. Who invented the microphone, the fluorescent lamp, the cell phone, the Wi-Fi? Do you think these things came from subsidies redistributed by an official? No, it was always companies that expected a return on their investments that invested in research. So I'd probably conclude with a sentence sir Humphrey said from a certain show: "Subsidies are for what people don't want, because what they want buys it." So I would recommend that the Council go further and cancel the entire Horizon 2020 programme.

name: Lambert van Nistelrooij (PPE). -
text: I would particularly like to thank Mrs Geoghegan-Quinn, the outgoing Commissioner, for her clarity today. She can say it a little easier now, but she was very clear. On the one hand you have the obligations, on the other hand the payments and in between comes an ever larger gap, a gap that rises to 40% at the end of the new period. If the Commissioner says this now, it means that the response given by the Council of 'we knit that right' and 'we are getting close', is incorrect.  At the last plenary session, we discussed cohesion money. There, the gap between payments and liabilities is more than EUR 20 billion. This is fundamental. And it also affects our own payment morale. We have adopted the directive on late payments for our own public organisations, for companies: pay within 30 days! What are we doing with the Council ourselves? We sit there with dry eyes, things are pushed through for a year and sometimes more than a year. This is not correct. This concerns our own morality, our own way of how we want to interact with others, our role model. I think that's very fundamental. A few small questions to conclude: do we get all the relevant information in the functional committees and not just in the finance committee? Who jumps when a company or researcher goes bankrupt? If he can't do it anymore, where are the Member States? Thirdly, I expect a lot from the new Commission: growth, jobs, investment. But I want to get this resolved first.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D). -
text: Madam President, I too would like to convey my concern and a request for compromise to the Council with the Horizon 2020 programme, because the situation we are debating today I think is a serious situation, if not awkward on the part of the Council. I would also like to begin by thanking the Commissioner for the clarity of the presentation. Horizon 2020 is an emblematic programme for Europe 2020 and, especially at the moment, it is a crucial programme, in the face of a youth unemployment rate that we could describe in Europe as unbearable.  Europe has the challenge of growth and competitiveness, but the truth is that, so far, the only measure we have seen put on the table to work for that competitiveness has been a reduction in wages in each of the Member States to combat the crisis, that is, an impoverishment of workers. But even if we believed to this extent, it is clearly insufficient. In the medium and long term it is essential to bet on knowledge, innovation and quality jobs. For this purpose Horizon 2020 was born, with this objective, although more and more important are the doubts we have regarding the Council's position — already at birth, it reduced it by 30% compared to the proposal made by the European Parliament, which called for 100 billion; he finally got an endowment of 70,000. The 2014 budget was reduced, and we are announced that in 2015 it will also be reduced by 190 million euros. The Commissioner's presentation highlights the serious problem of non-payment of committed programmes, which puts thousands of companies at risk, many of them small and medium-sized enterprises. Therefore, what we are asking for is a commitment by the Council, a commitment to the future of young people, to the future of the European Union and, above all, to entrepreneurs, to SMEs, industry and to scientific society, whom we create so much hope when we approved Horizon 2020 in 2011. Let us therefore look to the future, leave behind this lack of sight and this short journey, and leave behind positions as clumsy as the one we may be debating today, which would bring down such an important programme for the economic recovery of the European Union.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President, how can Europeans trust the European Union in this Council, if a few months after the adoption of Horizon 2020 and its budget, trumpeting with pomp and circumstance that it was in fact that it would realise the European Union's commitment to science and innovation with a view to building a development of society, how can you trust now that the ink that has drafted it has not yet dried up and is already including cuts of millions of more than EUR 1 500 million, in the so-called smart growth-inclusive chapter alone. What don't they like? Growth, The Intelligent or the Inclusive?  In fact, it seems to me that it is obvious that the Council has already lost its horizon even before 2020. But if the news of these cuts is bad for the world of research and universities, there is at least good news, it comes from Portugal, the next Commissioner is an expert in blind cuts, strangles universities, strangles research centres and, incidentally, even has a medal of merit for the troika and that is good news for the Council, although it is bad news for researchers.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE). -
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Yesterday, but also before, we devoted a great deal of time in the European Parliament to the debate on subsidising agricultural production, such as peppers and mandarins, but it is not potatoes that win the global economic war today, but modern technologies. The strength of the West today is the modern economy, its innovation and competitiveness. It should therefore be a necessary priority for the European Union to secure the necessary financial resources for research and science and the transfer of knowledge to industry.  The Horizon 2020 budget seems satisfactory, but we are currently discussing spending reductions for next year as well as the whole outlook for 2020. It therefore appears that, in view of the priority objective of Horizon 2020, the previously planned amounts should be maintained, in particular as regards expenditure on the small and medium-sized enterprises sector. Indeed, the knowledge economy is the only chance for the European Union to compete effectively with the United States, Japan, South Korea and other countries of the world.  So Let me repeat: in the 21st century, it is not agriculture that builds competitive advantages, but research, science and industry. Savings, on the other hand, should be sought primarily in administration and bureaucracy, limiting regulation and eliminating EU overregulation. There are billions of euros to be recovered for development. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: the blue card. – Indeed, the Russian embargo on the general diplomacy of the European Union has touched the whole country and sector in a different way. The Baltic states, Poland and Finland were particularly affected. And especially people who live in the village. And it is clear that the funds allocated today for compensation in this area will not be enough, so do you not think that other funds should also contribute?

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the "blue card". – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab There is no doubt that we should look at the European Union budget holistically, horizontally and look for savings opportunities in each fund, but by adopting certain clear and unmistakable priorities. In my opinion, the results of scientific research are undoubtedly a priority ahead of mandarins.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D). -
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Just now, on behalf of the Council, Secretary of State Zanetti has assured us of the Council's great sensitivity to research and development. Well, we do not expect sensitivity, we expect rationality supported by credibility and solidity. Credibility will mean convergence of declarations and decisions, it will mean decisions that confirm that we care about the pillars of the knowledge economy, which are research and development. On the other hand, soundness will mean that we will not allow for structural, cumulative payment arrears, which seriously undermine the trust of a huge group of scientists and very creative entrepreneurs in us; solidity will also mean that we will not artificially delay the deadline for completion of the work. Parliament cannot adopt a decision... (The President received the speaker's vote.)

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL). -
text: The financing of science and research in the European Union confirms the asymmetric and unequal nature of this process, let us see: several countries, as with Portugal, strongly compress their investment in these areas, among other reasons because they have cut themselves in the structural and cohesion funds from which the largest share of the budget to invest in science came from. On the other hand, the research framework programme, Horizon 2020, now strengthened, continues to serve mainly the interests of the major powers and some of their large companies and research units that absorb the bulk of resources. And so much so that these large beneficiaries have the luxury of putting and having the programme budget.  According to their interests, not paying what they owe when they should, while countries like Portugal remain net contributors to the program, i.e. they pay more than they benefit from. It is also here the story of Robin Hood in reverse. This is what this European Union brings to the end of this European Union: taking out the increasingly poor to give to the ever-richer.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE). -
text: Madam President, we want a more innovative, competitive Europe that is growing faster. We want to hire more. We all agree on this, and what do we do and what does this Council proposal bring? We are slowing down investment in growth drivers. We wrongly reduced the pre-financing of projects first in 2013, and the Council now wants to further slow down over 600 projects by reducing allocation for payments. We're postponing projects into the future, and we want growth now. It doesn't work with each other. The budget must not be a promise. And a common scenario is "The Promise of Mad Rejoicing." We must see the budget as our obligation to citizens, scientists, entrepreneurs, young people.  I agree that we must not blame each other, but let's find a solution that is not to give up our obligation to create an innovative and creative Europe where our children and our citizens have a future.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D). -
text: Europe's main problem is to maintain global competitiveness. This can't be achieved without the necessary financial resources.  A decrease in funding for research and innovation is not just a few cuts, as the Council mentioned. There are cuts that lead to job loss and a decrease in the role played by the Council, but also by the governments represented in the Council at the level of global research. We need to understand that the decrease in these funds will not only affect us now, but also for the years to come and the generations to come.  Horizon 2020 is a key project for what we want the European Union to look like in 2020. By doing so, researchers and innovation will bypass Europe, and our projects, the projects that could make our continent a leader in innovation, will disappear. It is important to maintain these amounts for this project, but at the same time I call on the Commission and the Council to make a concrete and transparent assessment of the amounts allocated and the projects financed.

name: Paloma López (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President, the Horizon 2020 programme has the potential to improve the European industrial base and finance important public research in areas of great social interest, provided that it incorporates criteria of territorial cohesion, public service and the democratisation of science into the objectives of research, development and innovation. And yet it also has some negative aspects, such as encouraging the subordination of research to business objectives and abandoning fields such as basic research. Research is also concentrated in few areas, implying a negative redistribution of technological potential between research centres strongly linked to the private sector. This accentuates the competitive disadvantages in the productive structure of each Member State, thereby increasing imbalances between the centre and the periphery. But the most negative aspect we are seeing today is that of the cut announced by the Council for next year compared to 2013. This reduction focuses on health, environment, climate change or Marie Curie programmes, which should be among the priority sectors for funding. This can't happen. These budgets must be invested precisely so that they are not the new scapegoat for austerity in Europe.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD). -
text: Madam President, I have enjoyed this debate. I have enjoyed watching it, as I always do when other Members speak about how they have not got enough money for all the projects that they are trying to do. As someone from the UK, which is a net contributor to this, I would ask you all to consider, when you think about taking more money from us, how people in my country are having to use food banks, how the NHS is struggling, and how people are being thrown out of their council homes. Everybody in the UK has had to tighten their belts. Food banks in the United Kingdom in the 21st century! This is madness, so I ask you: when you make your decisions about your spending programmes and you look for more money, think about the people whose pockets are being picked to fund all this – the people in the United Kingdom who are struggling just like everyone else. Please tighten your belts.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE). -
text: Madam President, rarely have I heard such a clear explanation of the state we are in as in the Commissioner’s speech. Madam Commissioner, I would like to thank you for that clarity today. Then I listened to Mr Etheridge, and his position is also clear. The problem with your position, Mr Etheridge, is that you fail to see that if we pool resources for research, we avoid duplication, and we should get much better results. Your narrow-minded approach unfortunately does a disservice to your constituents, as it does to mine. This debate has failed to acknowledge the importance of European solidarity. That is why we have a European budget. Member States benefit because they are members of the European Union and the money that is contributed, though large in its sum, is insignificant compared with the national budgets. I know we will continue to disagree with my good friend in seat 281, but I think the point is well made. We spend better if we do it collectively.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D). -
text: Horizon 2020 is the centrepiece for the growth of Europe's scientific, technological and industrial competitiveness. It will have strong positive impacts on society, including job creation. The scarcity of appropriations for this programme has to be corrected immediately.  Pre-financing under Horizon 2020 is being allocated, but also ongoing funding under the 7th Framework Programme. And the context of research and scientific production of institutes and universities is being affected and, particularly importantly, it can put into serious difficulties small and medium-sized enterprises for which Horizon 2020 has been very consistent. Expectations have been generated that cannot be betrayed.  I know this situation up close because I've been an investigator for over 30 years. I coordinated and was involved in dozens of European projects. This could affect the sustainability of research and scientific employment in many countries, including the UK. Horizon 2020 was created to ensure sustainable growth pace in the European Union. We cannot defraud society and the necessary budgetary reinforcement will have to be found to meet the needs of the programme.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE). -
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. We have been talking for many years about the fact that the Union is not innovative enough, that it is losing global competition not only with the United States, but even with growing economies. The Lisbon Strategy, which was supposed to make the European Union the most innovative economy in the world, was a complete failure. We have not learned from this failure. The 2020 strategy faces a similar fate, as there is no political will on the part of the Member States to implement it. The best example is Horizon 2020. The European Union's greatest success – the programmes included in this Horizon 2020 programme – was identified as the first to reduce funding after the decision to cut budgets. The new European Commission should focus its efforts on creating a stable legal and financial basis to strengthen the innovation of our European economy in particular.

name: Máire Geoghegan-Quinn
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, I have listened very carefully to what the Members of the House have had to say in the course of this debate, and you will not be surprised to hear that I agree with many of the remarks that you have made. The structural shortage of payments which affects Horizon 2020 should be of concern to all of us, and I definitely hear that concern here today. I am heartened by all of your comments. I have also taken good note of the position of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy on the 2015 EU budget as they expressed it in their vote on 2 September 2014. It is appropriate that, in the week when we meet and have this discussion, the world university rankings have just been published. These show that we have two European Union universities joint second in the world ranking: Cambridge and Imperial College. Both institutions benefit substantially from EU research funding. When we talked about Horizon 2020 and putting the programme together, we worked with the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy to ensure that it meant exactly what Mrs McGuiness talked about: collaboration, getting rid of duplication, and ensuring that the best of European researchers work together with companies, the private sector, SMEs to ensure that we get this synergy going and that we ensure European subsidiarity. Companies like Jaguar Land Rover which also benefit and are present – very present – in the framework programmes were very supportive of what we were trying to do in relation to simplification and other elements of Horizon 2020. We need the budget that the Commission has asked for in order that we can roll out Horizon 2020. I count, therefore, on the continued active support of the whole Parliament in addressing the payment shortage issue. For that reason, I would repeat once again my call at the beginning of this debate for adoption, without modification, of the Commission’s proposal for Draft Amending Budget No 3 to the 2014 budget and of course the draft EU budget for 2015.  If you would permit a last word, Madam President, in what I expect to be the final time that I get the opportunity to address the plenary session before leaving office., I can only say that it has been a great honour, a privilege and indeed a pleasure to work with all of you in this Parliament during my mandate as European Commissioner for Research, Innovation and Science. I am confident that, with the support and collaboration of my successor, you will continue in this Parliament to be champions of the research and innovation agenda throughout this parliamentary term. Guím rath ar bhur gcuid oibre agus guím rath ar an bhfear atá ag teacht mar chomharba orm agus tá súil agam go leanfaidh sé leis an gcomhoibriú dlúth a bhí idir an Coimisiún agus an Pharlaimint.

name: Enrico Zanetti
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I too have listened carefully to all the speeches in this debate and, focusing on the specific aspect of the Horizon 2020 programme, I would once again point out the centrality of this issue, which will certainly also be useful in the further negotiations on the budget. However, I think it is important to stress that we cannot talk about this position of the Council as a position of cuts. This is a position which, as I have already said when I speak in a broader sense about the budget, leads to a consolidation of positions on certain headings of expenditure – for example, item 1b on cohesion, in respect of which, moreover, the Council's position has led to zero proposals for reductions in commitments and just two hundred and twenty million in terms of payments. , out of a total context of over fifty-one billion, and it is a budget in which other headings of expenditure, starting with the one we are dealing with in this debate, still see the Council's position confirmed as significantly growing compared with the previous year. It is a fact that a comparison in the passage in the approval of a new budget must necessarily be made in relation to the last one that was approved, a situation which, as I said earlier, also sees the Council adopting a position which, not only is not at all pejorative, but rather significantly improving compared to the 2014 budget currently in force, but is also absolutely capable of confirming what is currently under discussion in relation to 2014 I am talking about the Commission's expectations, so I am talking about amending measures on which the Council will soon be expressing its opinion. Having said that, I would like to thank Parliament and all the Members who have spoken for their contributions, and I am sure that our Presidency, just as it has managed to find a synthesis, not trivial at this historic stage, in the Council, will also be able to work alongside Parliament and the Commission to get to the bottom of the budget negotiations.

name: Elnök asszony. -
text: The debate is over. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. – Horizon 2020 means research and innovation, economic development and, by implication, job creation. Unfortunately, in Romania only 2% of the amounts allocated to the previous research and innovation framework programme (FP7) could be accessed in the period 2007-2013.  However, there are many initiatives that start from the bottom up and for which Horizon 2020 is a real opportunity. Universities, research centres, IT clusters are just a few examples of entities in their region that have started innovative projects and could benefit from funding from research and innovation programmes. A technology cluster in Cluj-Napoca, started with the support of the right-wing government, brought together 32 IT firms under the same umbrella, starting 500 million euro projects with a hiring potential of 20,000 employees for the next 15 years. Currently, the revenues obtained amount to EUR 100 million, of which more than 85 million are from exports.  I regret that Council representatives do not understand the importance of support for such initiatives and propose drastic reductions in payments for research and innovation. I call on the Council, together with the Commission, to find solutions to avoid massive cuts in this programme.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. – Horizon 2020 is a project for the future. It is not only about the future of the Union and the Member States, but also about the future of the younger generations who must contribute to the continuation of the European project. The priority is investment, and all partners - the EU and the Member States - must cooperate so that investment in research and innovation contributes to the achievement of the Union's objectives in this area and, by implication, to the increase in the number of jobs.  In the previous budget year, more than EUR 23 billion of unpaid invoices were accumulated in a number of programmes, which will make it difficult to achieve the Union's objectives in those areas. It is desirable for the European Executive, together with the Member States, to find solutions to make such situations less frequent or even repeated, and in cases where a number of funds are not used, there is the possibility that they can be reallocated to investment in research and innovation.

name: Barbara Kudrycka (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Horizon 2020 was created from the concept of improving economic growth and job creation. It was created with the future in mind. The cuts will mean that we will not be able to fully meet the europe 2020 targets or horizon 2020 priorities. 10% cuts to research will not allow hundreds of new projects to be carried out by thousands of scholars. Nor can we allow a situation in which there are delays in disbursing funds or we are unable to pay for the commitments made at all – this undermines the credibility of the programme, the Commission and the European Union as a whole as an institution. Let us remember that this is a programme that runs from 2014 to 2020, that is, it has just started and needs to be given a chance. I believe that the planned almost EUR 80 billion for this programme is a good investment, and without further substantial investment in research, development, science and innovation, we will not be able to exploit the potential of Europeans.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE)
text: in writing. – The shortfall in payments in the European Union budget is increasing from one year to the next. Important projects with European funding cannot be completed. This occurs when most European leaders talk about the requirement to increase investment in order to create jobs and boost economic growth. That is why I believe that the governments of the Member States have a duty to finance this short-to-see deficit of payments and to abandon the transfer of bad national habits to the European Union level, namely to approve investment programmes and other actions without secured financing.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing – Many times it can be heard in various places that Europe is small and its competitiveness on a global scale is not growing as needed to keep pace with others. That is why we must gain a comparative advantage over the rest of the world by investing in the future of Europe. Invest in science, invest in research, invest in the development of European potential. At a time when some firms in Europe are struggling to survive and are unable to finance research projects, it is the EU that needs to kick-start their activities. In my opinion, Horizon 2020 is not only a step in the right direction, but above all a step necessary to ensure the EU's prosperity. The amount envisaged by the EU for Horizon 2020 is not insignifiable in the budget, but it is also not infinite. The spending must therefore be targeted, proportionate and transparent. In no case may they be abused.

text: Next point is the Commission statement - Digitised Single Market (2014/2840(RSP))

name: Michel Barnier
text: Vice-President of the Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased to meet you and first thank three of you, on behalf of the EPP Group: Andreas Schwab, Burkhard Balz and Kri-j-nis Kari's for their initiative to put this subject on the digital agenda, the digital single market on the agenda of your plenary session. Fortunately, the free movement of goods and services encounters fewer and fewer technical obstacles, making the persistence of legal, sometimes fiscal or political obstacles all the less understandable. These obstacles are even less comprehensible when this digital single market also has, and probably first of all, an economic, social and human dimension.  The digital economy generates 2.6 jobs for jobs lost in more traditional sectors. There are many opportunities in big data, cloud or connected objects. This important potential of the digital single market, we must exploit it. Just two figures, ladies and gentlemen. If we increase broadband usage by an additional 10%, we gain one more point of GDP. If e-commerce, e-commerce accounted for 15% of trade within the single market, instead of today's 5%, an additional 1.7% growth would be gained. We need to look for growth where it is. Right now, it is an emergency for citizens. And to do that, we need to establish a proactive regulatory framework.  Thanks to the commitment of your Parliament over the past five years, significant progress has been made. Do not count on me to be complacent, there is so much work waiting for the future Commission and waiting for you. I just want to make very specific reminders around three main areas of work: the ambition of our European Digital Strategy, the collective momentum given with the decisive support of your Parliament - Andreas Schwab knows this - on the Single Market Act I and II, and finally, the targeted nature of the action plan for trade and online services. I would like to telegraphly to remind us where we are today. First, telecommunications. The digital economy must be able to rely on a strong single telecoms market, promoting fair competition, reducing costs for consumers and developing new services that also attract private investment.  The regulation that we proposed in September 2013, under the leadership of Neelie Kroes, and of which your colleague, Mrs Pilar del Castillo is rapporteur, aims to bring the telecommunications sector really into the era of the internet and the internal market. The aim is to encourage operators to invest, to design new business models to integrate the twenty-eight national markets, which have so far often been juxtaposed next to each other, in a single market.  This regulation will make it easier to have more consistent rules for spectrum allocation and, as you have hoped, to end roaming charges, roaming charges, voice, text and data by the end of 2015. It will also set out the principles of net neutrality, which must both strengthen consumer protection measures for which Internet access must not be blocked or limited - neither blocked nor throttled - and develop innovative telecommunications tools for business users. I hope that an agreement will be reached quickly between your Parliament and the Council on this important package.  Since I am talking about net neutrality, I would just like to say a few words about the issue of your resolution on net neutrality. The Commission is, of course, very committed to ensuring that the internet operates in an open, non-discriminatory manner in all its dimensions, including search engines which have become, as we well know, an important tool for all users, consumers and service providers and many others. With regard to the Google investigation to which you clearly refer in your resolution, frankly, I will not add anything and will not comment on the information that has already been provided to you by my colleague Joaquin Almunia, who is in charge of this case. I think it is important for the European Parliament to be concerned about this subject, which in many respects affects very closely the functioning of our society, but an investigation is under way.
