The Directorate General of Competition, as always, does its job independently and in accordance with the rules and procedures in place, including listening to and responding to all complainants. That is all I can say about that. Second major project: services Online. In recent years, we have also acted with ambition to develop a diversified range of online services within the single market. The January 2012 e-commerce communication had identified three priorities often supported by your assembly.  First priority is to develop the legal and cross-border offer of online products and services. This is the aim of the guidelines on the implementation of Article 20 of the Services Directive adopted in June 2012, which will eliminate discriminatory requirements based on the nationality or place of residence of the recipient of services. The Commission has shown again this summer - and I have made sure - that we are determined to enforce these rules. For example, I reminded car rental companies that they had to respect the rules of the internal market and fight against price differences depending on the country of online booking.  The second priority is to improve operator information and consumer protection. This is the purpose of the agreement reached in April 2013 on the online settlement of consumer disputes, which should help to strengthen confidence in online purchases. Finally, there are the payment services, of which your colleague Antonio Tajani is responsible for rapporteur, and reliable and efficient delivery, which is in particular the objective of our December 2013 roadmap for improving the delivery of parcels within the single market. I met at length last week with all the presidents of the European postal operators who have committed to concrete results for the summer of 2015, so in a very short time, on the availability, quality and accessibility of parcel delivery solutions. With regard to payments, I proposed in July 2013 the revision of the Payment Services Directive, for which your colleague Pablo Zalba is responsible, and a regulation on interchange fees. I trust Parliament to reach an agreement there in the next few months, perhaps even before the end of my mandate.  Third project: copyright. For the past five years, I have been leading, with the support of President Barroso, a programme of reforms based on a common objective and method. Copyright, which is so important, must live with its time. Now, the time today is the time of the internet and the time of the single market. We must also, and at the same time, take into account the interests at stake and the great diversity in the positions of the Member States and the different operators and proceed in stages, without ideology, on the basis of solid analysis and evidence.  I think, ladies and gentlemen, that this pragmatic approach has been the right one. I take as proof the results we have achieved together: the adoption by the co-legislators of two pieces of legislation, namely the Orphan Works Directive, for which Lidia Geringer of Oedenberg is responsible, and the Directive on Collective Copyright Management, which owes so much to your former colleague, Marielle Gallo, adopted in February 2014 with the almost unanimous support of Parliament and the Council. In addition to these two texts, we can cite the signing of two international treaties, one of which on access to cultural content to whom I have paid great attention, like you: this is the Marrakesh agreement, which has occupied us a lot. Thank you again for your support for this initiative, as well as other non-legislative initiatives. Those are the achievements.  We have also opened the work of reforming the European framework for copyright. Just a word of the very intense work that has been done on this delicate subject: in addition to economic and legal analyses, dialogue with all stakeholders, the positive exercise on licensing for Europe - Licensing Europe - we launched a public consultation in early 2014. Nearly ten thousand citizens, industry actors, companies and public authorities have responded and highlighted, through this consultation, three key questions that a future reform should take into account. The development of supply throughout the single market, for example by removing barriers faced by consumers, citizens who wish to access video-on-demand services existing in non-Member States than their own.  Second, the link between copyright and new digital uses. I am thinking, for example, of the problems related to user generated content or what is called text and data mining. Third, the functioning of the market and the balance of the value chain, ensuring fair remuneration for authors and creators, while encouraging the emergence of new offerings and services.  On all of these issues, we have conducted intense discussions within and outside the Commission. For reasons related to the timetable, at the end of our mandate, I think it will be difficult now to move forward one step further, with the adoption of this white paper, as we would have liked. Nor am I prepared to distort the balance of work that we have done. I do not think, as some do, that copyright should be detracted from in order to create growth in Europe. On the contrary, I am convinced that the remuneration of investment in innovation, creation, the work of creators, including journalists and many others, and the development of the digital single market go together. We must find a common path to reconcile these two dimensions. It is regrettable that there is no white paper at this stage. I am convinced that all the preparation, consultation and drafting work, which I have just summarily recalled, will remain useful for the future initiatives of the new European Commission.  Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, telecommunications, online services, copyright, in these three areas we have made concrete progress in serving consumers and businesses.  I would also like to say a word - finally - of three other important successes for the Digital Single Market. The data protection regulation, carried by my former colleague and your new colleague Viviane Reding and today by your rapporteur Jan Philipp Albrecht, is another key issue of trust in digital technology. New provisions will make it easier for citizens to control their personal data, to better protect it, and for businesses to work more easily across borders.    The second topic is dematerialisation, the digitalisation of public procurement and the directive on electronic billing, of which Birgit Collin-Langen is rapporteur. I would like to remind you, since there is a lot of talk about jobs and growth, that if we achieve a real digitalisation of public order, ladies and gentlemen, which accounts for 18% of European GDP - 18%! If we can achieve, with the reform of public procurement and the concessions that I have proposed and which have been adopted, electronic billing and electronic signature, e-authentication, we could save every year by this simple digitalisation, which is at our fingertips, between 50 and 70 billion euros. We have to look for those savings and direct that money to other, more productive investments. Then, thirdly, we opened up the cyber security project, which Andreas Schwab is well aware of, by strengthening cooperation between Member States to deal with threats, which is a condition for the development of the digital economy and in particular to facilitate the use of secure online services between citizens, businesses and public services. At the time of all these espionage cases, I can say, as Commissioner, Vice-President of the Commission or as a citizen, that it is urgent that we all find or build together the tools of our strategic autonomy. All of this is part of it. On the basis of these achievements, we must continue our efforts, it is a reality. Technical progress has always been one step ahead of politics. It must be acknowledged that many obstacles still remain to build this true digital single market. To cite just one figure from the digital strategy dashboard, only 14% of European small and medium-sized enterprises trade online. Only 14%! This figure, moreover, has stagnated for four years and remains far from the target we set for 33%.  We need to create this digital single market, give these companies a broad business base, equivalent to that enjoyed by American companies in their own market. This will allow us to build on this foundation to succeed in creating growth in globalization. To achieve these goals, we must continue to remove obstacles one by one. We identified a lot of them with you in the Single Market Act I and II. We must go further by developing a comprehensive, comprehensive and comprehensive approach, which involves networks with the best global standards, a level playing field to enable the emergence and development of innovative and competitive European players and a comprehensive plan to adapt the skills of Europeans to the jobs of tomorrow. We must also rethink our governance, the commitment of all stakeholders by improving policy coherence, for example, copyright, taxation, data protection, competition, industrial policies. It all works together. and, from this point of view, the new functioning of the Commission, with its groups of Commissioners and Vice-Presidents, should allow for better coherence between all these subjects that work together - also by forming a grand coalition to promote the digital single market, using the newly created and I listen to structures, Founders Forum, Startup Europe, European Cloud Partnership , CEO networks. I believe that the single market is a great unifying project, which must remain a collective project led by the Commission, by you and by the Council, with pragmatism, without ideology and voluntarily. I simply hope, ladies and gentlemen, Madam President - as I have done in the field of financial regulation, by rebuilding with you the foundations of financial stability, which is the precondition for any growth and competitiveness initiative - than what we have done with my colleagues over the last five years on this digital issue. , is the basis on which the new Commission can now give new impetus, with the support, always, of your Parliament.

name: Andreas Schwab
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Mr Vice-President, Michel Barnier, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. It is good for us that, after five years, when we in the European Parliament have been able to work very closely with the current Vice-President of the European Commission on the issue of the Digital Single Market, today, after a long election campaign in which Commission President-designate Jean-Claude Juncker has proclaimed the Digital Single Market as one of the priorities for the new Commission, we can once again discuss what has been achieved and discuss the issues. , which are still separating us from the real completion of this digital single market. Unfortunately, I have only two minutes left, and that is why I would like to make it very brief in general: I believe that, in principle, we have two essential issues before us which will concern us in the coming years. I therefore regret to some extent that it was not possible today to debate a motion for a resolution and to adopt it tomorrow. But we can also talk about the content orally. The Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, for whom I am the first to speak, has always supported the completion of this digital internal market in the last few years by a very majority and very broadly – beyond the Committee on the Internal Market alone. I believe that we can say today that there are still major problems ahead of us in two places. On the one hand, we need more uniform rules, and this will only succeed – the Council has already left – if the Member States are able to broaden this egocentric approach to the preservation of their own rules and can work on it and want to work on creating more uniform rules in Europe. In this way, we are creating new growth, thereby strengthening small and medium-sized enterprises, thereby also creating opportunities for new employment – especially in the countries that currently have economic problems. Secondly, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that it is a question of creating a level playing field in which small, medium-sized and large companies, wherever they come from, have a fair market entry. I am pleased that the European Commission extended its investigation into a major search engine operator last week. I believe that in the end it is a question of finding a good solution and not necessarily a quick shot. Unfortunately, however, this is, of course, a difficult and long time, and we finally need clear regulation for small and medium-sized enterprises in Europe as well. This is the only way that innovative European companies can have a long-term chance.  I do not know whether six months will be enough for the programme that Jean-Claude Juncker has spent. It is an ambitious timetable. However, we in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats want to do everything we can to ensure that this programme succeeds, because it not only entails clear rules, but also real opportunities for new growth.

name: Evelyne Gebhardt
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We Social Democrats have also said time and again that the digital single market is a very important area of European policy. It is also extremely important because the digital market is becoming more and more and more enamoured. It is becoming increasingly important that we ensure that clear rules are also created in this area – clear rules that also give our citizens legal certainty, and, in addition to the citizens, consumers, workers in this area, and, of course, businesses. Because where there is legal certainty, there is also good cooperation. It is particularly important in this area, which concerns so many areas of life – all areas of life in fact – that we define a holistic approach and an ambitious strategy. This is extremely important. We have just heard that there are many examples in which this digital market also plays a role. To give just a few examples: payment transactions, accounting, public procurement law, e-commerce, online dispute resolution, telecommunications and so on, and so on. There are a lot of areas that go into this area. That is why it is also very important that we pursue a sensible European policy in this area. And that affects a great many areas, as I have already said. One of the highest priorities for our group is, of course, net neutrality in the area of the Internet. That must be the ultimate objective, because that is the guarantee that there will also be justice in this area. It is also very important that we also achieve neutrality in search engines in this area, including in other areas – as Mr Barnier has just mentioned with regard to Google. After all, this is an over-pre-emption of consumers, if e-commerce is supposed to be 'yes, we want to serve you as well as possible and respond to you' then there is actually a paternalism of the citizens. That is not what we want. We also want small and medium-sized enterprises to have a chance, and not just the very big ones, who can put a great deal of money into their hands in order to get the right place. These are the issues that we need to address. We must also address issues that raise ethical issues. This is because areas such as medicine, healthcare and others are also increasingly being involved in this area of the digital market. Here, too, we need to think very carefully about how we want to achieve this. Data protection, copyright and others are just as many issues that we need to address. Unfortunately, I do not have the time to do this even longer. We have a very big task ahead of us here. It is good that we are tackling them.

name: Vicky Ford
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, the digital economy is no longer a subset of economic activity. Today every market has digital elements, and Europe’s single market must not be left behind. Unlocking the opportunities of the digital world is crucial to delivering jobs and growth. In the G20, the internet economy is set to grow by eight per cent every year for the next five years. It is racing ahead of traditional sectors. But what do we mean by the digital single market, and what work do we need to do to achieve it? In e-commerce alone we could save our consumers EUR 60 billion a year as a result of lower prices and EUR 95 billion as a result of having more choices, but there is a lot of work for us to do. We need to reduce burdens on establishing new businesses, cut costs in our payment and settlement systems, and remove barriers which prevent the physical delivery of goods ordered online. Consumer confidence is vital. Buyers and sellers need to be sure that their rights and protections are no less than those afforded them in their traditional markets. Then there is fraud prevention, licences, copyright, logistics – issues which all need to be addressed. We must work with businesses and consumers to make sure that all legislation across the board is properly evaluated, impact-assessed and then future-proofed for the digital age.  The competition issues are also complex. Our laws must prevent abuse by market dominators, but must also strike the right balance between traditional operators and over-the-top players and ensure that the new peer-to-peer models are not blocked by incumbents.  But it is not just about e-commerce. If we want to get the best out of e-government, e-health and e-procurement, we need ICT systems which talk to each other. This is why finding solutions on interoperability is also on this Parliament’s agenda. Data are another priority, and remember that big data bring big benefits, not only economically, but to society in sectors like personalised medicines and health. Yes, we do need a data protection package but it needs to be one that is not only pro-individuals, but also pro-business and pro-innovation. I support a transparent approach to data, respecting privacy, but also staying open. To be able to share data, we also need to have confidence that they will not be misused, hence the work that some of our colleagues are doing on network security. Here Member States need to be able to cooperate in the fight against cybercrime. However, we must not stop individual countries from being able to take really rapid action to protect critical services. Last, but by no means least, there is the issue of inclusion. As we race to embrace a digital world, we must not leave parts of our communities – like rural communities – behind. Infrastructure is essential, both to reach our remotest areas, and to provide the deep coverage we need in cities. Different Member States are finding different solutions to deliver this digital access and to improve digital skills. There is no ‘one size fits all’, but we can do more to share best practices. Parliament colleagues, our Council and national leaders and our new Commissioners, we need to work together to get the right priorities and set them now. The digital world can bring us great benefits and we need to grasp them, because if we get this wrong, we will not get the chance again, and we will all live to regret it.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, on behalf of the ALDE Group, I am here to say that, for us, the digital market is not a future project: it is here today. It is already affecting all economic sectors and their value chains. This is the biggest challenge to the economy and employment. However, today the digital market is not a single one in Europe. It is broken up into 28 national markets, each defended by outdated protectionist policies and regulations. We must eliminate these barriers and we must modernise and simplify rules for online and digital transactions. National rules do not work when a business or consumer pays more for physical goods because his IP address is in Berlin instead of Prague. National rules do not work for digital goods or services especially where there is no logical or physical reason to block the free exchange and free movement of those goods. But today we have 28 different online rule books. We need harmonised rules, where appropriate, and increased mutual recognition on access to digital goods and services. A Czech should be able to buy music from France without hitting the firewall of obsolete copyright and data protection laws. We also need a clear European framework for the digital market on consumer and contract law. Without it, how can all European citizens trust that they are being treated equally? How can our SMEs truly work across borders? The digital single market must not be merely a goal on paper. It is a policy that every young European can understand. It is the way to show the value of the European project to our businesses and our economy.

name: Jan Philipp Albrecht
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Perhaps I am the one who pours a little bit of water into the wine – in connection with what has just been said. We are talking about the Digital Single Market, but we are far from doing so. We are working on it and we have to work on it, but there are difficulties. For I can already see that the situation is today, particularly in the areas of data protection.B or net neutrality, that companies that come to the European market from outside can choose which of the 28 legal systems they want to follow, and thus have a massive advantage over companies that are already in one of these 28 jurisdictions and want to sell their products and services to the other 28 countries. This is a problem for businesses in Europe. And it makes it a massive competitive disadvantage compared to those particularly .B from Silicon Valley, which are relatively unregulated in this market. But to conclude from this that we need to follow the Silicon Valley model and simply abolish or lower the rules, which I think is the wrong way to go. We are already losing the confidence of citizens, consumers, in our market. For we consumers are also concerned: in 90% of cases where my data are processed, European data protection law no longer applies. I can't trust that my data will be processed properly. In many cases, when it comes to IT security, cyber security is open to companies – everyone can go in there. It's so easy to get into the most sensitive systems - we basically don't have standards. We have to tackle this, and that also means making uncomfortable demands, to say that such a standard applies to everyone, that it cannot be lowered. Rather, we need a high standard in which people can trust, in terms of data protection, net neutrality and IT security and all the issues we are discussing. We must have this courage, including towards the Member States. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Richard Sulík (ALDE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". – You said that companies are now coming from abroad and can choose the country where the legal system suits them best, and that should be a disadvantage for European companies. But they can also choose any country where they want to be. On the one hand, I understand the common standards, but we do not have to overstate them. My question is: why is it a disadvantage for you when a company chooses a country? It is good for a COMPANY from the USA to choose which country suits it best.

name: Jan Philipp Albrecht (Verts/ALE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Thank you for your question! It is right that we are talking about this. After all, the answer actually leads us to what happens when everyone in the European Union basically chooses the standard that offers the lowest level of protection for consumers, so to speak. We see this trend. Then it is the lowest standard that applies. Then we can agree that this is the standard throughout Europe, and we do not have to ensure that 28 countries have different rules and that everyone gets used to it. However, I say to you: this is not accepted by consumers! They will turn away from this common market and will then decide to close their border again. Then we will no longer have an internal market, but then we will have 28 different markets in Europe. I don't think we all want that.

name: David Borrelli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, at a time of crisis such as this, it is right that the completion of the digital single market and the European agenda should be at the heart of Europe's initiatives and decisions, but we must be sure that it is the ordinary citizens in particular who benefit from the completion of the digital single market.  More investment must be made in the training of young people so that they are ready to enter a completely restructured labour market in the future. The digital economy is growing seven times more than the traditional economy and could give a decisive boost to get out of the crisis. However, Europe needs physical infrastructure first and foremost. In Italy, many homes have not yet reached broadband, which is well below the European average. It's time to start building these networks. The specific nature of the individual Member States is right to be protected. So what is the Commission's plan in the long term? The Italian Government has repeatedly stated, also on the occasion of the Digital Venice in July, that completing the process relating to the Connected Continent package, and therefore to the completion of the digital single market, is at the heart of the European Presidency. Now it would seem that everything is quite on the high seas. What is the Commission's view of the progress of this dossier and what is the real timetable? What will become of the progress made on net neutrality, which are in that package? I believe it is essential not to back down on this crucial aspect in order to guarantee free and equal access to knowledge for all, without discrimination, restrictions or interference.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Jean-Claude Juncker has made the digital single market his number one priority, which is not reassuring when we think, as I do, that he is the man of international banks and financial lobbies.  His project is a trap for citizens. It is based on an amalgamation and false promises. The amalgam is to artificially link the digital single market to net neutrality when these are two different things.  Net neutrality must be sought and protected because it guarantees the free access of all citizens, even the most modest, to the digital network. It is a shield against the will of some large companies to establish an access priority for those who are able to pay it a high price.  As I speak, the powerful GSMA association, which brings together mobile operators, is lobbying hard to bring down net neutrality. Will the Commission and the European Parliament be able to resist it? Nothing is less certain because the United States does not want net neutrality. However, the European Union usually ends up ceding to them.  False promises are about reforesting the future market with almost miraculous virtues. In its resolution of 4 July 2013, the European Parliament says it will bring 800 billion euros to the European economy, but a year later Mr Juncker lowers this forecast to 500 billion euros. How can we believe such fanciful assessments?  The same authorities assure us that the future market will benefit small and medium-sized enterprises and create 4,400,000 jobs by 2016. On the contrary, I believe that it will destroy businesses and jobs, especially in my country, France, by adding digital social dumping to the social dumping that already exists. In reality, this future market is a war machine against the sovereignty of states. With this project, the European Union is once again seeking to remove national protections which it equates to obstacles, without wanting to understand that free competition is not a goal in itself.

name: Monika Hohlmeier (PPE). -
text: Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues! First of all, I can only strongly support the idea that we are also using the European Digital Agenda as a matter of priority to make small businesses, medium-sized enterprises, competitive companies on the world market and to promote them there in such a way that they can be successful in the future. Secondly, however, it is also important to put the so-called monopolists, whether they are search engines or of any other kind, in the way of curbing them and reminding them, even if they are outside the European Union, that they must abide by European rules. The question is whether consumers can be made aware of 28 different standards in 28 different countries. But I don't think so. Because I do not know anything in Ireland, the Irish not in Germany, the French not in the United Kingdom – how can the consumer develop any security in an international digital market? However, we must ensure that those who, for example.B, suddenly turn private data into public data through seemingly innocuous changes to the general terms and conditions, and suddenly claim millions of data and addresses for themselves and not for the purposes for which they originally obtained it. People expect us to do data protection in an adequate way without simultaneously overburdening every micro-enterprise with the same data protection rules that we place on companies that have billions of dollars in data and use it accordingly. I have the impression that, according to the monopolists, we are still very timid towards the monopolists and we need to put them in a pretty clear position, otherwise a digital agenda will not be successful, because the monopolists do not abide by competition rules. That is why we need to change the rules of competition.

name: Dan Nica (S&D). -
text: Thank you, Madam President. Efficient digital single market cannot exist without reliable and high-speed infrastructure. A functioning digital single market needs connected European citizens all over Europe, but unfortunately the reality shows that Europe has fallen behind in the development of 4G networks.  Unfortunately, according to the Commission's latest data on high-speed broadband, only a small proportion of European households have a subscription of more than 100 Mbps. Recall that the objectives of the Digital Agenda 2020 are 30 Mbps for all citizens of the European Union and that at least 50% of European households have internet connections of more than 100 Mbps by 2020. What can the Union do to keep all its citizens connected, wherever it lives, so that we have a real digital society? With regard to the ongoing negotiations, I would like to ask the Commission what timetable it provides for the completion of the Telecom Package, because the Council is still very divided. I stress that the S&D Group will strongly defend the European Parliament's first reading position, especially with regard to roaming, consumer protection and net neutrality.  Even if the Member States are very reluctant, increased harmonisation of spectrum, combined with the application of common principles for spectrum rights within the European Union, is a key remedy for addressing the problem of lack of predictability in terms of spectrum availability. This would allow the innovative use of wireless broadband, while protecting emission times and preventing interference.  Regarding 5G: what is the current state of 5G development and in particular the public-private 5G partnership launched by the Commission to provide solutions, architectures, technologies, standards for state-of-the-art communications infrastructures over the past decade? What can the European Union do to avoid 4G mistakes and delays in Europe?

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR). -
text: Commissioner, Madam President, last year the European Parliament has had a very intensive debate on the digital single market, which included our vote on roaming in April. The digital market has huge economic potential and at the same time has a secondary impact on the development of many sectors. Various studies predict its growth opportunities for the future. We know that the Digital Single Market still encounters many barriers. The reality is the diversity of conditions in Member States, which have their logical historical reasons, but are often built on purposeful barriers protecting the commercial interests of different companies. In general, therefore, I can only welcome the European Commission's announced ambition to complete the Digital Single Market. But this also has its pitfalls, we must not overregulate the market. It can increase the financial burden on businesses in the digital market, and further investment could be hampered by excessive legislative ambition.  Also, when we talk about the Digital Single Market, we need to recall again some aspects that are a prerequisite for its successful functioning. This includes broadband infrastructure, data security including the cloud, digital network protection, as well as stimulating innovation and new technologies.

name: Morten Helveg Petersen (ALDE). -
text: Madam President! I would like to start by thanking the outgoing Commission, Commissioner Barnier and Commissioner Kroos for the great work that has been done over the past few years and for all the progress that has been made - indeed has been made - in the digital field. At the same time, I would like to draw attention to some of the challenges that have also been outlined here in the discussion so far, and to the challenges we need to take very seriously if we want to realise the vision of a true digital single market. The benefits of a digital single market are huge. This is something that citizens can feel very directly, and an example of an area where strong European cooperation makes an important difference. But the challenges are many. Overall, we must ensure a fair and fair rules across the EU. There needs to be a greater correlation between where digital services are consumed and their taxation. The Commission must ensure that Member States implement the rules uniformly, because digital knows no borders. If we do not have rules within the European Union that companies outside the EU must also comply with, yes, then companies are looking where the rules and, above all, the enforcement of the rules are relaxed. Europeans must be able to feel safe online. We need to get a new data protection regulation through. It must give European companies opportunities to compete, while at the same time making consumers feel safe. The discussion on online surveillance after the Snowden case clearly shows that we have not yet found our legs to stand on in the European Union. We need to have open standards in software policy so that neither users nor companies get caught up in proprietary formats. We need interoperability so that citizens can take their data with them unhindered when the data is in the cloud. A common European e-label may be needed to strengthen cross-border trade and, finally, we must of course continue the fight against tele roaming. Enhanced cooperation between telecommunications authorities can bring tangible benefits to consumers. We look forward to good and constructive cooperation, including with the new Commission. Thanks.

name: Michel Reimon (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which A great deal of right and good things have already been said by most groups. Having only one minute, I would like to add a point that has been neglected for me. There has been a great deal of talk about opportunities for businesses, very little about what the common digital market means for citizens, for voters. We are talking here about an infrastructure of the 21st century that is important in terms of democracy– perhaps the most important one. We should make a massive following that we create an infrastructure here that is relevant to democracy policy and that stands up to it. This concerns net neutrality, and search neutrality. It is not just a question of giving companies equal access to search results, it is also about regulating or not regulating the information of our population, depending on how the laws are adopted. Citizens' rights, citizens' rights are an essential part of this issue and must, from Parliament's point of view, be at the heart of our intentions.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, my party is in favour of free trade and free markets, but we have serious reservations about the digital single market. It will be a managed market, not a free market; it will be geographically restricted; it will be an over-regulated market which is inimical to growth, to employment and to innovation. Rather than seeing the dead hand of the Commission setting the rules, we would rather see nations, states and industry working together to achieve interoperability and mutual recognition. We would rather see organic convergence of regulatory systems than centrally imposed solutions. We are struck by the irony of the Commission’s claim that its plans will create thousands of new jobs, because our experience is that EU rules usually have the opposite effect. Nor are we convinced that a digital single market will enable Europe to become a leader in the creative industries, as the Commission claims. That depends on creating content that paying customers wish to buy, not on delivery mechanisms. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari (S&D)
text: blue card question. – You, the previous speaker, warned very much about the dangers of regulation, even though the problem with the digital market is that they are not regulated, there are no ethical rules, and that has led to a great monopolisation in the world, and European companies have been left behind. The advantage of the digital market, which in principle allows small businesses to flourish properly, has led to monopolisation. Don't you think we need regulation here?

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – The short answer to your question is ‘no’. What we find is that, in the IT sector, large companies come and go. The history of the IT sector is very clear in that respect and there are opportunities for both large companies and small companies. We seem to have forgotten that Europe exists as part of a wider world. Yes, we can buy stuff from other European Member States on the Internet but we can also buy stuff from the other side of the world if we choose to – and, frankly, setting up our own controls and our little own barriers in Europe is simply ignoring the direction in which the world as a whole is going.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE). -
text: When my father was a young child, people basically moved with the help of horses. He has told me as a boy – he had a 2-day trip to Riga, to the capital, about 110 km away. In the short term, we are thinking about how the world has changed – not only can we call anyone in the world by mobile phones today, wander around the world by means of the Internet, we also did not find today, here in plenary, neither the surprising nor the technologically exciting fact that there was a live broadcast between the European Parliament and the Ukrainian Parliament in the process of ratifying the Cooperation Treaty between the European Union and Ukraine. Its difficulty is that while technology is fast going forward, our legislation is very lagging behind. And this so-called digital market, which has enormous economic potential, is still very squabbled, we have a great many obstacles to the good and normal functioning of this market. For example, we have big questions about consumer protection. We have unclear data protection. We have an even more unclear issue of copyright – what is happening between Member States. And that means that we need to continue our work rapidly by supporting the Commission in freeing up this digital single market. Because here is the key, if we talk about how we can get economic growth in Europe, that is, by opening up this digital market to the single market. We need to break down existing barriers.

name: Jörg Leichtfried (S&D). -
text: Mr. President, esteemed colleagues! Sometimes it happens in this House – and now I think it is such a time – when we have discussions – if you listen to them, if you understand something about the subject matter, you know what it is about, if you are a normal citizen, you sometimes think: what exactly do they discuss, what is the term digital economy, what is happening there?  We also need to talk about this in order to be able to assess the consequences. A colleague mentioned high-speed Internet. Yes, these are all things that are at stake now. But there is much, much more at stake. I recently read a study by one of the big companies in this area, and they talk about the fact that in the future there should be toothbrushes that report when brushing their teeth when something is broken, and immediately make an appointment with the dentist, that there should be refrigerators that refill themselves and think about what the owner wants, that there should be espresso machines that match their function with the calendar and then make a strong espresso when a bunch of appointments.  That is what we are talking about in the future. When we have such a situation, I believe that there is a core element of this digital economy, and that is data protection. As in the past, when our predecessors fought for the secrecy of letters, it is now time to ensure that all the sensitive data at stake is kept carefully, that it cannot be misused. This must become a central element of this digital economy.  A colleague from the top right said that we have to weigh up this, and we have to see whether it is not also a question of the interests of the economy. No, data protection takes this area before all other interests, including economic interests. It is not acceptable for anything else to happen here. I think that is very important, and that is what we need to address.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR). -
text: Mr President, the digital single market could help stimulate the European economy, boost the Union's GDP and create thousands of jobs. For this reason, significant investments need to be made in the research and development of information and communication technologies. And yet, the European Union lags dramatically behind in this area and has fallen behind in relation to the funds invested by the United States and Japan. And that's no accident. This is because the European Union's economic model is based on the euro pact. In other words, it supports the competitiveness of the old continent in the 'Chineseisation' of wages. However, in order to be competitive, the European Union cannot rely on low wages, since it cannot compete with the low wages of China and India. Instead, it must invest in the knowledge economy, education and training. But this is at the heart of Mrs Merkel's doctrine of primary surpluses and the consequent reduction in public spending on education, innovation and new technologies. For this reason, the European Union must abandon its outdated economic model and increase public spending as the United States of America does. The European Central Bank must "cut" money as the US Fed and the European Union do to support its competitiveness in the knowledge economy and digital technology.

name: Kaja Kallas (ALDE). -
text: Mr President, the completion of the digital single market has been and still is one of the priorities of the ALDE Group, as my colleague already mentioned, as it has the potential to increase economic growth in Europe and create hundreds of thousands of new jobs. I also take the opportunity to welcome the nomination of Andrus Ansip as Vice-President designate for the Digital Single Market, Estonia being at the forefront of the digital economy. His task will not be easy.  I am worried about the comments that the European leaders have made that could greatly undermine the open Internet and development of our economy. This trend is caused by the digital domination of the United States. But overregulating and over controlling the Internet will simply destroy innovation. The digital single market is still very much fragmented and, overall, current regulations on digital services do not encourage solutions, but rather deter the creation of innovative start-ups. This needs to be reviewed. I, of course, strongly believe in high standards of data privacy, but also that it is by creating a European network that is Internet-friendly, boosts innovation and favours the creation of European companies that we will better ensure that the European standards of data protection are met.

name: Róża Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking I would like to say that I very much regret that, in this role, we are meeting the Commissioner here for the last time. If something comforts me, the fact that the consequence planned for the commissioner's place is a very outstanding figure, Mrs. Elżbieta Bieńkowska. And I am convinced that we will also establish such constructive and good cooperation with her as we have been with you, Commissioner. I thank the Lord for all the work and all the successes you have talked about here. These successes, which we have achieved together for the ever-better functioning of the European market, but I am also grateful for your commitment to dialogue with European society, which you have been conducting all the time, for your frequent trips to different countries, for your participation in conferences, meetings in many European countries, in different places, including my home town of Krakow twice.  We all agree here that the subject of the Digital Single Market is a huge opportunity for the whole of the European Union, and today an extremely ambitious, horizontal approach to this subject by the European Commission is needed. I agree with my colleagues that we cannot accept or accept those barriers that still divide our common market into 28 different areas. We cannot legis lair for consumer protection, which is in opposition to the legislation we create for businesses. We cannot divide the rights we create into the right to virtual reality and the right to physical reality. We need a more ambitious approach from the European Commission in order to finally get rid of these additional roaming costs and create a genuine European telecommunications market. We need more ambitious action to make online shopping easier – I am thinking here of postal services, especially cross-border services. Last point: yes, we must introduce existing rules and perhaps also introduce new rules so that our internet is not completely dominated by the global internet, usually non-European. Our European companies must be strong in the global race and their user, the European user, must be safe.

name: Birgit Sippel (S&D). -
text: Mr. President! This afternoon we are discussing the Digital Single Market, growth potential, new jobs. Digital products and services will also come more from Europe in the future. However, all this can only work if consumers and citizens have confidence in these services. This also applies to our companies whenever they use online services. Can we all really trust that personal documents – business records, for example – are actually secure in a cloud? If we want to not only catch up with other bidders, but move forward, we need confidence in offers and opportunities. The fundamental right to data protection must become a priority, a basis for the further development of the Digital Single Market. And for that we finally need the European data protection reform. People must not only become the object of economic interests, but they should decide informs about their own data, about what data is collected and analyzed by whom and for what purpose and where and for how long. Users should be able to avaise these and other rights from providers, no matter where in the world this provider is located. This is an important prerequisite. Strong data protection is the key to a successful Digital Single Market. And it is precisely small and medium-sized enterprises that need to be increased in order to avoid risks in the area of cloud computing, for example. It is only when I know the risks I am taking that companies can act on, for example by using European and hopefully privacy-friendly cloud systems. Data protection and growth, my conclusion, are the two sides of the Digital Single Market. And it will be all the more successful the more we can all rely on fundamental rights to apply online, including digital.

name: Julie Girling (ECR). -
text: Mr President, I would like to thank Commissioner Barnier for his résumé of the work on the digital single market through the last legislature, which of course we all found very interesting.  We all know that the EU is not yet a properly functioning single market; it is still divided by national borders; it is still not properly functioning. It is still not attractive to digital start-up companies because it cannot offer seamless access to the market. We have heard much about the achievements but, and I congratulate the Commissioner for being so straightforward, we have also heard that there is a clear acknowledgement that we have failed to achieve some of our targets and that we will continue to set ourselves those targets and aims for the future. I would like to draw colleagues’ attention to the joint paper on priorities put together by 11 Member States, including the UK and Germany, because I think that to some extent it does the job of setting out how we should go forward.  There is a clear list of priorities for realising a vision for completing this single market. I would like to focus my remarks on simply one of these areas. As with all of our work here in the European Parliament, we talk about regulation and legislation and there are always two dimensions. There is the technical work that we do, there are the impact assessments – there is all of that – and then there are the tangible benefits to consumers: the things that our constituents really want to hear about. So I make no apology for mentioning yet again the issue of ensuring the right digital infrastructure. Connecting every citizen is still a work in progress, both in terms of broadband speeds and mobile connectivity, particularly data services. In my own region of five million people, one quarter still do not have access to either of these benefits and when I talk to my citizens, to my constituents, and I talk about all of the good work that we are doing here, I am often met with cynical laughter from part of the room because they do not have that basic connectivity to begin with. So let us forge ahead on all of the fronts that people have talked about, I support them all. But also let us make sure that we speed up the basic building blocks that the digital economy is built on and not leave that basic infrastructure behind.

name: Nils Torvalds (ALDE). -
text: Mr President, if words could be transformed into action by digital means, the digital single market would certainly be in place already. But the world does not function in that way and we have a lot of challenges in front of us. This House is not actually leading, either. When we have to report our journeys from Strasbourg back to our hometown we have to do it on paper, even if the boarding passes we have are already digital. So, if we could get some action in this House, we could probably make some progress. Commissioner Barnier, I do not know if you are allowed to google anymore, but if you are, then you can google Helsinki Region Infoshare, as Helsinki city and region has actually opened up a lot of data and information to be used by SMEs or by individuals. They have created apps which are used by the citizens in the region. So they actually did it another way. They opened it up to possibilities; they opened up the market. If we were able to do it the same way and not just wait for the right paper to be written, we could probably achieve the digital agenda slightly faster.

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I think we need to understand the logic of digital development. It is a worldwide development, which means that things are happening all the time: new products, new services, new generations coming up everywhere, here and there, and all the time. This means that, in this global market, you cannot be number two, because everyone will, in the long run, choose the number one. This means that if you are to be the leading digital single market, you need to be the most digitalised market. A more digitalised Europe really means more Europe.  That is why we need to have structural reforms to get rid of 28 different local markets – it is so old-fashioned. We need to ensure that we can have lower costs and more investments, and that is why we need a single market with operators covering all the markets and delivering the best services. We need to aim for the highest capacities and the best speeds; because where you have those things, you will have new things developing. The services of tomorrow are not possible with the capacities of today. If we ensure that we have the best capacities, the highest speeds, the greatest spectrum, and the most opportunities, then we will see the new services of tomorrow and the day after that develop here in Europe. The new products and the new companies, as well as our old companies, will be able to lead, and we will have the leading digital single market making the single market of the European Union a reality. That is what we need to do. It is very simple, very complicated, but requires decisiveness.

name: Petra Kammerevert (S&D). -
text: Mr. President! I would like to mention two points that you raised, Mr Barnier, in your introductory remarks. Firstly, I am convinced that the Commission is now called upon to deal with Google and its market power in a tough but fair manner in order to finally present an acceptable solution here. Google has now proposed unacceptable things three times – I think it's enough! To assume that would not have been acceptable either. I am therefore glad that the Commission has once again postponed this. Transparency can and must be demanded of a corporation that permeates the lives of each individual in its breadth and depth and, incidentally, also affects diversity of opinion and media pluralism. The obligation to disclose previously secret search algorithms would be a tried and tested remedy here. We must also oblige search engines throughout Europe to apply only the same search criterion to all services. I am convinced that this criterion must be relevant.  Secondly, fairness can only be done in a truly open Internet. The Google case clearly shows what happens when business interests are put above the general interest. Politics has given Google a free hand for too long.  This must not happen to us again. If, in the forthcoming trialogue procedures surrounding the Regulation on the Digital Single Market Regulation, we allow ourselves to be drawn into the lax regulation of net neutrality and, through hardly regulated special services, open the back door to circumventing net neutrality, the Google case will in fact have been nothing more than a lukewarm air.  Comprehensive net neutrality, which must be guaranteed without exception, is the technologically necessary security for fair competition. It must not be undermined by special services, which is why special services must only be permitted where they are technically absolutely necessary and do not restrict the freedom and openness of the Internet. This should be insightful and effective for us in the negotiations in the trialogue.

name: Lambert van Nistelrooij (PPE). -
text: Commissioner, thank you for your speech, with a wonderful overview of your activities. Still, there is a need for some criticism. Where is the Europe that is setting the trend? Where is europe with its mobile phone standard, where it inspires Europe? I can tell you that in 2004, when I was also in this Parliament, I attended a conference on internet governance at the United Nations. That's where our European companies were at the forefront. What's happened now? You can see that the big American companies are in charge of the whole cloud thing. So we need to create a spirit that is different and also sets the trend. I think that's a trend from the bottom up. A trend of our education, of our companies, of young people starting start-ups in the app economy. A trend that actually determines our lives to a great extent. That's it. It's not always the case that Alibaba will set the trend, it's our people close to home. That is why I welcome the initiative that is now on the table. Putting two Commissioners on this digital, partly internal market is a very wise idea, because we have to move on. With 28 separated systems, this is not possible. I am really watching - it was Mrs Kroes who said that let us contract the spectrum in large parts of Europe. What is going on? It is precisely because of these finances that it is being cut back into these little stamps, puzzle pieces, which is Europe. We can't achieve it that way. I am asking for leadership from the new Commission, and that will indeed bring with it that contribution to growth that this internal market can bring. That is where the task lies, and this is a good time to have this debate, including the prepared resolution which we will certainly have to bring in next time with the support of the other groups.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, there is a long way to go to build a genuine digital single market. progress has been made, much remains to be done.  I believe that there are three priorities, but they are not adequately resolved in the things that await us. The first, which has been mentioned several times and not coincidentally, concerns the protection of personal data. Without uniformity we will not have fair competition between companies and at the same time we will have the denial of one of the fundamental rights of citizenship, which is that of privacy.  The second is over-concentration and the presence of dominant operators. We are not in front of a market. There are places, spaces of oligopoly that must be overcome. We must introduce what is the basic rule in any market: the possibility of operating on equal terms. The third concerns copyright. If we do not defend and value those who think and therefore create innovation in an area which is itself objectively characterised by innovation processes, we risk once again having conditions that deny the market and instead favour the processes of concentration that we want to combat.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking The Digital Single Market can be the cornerstone of the European Union's socio-economic development. The internet alone is already responsible for 20% of economic growth and about 25% of job growth. For these reasons, the bodies of the European Union, including the European Parliament, should continue their efforts to remove barriers to the development of the Digital Single Market. One challenge is to tackle the legal fragmentation of this area in national laws, another problem is the lack of good cross-border rules and the lack of websites available in many languages. Attention should also be paid to dispute resolution methods, in particular for online purchases in cross-border transactions, as this is essential for the level of trust in online purchases.  It is very important for the development of digitalisation – it is also necessary to increase the level of e-skills among the inhabitants of the Member States of the European Union in parallel with investments, e.g. in broadband infrastructure, and in all age groups. It is about inducing e-readiness to use computer and information technologies, both in the economy and in communication with public administrations.  It is also important to regulate well the cooperation between private investors and private operators with the administrations of the governments of individual Member States. This entails an economically efficient pooling of market forces and the public interest. This is an excellent space for the development of public-private partnerships in all Member States of the European Union. I therefore call, also as the author of the Law on Public-Private Partnership in Poland, to promote and support PPPs in the Member States of the European Union.  Another major challenge for the Community is the integration of small and medium-sized enterprises into the digital revolution, e.g. through e-commerce. This is mainly linked to breaking down digital barriers between Member States. These are just some of the tasks that we face.

name: Marju Lauristin (S&D). -
text: Since I am from Estonia, I am very pleased that the new Vice-President of the European Commission, which will be working on the digital market, is also from Estonia. We have a great deal of experience in how to get far enough with the services that the Commission is now talking about as a dream. For example, electronic invoices, digital signature – that's our people's every day. We can talk about the problems that we can already see. We have really clashed very hard with the fact that there is no digital market in common. We could also offer a great deal more to the whole of Europe if we had such a market.  In fact, I would like to stress that the problems of this market are not just economic problems. What my previous speaker spoke about is very important. A cultural and educational moment is very important, which has been little talked about. I am actually concerned that the Commission's digital programme is very much economic-oriented. Its time frame is very narrow, and we in Parliament should be able to expand it and also see how to work with a number of committees.  Currently, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs is working on data protection, the Committee on Culture and Education on media content creation and the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection on everything concerning the market. We, in cooperation with our committees, could actually complement and balance the European Commission's rather narrow, market, economic and technology-oriented mandate. I think that our role here is precisely to show and bring solutions to these very complex common problems, in cooperation with the Commission.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE). -
text: Mr President, in the late 1980s and early 1990s, we Europeans were certainly pioneers. This is because we have established the common market for products, because we have adopted GSM, that is, the common mobile telephony system, a European innovation with a global impact. Unfortunately, today in the area of the digital single market, we are in danger of losing the train. Because when it comes to competition with other countries – and the example is the United States of America – we must first overcome the major disadvantage, which is none other than the fragmentation of the single market into 28 different markets. While products in the United States are aimed at 300 million consumers, products and services in the European Union could be aimed at 500 million potential consumers. However, we have not yet completed the institutional framework to take advantage of this comparative advantage. Mr President, I have said this before in plenary, politicians cannot create jobs. This is the role of the companies and entrepreneurs who take risks. But we have an obligation to create the conditions and the environment that will facilitate job creation. I say this because in Greece, because of the crisis, we have 178 000 over-qualified unemployed young people. We have hundreds of thousands of unemployed under the age of 25. And, at the same time, despite the crisis, we are seeing not only in Greece but throughout Europe, that those jobs that require digital literacy are flourishing and that is the very great need. To the point where in 2020 we estimate that in Europe we will have a deficit of almost one million 'digital' jobs. The evidence you have presented to us, Commissioner, has been very interesting because it shows the work you have done. But you also showed us that we have to rush. To rush to adapt businesses, to rush to remove obstacles. We often say that the European Union must be present on the big issues. What is happening with the digital single market is too great, because it covers hundreds of potential jobs that we urgently need. So let us run, let us translate the institutional framework into EUR 500 billion of development over the next 5 years. We have an obligation to people who ask for work.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you to Commissioner Barnier for his many activities, including the social economy. We want to make Europe a continent with industrial leadership, which is very advanced, but I wonder: is Europe really a continent prepared for the digital age? Are we making all the necessary choices and actions? Probably not yet. So we must push hard, both on the digital single market, on the package that is being negotiated, on the things that have been said here and also on many other stages that we have to do, but we have a vision as Europe and a very clear project. We must therefore aim – I say three adjectives, but they involve many legislative choices and not only – on a connected, open and secure Europe. Connected means developing a lot of investment in infrastructure and also in all innovations and research in this area. Are we prepared, with Juncker's plan, to really go in this direction? Are we ready, for example, for countries that invest in digital to remove this from budgetary constraints? I think it needs to be done. Connected means accessibility, it means openness, it means that single market and a single authority that we have been calling for for a long time, it means interoperability, it means zero roaming, it means many things and many choices that are also concrete. Secondly, open. Open data, the open Internet, is a point of reference for us. It also means accessibility to disadvantaged groups and also means open governance of the Internet and network management that takes into account everyone, the strengthening of stakeholders and also the participation of users and citizens. Finally, safe – the theme of privacy that has been mentioned several times.

name: Siegfried Mureşan (PPE). -
text: Mr President, the completion of the digital single market means more growth and more jobs for the people of Europe without putting more debt on the shoulder of the people of Europe. Therefore, it is high time to address the existing barriers that hinder the development of a digital single market and unleash the potential of our digital products and services. Commissioner, you have rightly pointed to the impressive potential GDP increase coming from the digital single market in Europe, but the question is: why were Nokia and Ericsson pioneers of the mobile era which then lost their supremacy to Apple and Samsung over the past 15 years? Twenty-eight national digital markets regulated at national level are a competitive disadvantage and a considerable burden for investors and consumers in Europe. We cannot afford fragmented regulation if we want to unleash the potential of our digital products and services. We have to remove the remaining fiscal and legal barriers. We need European regulators, pan-European operators and a truly Europe market. We also need an integrated online and mobile payments market. It is also high time to have fast fibre European networks in every household in Europe. A slow Internet connection is a competitive disadvantage for a company, and we see that especially in rural areas. We should set ambitious targets and respect them. We should aim to connect most European households, even in rural areas, with 100 megabytes of Internet connections by 2020. My last point: we should also push forward with the digitalisation of the public sector. Supply and demand of public services should meet online. Too often it is human interference which is a source of imperfection and even corruption in delivering high-quality public services to the people of Europe.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D). -
text: Mr. President! Today's discussion has shown that Europe is clearly still a long way from a single digital single market. How fast and whether you surf through the Internet and how much you pay for it still depends on which country, in which region you live and how good the broadband coverage is in the respective place of residence. We need rapid action to remove this digital fragmentation. Access to the Internet is a fundamental right and no one should be excluded from it. A discussion on the completion of the internal market must not spare these issues. But other conditions must also be addressed, such as the legal anchoring of net neutrality, the re-establishment of trust in the digital network through a rapid adoption of the data protection package, a copyright reform that harnesses the potential of the digital era, and finally better possibilities for data portability and provider switching in order to break up entrenching monopolies. Finally, an appeal to all of us, to us parliamentarians, is too little to wait just for what comes from the Commission. The European Parliament itself must play a leading and demanding role in the development of the Digital Single Market. This is also a very important message for the new Commissioner.

name: Anne Sander (PPE). -
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, it must be recognised that the digital revolution has been mainly outside our borders. Today this revolution is defying our old Europe. If we do not want to become a mere colony of the digital world, we must redouble our efforts.  The digital agenda is a key part of the European Commission's new programme, and I would like to welcome two major initiatives by President Juncker. The first is to have made the completion of a digital single market its priority. The second is to have appointed a vice-president specifically in charge of this policy.  Much progress has been made in internet access since 2010. However, our policy will have failed if a digital divide persists between the territories of the European Union, among its companies and among its population. Commissioner Barnier said that only one in seven SMEs sells products online. I would add that only one in five households in rural areas has access to a broadband connection. In France, only a quarter of over-75s have internet access at home.  We need to address these disparities and invest in broadband infrastructure in rural areas, support the digitisation of SMEs and train citizens in new technologies.  Thus, I hope that we will be able to meet this dual challenge: to regain our digital sovereignty and to benefit all our fellow citizens.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D). -
text: Commissioner, today's whole debate is about the huge possibilities, the innovation potential, the benefits for growth and jobs, but also the challenges of the current rapid technological development.  From the consumer's point of view, the digital market cannot just be about removing barriers to buying goods and services online. It must also be about consumer confidence. Not only what their theoretical rights are, but also whether they can realistically obtain them if, for example, they have purchased a poor quality product or service. In this context, it is important to fully implement and implement the legislative acts already adopted. Particular attention should also be paid to the elimination of discriminatory practices, which are unfortunately still a common reality of the internal market. Limiting payment options, delivering goods, or different prices based on nationality or country of origin does not look like a fair single internal market. Setting up a consumer-friendly and responsible digital internal market will therefore rightly be one of the main tasks of the new Commission.

name: Adina-Ioana Vălean (PPE). -
text: Mr President, while I am very pleased to see that the digital single market has been a top priority for the outgoing Commission, as it is for President Juncker’s new team, we do need an online market flexible enough for businesses to grow and secure enough for citizens to make use of it. Cross-border purchases are still rare in Europe. Standards for electronic signatures and contracts still vary from one Member State to another. Corporate legislation is far from being harmonised, while the data protection regulation is nowhere near implementation. Too many barriers hamper companies’ investment in the use of ICT as well as cross-border and Internet-based economic activity. We want to encourage innovative entrepreneurship among our youth. We all want to see a digital market where goods and services flow freely among Member States, where competition drives knowledge forward and prices down, but that requires a shift in approach from a national market mindset towards a European one. If we want a pan-European digital market, we need investment in infrastructure, and therefore we need to provide the appropriate regulatory framework and stability for electronic communication providers. We should also take a closer look at our competition rules. We know what the hurdles are and what we want to do. We therefore expect the Commission to define a concrete action plan with clear policy targets and a viable timetable. We must also understand that the digital single market is not something we politicians are going to build. We must always involve and consult all the relevant stakeholders. I am thankful to the outgoing Commission for its work and I very much look forward to working with the new Commission to make the digital single market a reality.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner, is the digital single market an opportunity? Yes, but there is not much less time left for it to be a close reality: there are 100 million Europeans who do not have access to the internet today; 12% of European companies do not trade or are not able to trade online; and only 12% of Europeans make purchases in Member States other than their own. Commissioner, there will not be a real digital single market if small and medium-sized enterprises, which account for 90% of jobs in the European Union, are not incorporated into it quickly and efficiently. And for this, there is a lack of a strategy, a real action plan that is politically coordinated, heavily funded and implemented quickly, because Europe is once again losing the train - the train, in this case, the digital single market, because there are many economic zones, other than the European Union, which give us a lot of advantage in this field - and we have to correct that. And for all this we need your successor, Commissioner, to coordinate with the new Employment Commissioner to use training funds to make e-commerce accessible to small and medium-sized enterprises; we need you to coordinate with the economic team to facilitate financing pathways to modernize our companies; we need to coordinate with innovation to correct the defects we have in broadband and also, for example, in 4G. And above all, we need to coordinate with your legal team to maintain the necessary protection of consumer rights in the face of the new challenges that e-commerce also poses in this area.

name: Axel Voss (PPE). -
text: Mr. President! Thank you to the Commission for taking this approach. I also think it is good that the new Commission is a priority there. We all have very high expectations of this, because it is about our technological future on the one hand, but also about our data and the protection of our data on the other. One of the major priorities in this area must be the issue of security on the Internet, in order to create confidence here: security against cyber-attacks, from mass spying, from economic espionage, from fraud. Ultimately, we also want to combat terror and crime through data and digital technology. We do not want a surveillance state here, but we also want the state to be able to fulfil its security tasks in the digital market as well. That is why we need a regulatory framework here – the sooner, the better – for this digital world, for the protection of the individual, but also for the fight against crime. We must draw new boundaries everywhere and not leave the net to anarchy and the right of the strongest. We must therefore also try harder to create common standards with our American partners here. If we do not succeed in this, and if privacy is still important to us in the future, then we really must make ourselves even more independent, including from our American partners. We described this in the NSA investigation report. Google is one issue, and we should also consider whether we are not creating a Community European company here, such as Airbus or Galileo, in order to build something there that will be fairer for the confidence of the citizens. And we must also see that, with regard to safe harbour, we are making more assertiveness in this area of privacy and the protection of citizens. I would like to encourage the Commission to have the courage here to repeal safe harbour and to put this on a new footing.

name: Miapetra Kumpula-Natri (S&D). -
text: Mr President, the debate shows that politicians have work to do, but hopefully there will also be work in the digital sector. We are three years behind the United States and we just need to succeed in creating positive regulation for innovation, because the digital market needs rules of the game, but it just does not need harmonisation.  I believe that Europe must have the courage to give small businesses and small operators in different regions the opportunity to be the first in the world to generate new innovations that will grow into great use. This is what we have seen. Every company has ever been small, and I would not like to legislate so strict that we cannot invent innovations.  But data protection, which has been talked about a great deal today, is a fundamental European right. I would say that then we will not be an involtive commodity as people and consumers. But consumers quite rarely look at country of origin labelling when choosing digital services. They choose the best apps. Europe must be able to create innovation.
