I look forward to good regulation from the future Commission as we take another step forward from 4G technology. Will European companies and Europe then be involved in the market, or will the benefit of innovation go elsewhere again?

name: Michał Boni (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. The benefits of the Digital Single Market are obvious, but Europe still cannot make the digital leap into the Digital Single Market. What do I need for this? Firstly, a comprehensive approach so that we treat digital issues when they concern education, telecommunications or health in one and the same way. Secondly, breaking the selfishness of the 28 countries, because this selfishness kills the possibility of developing the Digital Single Market. Thirdly, the development of investment so that access to high-speed internet has caused us not to have the situation we had today: with a delay of 30 seconds, almost a minute, we have heard our friends in Kiev. This is a weakness in internet speed. These investments clearly require market consolidation, breaking down fragmentation, including harmonisation when we share the future spectrum. Fourthly, there is a need to harmonise standards and services, including in the area of privacy, so that not 28 regimes, but one legal regime, decide on this digital leap. Fifthly, big data is a great opportunity for the economy, the development of big data is probably an additional EUR 280 billion to European GDP over the next few years.  But for big data to grow well, you need to combine three elements. First, adopt privacy and personal data protection arrangements. They build trust and they will also allow small business to grow across the European continent. Secondly, it is necessary to open data, reuse and use data with this development, so that the obstacles that sometimes exist in excessive protection, excessive copyright do not restrict the development, movement of various goods, products and data. And thirdly, security. In a modern way... (The President has received the speaker's vote.)

name: Sabine Verheyen (PPE). -
text: Mr Vice-President, Commissioner Barnier, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has The further development and strengthening of the Digital Single Market is also of the utmost importance for the creative industries, media pluralism and cultural diversity in Europe. However, as we develop, we must ensure that we create a level playing field for all. The cultural sector in particular is supported by small and medium-sized enterprises in the creative industries and is characterised by linguistic and content diversity.  In order to promote and maintain this, a non-discriminatory, open and transparent Internet is essential. That is why we must ensure fair conditions of competition, especially for platforms, search engines and other distribution channels on the Internet. Search engines and platforms often perform a gatekeeper function that can quickly disrupt this diversity of creative education and media offerings. The bundling of search engines with their own offers of content and service risks distorting competition. It is therefore important that the Commission pays attention to transparency, openness and non-discrimination, particularly in the case of platforms with considerable market dominance, so that its own offers and services of platform operators are not privileged and others are penalised.  Market dominance must not lead to consumers receiving only limited other offers or to finding only certain suppliers on the network easily. Culture, education and also the media live on the great diversity in Europe. This wide variety of content and offerings is an invaluable value that needs to be strengthened and preserved. Finding the Internet will be the key to the success of any offer in the future.  That is why, from the point of view of the creative and educational sector and media pluralism, we are calling for the safeguarding of search neutrality and an open, transparent and non-discriminatory Internet. All citizens must have non-discriminatory access to content, services and goods on the internet. Only in this way can we raise the great potential of the Digital Single Market in the long term. We need this neutrality, both in search and on the net.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE). -
text: Mr President, it is never more necessary to reiterate in this House that the European digital single market is a priority. And it is a priority because it will be one of Europe's growth axes in the coming years. And if we are demanding and ambitious with the European project — and, of course, I am — if we want more Europe, we need growth. Achieving a truly integrated digital single market would mean increasing gross domestic product by at least 4%. We are talking about 500 billion euros over a ten-year period. In recent years, the European Union has approved numerous initiatives aimed at fostering the digital economy and taking advantage of the growth opportunities it offers.  Je veux saluer dans ce contexte le magnifique travail qui a déjo été fait par le commissaire Michel Barnier et son équipe. The future Juncker Commission also points to the digital single market as one of its standards. In reality, the development of the digital single market must be at the heart of the European Union's efforts to generate economic growth and employment, as well as to strengthen the competitiveness of the Union and its resilience within the global economy. Together, the European Commission and the Member States need to promote the application of existing rules and regulations and, where necessary, impose sanctions. It is necessary for the Commission to ensure rapid application of existing legislation in order to subsequently further open up the single market for services. The Commission must, in my view, ensure the application and enforcement of rules such as the Consumer Rights Directive, alternative dispute resolution and online dispute resolution, while ensuring the reduction of administrative burdens. Another challenge would be to ensure a level playing field for companies operating in the digital single market, so that they are able to compete. In the same sense, ensuring a vibrant digital economy in the European Union depends on strict application of competition rules in the digital single market. Indexing, evaluating, presenting, and ranking search engines should be impartial and transparent, while for interrelated services, search engines must ensure full transparency when displaying search results.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE). -
text: Mr President, the digital economy is a topic that is for me very much linked to the hopes and worries of younger citizens. Hence, let me share with you a few thoughts of the EPP’s youngest MEP. It is typically the younger generations in Europe that are contributing to the development of a competitive European digital economy. Examples such as Spotify, the South Cloud and Skype were all start-ups by young European entrepreneurs. I would like to further urge the Commission to foster an environment that makes it easier, more affordable and simply more desirable for my young fellow citizens to keep on thinking about the next wave of digital innovation ‘made in Europe’. It is the younger generations that not only drive and benefit from digitalisation but are most vulnerable to its potential negative consequences. Young people often share every aspect of their life, as well as important personal data, via Internet platforms and social media. This can and often has negative consequences for their career prospects, for their safety and their security. The spread of digitalisation can make such cases more common. Thus, although a dynamic, pro-business, pro-innovation and integrated digital market is something I encourage and embrace, it should be completed by a very carefully devised online security strategy. I urge the Commission to introduce standards guaranteeing the online safety of one of the most vulnerable social groups: European youth. I also would like to address you, not only as one of the youngest MEPs but also as a Member from a young EU Member State and, more importantly, a young democracy. One of the many advantages of the digital single market is that it can help us improve transparency and accountability through instruments such as e-government. E-government is a key priority of some Member States.  Yet countries like Bulgaria need European support for completing such an ambitious project. I ask the Commission to assist Member States in strengthening democracy through the introduction of digital tools. I congratulate Commissioner Barnier for the extensive work he has done and I look forward to working with Team Juncker on finalising the digital single market as soon as possible.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE). -
text: Mr. President, the establishment of the Digital Single Market is definitely the room for such desired economic growth. We live in an age of information technology. Stronger and better become those who do better in this area. Different rules in internet business mean barriers and prevent Member States from benefiting from new modern ways of working. By internetizing the business of medium and small entrepreneurs, we will make them more competitive and their services and goods available.  It'll make life easier for citizens. The Digital Single Market will enable them to feel the advantage of living in the European Union without physically travelling. And now one question for the European Commission, for the Commissioner: regulations have been adopted, agendas and action plans written. What is the plan for more decisive and faster implementation?

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D). -
text: Mr President, contrary to what has been said, the conviction when we look at how the digital market works is that this market already exists today. Transactions as well as non-market trade go far beyond national borders. It is also, it has been said, a formidable source of innovation, of the evolution of economic models, but also of the evolution of social relations, of cooperative uses. All this is changing very quickly, much faster than European legislation.  But that is not why we have to give up. On the contrary, I am convinced, we must act because it is our responsibility as the European Parliament to establish and strengthen a number of principles in the digital space, as we are trying to do in the physical space.  The first of these principles, which we have talked about extensively, is the protection of consumers and citizens. I am concerned when I intend to challenge, under the guise of competitiveness, a rule as fundamental as the protection of personal data. Parliament, the European Union has done a lot in this area, but we must continue and not sell this principle for reasons of economic efficiency. We also need to ensure fairness. I am also surprised when I intend to justify monopoly situations. We need to ensure fairness, net neutrality and also research.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL). -
text: Advances in the field of digital face us with enormous and irrefutable challenges. In online services, e-commerce, for example in the field of copyright, data protection, net neutrality, certainly. The response to these challenges obviously requires a joint, Community and international approach. But the response to these challenges, some of them complex, must have as an indecible guiding principle the defense of the public interest, which must in any circumstances overlap with the pure and simple logic of the market. Now this is all that has not happened in two decades of the single market. Two decades of propaganda with many promises of job creation, growth and cohesion - all delied by reality. Two decades of prevalence of business over the public interest, market advancement of essential public services generating poverty and exclusion, exclusion that will inevitably deepen with the deepening and expansion of the single market. That is why the answer to these challenges we are talking about here cannot be found in this picture. Before it requires a break with it.

name: Renato Soru (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a few weeks ago I read an interesting interview with the Prime Minister of South Korea.  When asked by the interviewer what this country's secret was to rapid growth, to having emerged from poverty, to quickly becoming Asia's fourth largest economy and, I think, the fifteenth economy on the planet, the Prime Minister responded very simply. He said, "We believed it. Over the past few decades, we've spent our time investing in education, education, training, and we've spent our time investing in broadband connections, we've wired our country."  The result is that today there is Samsung in our pockets and there is less Nokia, the result is that each of us, in our pockets has either a mobile phone or has a video or has a chipset, or in the car has a piece of technology from that country and less and less of our technology. That is why, when I heard the Commissioner's fine statement, which said that with technology, with digital innovation, for every job that is lost in traditional sectors, more than two jobs are gained in new sectors, it occurs to me that we lose traditional jobs and someone else gains new jobs. So much so that in recent years we have lost several million jobs in Europe without earning any new ones... (The President cut the speaker off.)

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE). -
text: Mr. President, we can ask a question at the end of this debate, since I'm the last. What is the digital economy and what is the digital market?  We are constantly talking about some future, I would say, that this is not the market of the future but of the present and I want to thank Commissioner Barnier who worked very intensively on this dossier and that this was part of his portfolio and I want to believe that the new Commissioner will continue to do this well. However, this project needs to be completed, it needs to be completed, I see in Mr Juncker's proposal that this is one of the main points of his Commission's work and I believe that we will all succeed together.  However, what interests me about this dossier is roaming and I want to thank and express my joy on behalf of thousands of citizens and voters that we will have equal roaming across the European Union on 15 December 2015. I think that concerns many new citizens of the European Union.

name: Michel Barnier
text: Vice-President of the Commission. Mr President, thank you to each and every one of you for the diversity, the intensity and the quality of this debate. I believe that Mr Schwab and his colleagues who have taken this initiative will not regret it, given the richness of this debate. He himself, like Mrs Raa Thun, and mr H-kmark and many others, at the moment Mrs Ouica, have spoken of the economic importance of the digital market and I have said the potential of it if a number of technical, fiscal and administrative barriers are removed. I also want to say - and this has been the mindset of my work over the last five years as Commissioner for the Single Market and Financial Services - that there is a dimension in the single market that is primarily economic but also social, human, civic, with issues related to data freedom and protection, and also a cultural dimension. It is by thinking of all this that we must give this impetus to a project, Mrs Ouica, which is indeed that of the present and not that of the past or the future. We are in the present to bring this digital single market to life. You have to move forward, that's what you're going to do with the next college. It is absolutely necessary to implement the rules agreed together. He insisted on implementation through directives, texts, monitoring, evaluation and your Parliament has a very important role of vigilance towards the Commission and the Council. That is what needs to be done, I say this to Mrs Spyraki who was asking for an increase in the pace.  You have to be as conscious or realistic. Earlier I was listening to your Estonian colleague, who has left us, Mrs Marju Lauristin, who was talking about a point to which I was very attached, I quoted earlier, it is the electronic signature which is, in the great project of the digitalisation of public order and many other issues, one of the key elements with electronic billing and the reform of public procurement that I have implemented. I could say to Mrs Lauristin that it took two years between the commission's proposal and the vote in Parliament and the Council to come up with a text that is not yet fully operational.  Ms Gebhardt, Mr Albrecht, Mr Borelli, Mrs Verheyen and many others spoke of net neutrality, as I had done myself. I think everyone should have access to services, applications on an open internet. The Commission has proposed European legislation to ban all kinds of blockages, strangulations, discrimination of specific content, applications or services, with very limited exceptions.  This regulation proposes the promotion of innovation as a guarantor of the open internet while allowing specialized services such as digital television or other services that may surface in the future provided that the open internet is not hindered. Parliament has supported this proposal and we hope that an agreement can be reached before the end of this year. On cybersecurity, Mr. Albrecht and Mr. Voigt asked the question of where we stand with regard to the legislative proposal on network security and information. Your House has adopted its report at first reading, the Council for its part is finalising its negotiations and I hope that the trilogues can start soon under the very active presidency of Italy.  Vicky Ford earlier and others have talked about consumer protection, which is a priority, which justifies the Commission's action in the area of data protection, I myself mentioned earlier. Another example of this consumer consideration is online payment, so that they are protected in daily payments, and - I say to Mr Albrecht - by pulling the standards up and not down.  Ms Ford also mentioned, like Mr Nica, this major project of inclusion which focuses on the digital single market. The whole single market, all Member States must be covered by the internet. All the citizens wherever they are, the most fragile, the most remote, the most isolated, must receive appropriate services and this justifies the investments that Mr Murean has mentioned with great skill and dynamism like your colleague Weiden Holzer. This is the meaning of the Telecom Single Market proposal, for which we hope for a quick agreement, and also the investments that can be made in this area of digital through the initiatives that President Juncker will propose to you.  I'd like to thank you, ladies and gentlemen. Many of you have pointed out the work I have had the honour of doing over the past five years and I would like to thank in particular, on your behalf, one of your younger colleagues, Mrs. There is no complacency, there is no nostalgia. The Commission has a continuity, a new impetus. A new era will begin by, I hope, emerging from this financial crisis that I had to face with all my colleagues. I simply believe, Mr President, that this debate, its quality and diversity is a very important signal for the new Commission. This area is a priority for her, which President Juncker has indicated, as Mrs Sander has said, by appointing Prime Minister Andrew Ansip to coordinate this work, and my colleague Gunther Oettinger, who will be in charge of this subject, as Commissioner-designate Mrs Bie-kowska responsible for the internal market and therefore for dialogue with small and medium-sized enterprises.  Many of you have spoken of the opportunity that this can be - if we want to if we make their lives technically, legally, fiscally easier - for small and medium-sized enterprises. I think it is a real issue to put consumer citizens and small and medium-sized enterprises back at the heart of the internal market. That was the goal I set for myself five years ago. We have made great progress, as you have indicated, but I think the next Commission will have to make more, with the voluntarism that President Juncker has mentioned.

name: Andrus Ansip (ALDE)
text: in writting. –  I would like to thank Michel Barnier for the Commission statement. This statement on the Digital Single Market underlines the urgency faced by Europe. The digital economy moves at a far faster pace than politicians and officials are accustomed to, and Europe is playing catch up. Completing the Digital Single Market is particularly close to my heart. As Prime Minister, I co-wrote a letter with colleagues from three countries that first introduced the term to the European Council. Building the Digital Single Market was among my government’s top priorities toward the EU. I am excited to continue this work as a member of Jean-Claude Juncker’s team in the new Commission. During the first six months of our mandate, we will propose ambitious legislative steps towards a connected Digital Single Market. This will not be easy. The outgoing Commission and previous Parliament worked hard to break down national silos in telecoms regulation, copyright and data protection legislation, the management of radio waves and consumer rules, and encountered many barriers. To succeed now, we will need the strong contribution and support of the Parliament.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. – We are living in a digital era that not only changes the way we communicate and the platforms where we work but also our consumption patterns. We buy and sell goods online rather than at local shops. For this reason, a well-functioning EU single market should also adapt to this ‘new’ digital era. Still today, we face difficulties in our European cross-border trades; and far too many barriers still block the free flow of online sales and services across national borders. I believe that we must update the EU single market rules for the digital era, and we should aim for: 1. Enabling our businesses to compete across all EU countries by making online selling an option for all of our businesses; 2. Establishing a single area for online payments; 3. Fostering the involvement of SMEs, making them more knowledgeable about online systems; 4. Protecting EU consumers in the cyberspace; 5. Empowering our citizens and economies in the digital era. I truly believe that Europe’s digital potential should be recognised and supported by EU legislation. I give my full support for this huge EU project.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. – According to a study by the European Parliament, the creation of a single digital market would generate EUR 260 billion at European level. This can represent thousands of new jobs both horizontally and vertically, bearing in mind that the internet creates five jobs for every two jobs lost. However, it is important to set the best possible priorities for the investment of European funds in the coming years and actions to make their use more efficient at European level.  We must not forget that Europe is part of a very competitive global economy, including in the digital sector, which is also constantly evolving and very rapid, and some Member States need support to catch up with infrastructure.  In this context, one of the key points of the success of the success of the digital single market or achievement in the European Union is the establishment of sound legislative and administrative safeguards to boost citizens' and business confidence in the digital economy, including through a legal framework for strong data protection, but also to increase the participation rate of small and medium-sized enterprises in e-Commerce up to 50%.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing – I am very glad that the EP has played an important role in revital ingesting the internal market. The Digital Single Market opens up new opportunities to support the economy through e-commerce, while facilitating business compliance with administrative and financial rules. The promotion of the Digital Single Market was the right choice, as today it is one of the most dynamic emerging sectors and generates annual profits of EUR 260 billion. However, we cannot forget that, even today, there are still many obstacles that block the free movement of online services and entertainment across national borders. It is regrettable that only 12% of European internet users feel absolutely safe carrying out online transactions, because various threats of fraud and other disturbances reduce consumer confidence in the safe functioning of the online economy. If Europe wants to offer new services, it must provide its citizens with much faster internet access than is currently available. I believe that much more money will need to be invested in ICT research in the future in order to be able to maintain and remain competitive.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. First of all, I would like to welcome Commissioner Barnier's decisive action in the service of the achievement of the single market and the development of the digital economy in Europe. These two aspects are consubstantial because the Digital Single Market is one of the key areas for improving the functioning of the single market and is a key area of growth. Michel Barnier's successors will have to live up to his legacy and continue efforts to free up online services, communication services and e-commerce by breaking down technical, fiscal and administrative barriers. They will also need to strengthen the confidence and ownership of digital technology by citizens, SMEs and administrations. The EU must now resolutely focus on the development of a safe and competitive digital sector and I am pleased that Jean-Claude Juncker is making it a priority in his draft investment plan of 300 billion euros. It will be essential for the EU to seek greater technological independence and strategic autonomy, but also to protect the sector of culture and creation which is a source of wealth and jobs.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. –  I am glad that for the first time digital issues get such a prominent position among EU policies. A vice-president for the digital single market and a commissioner for the digital economy and society have been designated. Coordinated digitalisation of the EU must become one of the new Commission’s priorities. As initiator of the EP’s first report on cyber security and defence, I can give an assurance that MEPs are committed to working closely with the EC and the Council to achieve real progress. Three main issues have to be solved: 1. Full integration of the digital single market – we need a full set of joint EU rules. This means removing obstacles for cross-border e-commerce, first of all eliminating differentiations in the e-sphere based on country of origin and opening up borders separating national digital markets. I call on Member States to fully cooperate in establishing a respective legal framework without further delay. 2. Secure cyber space – involving both companies and public sector – is required to apply the highest standards to protect critical networks and information. The NIS Directive can solve part of this, but one needs further advances in the public sector. 3. For Member States, it should become their highest priority to complete national cyber-security strategies and prepare national digital agendas.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. –  Completion of the digital single market in Europe is a key component of Europe’s convergence into a knowledge-driven economy fostering competitiveness, economic growth and highly-qualified jobs in Europe. Completion of a digital single market requires urgent actions at all political levels ensuring that all citizens, regardless of their location, have access to the internet and the necessary skills to use it. We need to face many challenges in completing the digital single market. Despite the crisis and the high level of unemployment, the Commission estimates that more than 700 000 to 1 million high-quality ICT jobs will not be filled. E-skills and digital education, therefore, can be of extraordinary importance in tackling rising unemployment, especially among young people; the Commission and the Member States should seize the occasion and take ownership in empowering European citizens with the appropriate digital skills and reducing digital literacy and competence gaps by half by 2015.

name: Claudia Schmidt (PPE)
text: Writing. – Today, the Internet occupies an aspect that is hard to imagine in our everyday private and professional life. It offers new opportunities, but it also presents challenges and difficulties that need to be solved in order not to jeopardise this emerging market and the opportunities that come with it and to create an optimal framework for all parties involved. It is not expedient for a trader or a consumer to have to pay attention to 28 different regulations from 28 different countries within a digital single market. I therefore consider it essential to create framework conditions within Europe that offer the residents of all Member States the same standard of security and, at the same time, give companies the opportunity and scope to compete on the international market against their strong non-European competitors.

name: Presidente. -
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the UN Climate Summit in 2014 (23 September 2014 - New York) (2014/2847(RSP)).

name: Benedetto Della Vedova
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, next week political leaders, together with businesses and civil society, will meet in New York for the UN climate summit aimed at catalysing actions and ambitions on climate change.  We have high hopes and expectations that the summit will produce a climate of mutual trust between the parties and generate the political impetus necessary to contribute to a successful outcome of the international climate negotiations, with a view to a comprehensive agreement at the Paris Conference in December next year. As you know, the main objective of these climate negotiations is to ensure that the rise in temperature remains below two degrees centigrade. This commitment was accepted overall in Copenhagen and reaffirmed in Cancún. It must now be put into practice and everyone must contribute. The fifth evaluation report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change once again underlines the need for urgent global action if we are not to leave it to future generations to cope with the advancing climate change. The European Union therefore continues to work hard both internally and within the framework of the UNFCCC in the fight against climate change. Between 1990 and 2012, the European Union effectively managed to dissociate growth, which was by a plus 44%, from greenhouse gas emissions, which fell by 19%, thanks to a whole series of policies and measures. This shows that the two are not mutually exclusive.  The European Union and its Member States are determined to reach a comprehensive agreement in Paris in 2015. Ambitious mitigation commitments are needed to keep the global average temperature rise below two degrees centigrade below pre-industrial levels.  It is essential that the major economies and emerging economies take the lead. In March 2014, the European Council announced that it would take a decision in October on a framework for energy and climate policies until 2030. This will enable the European Union to present its contribution to the global agreement by the first quarter of next year, in line with what was agreed last year in Warsaw. Let us hope that others do the same. There is a high degree of awareness at EU and Member State level about the importance of climate finance. They are committed, along with others, to mobilising a hundred billion dollars by 2020, as well as being ready to start the initial capitalization of the green climate fund this year. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am fully aware that the same high level of ambition is shared by the vast majority of Members of this House. The Presidency therefore looks forward to hearing your views and welcoming some of you to the Lima Conference later this year.

name: Connie Hedegaard
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, in a way there is not much to add to what we have just heard from the Italian Presidency. It is very clear that we see eye-to-eye on what is the purpose of this huge international event on climate change next week in New York. It is clear that the purpose of such a meeting must be to try to create renewed momentum and more awareness. It is not a place where you negotiate in all sorts of detail the next climate agreement, everybody knows that, but I must say that I think it is encouraging that more than 125 Heads of State and Governments have now accepted Secretary-General Ban Ki Moon’s bold invitation. I think that is also a very good sign, because what it really means is that all these Heads of State, already at this stage, before they go to New York, have needed to ask in their own governments ‘what are we prepared to deliver in Paris next year?’ That is where the real significance of this New York meeting lies.  It is clear that the European objective must be that the agreement reached next year in Paris must be sufficiently ambitious to make it credible that the world will stay below the two degrees Celsius threshold, as was agreed by leaders in Copenhagen in 2009. It is also worth noting that we are actually to a large extent talking about a new generation of Heads of State, because governments have changed so fast that we really need to bring these messages and this issue to the top of governments, many of which have changed heads of state since the last similar meeting in September 2009. I must say that I am confident that the EU and its Member States will project a confident, united, committed EU at the summit. I think we have already had a rehearsal at the recent Bonn Ministerial meeting back in June, where we really made a united effort and portrayed a united Europe. It is a Europe that is both credible in our own action and responsive to the needs of the most vulnerable. That means that it is also absolutely key next week that our governments send a very strong signal that Europe intends to deliver on our financial pledges made in Copenhagen. I believe that the summit will see EU leaders reaffirm their commitment to the 2015 Paris agreement timetable and to tabling our contribution on time, which is the first quarter next year, after this October when we will have adopted our own 2030 targets. This is not just wishful thinking. It is something that the leaders of the European Union have twice said will happen, in March and again in June: that we will have the 2030 targets known by next month. Therefore, of course, Commission President Barroso will present at the summit our ambitious 2030 proposal for, among other things, a 40% domestic reduction target of greenhouse gas emissions. It is essential, though, that all the major economies in the G20 also table their contributions in the first quarter next year. The EU will press strongly for this during the summit. We want a single ambition and leadership across the different thematic areas of the Summit, which range from climate finance to energy, to agriculture, to cities and the economic case for action. And Member States of course have their own planned national announcements that will be made. The EU will also express its support for the many UN-led initiatives which will be launched at the summit, among them an initiative on HFCs; a statement on HFCs, which is very, very important; the Global Alliance for Climate-Smart Agriculture and the carbon pricing statement – it is a good thing that the carbon-pricing family is actually growing globally – and the global forest declaration.  The EU wants to ensure that the summit delivers a political outcome which meets our objectives for 2015, particularly on commitments to reach an ambitious agreement in Paris, on ensuring that major economies table their CO2 reduction contributions by March 2015, and on climate finance. Hopefully, as I said, the involvement of Heads of State will give a push towards Lima, because it is not all about Paris next year. In order for Paris to be a success, already in Lima we need to start to have text on the table and that is what we should push for with the momentum that can be created in New York next week. And then a final point: I also hope that the message will come clearly through that it is essential that all parties, particularly the big emitters, present no later than the first quarter of 2015 their contributions: what they intend to do. Why is that important? Because we need time, prior to Paris, to see whether the combined global effort will be enough to make us stay below the two degrees. That is basically what Paris should be all about and that must be the ambition level that we have for Paris.

name: Peter Liese
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for the way in which he has been rapporteur for her excellent Before I come to the Ban Ki-moon Summit, I would like to begin by thanking Connie Hedegaard. This may be the last plenary debate she is taking part in here in the European Parliament. I would like to express my sincere thanks for your work. I have often heard that the last five years have not been so easy for climate protection. That is certainly true. But anyone who says it was up to the Commissioner should imagine what would have happened if we had had a less committed, not so strong Commissioner. So thank you very much, Connie, for your dedicated work. You have kept climate protection alive in the European Union and around the world. It was a great achievement in difficult times. The next 15 months will be crucial for progress in the global fight against climate change. This week's summit will be a first step. But, for all the importance, we should not expect too much. The big solution, of course, will not come on Friday. We must continue to work gradually. I would like to support everything that has been said by the President-in-Office of the Council and Connie Hedegaard, and I would add that next year's G7 process will also play an important role in this context. When we talk about climate protection, many people think primarily of renewable energies. Renewable energy is also important in my view. I had a conversation last week with the chairman of Europe's electricity producers, Eurelectric. He has said he also believes that renewables will be cost-effective and competitive in a few years' time. But at the moment we still have a big cost problem. That is why we should all work even harder together on energy efficiency. I would also like to express my thanks to Jean-Claude Juncker here in plenary for his commitment to the new Commission: at least 30% energy efficiency binding. I believe that this is a good signal, including for the international negotiations. We will also remind the new Commission of this promise.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – It may be a fait diverse, but we now know that the last month of August was the warmest month in a long time. A fait diverse on the suit scientific work from which we know that climate change is not something that is going to happen, but that we are in the middle of. What we must therefore do is to act quickly and to ensure that we can reduce a phenomenon that we are in the middle of and better assess the consequences. Hence - as has already been said by the President of the Council and the Commissioner - the Lima climate conference is a first important step. Because what we need are clear, ambitious, enforceable and verifiable goals for the whole world.  In order to do this, we first need our own responsibility. I want to join the compliments. Over the last five years, climate change has been particularly difficult and very poor progress has been made, including in the European Union. I hope, I wish, Commissioner, that you will succeed in ensuring, at that last Council of this and your legislative period, that the Council does take responsibility for the 2030 climate package and ensures that we, as Europe, enroll those climate targets in our own legislation: reduction of CO2, energy efficiency standards and finally renewable energy standards. I wish you every success and my group will fully support that.

name: Julie Girling
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, although the climate change summit next week in New York is not part of the UNFCCC negotiations – not part of the process that we have all got so used to – it is an important gathering which, arguably, may be actually more important than these set-piece COP events, which are often seen by the public as very inflexible, rather frenzied and a little unintelligible. I think Ban Ki-moon’s initiative in New York has the opportunity to engage the imagination of the public in a much more meaningful way. I look forward to that, because I think it could have real political influence. Of course, all the parties present in New York are already committed to agreeing a new global and legally-binding deal by COP 21 in Paris. In the ECR, we recognise that developed countries need to take a leading role in the reduction of emissions, but we have always questioned the sense of forging too far ahead too quickly with unilateral action. That action may disadvantage the EU economy without any real impact on greenhouse gas emissions. This has been a constant theme in the five years I have been in this Parliament. At times, it has seemed that the EU really has been acting alone. I know people talk about that as leadership, but there is another way of looking at that, which is isolation. I am pleased to say that I think this rather lonely position seems to be changing. I am delighted that this meeting is actually taking place in New York in the United States. I think it is fitting as a venue as we see at long last some real and meaningful action from the US Government. The US Government’s climate power plan is a real step forward, and I really do welcome that this summer. China – that other giant economic power – is committed to implementing a carbon market by 2020, along with tangible targets for emissions reductions. So I think the news is becoming more optimistic. This is the context for Ban Ki-moon’s meeting in New York. As I understand it, the climate summit will concentrate on highlighting the benefits of taking action, not just the cataclysmic Armageddon-style warnings, but looking at the real positives for the future of climate action. For too long we have been lectured and hectored about our obligations. It is high time that the tone was changed and that the moral high ground ceded to a spirit of true global cooperation and recognition of mutual benefits. We just need to look at the energy market as an example of where those two issues have become juxtaposed, I think to the benefit of us all. So it seems that the New York meeting will be taking us in that direction, and I wish it every success. Indeed, to echo Peter Liese, I also wish Commissioner Hedegaard success in whatever she is doing next.

name: Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I would also like to start by thanking Commissioner Hedegaard for her dedication and incredible fighting spirit the last couple of years. It normally takes quite some pressure to get difficult political decisions and we must wonder how much additional pressure is still needed to finally take necessary measures in the field of climate. Scientific evidence is one, of course, and last week we saw the World Meteorological Report, which stated that CO2 concentrations are at the moment the highest ever. So, all the steps taken so far have been very small steps compared to what is still needed. Unfortunately climate change is still strengthening its grip on our planet. An alarming element of last week’s report is that oceans and forests are losing their capacity to absorb CO2 and that is really alarming. So, there is sufficient pressure to take bold measures, I would say, in these kind of reports. ‘But what about our economy?’ people say. Yes, well, let us look at it from an economic angle. Future costs due to climate change are astronomical and today’s new climate economy report shows that the road to a low carbon economy does not have to hurt the economy. Every economist should be in favour of ambitious climate policy. How much and what kind of pressure is further needed to have a positive outcome at the European Council meeting in October? I would say three ambitious and binding targets is what we need. The Parliament has endorsed that and the idea is gaining ground in the Juncker Commission. Now it is time for the Council to follow this example. So, Member States, please take our citizens’ future seriously and overcome your short-term disagreements by deciding in favour of three ambitious and binding targets in October.

name: Merja Kyllönen
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, this is my first speech here, so let me borrow Madonna’s words: ‘like a virgin speaking for the very first time’, but hopefully not the last. It is clear that we have no time to waste. The new results of the IPCC regarding the scientific basis of climate change leave no room for hesitation. The global society must act now.  I do hope that world leaders will do what UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon has invited them to do next week, which is to bring bold announcements and actions that will reduce emissions, strengthen climate resilience and mobilise political will for an ambitious legally-binding agreement in 2015. We truly need a meaningful global agreement in 2015, and we must make progress in Lima. There is only one COP conference before the Paris Agreement, so pressure is mounting. Are we all on track, preparing our national commitments? Are our joint ambitions sufficient to make real progress in Paris? We need to raise the ambition level before 2020, and – at the same time – we have to create a credible pathway towards a low-carbon planet. We, who are economically stronger, must help those who are most vulnerable to climate change. We must do all we can to share the burden of taking action justly. It is a tall order for a one-day summit, but do we have an alternative while glaciers are melting?

name: Bas Eickhout
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. I would also like to thank Mrs Hedegaard first of all for the five years of commitment. I have known you for about five years, after the Copenhagen fiasco, which you also led. But you have shown an incredible amount of commitment over the last five years and that is also greatly appreciated by our group. The result is only too limited, which remains our major problem, of course. And I think that will also be the problem, next week in New York, that the rest of the world will be a little tired of the european Union's empty words. We lead, we are doing so well, we are on our way to the 2020 goals. But where exactly are we headed? The 2020 targets are not ambitious at all, we have already achieved them. So we are now promising eight years of stagnation as an EU for the rest of the world. What exactly are we going to promise after 2020? We are talking about minus 40%, but if you look at the negotiations now, we are going to take some rights from emissions trading after 2020 and from non-ETS sectors, all to make those minus 40% mainly a paper reality, but in reality this will not be anything. And then the finances. We have been calling for years for finance for developing countries, but we are still not delivering anything! We are being called upon to say that kind of empty phrases and it will be important, next week in New York, for Europe to do more. You have the Heads of Government - and I am also looking at the Italian President - together, but it is time that we also brought the finance ministers together and that we really get a commitment from the Heads of Government to get a very ambitious and credible 2030 package without horse-trading on the table in October.

name: Piernicola Pedicini
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I must say that we are indeed very surprised, because I have here with me the final document of the European Council of 20 and 21 March 2014, where the 'Climate and Energy' section is confirmed as the framework for strategic action to achieve the specific objectives of the European Union set for both 2030 and 2050 – the most ambitious ones. The document once again talks about increasing energy production from renewable sources, about further reducing greenhouse gas emissions, about modernising the energy sector, about energy security in both the supply and supply of energy, and who could disagree with all this? Who could oppose this? But then we find out once again that words are not matched by deeds, because this document was signed by Juncker, who has just appointed Miguel Arias Cañete, who has been the oil industry's impresario and has spoken out strongly in favour of fracking techniques, that is, highly polluting techniques such as hydraulic fracking. The same is the case for Renzi, who was a signatory of the same document, who at the same time implemented a completely unconstitutional measure in Italy to double oil extractions both in the Adriatic Sea and in the Ionian Sea and on the Sicilian coasts, and on land in Basilicata and Sicily.  Gentlemen, we are in Europe, so these are also your seas and they are also your lands. All this with the complicity of the Lucanian Pittella, who then sold off his land. That is why I am addressing you, ladies and gentlemen. Let's not trust these people who say things and then do exactly the opposite of what they say. If we do not want to be their accomplices, we absolutely control every single measure they produce, because we must never trust those who betray their land.

name: Olaf Stuger (NI). -
text: The EU spends tens of billions each year to combat the alleged climate change. This is the way for every European citizen to be able to take a hard look without any scientific justification for the need for this. This money can be better spent by the independent Member States themselves on really important issues, such as research into ALS, cancer, health care, education or the care of our elderly. These are goals that have real results. After years of intensive research into climate change, it is still unclear whether our earth is warming or cooling down. The IPCC, through its juggling of figures and demonstrable scientific errors, has fed the argument that we do not really know at all how the climate will develop. Unexpectedly, for example, it appears that 1.8 million km2 of Arctic ice has grown in two years. But even if the earth were to warm, it remains to be seen whether humans have any influence over it. Of the 100 scientists, 50 claim that man has a very strong hand in this, and the other 50 strongly deny this. There is so much uncertainty in this climate debate that I have started to look for one fact that is beyond the surface and I have come across that. The only thing that is undisputed is that every day thousands of people make a lot of money from this hype. And that these people have every interest in perpetuating this hype, this very uncomfortable big lie.

name: Ivo Belet (PPE). -
text: Unfortunately, dear friends, democracy requires us to listen to nonsense from time to time. That is our fate and we are, of course, committed to it. Commissioner, first of all, warm congratulations on your sincere and effective efforts in all that you have done, on your commitment and on the results you have achieved. Thank you very much and good luck and all the best in your future career. It is clear that next week's climate summit in New York offers us an excellent new opportunity to build a global coalition to tackle this warming. The political leaders of India and China plan to send their cat to New York. However, this does not absolve us Europeans of the moral obligation to be present at the highest level. We are counting on the EU, the European Commission and the Council to be present at the highest level and to underline our commitment in New York, to strengthen a binding agreement in Lima and, of course, in Paris next year.  The European Commission has already put the EU proposals for 2030 on the table.    It is now up to our Heads of State and Government to conclude an ambitious agreement on this next month, on 23 October, and to make it clear that Europe is in favour of continuing to take its leading role. It is also important that next week we make it clear that we support the World Bank's call on the price of CO2. We have, of course, put a price on CO2 in Europe and we want to strengthen our ETS system, which is under pressure during the economic crisis. Crucially, we are going for a robust and predictable CO2 price that gives our companies and governments effective incentives to turn these climate efforts into a real opportunity.

name: Linda McAvan (S&D). -
text: Madam President, I think it was a good idea by Ban Ki-moon to have the summit next week. As Commissioner Hedegaard has said, we do need some momentum because it really is ‘make your mind up time’ on climate change in the next 15 months. Will we do something, or will we simply let the problem get worse? I agree with everybody here who said that we need to go with a credible EU package – a package on our emissions for 2030, but also, as the Commissioner has said, on our finances. A few years ago, I went to northern Kenya and met pastoralists who lived in a very remote community. Those people’s lives have changed already because of climate change. Their children are going hungry now because of climate change. Their daughters were being married off younger nine years ago because of climate change. It was just before Gleneagles, and we talked about ‘Make Poverty History’ but we will never make poverty history unless we tackle climate change. That is why next week is so important. I want to ask the Commissioner – and I think President Barroso is going to New York– what we are taking there. Are we taking a package from Member States? Are we going to speak with one voice there? How is the Commission going to present in New York what the EU is doing? Lastly, I want to add my voice to everybody here who has spoken about the work of Connie Hedegaard and her commitment to climate change in the past five years. As Peter Liese said, Commissioner, there have been some very difficult moments and you always remained optimistic and always said that we would get somewhere in the end. I hope that next week we get somewhere, and I hope your optimism becomes infectious among the world leaders and that you continue to work in this area in the future. Thank you very much. I would also like to thank your staff for all the work they did.

name: Marek Józef Gróbarczyk (ECR). -
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Climate policy assumptions in the light of the forthcoming climate summit should raise doubts among individual Member States and citizens of the European Union. For years, the position of EU bodies has been rejected by the world's largest economies, not particularly China and the United States. This position should be reviewed on the basis of the need to guarantee the european Union's energy security and ensure the competitiveness of the Union's economies. The Union's non-reflective policy of dismantling the coal industry is self-harming and has the direct effect of making Europe completely dependent on focused supplies from the east. The direct effect of decarbonising eu economies is to increase the unemployment rate, which is the cause of severe social consequences. I therefore call on the Commission and the Council and its President to break with the existing climate policy, which is ruining the economies of many European Union countries.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union and its Member States are from the very first moment at the forefront of the global fight to limit greenhouse gas emissions. The truth is that the European Union has been meeting the objectives it has set for itself. Not only did it reduce its emissions, but it has liquidated its financial commitments with developing countries so that they, in turn, are part of the global effort to reduce those same emissions. The reality leads us to increasingly believe that the need for the involvement of our external partners in this process is crucial, in a context where the European Union accounts for a d-least share of global emissions. Underlying climate negotiations are two conflicting development models: one that remains stuck in the past and the other facing the future. The present economic context has made the transition between these two models much more difficult. The truth is that globalisation results in part from the competitiveness of industry, resulting in a loss of competitiveness of European industry vis-à-vis our external partners when they acquire advantages through environmental dumping. However, the current costs of investing in research, innovation and the reconversion of our productive resources, as well as into a societal model, are much lower than future environmental costs if nothing is done. As Europeans we will always be in a good position to take advantage of the economic opportunities that green growth offers. That is why I believe that the European Union's commitment to the next UN summit, which will be held this month in New York, should be fully and concerted. We must work to achieve truly ambitious and binding commitments if we are to continue to believe that it is possible to halt the ongoing climate change. I believe that the path chosen by the European Union is the right one.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President, I believe that, at the UN Summit in New York, all developed and populous states must be called upon to join the commitment to reduce CO2. Without a uniform procedure, there is a very uneven economic situation, which, among other things, is mainly paid for by the Countries of the European Union with a large share of industrial production.  Meanwhile, CO2 reduction will remain merely a symbol of the search for new carbon-free technologies. It is necessary to abandon the ideological approach and concentrate on finding new sources of energy. The ideological approach of some countries is both a vicious circle and a dead end at the same time. We do not need to combat climate change, which has always taken place, will always take place and are completely beyond the reach of being influenced by means of civilisation. We need to secure resources and energy for future generations and reduce energy poverty. It is necessary to secure resources that do not fundamentally harm key elements of the environment and are affordable. This is the position I expect the Member States and the Commission to hold at the UN Climate Summit in New York in a few days' time.

name: Isabella Lövin (Verts/ALE). -
text: Madam President, we had a very unusual summer in Sweden this year. We had the largest forest fire in modern Swedish history. I do not know if you could even smell the smoke in Denmark, but we actually had to call for fire-fighters from Italy to help us. We had floods, we had sudden violent rainfall and the human and economic consequences of all this are enormous. When we look at the future, the consequences of a warming planet with competition for water and for farmland, with rising sea levels, we will see climate refugees and there will be enormous economic and human consequences. So how will we explain all this to our children and grandchildren? That the burning of brown coal was just so cheap that it was not profitable to switch to renewables? That we had the technology for renewables but we did not use it, we did not invest in it because it was not competitive? I would like to say to the Council that we all know that the only way of making renewable energy and smart energy savings lucrative for the industry is if the EU sets binding targets that will drive global innovation and investment in this direction, so we can eventually leave the cheap and dirty coal in the ground. We know there is enough free and eternally renewable energy around for us to build a new clean society that we can be proud of and that is what I want to be able to tell my children and grandchildren that we did. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: It asks according to the procedure "blue card". – Mr President, Mrs Lövin has touched on one crucial aspect: burning coal is really cheap. Technologies exist, but burning is cheaper and the question I ask you here, to you, taking into account the position of your carbon market support group, a mechanism that has revealed to society its perversity, which has brought us to this situation where burning is cheaper, if they are finally willing to change that position and defend instead of the market approach they have been advocating , a regulatory approach that replaces the carbon market.

name: Isabella Lövin (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you Mr Ferreira, it is clear that the emission trading scheme is not sufficient in order to replace fossil fuels and switch over to renewables, so we need the binding targets. I think that is the main political message that we can send to the industry and to research: that this is the future for Europe. Now to emit one tonne of CO2 costs only EUR 5 and to try to put it in the ground with carbon capture and storage costs EUR 40; by that I mean it is too cheap to put this CO2 in the air. That is a fact.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD). -
text: Madam President, it seems that some of our colleagues are determined to write a suicide note for European economies. Energy Commissioner Günther Oettinger said that Europe cannot afford a unilateral climate policy. Former Industry Commissioner Antonio Tajani said that we are creating an industrial massacre in Europe with energy prices. They were right. We should listen to them.  Our energy prices are driving industry, jobs and investment out of the EU altogether, often to jurisdictions with lower environmental standards. We are damaging our economies and arguably increasing global emissions at the same time. Major economies around the world will not agree to swingeing emission cuts. We cannot lead if nobody follows. Our first priority in Lima must be to ensure that the EU is no longer disadvantaged in terms of energy prices compared with our major competitors.  There are 1200 new coal-fired power stations in the global pipe line. Emissions will rise whatever we do. Let us not ruin our economy in a futile attempt to halt the inevitable. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: blue-card question. – I have a question for Mr Helmer. Have you ever looked outside your own nation and your own Parliament? Because there actually are countries that are succeeding in having economic growth and strong industry and a strong economy, and still lowering their emissions from fossil fuels. In Sweden we currently have more than 50% of renewables in our energy system. But, in order to achieve that, you need to have a government that is actually able to do it, and if industries are moving away from your country it is not because you have a strong scheme for saving the climate, it is probably because you have a too weak one that is not forcing your industries to be better at doing the right thing.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – Well, I do not know the details of energy prices in your country, but I do know that Europe as a whole has the most expensive energy prices of any major economic area. I know that the reason for that is gross over-investment in inefficient and intermittent renewables. We are doing huge damage to our economy; there is no question of it. And we have to compete with America, which has cheap shale gas; with China and India, which have cheap coal and are building coal-fired power stations as if they were going out of style. Get real, realise the dangers. These are your countrymen’s jobs you are worrying about – or not worrying about.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to highlight here the contradictions of European Union policy just days before the New York climate summit.  Indeed, Europe is hypocritical. On the one hand, our economies are being imposed repressive and costly environmental policies in the name of global warming, and on the other hand, we are promoting globalized trade that is completely disastrous for our jobs and whose carbon footprint, to reason like you, is catastrophic. What environmental policies do, liberal policies do, defeat it. In fact, to take an example, when you import a toaster made in China, you not only have to transfer the raw materials to China, process them in factories that often have an energy efficiency three times lower than ours, but also re-export the finished product to Europe. The question is: how many trees do you need to plant to offset the carbon footprint of the manufacture and import of this toaster? So I ask myself the following question: is Europe, in pursuing this liberal policy, not really seeking to relocate pollution at the same time as jobs? When you go to the New York summit to demand that developing countries reduce their carbon emissions, remember that these countries produce pollution to produce cheaply the goods we import. So we have to stop the pretences.  Europe, at the New York climate summit, can show what its real priorities are. Either save both the climate and our jobs, or pursue unbridled and destructive free trade. We have to stop covering our faces. The climate objective and widespread free trade are totally incompatible.  That is why we advocate, for our part, the development of short circuits and localism, because only this mode of production and distribution will significantly reduce the energy balance and the carbon footprint of freight transport. Above all, it will help to stop the hemorrhaging of jobs that you have unleashed and which Europe is experiencing today.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE). -
text: Madam President, climate change and their slowdown are a key political issue today. The negotiations so far have shown that despite being aware of the need to agree on reducing greenhouse gas emissions, there is still a lack of consensus on how commitments should be shared between countries. Europe is working hard to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, while encouraging other countries and regions to do the same. But are we still doing enough and just what we need to do? My view is that climate change must be better prevented, but not that our main mechanism is to relocate production to other countries or to trade in emissions, as this does not help either the economy or the environment. I am in favour of supporting more strongly low-carbon and green economies that create new jobs, protect the social security of employees and protect the environment. Better prevented than treated, it's an old folk proverb. We should listen to the people and already take concrete measures so that tomorrow is not too late for us, our children, our planet. Because climate change is happening today, it is happening to us and its negative impact includes damages caused by more frequent and stronger natural disasters.  Croatian citizens are experiencing terrible and unprecedented floods for the third time this year. Many of them were left behind by Serbian aggression without homes, and now floods have destroyed both their houses and their land. Therefore, I call for solidarity with the Croatian people but also for a fair balance of distributed obligations between industrial countries and those that contribute very little to greenhouse gas emissions and suffer because of them, because they are faced with a lack of capacity and resources in order to adapt to them.

name: Jo Leinen (S&D). -
text: Madam President! The New York Summit is intended to bring new dynamism. This is also urgently needed, because emissions are rising and rising, and we are actually moving further away from the 2° Celsius target than we are approaching this goal. Today, a study was published: Better Growth, better Climate, made for the summit, which once again shows clearly that climate protection can be a driver of economic activity and investment and is not a contradiction. However, the right policy framework is lacking. Fossil and nuclear energy is still subsidised. The price of CO2 is far too low. With around 70 trillion or trillions of investments, the wrong priorities are set, just not sustainable projects.  I believe that the EU is good, but not good enough, and I hope that we will not get any worse in the new period. Climate protection must be an independent category and must not be squeezed into another portfolio. Mrs Hedegaard, you have set standards, thank you for that. We will also have to judge the new Commission on this.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE). -
text: Madam President, as a token of respect for the Commissioner who is leaving office, and as a thank you for the good job she has done, I will speak in Swedish, my native language. Madam President, I would like to begin by congratul It is an extremely important meeting that we will meet next week. During these years of financial crisis, ambitions in the climate field have become much, much weaker. Too many people have not seen the challenges that have turned into opportunities in terms of research, new jobs and an increased flow of energy. We can also see an energy, political and security crisis vis-à-vis our eastern neighbours. We can see how Ukraine is struggling and now fear the winter to come. We all have a responsibility to ensure that we get more of the energy but also more of the right energy in our energy mix. We need systems that are strong and are moving in the right direction. It will also drive forward jobs.  Anyone who says that it costs jobs has missed the debate that is going on about all the technology, all the companies and all the jobs that can be done from this. Anyone who does not want to see emissions and climate gases as a major problem also misses the fact that 94 000 people are estimated to die annually because of emissions that we make and which affect their health and their lives. We have a chance to do this, but for that we need to put a lot of political weight into next week's meeting, so that we have momentum for the meetings to come. I wish you all the best.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President, Ban Ki-moon’s UN climate change summit later this month should be an opportunity to provide a much needed refocusing for political leaders across the world to pledge serious climate commitments. Unfortunately, however, given past experience, I have serious doubts that the right actions will be taken at the right time; time which we are letting run through our hands. As the global poor suffer from a climate crisis not of their doing, developed regions such as Europe must take the lead on this issue and it is regrettable, therefore, that the European Commission has not adopted a more ambitious position. Europe’s political leaders have to start listening to scientists, environmental groups and people’s movements that will be on the streets across the world this Sunday, including in my own native town of Dublin, the People’s Picnic, and stop listening to the scare stories of lost profits spread by big business who will decry anything which requires them to take account for their actions which harm the environment.

name: Yannick Jadot (Verts/ALE). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I join in the congratulations, and it would be absolutely tragic, pitiful, if this House were to validate the transformation of the Climate Commissioner into an oil and conflict of interest commissioner. Because there's an emergency. With all the scientific reports that follow, inaction today is a crime against humanity. We see it all the time on climate issues, the future catches up with us: the effects that were foreseen in ten, twenty or thirty years are happening. Unfortunately, when it comes to energy, the past paralyzes us.  It is clear that there is a tendency for the European Union today to act less on energy transition, to listen to the sirens of an energy counter-revolution. As we know, the Stern report says, acting in the energy transition also means getting out of the crisis.  We cannot be satisfied today with the Commission's proposals on energy efficiency, renewable energy, in the climate-energy package. 40% energy efficiency by 2030, this is what the ENVI and ITRE commissions recommend, and it is also two thirds less Russian gas imports by 2030. Nor can we be satisfied with the weakness of the renewable energy target. So, and I am speaking to the Italian Presidency and the European Commission, we must have a big climate-energy package, because Europe will lead the climate negotiations if it is exemplary.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this summer in the South, in my saffron field in Italy, while in the middle of August the orange trees were still exceptionally in bloom, I was already catching spontaneous broccoli months in advance. Why do I tell that? Several years ago – we never thought we would end up here and have those responsibilities – we learned about climate change. A long time ago. We have been sitting here for years, comfortable, arguing, while outside this change is a serious reality. It reaps victims, it triggers conflicts over resources, it increases migratory flows. It is a perfect, social and energy storm, climatic and economic, which is not yet understood or accepted. We care more about the market and the default of banks than about the chaos of the natural systems on which we depend. Very soon, the same extreme solutions that today seem politically impractical, economically impracticable, will become the only way out for everyone. We soon rewrite our history, the history of humanity in New York.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE). -
text: Madam President, I'm looking at something more optimistic on this subject, maybe we could give the headline "From Copenhagen and Cancun through New York and Lima to Paris." We see for ourselves that the climate is changing faster than expected and the effect is worse than predicted. The UN Climate Change Conference in New York should make all participants aware that fighting climate change has much more positive effects than can be done at first glance.  Here, first of all, I think of a green economy that is slightly promoted as one of the main generators of economic growth. Reducing greenhouse gas emissions, increasing the share of renewables, increasing energy efficiency is the only correct way if we want to leave this world to our children. Binding targets are needed, not only between European Union countries, but also worldwide. Europe is one of the important, global players on the world stage, which must show by its example that fighting climate change can create jobs. I am also talking about Mr Juncker and his agenda, where one of the very important points is a strong Energy Union with a forward-thinking climate policy. And he calls the administration on the green economy. I believe we'll prove it over a five-year period. In any case, this fight should be seen as an opportunity, not a threat, because I believe that we are witnesses - storms, floods, sea level rise, droughts, etc., especially in my home country of Croatia, have happened several times in a year, caused umeasurable economic damage - so I urge that we all roll up our sleeves together and protect our planet so that we can hand it over to those from whom we borrowed this country. Finally, I want to thank Commissioner Hedegaard for her hard work and I am positive.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it has already been mentioned that the international roadmap of climate policies has important stages ahead of it between now and the coming months: the UN climate summit in New York as early as next week, the twentieth conference between the parties in Lima next December and finally the agreement that will emerge from the Paris Conference in 2015. Of course, the UN summit is a valuable opportunity to immediately relaunch the urgent need for decisive decisions for a global policy to combat climate change. We must tell ourselves, the European Union has always played a leading role in climate policies, a role that will have to be reiterated in the new Climate 2030 package and which I hope the new Commission will love to interpret. It is also because what many speakers have said before me is true: promoting a low-emission society is not only the way to combine environmental protection, but also to set up and promote new industrial policies, to relaunch the competitiveness of our economies and also to create new jobs. But we have to be serious. The European effort alone is not enough, because then it becomes a zero-sum game for Europe. We, the fight against climate change, must do so with a global agreement, but unfortunately it has not yet been achieved. That is why I believe that, in my opinion, the European Union should strengthen its initiative and combine traditional diplomacy with a strengthened role... (The President withdrew the speaker from the floor.)

name: Richard Sulík (ALDE). -
text: Madam President! Climate targets are important, without question. It is also nice that the UN is committed to this and is calling for a summit in New York. But this is not the European Union's biggest problem at the moment. The biggest problem is unemployment, and it exists because competitiveness is steadily declining. The climate targets are in direct conflict with competitiveness. It is a question of what we need more. The EU cannot afford to lead the way for financial reasons. These are dreams; the EU is in debt to the ears. The EU has 26 million unemployed, little growth and a heap of debt. In New York, there may be good food for 25 or 28 heads of government, but there are no jobs there. This will only be the case if the EU continues to increase its competitiveness. But it is doing the opposite, and that is why the share of industry is falling. Perhaps the EU should take a break in the area of climate targets and devote itself to the unemployed.

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD)
text: Question "blue card" to Simona Bonafè.
