Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to know from the honourable Member whether you are aware that there is perhaps no compatibility with oil extraction in order to achieve the objectives we are talking about. I would like to know whether you are aware that fracking has repercussions with very serious environmental damage in the territory, and I would like to know whether you are aware that exposure to hydrocarbons is carcinogenic.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: Answer to a blue card question. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I shall also take less than thirty seconds to reply to the honourable Member, not least because I do not understand where these questions come from in relation to my speech, which I have not even been able to conclude.  After that, they seem to me to be such technical issues that, I think, here, which is a more political forum, perhaps it would be worth perhaps focusing on other issues and, above all, highlighting the effort all together – because that is what it is – to bring about changes to climate change policies now.

name: Iosu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President, I am more pessimistic than the Commission. It's not just that they close their eyes to climate change, it's that many states are actively working in the wrong direction. It follows the game of the sale of broadcast rights, the game of large corporations; there is no political will or vision for the future to develop an economy based on renewable energy; and it is clear that they will not meet the already insufficient obligations by 2030 in climate policy. And now they nominate Mr Arias Cañete as European Commissioner for Climate and Energy. I recognize your coherence – it will be perfect to continue in the wrong direction – but I invite you to reconsider. It's a dire choice for the environment. Ladies and gentlemen, let us send the right message to society, to youth. Let us act, let us already address the structural causes of climate change and change the system that generates them. The public sector must finance the transition to economic models based on renewable energy, food sovereignty, public transport, education... It's not utopia, it's social justice, it's economic justice, and it's what the climate needs.

name: Marco Affronte (EFDD). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I hear talk of climate change still using the future: 'it will happen', 'it will happen', 'we will do'. In fact, the effects of global warming are an emergency that is already under way and the term 'climate refugees' is sadly topical. Next week's summit will be held in New York. Well, it is a few months ago, in March 2014, a worrying fact that concerns the United States: 65% of respondents to a survey know that global warming is taking place, but half of them do not believe that it will entail serious risks or consequences. We call for the European Union to be a leader in combating climate change, including by engaging productively with the world of science, the world of scientific dissemination, information and public involvement. We have heard in this House how much we need the right scientific information, because someone still does not believe in climate change. We call on the European Union to speak with one voice and to participate as a protagonist in international climate negotiations. By the next Summit in Paris, a new agreement must be reached, otherwise next year's summit will end like the previous ones: so many promises and few facts.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D). -
text: Madam President, it has already been said here that the New York Summit is not binding, but it is important. In the light of the latest scientific data, neither extensions nor postponements can be possible. It is therefore essential that the European Union, which has once been an undisputed leader against climate change, does not turn its back on Ban Ki-moon. And for that, gestures count. We do not fight climate change by penalizing renewable energy, selling natural spaces to the highest bidder, or prudently opening, wide doors, or betting exclusively on fossil fuels. This is not how we fight climate change. We would not like the United Nations to start looking to European bench with concern and concern. That is why, from this Parliament, we will be very demanding with the role that the new College of Commissioners will play in this area. It's a lot of responsibility and any step back would be irresponsible.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, in essence, if we take seriously the issue of climate change, as you and we do, what you have said about the two-degree objective is absolute. And yet we are not sure we will. In this spirit, the New York meeting comes a little, for us Europeans, as a countdown to be able to make the Paris conference, this CoP 21, the success to which we all aspire. But for that, there are steps to be taken along the way. First, there is this October summit that must be succeeded. We are counting on you to transform the situation and to convince the Heads of State and Government, through President Barroso, that these binding targets will finally be adopted.  Then there is the issue of inequalities in the fight against climate change and disruption. This issue of inequality invites us to raise the issue of the financial aspect that you mentioned, to which we are very attached and which also concerns inequalities in our Member States. And finally, of course, the question arises of the growth model and therefore what is the model that allows us to be in harmony with a coherent strategy in Europe and on a global scale.

name: Jytte Guteland (S&D). -
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by congratul This is my first intervention in Parliament. It feels good to speak in Swedish, because I know that the Swedish people want us to take a strong position for the climate. I would therefore also like to address the Swedish electorate and say that it is very, very important to do so for Parliament. I would like to address the outgoing Commissioner and say that next week is an important summit. I think that by virtue of our size we should absolutely take a leading role in all contexts where we have an opportunity to take the leadership. However, be it at the meeting next week, I would also like to point out to this Parliament that we have an important role to play in ensuring that the climate and energy package is tough, that it contains three binding targets, that we take responsibility both for emissions, for renewable energy and for energy efficiency. So whatever happens next week, we as a Parliament too must continue to push ahead and ensure that this becomes a reality by 2030. World leaders have an important role next week, but we in the European Parliament and the next Commission must also ensure that there are important years to come.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner Hedegaard, we were together in December 2009 in Copenhagen to witness, unfortunately, this fiasco, for us who are these lovers of the Earth - you, all of us - preventing us from effectively combating warming and climate change.  You were also a pioneer in 2012 to enable the Green Fund to be set up. We know that it must be worth EUR 100 billion by 2020 in order to be transferred to developing countries. Today, however, it is a transfer of a few million euros to these developing countries. You said recently, in June, that finally there would be no direct distribution, direct funding from the European Commission, because we were not on the board. I think we need to make sure that we have direct funding before this summit. I would like you to be able to respond to that.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, from the forthcoming climate summit in New York, we expect progress to be made towards a new global agreement on the future international climate regime and on measures to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The European Union must promote an agreement that obliges all countries to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions and must propose a sound and stable regulatory framework. The summit should be an opportunity to mobilise all states in favour of climate protection and to show that, with the necessary technological and financial support, emerging and developing countries can effectively reduce CO2 emissions without compromising their economic growth. Unfortunately, China and India, the world's first and third most polluting countries, have announced that they will not be attending the summit. In line with shared targets for 2030, decarbonisation can be accelerated, implementing a number of measures including a programme of progressive replacement of high-carbon fuels and technologies, a global carbon tax and overcoming tariff barriers and low-emission technologies. Today is International Day for the Protection of the Ozone Layer. I hope that the new European Commission, which has brought energy and climate matters into line... (The President withdrew the speaker from the floor.) (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question, Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: Blue card question. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Caputo, I would like to ask you how you reconcile your statements, with which I agree, with what are then the facts, with what you are combining in Italy with the granting of new oil concessions at sea, despite what you have just said about the need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and the consumption of fossil fuels.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: Answer to a blue card question. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am, of course, answering my ideas and the things I say. I have said things that you agree with, so I do not understand the reason for your question and I would like to take this opportunity to continue the reasoning of earlier.  I said that today, which is International Day for the Protection of the Ozone Layer, I hope that the new European Commission, which has brought energy and climate matter into line, will be able to take all the necessary action to keep the rise in global temperature at less than two degrees Celsius, without burying its head in the sand, or worse under a lot of coal.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE). -
text: Madam President, I support the reports submitted by the Council representative and commissioners and welcome the continued cooperation as part of the UN Climate Conference convened in New York by the UN Secretary-General, Ban Ki Moon, to ensure that a final agreement is reached on reducing greenhouse gas emissions in Paris next year. The issue of climate change is a global issue where the European Union is not only a leader in reaching emissions reduction standards, but also in developing innovative green technologies that should enable the transition to a low-carbon economy. It is evident that we are working on achieving the goals by 2020, Croatia is a good example that has already exceeded the objectives of the Kyoto Protocol, and by adopting a low-carbon development strategy by 2050 it has ensured the continuation of the same policy. In my view, our support to developing countries of €4.5 billion from 2007 to 2013 was very important.  In the last term, we started developing a framework for the European Union's climate and energy policy by 2030, and I think it is essential that we finalise it soon. I expect the messages of the Climate Conference in New York to be a quality basis for reaching a final international agreement. (The Speaker agreed to answer the question by raising the blue card on the basis of Article 149(8) of the EEA. Rules of procedure.)

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD)
text: Blue card question. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, are you aware that Croatia is extracting, has it decided to extract oil throughout the Adriatic and is it already implementing them? Does that collide with what you just said?

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Madam President, what I was saying, I was talking about Croatia adopting a low-carbon development strategy by 2050 and ensuring the continuation of the policy, which is the policy of fulfilling the Kyoto Protocol. It's been going on for a few years. What you said is about explorations of the Adriatic that have been in normal process for several years.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, on the eve of another climate summit, we leave here questions that we have left in the past and which remain unanswered. First: carbon market. The failure and perversity of this option is well in sight. The measures proposed by the Commission to remove excess licences from the market do not solve the continuing problem. When to replace the market approach they have chosen with a normative approach?  Second ly: liberalisation and deregulation of international trade. The European Union, which is calling for a leader in combating climate change worldwide, is the same as the one that is continuing around the world to deregulate international trade, thereby increasing the flows of energy and matter associated with meeting the most basic human needs. For when the resolution of this contradiction?  Commissioner, in other words, and now that you have mr. Commissioner for Trade behind you, have you exchanged a few words about this? Have you thought about how many tons of CO2 are associated with the free trade agreements that the European Union is signing around the world?

name: Teresa Rodríguez-Rubio (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, life is more important than the benefit of business. A member of catastrophism was talking about the catastrophism of environmentalists. And it seems that we are the only ones who want to have children and grandchildren. Putting life at the center, that's our obligation. With unprecedented concentrations of greenhouse gases and seven million death from air pollution—some of them in my province, where Mr. Arias Cañete lives as well—heads of state and representatives of the world's most polluting transnational corporations gather in New York so that we can continue to dictate the policies that fill their pockets. To us policy dictaters are social movements and citizens, and they tell us: mandatory commitments already, renewable, local production and consumption. But no. My adopted countryman, Mr Cañete, is appointed Commissioner of Climate Action and Energy, who has just put his shares in oil companies up for sale. Minister of a government that spent eight hundred million euros buying allowances to pollute, while cutting in education, health and social services. Thanks for the example.

name: Connie Hedegaard
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, Linda McAvan asked how the EU will act in New York. I have already stressed it, but President Barroso will address the plenary, and he will do so as the first speaker in that plenary. That also says something about how the world perceives Europe’s role in international climate change. He will also bring messages – not only on our 2030 intentions and what we are planning to do and hopefully adopt by October – but he will also bring messages on financing and other key issues. He will also focus on what will come from the EU budget when it comes to international climate finance. I will, of course, also be there and will be participating in some of the thematic groups, while Commissioners Cioloş and Piebalgs will attend different side events. We will therefore have a strong representation there. Furthermore, 19 EU Heads of State and Government and of course the Italian Presidency will also be present. I must say that I am confident that the EU’s contribution on that day will help the UN Secretary-General to make the strongest possible résumé by the end of the day, with a view to pushing forward to Lima and from there on to Paris.  We also have a lot of other things planned on the sidelines of this major event. There is a major economic forum taking place, and the European Union has invited our good friends and allies from Durban. We will have a meeting of the progressive countries. A lot of things will take place that will, together, hopefully create momentum.  Mr Pargneaux asked about the Green Climate Fund and how it is that we – that is, the Commission – cannot pay money through a fund where we are not on the board. As far as I have understood it, it is an established practice, which is also accepted and endorsed by the European Parliament, that Community money can only be spent through international institutions if we actually have first-hand knowledge of how this money will be spent. That is a guarantee to European taxpayers. That is why, but it definitely does not mean that we will not give a lot of money to international climate finance through the EU Community budget, and this will also be made very clear in President Barroso’s speech.  Now, just one comment: I know that Mr Helmer has gone and I know that, even if he had been here, I would not be able to persuade him about climate change. But there is one thing I simply do not understand: how is it that efforts to reduce Europe’s energy dependency be blamed for rising energy prices in Europe? It could be that one of the reasons why we have higher energy prices in Europe than in other regions is that we have to import around 60% of our energy, meaning that today we are spending around EUR 400 billion each year. This is money that we send out of Europe to pay for our imported fossil fuels. Of those EUR 400 billion, EUR 140 billion is sent to Putin’s Russia. That is almost EUR 3 billion each week. Maybe that could also be an argument for European citizens being interested in knowing where their money is going.  Finally, thank you very much for the many kind words. I would like to reciprocate them by thanking many of you for the good cooperation over the years. I sincerely do hope that this new Parliament will help my successor to keep climate change high on the Commissions agenda, as well as on the EU’s agenda as a whole – including on our growth and economic agenda, which is where it really belongs. I really do believe that the world needs a strong European climate policy, and that it has to be very visible in the run-up to Paris next year. There will be a lot of work to do, not only for the Commission and the Council, but also without doubt for this new European Parliament. (Applause)

name: Benedetto Della Vedova
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a few words in conclusion. First of all, I would like to thank Commissioner Hedegaard for the efficiency with which she has summarised the European position on this issue and the position that we will be adopting as a Union in New York next week. It was certainly an explicit debate, as it were. We are comforted by the fact that today's debate also shows a majority consonance – evidently not unanimous, but majority – of views between the actors of the European Union – Parliament, the Commission and the Council. I would like to highlight one point among those that has been raised and which we particularly appreciate: the effort and the call to raise awareness of all Europe's partners worldwide, in the differences that we know – economic, growth and also the level of pollution – the effort to involve all partners. Therefore, the Presidency intends to continue this exchange and cooperate closely with Parliament in the run-up to the Lima Conference, in order to achieve the best possible results in view – it has been mentioned by many speeches – of the decisive Paris Conference next year for which we hope for success, and for success the European Union will commit itself without saving energy.

name: Sirpa Pietikäinen (PPE)
text: Written. – Next week, heads of state will meet in New York to discuss climate change for the first time since the Copenhagen Climate Conference in 2009. The gathering of 125 presidents and prime minister is an important moment to demonstrate the international community's determination to prevent humanity-induced climate change in the run-up to the 2015 Paris climate talks. The aim is both to accelerate the progress of difficult international negotiations and to encourage participants to hold discussions in their home countries on what that country is able to do to achieve a climate agreement. If we want to halt the disastrous consequences of uncontrolled climate change, next year's climate agreement must be both ambitious and internationally acceptable at the same time. The European Union's role in this process is still important, even though our share of the world's CO2 is falling. The EU must succeed in constructive cooperation with a wide range of partners and interests, and there is no room for a gap in the common European front.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. - More than ever, climate change is affecting the daily lives of citizens around the world. That is why I believe that environmental issues must become an integral part of the Union's security strategies. Achieving a low-carbon society by 2050 is one of the strategic guidelines, and the road ahead calls for even greater commitment and commitment to smart and sustainable growth, and a competitive market based on innovation and knowledge. According to the latest Eurobarometer survey, the level of awareness among European citizens in terms of environmental protection has increased significantly, despite the economic crisis, thus representing a fertile ground for implementing sustainable development policies that are significantly mapped out within the European Union by the Europe 2020 strategy. While recognising the interdeciousness of national economies, the fight against climate change creates the necessary synergy of sustainable economic development as well as the fulfilment of the set goals in respecting environmental standards in which the EU has always been at the forefront. The UN summit in New York is a call to make clear "yes" to a stronger implementation of measures to combat climate change and protect the environment. This is only a prelude to what awaits us in Paris in 2015, when we have to adopt a binding global climate treaty, acceptable to all parties. The clock is ticking, and Europe must play a leading role in the negotiations and take responsibility.

name: Die Präsidentin. -
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission's statement on the EU-Canada Free Trade Agreement (CETA) (2014/2848(RSP)).

name: Karel De Gucht
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, honourable Members of Parliament, after five years of intensive negotiations, the chief negotiators have finished their work to deliver a comprehensive economic and trade agreement between the EU and Canada. The Committee on International Trade (INTA) immediately received the full text, and it will be made public shortly. Canada is the first G8 member with whom we have agreed on a comprehensive trade deal. The agreement is crucial for the credibility of our trade agenda, because it confirms that we can do deals – even very good deals – in this case with a developed economy with its own established approach and regulatory framework. Hence the challenging times during the negotiations. The agreement is also very valuable in its own right; it creates opportunities for our business. Canada offers a sizeable market for European products and services. The operators get the same treatment, which is even better than that received by US competitors. This is an important achievement, sustaining our quest for more jobs and growth in Europe when you consider the uncertain economic backdrop on our continent. Politically, Canada is an important ally. It is also an important destination for European investments, and it also invests massively in the EU, creating jobs and wealth. Canada is rich in natural resources and raw materials and is a significant source of know-how. In short, through CETA, both sides will eliminate almost all customs tariffs (with very few exceptions). At the same time, a few very sensitive agricultural products will remain protected. The outcome concerning services and investment market access puts us on an even better footing than the US under NAFTA. It will also in no way affect the ability of EU governments at all levels to provide and subsidise public services. We have also achieved an unprecedented result on public procurement. Under CETA we receive significant access to public procurement markets in Canada at all levels of government. On investment, the agreement establishes a system that sets a new standard for investor-to-state dispute settlement procedures. We are well aware of the concerns that exist. This agreement directly addresses all the concerns that have emerged so far. Also I want to highlight the result on geographical indications. We have achieved very extensive protection in Canada of the designations of Europe’s high-quality agricultural products, be they Parmigiano Reggiano, Schwarzwälder Schinken, Bleu d’Auvergne or 132 others which are fully protected. This is one of the parts which most visibly show how CETA can also benefit small and medium-sized operators across Europe. The EU-Canada trade and investment relationship will not come at the expense of environmental or social and labour standards. We are both aware that we have a responsibility here. We have a higher standard in trade agreements, and it is more than Canada has done before. In terms of what happens next, President Barroso and the Canadian Prime Minister, Mr Harper, intend to publicly announce the conclusion of the negotiations at the EU-Canada Summit in Ottawa on 26 September. Further to this, both sides will submit this text to their respective legislators for verification and ratification. In the case of the EU this means to the Council and Parliament. Because legal verification and official translations take so long, I would expect signature and formal transmission of the text to Parliament to take place well into 2015. Coming this far, at a pace which has been punishing for those involved, is an important achievement which the Commission is proud of, and I look forward to this legislator’s support for CETA’s contribution to the creation of more jobs and growth in Europe.

name: Salvatore Cicu
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the aspects that have been mentioned by the Commissioner are important, particularly as regards the expectations that were there on this agreement. A troubled agreement, an agreement which logically raised the problem of transparency, raised the problem of protecting our small and medium-sized enterprises, but posed the problem of opening up a large market.  I believe that we have done an excellent job, and we have done an excellent job, particularly on the process of involving small and medium-sized enterprises. With the protection of geographical indications, an important result is achieved which sees one hundred and twenty-five of the one hundred and forty-five PGIs being protected, guaranteed and placed in a context, in an important international market. I would like to make a comment, however, on this point. I think it is important for each Member State to be invited to provide instruments, to give a leading role, to accompany a process of participation by small and medium-sized enterprises which, precisely because of their size and characteristics, are not capable of achieving in precise and concrete terms an immediate capacity to understand these rules, these schemes and these agreements. So, in order for there to be a production of effects, for there to be real automatism, we must, together with each Member State, realize the possibility that there will be a tutor, that there will be a trustworthiness, a reliability of financial and economic support. We are in a time of crisis, we are in a time where the small and medium closes, we are in a time where the suburbs are left alone to try to understand how to overcome this problem. I therefore believe that the agreement reached is important, but I believe that it is not enough, I believe that it is necessary that with sensitivity, with vision, we give dimension to this role of opening up the market to a Europe that needs, in its small and medium term, to find dignity, to find the capacity, to find an outlet that can certainly be achieved, because I would add, moreover – and it must be stressed – that the list of geographical indications is not closed. , the list of geographical indications still has the possibility, in addition to having Parmigiano Reggiano to have, for example – I come from Sardinia – Sardinian pecorino cheese and Pecorino Romano.  Therefore, my commitment – and I will also ask my other Sardinian colleagues – will be to include other protections, other geographical identities, other possibilities and opportunities for territories that need today, compared to a system that is suffering, to finally find a different outlet.

name: David Martin
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. –  Mr President, I should like to thank the Commissioner, for being with us this evening. On CETA, I really have more questions than comments that I wish to put to you tonight. Firstly, it is strongly rumoured that the Council is not going to initial this text. I may be wrong, but I think this is the first time that the Council has not initialled a text at the end of the negotiations. I would be interested to know if that is for political reasons, or if it has objections to the text, or if the Council does not regard the text as having been concluded. If indeed it does not regard the text as having been concluded, is there a possibility that investor state disputes could still come out of the CETA-negotiated text? As you know, Commissioner, my group would find it much easier to put its weight behind CETA if ISDS was removed from the text. We also have concerns in my group about generic medicines. We did hear from the chief negotiator in the Committee on International Trade, who gave me some reassurances, but I would like to hear from you tonight, Commissioner, that the CETA agreement will do nothing to limit Canadian production of generic medicines for the developing world. We also believe that the sustainable development chapter in CETA could be improved. And we also have issues regarding non-trade irritants, such as the seal ban, the visa-free travel that is denied to some EU citizens, and the issue of tar sands. Again, although they are separate from the trade deal, we would like to hear the Commission say that it is still working on solving these issues outside of the CETA negotiations. Just to be absolutely clear, though – just like the Commissioner, just as was outlined on the list – I see many positives in CETA, not least the issue of GIs, not least the opportunities for small and medium-sized industries, not least the access that dairy products are being given to the market and the beneficial access that spirits will be given to this market. These are all good news. However, we have certain principles in our group. We understand that trade negotiations mean that compromises have to be made on both sides, but there are certain things that we will not compromise on.

name: Ruža Tomašić
text: On behalf of the ECR Club– Madam President, at this session we have already considered the negative effects of the chilling relations with Russia. While I fear that the latest bans from Russia on agricultural and food products are not the last we will see from Putin, this example nevertheless makes it clear how damaging the closure of one major market can be for our products and services. But despite the alarming situation in trade relations with Russia, the European Union has a fantastic opportunity to finally improve its relationship with another major world state and tempting market - Canada. Under this treaty, Canada will open its public procurement market to European suppliers for the first time, and the expected 23% increase in exchanges of goods and services should lead to a 23% reduction in unemployment and annual gains for the EU of more than €10 billion. This is great news for Europe, which at the moment is in a bad way in need of new partners on the global stage. I understand reservations about ISDS, safeguards, but I don't consider them well-founded. Nine Member States have an ISDS instrument in their bilateral investment agreements with the United States, including Croatia. To my knowledge, there have been no problems so far to conclude that such an instrument is harmful to Member States. ISDS strikes a balance between the right and the state's need to regulate the market and investors' right to be protected from possible willfulness or discriminatory behaviour by national governments towards foreign investors. ISDS does not favour foreign capital before national sovereignty, as those who fear the application of this instrument think, but simply ensures respect for international law.  I believe that you will agree with me that the role of national government is not in opposition to profit, but indeed, ensuring a level playing field it participates in its creation. Through the ISDS instrument, private investors are guaranteed that national governments will actually fulfil their role, making the European market safer and thus even more desirable for foreign investment.  (The Speaker agreed to answer the question by raising the blue card on the basis of Article 162(8) of the Code of Health. Rules of procedure.)

name: Jörg Leichtfried (S&D)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Perhaps I would just like to say briefly that it is a great pleasure to see you here as chairman. On the question, Mrs President, you said that you are not aware of any problems relating to ISDS. Do you know that a Canadian minerals company is going to sue Romania because Romania is not prepared to grind out a village where people do not want to move out? Are you aware that a cigarette manufacturer wants to sue Australia because Australia wants to extend its non-smoking protection? Are you aware that an energy company wants to sue Germany because Germany wants to phase out nuclear energy? Are these no problems for you?

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Colleague, these may be problems, but not big enough to stop this big market with Canada. We lost Russia, we're going to lose Canada, we haven't established any better markets. So we may stay with our principles, but we're going to lose jobs and the market.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. –  Mr President, after five years of intense negotiations, reaching accord on the EU-Canada agreement is no small achievement. Congratulations on the results for Europe, but also for Canada. I hope this can be a true win-win. In all the complexities and controversies, we should not forget why we engage in trade negotiations at all. Our goals are clear: we seek economic growth and the creation of jobs for Europeans, especially as Russia has reacted to the much-needed EU sanctions for its aggression in our Eastern Neighbourhood. The best way we can alleviate the impact of the damage to European businesses and farmers is by facilitating exports and market access elsewhere in the world. Market access through procurement is an important accomplishment in the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) and, by and large, the standards in relation to the planet, privacy and food safety have not been traded away. That is important. More controversial, however, is the investor-state dispute settlement (ISDS) mechanism. EU Member States have no less than 1400 bilateral agreements that include ISDS, and while the mechanism was sought after by Europeans investing in countries where the rule of law does not exist, it is now leading to controversy. In the CETA, I see that some improvements have been realised, such as the inclusion of provisions to increase the impartiality of arbitration judges and to provide more transparency and better protection against frivolous cases, but still the key question of whether or not we need ISDS between two mature democracies with the rule of law should be answered. This question is relevant not only for the CETA: many of us look at the text of this agreement with the anticipation of finding clues for the much more impactful 	 currently in negotiation. I look forward to learning more about the results of the public consultation, to which an unprecedented number of citizens and stakeholders replied. Even though the text of the CETA cannot now be changed, Commissioner, I urge the Commission to ensure that Europeans can engage actively and transparently with you to obtain clarification before having to give their votes.

name: Anne-Marie Mineur
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – The CETA agreement is still not final. That is good news and should remain so. There are far too many open issues that the national parliaments have yet to discuss. This agreement gives power to the big companies in Europe and Canada. They have had an extensive opportunity to say exactly what they want and the 150,000 responses of the European population to the ISDS mechanism are set aside. These are the people who have elected this Parliament together and who are ultimately your boss, Mr De Gucht. It is clear that the people do not want these agreements, and rightly so. There are more and more examples of companies appealing against democratic decision-making. Can you guarantee, Mr De Gucht, that Canadian companies such as Lone Pine Resources will not also force European countries to extract shale gas, as they do in Canada? Can you guarantee that European countries can decide to freeze nuclear energy without being sued? Can you guarantee that our European workers will retain the right to strike and that our collective agreements will remain valid unabated? Sixteen European parliaments, including the Dutch, sent a letter to you in June, stating that both CETA and TTIP should remain in mixed agreements so that the national parliaments have the final say. These parliaments represent two thirds of the European population. Can you guarantee that CETA and TTIP are mixed agreements?

name: Yannick Jadot
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Commissioner, for environmentalists, this agreement - on which citizens will learn that the negotiations have been concluded but they still do not have access to their content - carries, very clearly, much more risks than benefits.  As far as agriculture is concerned, we are dealing with farms in Canada that are ten times larger on average than farms in France. The risk is known for breeding. On the issue of GMOs, this agreement seems to say that there would be a forum for cooperation between the Canadian authorities and the European authorities, including so that European GMO legislation does not call into question the prospects for trade. We believe that public procurement should not simply be seen as commercial tools but as tools for assistance, especially to local businesses. Then, of course, there is this ISDS issue. You see that more and more governments and members of this Parliament are opposing it because they see it as a challenge to their ability to make a democratic decision. I understand that the German government is trying to change this ISDS, particularly on the issue of debt restructuring or banks. We will not be enough in the European Parliament and I hope that the groups that are speaking out against isIS will continue in the coming weeks. This Parliament must reject CETA, especially if there is this investment agreement.

name: Tiziana Beghin
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, just like TTIP, CETA is an agreement conceived secretly in the rooms of Brussels, decided by bureaucrats who have not been elected by anyone and who will have to answer to no one for what they do. And just like TTIP, the consequences for citizens will be as unknown as they are harmful, because actually eliminating duties is not the only thing, but we have seen that all barriers to selling a product in a state that has different regulations are removed. Therefore, we are probably giving the green light to GMOs on our tables, and Canada is not complying with the same environmental constraints as small and medium-sized enterprises in Europe. I have already said on other occasions that Canada has not signed the extension of the Kyoto Protocol. I am an entrepreneur and I have in mind what it means to produce in Europe with environmental and health constraints, which I share anyway. But do you have any idea what that means? How can our small and medium-sized enterprises compete with those who do not have to comply with these constraints at all?  And then we talk about the environment. When in Canada, in the Alberta region, oil is extracted from the tar sands deforesting entire forests. With this agreement we may have access to cheaper oil, but at what price? And then the ISDS clause. It's a clause, gentlemen, that would be really ridiculous if it wasn't so dangerous. It allows a multinational company to sue a state. So, ladies and gentlemen, I am addressing all of you with a public consultation that was done when everything had already been decided anyway... (The President withdrew the speaker from the floor.)

name: Marine Le Pen (NI). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as you know, the free trade treaty between the European Union and Canada will soon be put to your vote. A chapter is crucial regardless of your political beliefs, since it is about justice. This text that we have received provides for the establishment of private justice between multinationals and states in place of public justice. This is the investor-state dispute settlement mechanism. This private court is made up of an arbitration tribunal that can be referred when a multinational based in France, for example, considers that the new laws, the new standards are unfavourable to its activity. The State will no longer be able to enforce the French people's social choices, their collective preferences, it must first take into account the interests of multinationals before making a decision.  For example, the Canadian government is being attacked in this private court by an oil company that accuses it of having a moratorium on shale gas. The private court is before us, Canada could be convicted for trying to protect its groundwater and the health of its inhabitants.  I am fundamentally opposed to the emergence of this private and opaque justice, created for multinationals. Justice must remain public and transparent. It is the best guarantee that it is fair, that the most powerful do not impose their law on all others.  In the Committee on International Trade, where I sit in Brussels, I have heard almost all Members say their opposition to this private justice, who is snuding. But the time for the vote is approaching, so is the hour of truth. Then, you will know, Members of the European Parliament, to show courage and defend your peoples. Will you, for once, say no to this shameful treaty imposed on us by the European Commission? The stakes are high. It is about justice and injustice. I beg you be brave. For once, vote no.

name: Franck Proust (PPE). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, what a tirade, Mrs Le Pen! We'll never change you. You think you're in a tragedy. "Cover this white-seing given to the commission that I cannot see!" You are there, Mrs Le Pen, but in history, if I may say so, it is you, tonight, Tartuffe. Ladies and gentlemen, of course we can be critical of everything, but we need arguments. Is it the role of parliamentarians here to mix credible arguments with conspiracy theories or ideologies?  This debate tonight comes as usual too soon. Some repeat the positions sent by lobbyists by spreading alarmist speeches. Yes, it is a historic agreement, with a Western partner and friend. Yes, we must be vigilant about the european Commission's mandate. And yes, some red lines should not be crossed. But, more than anything, we have to explain. To say that we will be subjected to Canada and then to the United States, because it will come, is caricature.  It is also interesting to see that the first to say that we are subject, as soon as we sign a free trade agreement, are the first to defend Russia's aggressive trade policy against the European Union. The most regrettable thing about these debates on free trade agreements in general is that you are either seen as the defender of democracy when you shout at the conspiracy, or you are a monster who wants to ruin the European economy as long as you seek to be positive.  And the European Commission, as too often, arrives too late with technical arguments in the face of a population that needs concrete arguments. A population that needs to understand that small and medium-sized enterprises can also benefit from these agreements and open new markets; that our companies will have equitable access to public procurement in Canada.  Now, as we can see, some here have already installed the guillotine. They are just waiting for the final "no" vote in Parliament to complete any hope of progress.  So, to avoid that, Commissioner, how can you guarantee that the free trade agreement will be respected? What are the means used to monitor this agreement? And finally, what will be our guarantees that Canada will implement this agreement in a reciprocal way and not favour its businesses at the expense of ours?

name: Bernd Lange (S&D). -
text: Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues! There are three things that concern me about the agreement with Canada. The first is that, Commissioner, you are aware of the critical debate in many civil society circles in Europe on trade policy. To be honest, I do not understand why, when Parliament receives the text on 6 August, you have still not published this text and have just said that you will do so in a few days' time. I believe that, in order to have a rational discussion among the population, the texts must be published quickly so that everyone has the opportunity to look in and know what it actually says. My second point is that there will certainly be some very positive elements that I saw at the first review – with regard to geographical indicators, with regard to the agricultural sector, with regard to market access, there is no question at all. However, we also have a few question marks about services of general interest and also the question of how the standstill clause actually affects the development of services, particularly in the case of re-municipalisation. We will have to analyse this in detail. The third point, Commissioner, is indeed the question of ISDS, the investment protection mechanism. I am not sure that such an instrument can still be tackled today. It was once thought of as a safeguard against insecure states, which then carry out undemocratic expropriations. Today, this is directed against democratic decisions by parliaments, and that is no longer up-to-date. We cannot agree on such an instrument. I therefore urge you to renegotiate and ensure that this comes out. I don't want you to see another ACTA.

name: James Nicholson (ECR). -
text: Mr President, while the ongoing talks between the EU and the United States have tended to be the focus of media and political attention, the Canadian trade deal is no less significant. A number of colleagues have already touched on many of the risks and opportunities of trade deals, so I will focus mainly on the agricultural sector, which will, to a large extent, be the most affected. I see the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) with Canada as one of the more ambitious in the agriculture sector. Local producers will derive some hope from the arrangements on cheese, and producers with recognised geographical indications (GIs) will be delighted with the increased quotas, and with the protection of the vast majority of other GIs. These are aspects of the deal which I believe the Commission should build on in future trade agreements, confidently promoting our high-quality produce on the global stage. I had the opportunity to meet Canadian farmers recently and, believe you me, they are as concerned about this trade deal with the European Union as we are about them – and that probably goes for all trade deals that one enters into: there is always a degree of trepidation as to what may or may not happen. We should go forward with a degree of confidence and we should learn the lessons from this one.

name: Helmut Scholz (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner de Gucht, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work 150 000 people, myself included, have responded to your request and participated in the ISDS consultation. As a text, you presented the ISDS chapter of the CETA agreement. Even before you present the evaluation, you want to declare the negotiations closed and not change the stroke of the pen on the ISDS chapter. They even want to protect speculative financial market investments. Even investors who haven't made any investments yet. In other words, if even one person is planning an investment, he can already run against the private cadres , which are unjustified at his discretion – outside the party's existing legal systems.   Why did you conduct the consultation? If you try to hide opinions, you are further discrediting European policy in the eyes of the public. The EU is already dramatically losing confidence in the eyes of the public. Do we not finally have to act differently?  The population does not want ISDS, either in TTIP or CETA. As democratically elected representatives of millions of people in the EU, it is impossible for us to agree to an agreement with Canada with this ISDS.

name: Michel Reimon (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mr. President! Commissioner, you do not have to publish the agreement next week, because it has already been published by civil society. One can already form an opinion on this, and this is also a democratic scandal, that civil society had to do. The core problem of this agreement is investment protection. What is happening here is anti-democratic. If we in the European Parliament agree, we would take decisions for the future ourselves, because we would have to take into account whether or not we should be charged in every single decision. Anyone who agrees here in this Parliament takes away rights for the future in his democratic will-building and winning a majority. This can only be rejected, and we can only vote against it with all our might. As a democratic representative of the people of Europe, I have absolutely no understanding that this would be done differently. It fits into the picture of how these negotiations have been conducted, that this is represented differently, how the votes in the consultation process have been handled, how the publication of documents has been handled, how the ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Steven Woolfe (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, we in UKIP believe in free trade; we seek engagement with the rest of the world; we are neither isolationist, nor protectionist. The EU, however, is corporatist and a protectionist customs union; the EU is an administrative and regulatory single market; the EU is inefficient and costly. We support the principles and ideas behind a free trade arrangement which removes tariff barriers between countries. The idea of the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) should, in principle, be fine. But we recognise that so long as it is debated and controlled in private, in secret, by administrators who do not have our interests at heart this arrangement will create problems. My constituents are concerned that our great National Health Service could come under threat from corporations who would seek to challenge the government if we change the policies. We do not believe this is correct or right. We believe that the only way a proper arrangement and negotiations can be achieved is by the nation state looking after the interests of its own people. We do not believe in paying lip service to free trade, as the EU does. We believe in freedom, democracy and the nation state.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE). -
text: A Uachtaráin, fáiltím roimh an gcomhréiteach cuimsitheach trádála agus eacnamaíochta seo idir Ceanada agus an tAontas agus go háirithe ba mhaith liom an Coimisinéir de Gucht a mholadh as ucht an dea-obair a rinne sé agus a oifigigh agus freisin ba chóir dúinn cathaoirleach ar an Toscaireacht idir Ceanada agus an tAontas a mholadh. Is é sin Philip Bradbourn. Bhí sé ina chathaoirleach ar an gcoiste ar feadh cúig bliana. Mar a deirim is dóigh liom go bhfuil toradh maith faighte againn agus seasfaidh sé sin an fód amach anseo.  Concluding an agreement with Canada makes ample sense because Canada, of all non-European countries, is probably closest to us in terms of culture, language, law and politics and, while this agreement took five long years, I think we have reached a reasonable agreement at the end of the day. There are difficulties, which have been highlighted, but on balance we can support it, while at the same time expressing our reservations. For that reason I have written to the Commission to express my concern on the treatment of beef products under the quota system for non-hormone-treated high-quality Canadian beef exported to the EU. I welcome the recognition that beef is a sensitive sector. Our beef sector is characterised by small-scale, environment-friendly production on permanent grassland, in an extensive manner based on the family farm model, which is a unique European social structure predominant in my constituency of Ireland South as in other areas in Europe. I believe the Commission was not alert to the distinction between high-quality cuts of beef, such as steaks, and lower-quality cuts. It is my assertion that more restrictive quotas should be placed on the high-quality cuts, as the current quota plan could permit Canadian exports to flood EU markets with high-quality steak at sensitive times of the year such as the barbecue season, undermining the EU sector. Nevertheless, I am prepared to vote in favour of this agreement because of one redeeming factor – the review clause. If, as I expect, there are difficulties, they can be reviewed and this can be taken into account when it comes to negotiating the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) agreement with the USA, because the TTIP could not be modelled on what is here in relation to beef. That would multiply the problems seven times over, as has been outlined in the study carried out by Parliament’s Committee on Agriculture. Finally I just want to say that the details of this arrived in my in-box on 25 August. Perhaps I am privileged. I am not sure.

name: Jörg Leichtfried (S&D). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for his In the last Austrian National Council election campaign, a list was made by a billionaire who, astonishingly, made his billions in Canada, and he said, in terms of his understanding of democracy, that the golden rule applies to him. The golden rule is that whoever has the gold makes the rules. That is what he said. I actually laughed about it at the time and didn't really take it seriously.  Now, when I look at what is happening with Canada, but also with the United States, I am not sure that I should laugh about it, because I am starting to get scared that it might actually happen. I really want you to understand that European social democracy not only has serious concerns about this ISDS, but that we see this as a threat to democracy and the rule of law, as a possibility exclusively for large investors, for large corporations, to evade state jurisdiction. There are examples of how this happens. Moreover, as a way for large corporations to influence state democratic processes differently from ordinary voters. We do not want and cannot accept that.  Nor do I understand how it is possible for a citizens' initiative dealing with this issue to be turned off by the European Commission. I think that is undemocratic. These are things that have now happened, and now we are at the point where this majority is wobbling here in the European Parliament for this agreement, which also has positive things in it. If we Social Democrats vote against it in the end, there will be no agreement.  I want you to really think about finding ways to get out of this process, that you are looking for ways to get this ISDS out of the agreements. Then we can continue to discuss it sensibly, otherwise we will not.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today too, the debate on CETA has spoken of economic benefits, of the need for agreement. In fact, like TTIP, of which it is a forerunner, CETA aims to put the interests of the private sector and business above rights, social justice, democratic control and economic sustainability.  Once again, we are faced with negotiations that have been conducted without the slightest possibility of public monitoring. In particular, it is the lack of a clear assessment of the social impact of the agreement that worries us, along with the almost absolute lack of guarantees for safeguarding social protection and the labour market. Once again, the idea of trade agreements that function as a grimaldello to undermine the system of support for work present in Europe and Canada for the benefit of profit and rent prevails. The Commission has not fought to safeguard labour and welfare standards, and this result is clear to everyone. We will not make discounts, we will build a great campaign inside and outside this Parliament against CETA, as well as against all agreements such as TTIP that put liberalism before us... (The President withdrew the speaker from the floor.)

name: Keith Taylor (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mr President, as a Green MEP, I call for the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) to be rejected because it contains a damaging investor-state dispute settlement (ISDS) mechanism, which threatens both democracy and the democratic process. The public consultation the Commission ran on the inclusion of a very similar ISDS system in the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) agreement with the USA prompted 150 000 responses, and I think they are still being analysed. I would ask why the inclusion of ISDS in CETA is still going ahead without any heed for public opinion and concerns. If ISDS remains in CETA it is a step closer to corporations writing our laws instead of governments, and the UK Government, to its shame, supports CETA as it stands. I implore David Cameron and the other Heads of State to reject it, as the Greens certainly have every intention of doing when it comes before Parliament ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE). -
text: Commissioner, colleagues, the trade agreement reached should help us broaden the scope of our partnership with Canada, which is a historically close friend and is one of Europe's main strategic partners. The Free Trade Agreement is key to deepening our relationship. It will help transform the transatlantic space into a common market and promote economic growth. As a result of this agreement, trade is expected to increase by EUR 26 billion. More trade means more investment and jobs. By strengthening our economic ties with Canada, we will infuse new powers into our economies as well as our competitiveness.  Colleagues, however, I would like to draw attention to one important aspect and it is that access to canada's market must be equal for the whole European Union, and for this the remaining visa restrictions for some member states, including Bulgaria and Romania, should be lifted. Our close partnership with the US and Canada implies a visa-free regime for all European citizens. This, Commissioner, should happen soon.  Canada's energy and raw materials resources could be a useful alternative for Europe. In the context of what is happening on our eastern borders, I am convinced that we need to deepen the North Atlantic partnership in the energy sphere as well. Finally, Commissioner, last but not least, the Communication Strategy of the European Commission on the trade agreement with the US and Canada must be much better than it has been in the past in order to address the concerns of the European public and business in order not to spread, whether with or without justification, rumours and fears about these agreements, as we have seen here, and to be used for ideologically decorated speeches by some of our colleagues.

name: Maria Arena (S&D). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner, my colleagues in the group have already raised a number of reservations about the CETA agreement and, in particular, about the ISDS. Therefore, I will not return to this isSD issue. My concern will go instead to the mechanism of regulatory cooperation as set out today in the CETA agreement. It is a mechanism that allows multinationals, it is true, both European and Canadian, to define a number of rules that are right for them and that make this agreement alive. That is to say, your initial commitment not to lower European standards through this mechanism cannot be kept because companies could decide among themselves that rules violate this freedom of exchange.  In relation to this, Mr De Gucht, you have said, at times, that European standards are finally your sure value. These were the standards that should not be negotiated. Well, we have mechanisms in this agreement that undermine that position, that undermine your commitment, and so I would like to have a clear position on that. Is there really an opportunity to preserve European health, social and environmental standards?

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner, we do not miss the indecent attack on democracy that this Agreement entails and which few of you are talking about. The secrecy in the negotiations responds to your fear that people will know what they are up to. The biggest example is the refusal to accept the citizen initiative to curb this and other agreements of the same kind, which is an absolute contempt for citizenship and popular will. They are selling to Europeans, as this Agreement makes citizens' rights subject to the greed of investors, and the worst thing is that they know it. Commissioner, you are not politicians. They're businessmen and they have no credibility. It should be used to answer to the Belgian Court for the alleged tax evasion for which it is being investigated. We reject this Agreement because, unlike you, we defend the interests of most people and take their will to the end. Do not forget that this Parliament has already rejected the ACTA and we will do the same with the CETA. On October 11 you will be able to see it throughout Europe, because it will come out ... (The Chair withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D). -
text: Mr President, this is a historic agreement but, in a period of intense public interest in EU trade negotiations, the EU’s rhetoric around transparency in democratic participation is rendered redundant if it is not put into action. It is therefore incredible that CETA was concluded only two weeks after the close of the public consultation on ISDS, which used the CETA text as its basis. What signal are we sending to Europe’s citizens? Concerns about the treatment of public services have been similarly dismissed, despite the scale of ambiguity surrounding what is actually included in this agreement. There has been no public debate about what our governments have included in the negative list, and there is no public support for the locking-in of the privatisation of public services, both through the inclusion of ISDS and ratchet clauses. Transparency is needed on what is included for each Member State, and therefore we would request that you publish exactly what is included in this trade agreement for each Member State.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to start with the positive aspects of the agreement with Canada, which I believe may represent an opportunity for our production system, for integration with a system that is not only economic, but also social and cultural not far from the European one. Also in the light of the current geopolitical situation that was mentioned yesterday and today in this House, it can be seen as a step in the direction of strengthening Europe's trade partnership with the most reliable players at global level. I would particularly like to stress my appreciation of the achievement of a good compromise on the issue of geographical indications, especially given Canada's traditional alienation from this system. In general, I think it is the role of this Parliament to judge these negotiations with the utmost care, lucidity and frankness, while remaining as attached as possible to the letter of the negotiations itself, avoiding an understandable but risky overlap with the debate on TTIP, which would confuse the plans and undermine the good parts of these negotiations. We still think and think that many elements of this agreement can improve, and that is why we are asking the Commission to take all possible steps in this direction.

name: Joachim Schuster (S&D). -
text: Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues! The text for the CETA agreement is now available.  The Commission wishes to declare the negotiations over. I think that is wrong. Even without us as a Parliament being able to examine the texts thoroughly, the first sighting shows a need for improvement.  Investment protection agreements include the establishment of arbitral tribunals beyond national courts. Such arbitral tribunals are an erosion of democracy and the rule of law. For a fundamental principle is that all are equal before the law. With the arbitral tribunals, companies and corporations become equal. This is unacceptable. Secondly, negative lists define which sectors are not covered by the agreement. Will it be possible to re-municipalise sectors or sectors that have once been liberalised? It is part of democracy that political decisions remain reversible in democratic procedures. CETA cannot be approved if fundamental principles of the rule of law and democracy are overridden. That is why the Commission is called upon to renegotiate.

name: Guillaume Balas (S&D). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner, you are witnessing the debate and you can see from that point on that it takes some wisdom in this matter. The ISDS today will not pass. It's a pretty strong fact. There is a consultation that has been issued by the Commission. We do not know the results when citizens have been involved. It is already - I want to say - a flaw that is strong in the agenda. Second, then: you are members of an outgoing Commission. The President of the new Commission, Mr Juncker, has said publicly that he is opposed to isDS, particularly in trade agreements concerning the United States, and therefore by reference for Canada.  From that moment on, we are democratically elected representatives here, we are a democracy in the European Union, it is impossible to speed up the process to ensure that things are signed and therefore uncontrollable. Therefore, I believe that the wisdom now would be to leave it to the next Commission to work on this subject.

name: Pedro Silva Pereira (S&D). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the conclusion of the negotiations on the European Union's trade agreement with Canada is a positive development. The economic potential is great and our task is to assess whether an acceptable compromise has been reached. But one thing is clear, Commissioner: we need to find a political solution to the problem of ISDS clauses, a dispute resolution mechanism that threatens the future of agreements not only with Canada, but also with the United States and Japan. The Commission has to give an appropriate response, and no response is adequate if it is not politically feasible.  So what is the Commission's strategy for the political problem of ISDS? Are you in a position to convince us that each case is a case and the solution found in CETA is balanced and not a precedent? Or will the Commission finally present a comprehensive political response, valid for the various trade agreements under negotiation? Now something the Commission has to do, and it cannot pretend that the problem does not exist.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D). -
text: Mr President, first of all I would like to mention the historical link between Canada and my country, most noparticular the Azores, because there live many Azoreans and descendants of Azoreans, who make up a large successful community, even occupying places in governance. There are half a million Portuguese in Canada. As regards the terms of the agreement and with regard to the protection of geographical indications, the result we have achieved has been very satisfactory. We have achieved a level of protection similar to that within the European Union, and I am especially pleased with the names of St George's cheese and the Azores' dwarfs. I call for this to be a precedent that could mark the negotiations for other agreements currently underway. There are other aspects of the agreement that are not so well regarded, notably the investor-state dispute settlement mechanism, but other colleagues have already mentioned it. In negotiating this agreement we have already achieved some successes and it was necessary to achieve them on other fronts, notably in the context of the Galway declaration, for the observation and better knowledge of the Atlantic Ocean. This text was signed in 2013 between the European Union, Canada and the United States, and we should be able to ensure its good implementation... (The President withdraws his word to the speaker)

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE). -
text: Mr President, in my one minute I just wish to deal with the inclusion of ISDS in the proposed trade deal. Commissioner, my bottom line question is this: why is it necessary in countries that have highly developed and well-understood legal systems to include extra mechanisms for resolving disputes? But, as you know, I am not the only one who has this concern. Over 150 000 citizens responded to your consultation because they, like me, are concerned among other things about the fact that an arbitration panel, which will make final decisions, will not be subject to the ECJ, for example. Jean-Claude Juncker said – and I quote – that he would not accept that the jurisdiction of courts in EU Member States is limited by special regimes for investor disputes. Finally, in 2011 the Parliament warned you in a resolution that a state-to-state dispute settlement mechanism and the use of local judicial remedies are the most appropriate tools to address investment disputes. Commissioner, the trade deal has many positives. Do not be responsible for losing it. Before it is initialled, delete ISDS.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I am intervening to call for the withdrawal of CETA. The CETA, with the ISDS, implies the surrender of the sovereignty of peoples to transnational corporations. Secondly, CETA will destroy many more jobs in small and medium-sized enterprises than multinationals will create, for which this CETA is made. CETA will also destroy peasant agriculture, especially meat beef production on small and medium-sized family farms. But there's still another reason. There has been talk in this Parliament before about climate change: circulating food that we can produce every day in our villages for short circuits means energy waste and means greenhouse gas emissions, which also cause climate change. For these reasons and many others that I do not have time to set out, I call for the withdrawal of the CETA.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, employment and growth depend above all on a trade policy aimed at helping businesses and exploiting international demand. That is why the EU-Canada agreement is crucial. The CETA agreement could bring great benefits for all industrial sectors. The compromise on the non-exhaustive recognition of certain geographical indications is certainly positive, for example. The European Union is Canada's second largest trading partner, after the United States. The CETA agreement is therefore of fundamental importance.  However, this agreement must not be tainted by the ISDS clause. If this clause were to be applied, a multinational company investing in a country would be able to challenge the national government of that country through the use of international arbitration procedures, having allegedly bypassed the ordinary judicial system. A kind of parallel jurisdiction mechanism could therefore be created which would strip the State of the right to have the last word on very sensitive matters. I therefore call on the Commission to listen to and take account of the European Parliament's considerations.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: Thank you, Mr Caputo. It is not really one of my tasks to educate adult people.  But we are at the beginning of a parliamentary term, and you, Mr Caputo, have been lighting the interpreters' emergency lights from the very beginning: slow down! The interpreters can only interpret a certain speaking speed. If you want not only your Italian compatriots to understand what you are saying, but the whole continent, then it would make sense if you were to pack into a speaking time of one minute even as much as an interpreter of excellent quality, as we have here, which can also interpret sensibly. I'm not going to say that again. I admonish the speaker once by knocking, and then I take the floor out of him. Otherwise, the interpreting booths will stop interpreting them, and then we will not be able to give further advice anyway.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, this agreement contains many opportunities: broad market access for our imports and a significant opening up of the public procurement market at local level as well. An important result has also been achieved on the subject of the protection of European geographical indications. For most of the indications on the negotiating list we get full recognition in the North American market, so far a real off-limits zone for our agri-food export. This is a significant result, therefore, but one that it cannot fully satisfy. The European Union must show greater ambition in protecting its quality products in the world. However, over and above the technical evaluation of the text, this agreement and, in the long term, TTIP become even more important given the development of relations with Russia and the stalling of other bilateral negotiations. Finally, it will certainly be necessary to reflect very thoroughly on the dispute settlement mechanism, the so-called ISDS, also on the basis of the consultation initiated. I believe, however, that this reflection should not prejudge a balanced assessment of the agreement a priori.

name: Karel De Gucht
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, before turning to investor-state dispute settlement (ISDS) – which is obviously the one issue that will ensure most of the Members present here tonight are not going to sleep very well – I will try to reply to a number of questions that have been put. However, Mr Leichtfried, I think you will sleep well. The first question came from Mr Martin: why does the Council not initial this agreement, whereas it would have done so for all others? The Council never initials an agreement. It has never done so. The procedure is that it is the Commission which initials an agreement after the legal scrubbing process, and the legal scrubbing has not yet been done. So what President Barroso and Prime Minister Harper will announce at the EU-Canada Summit will be the conclusion of the negotiations. That is the simple answer to your question. In relation to generic medicines, I can give you an assurance that we are not going to change the arrangements – not only those with Canada but also those with other countries. Take, for example, the negotiations with India that are not yet concluded: there too we have taken the approach that trade in generic medicines should not be hampered. On the non-trade issues, like the EU seals ban and tar sands, we have decided that it is up to the World Trade Organisation to decide. That was probably a sign of wisdom to a certain degree. With regard to the mandate, and to public consultation, I would like to make it very clear that we were asked to discuss and come to an agreement on ISDS – but I will return to that later. Mr Mineur and some other Members also said that this would only be an agreement for big companies and not one for SMEs. However, big companies do not need free trade agreements; the companies that need free trade agreements are the SMEs, because what you are really doing with this type of deep and comprehensive free trade agreement is giving them a new home market. That is what you are effectively doing, so the assertion is certainly not true. Mr Jadot and Mr Lange put a number of questions concerning access to the agreement. This is very simple: as soon as the negotiations were concluded we sent the outcome to Parliament, to you and your fellow Members, Mr Lange, and to the Member States. The text of the CETA will also be published: at this moment, both sides are coordinating their preparations, which include preparing a version for the visually impaired, as well as some minor editing, and the publication date should not be far from that of next week’s summit. It is very simple, we are not hiding anything, although I am not sure whether many citizens are waiting to read this agreement during the autumn nights. I have my doubts about that. If I could give you some advice, I would not read it! Even with some editing it is very dry stuff. Ms Beghin was afraid that citizens were not aware of the text. Ms Le Pen – who was here with many supporters but has now disappeared – asked you, for once, to vote in the right direction. She asks that all the time and I can only conclude that you are not following her advice, so maybe sooner or later you should explain why. Mr Kelly had a question on the quota system but I see that he too has disappeared. Everybody is leaving: perhaps it is because I am speaking for too long. With regard to the quota system and high quality cuts: there is differentiation between high quality and other cuts – very clear differentiation – and we know the difference. These are separate markets and you have to take that into account. Then there was a question by Ms Arena on whether we are going to change social, environmental and other norms and standards. Of course we are not, and you will not change them by discussing them. Changing those standards, Ms Arena, is a matter solely for yourselves in the European Parliament.
