With regard to the Citizens’ Initiative, a citizens’ initiative allows citizens to ask the Commission to use its powers to propose the adoption of legislation – it could, for instance, call on the Commission to propose concluding an agreement with a third country – but it does not cover requests to EU institutions not to do something, for example to stop negotiating a trade agreement such as the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP), or not to sign or conclude an agreement such as CETA once the negotiations have ended. The matter is then in the hands of Parliament and the Council. For that reason the request not to conclude the CETA agreement and to stop the on-going TTIP negotiations has been considered inadmissible. The criteria on which the Commission’s decision here was based are purely legal criteria. I understand that you are going to oppose this and, of course, it is your right to do so. Now on ISDS – if I have some more speaking time, Mr President, because I have hundreds of questions on this and I understand this is what is keeping everybody awake – I will try to give an answer. Let me start by saying that in its April 2011 resolution on the future European international investment policy, the resolution in the Arif report which was adopted by a very large majority including the S&D in response to the Commission’s communication on investments, Parliament did call for the inclusion of ISDS procedures in EU investment agreements by calling for measures to ensure there would be no abuses of the system. That is the starting point of my reasoning. The same goes for the mandate we received from the Council of Ministers. It is stated explicitly in that mandate, which was adopted unanimously, that we should go for an ISDS agreement. I do not know exactly why, but all of a sudden this has become the overriding issue when it comes to trade. Many Members have mentioned the public consultation, showing apparently that the whole of the European population is thinking along those lines. We will come next week, or in a couple of weeks, with the first analysis of the public consultation results. What it shows is that more than 50 000 out of 150 000 answers are identical. Normally, you have to get into the system; you have to answer 12 questions and then submit your answers. However, these respondents have found a way – I do not understand anything about the technicalities – to circumvent this and give an answer without getting into the system, and that of course makes it very easy to get 50 000 identical answers. You could have 500 000 – why not? Then there are another 50 000 who are simply saying ‘we are against’. But we will look into all the answers, and if there are interesting elements there we will certainly take them into account. Now, is the CETA a blueprint for the TTIP or any other EU agreements? I prefer to think that the CETA (along with the agreement with Singapore by the way) is more than a blueprint: that it marks a turning point in the European approach on investment protection. It demonstrates beyond any doubt that the Commission is generally committed to reforming the system. Let me cite a few of the novelties and unique improvements achieved in the CETA. First, there is explicit reference to the capacity of states to regulate in the public interest. Second, there is a precise definition of investment protection standards to prevent abusive interpretations. Third, there is full transparency in ISDS: all hearings are open, all documents are public, interested parties can make submissions. By the way, this goes much further than any proceedings in a commercial court. In a commercial court the only thing that is open is the judgment. You cannot get access to the parties’ files. There are many lawyers in the House – though not many tonight of course – and they know that you cannot dig into the file of the other party. You simply cannot do that. The judgment will be much more transparent here. It is the first ever agreement incorporating binding rules on ethics and arbitrators of conduct. There are strict controls on cost, and the ‘loser pays’ principle has been introduced, making sure that investors bringing spurious claims pay the cost. We have agreed that an appellate body will be established, based largely on the WTO appellate body practice, and this is the most effective way to create consistency in arbitration decisions, make arbitrators accountable and ensure predictability. There are many other improvements in the CETA and it is not excluded that further improvements of the EU’s approach in other negotiations are possible. One has to be clear, however, that the CETA and the TTIP negotiations are different. The CETA text has already been agreed with Canada. By contrast, the Commission has launched a public consultation to receive the views of stakeholders, and especially of citizens, on the TTIP. Analyses of the replies received in the consultation will inform decisively the EU position on the TTIP. So I can confirm that the CETA is not a blueprint for the TTIP, just as I can confirm that the process of reform of the system, to which the EU is committed, is a one-way street. There is no going back. What we have tried to improve in the CETA will only be further improved in future negotiations. Several Members put the question: why do we need ISDS in a CETA between countries with solid, mature judicial systems. The issue is more one of enforcement, however, than of the standard of maturity of the legal system per se. We need to make sure that EU investors can enforce their rights because the CETA would not be enforceable in Canadian domestic courts. It would not be enforceable there – as you probably know, Mr Leichtfried – because they have a dualist approach whereas we have a monist approach. Any trade agreements, including any guarantees on investment protection, signed by the EU with a third country, whether it be Canada or Singapore, would not be automatically enforceable by the domestic courts of either partner, and, under Canada’s consistent practice, domestic courts cannot give effect to international treaties. Secondly, the presence of a solid legal system does not mean the absence of problems for investors. The Energy Charter Treaty already applies between many countries with developed legal systems. Also, the EU Member States themselves have numerous bilateral investment treaties. According to recent figures from the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD), of the 271 cases registered between 2008 and 2013, 15% – that is 40 cases – are intra-EU cases: ISDS cases initiated by investors from an EU Member State against another EU Member State. We have proposed, by the way, having a different rule within the European Union, but many Member States – including yours, Mr Lange – refused to have different arrangements in respect of other Member States of the European Union. Thirdly, there are several imbalances on the policy side that we need to address: currently eight Member States have bilateral investment treaties with Canada and this means that only investors from those Member States are protected in Canada, while others are not. Finally, the CETA offers an opportunity for us to introduce reforms to the ISDS system. It could pave the way for a new era of investment agreements and serve as a model for the rest of the world, and that is a very important argument. I remember well a public meeting in Berlin, in which the Vice-Chancellor, Sigmar Gabriel, participated and there was a very lively discussion – the kind of discussion I like. (That is why I have been doing politics for 35 years, by the way!) At the end, Mr Gabriel said there might be some positive elements in the agreement: for example, the fact that it is difficult to refuse ISDS clauses with the United States or with Canada and to ask for them with China. We have to set a template for the rest of the world, and I hope that Parliament too, in the course of the discussions on this agreement, will understand that.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: Thank you very much, Commissioner. Commissioner De Gucht, you have now spoken longer than we actually expected. However, I would like to make it clear that you spoke much less recently last night than the speaking time we had provided. In any case, I would like to say from my point of view that I very much appreciate the fact that you are also addressing individual Members in a largely free speech. I also appreciate the fact that some of the Members who have had a speech have also stayed, while I think it is a nonsense that a question is asked or heard here in a debate and is not waiting for the Commissioner's answer. The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Eduard-Raul Hellvig (PPE)
text: in writing. – The EU-Canada Summit in Ottawa will conclude, within days, a lengthy process of negotiating one of the most ambitious economic and trade partnership agreements. It is relevant to the scale of the EU-Canada Free Trade Agreement the estimate that the application of the agreement will lead to an increase in bilateral trade of EUR 25 billion, while the current value of bilateral trade in goods and services amounts to EUR 85 billion. EU GDP is expected to increase by EUR 11.6 billion annually, following increased exports and mutual investment, with the abolition of customs, industrial and agricultural duties, non-tariff barriers, by ensuring access for suppliers to public markets, liberalisation of trade in services, mutual recognition of qualifications and specific rules in key sectors.  I support the Euro-Canadian partnership for the premises it offers to economic dynamite, but also because it is based on the solid foundation of common values. The exclusion of discrimination is one of these, which is why I call for the inclusion in the agreement of the firm commitment to the abolition of visas still imposed on The Canadian side by Romanian citizens and other new EU Member States, in accordance with the European Parliament resolution of September 2013 on the establishment of the visa reciprocity clause.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. – The EU-Canada Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) is a generally positively accepted agreement aimed at providing opportunities for economic growth and increasing employment on both sides of the Atlantic. The TTIP agreement with the US has similarly attractive objectives. However, the two agreements have several common problems. CETA also proposes the ISDS mechanism as a mechanism for resolving investment disputes. But here, too, it is relevant to ask, to whom will this mechanism actually benefit? Are bureaucratic and no-one responsible officials on the Commission trying to sell off European interests in the same way as they do with TTIP, and how did they want to do so in the case of ACTA? Just so they can make an imaginary "pipe" on the task of making a trade deal? In both cases, the incorporation of the ISDS mechanism is a requirement of the other party, not the EU. The task of the European Parliament and MEPs is to ensure that the activities of the European Union are in line with the interests of citizens. Non-transparent arbitrations made possible by the ISDS mechanism are clearly not in the interest of citizens. I am therefore against the inclusion of the ISDS mechanism in CETA in the same way that I am against it in the case of TTIP. This incessant inclusion of arbitrations in CETA is only an unnecessary threat to its ratification by the European Parliament.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D)
text: Writing. – CETA and subsequently other agreements such as TTIP and TISA, if concluded, will have far-reaching consequences for millions of people in the EU and the world. Three points are particularly important to me. All these agreements have something in common: the lack of transparency with which they are negotiated. MEPs, but also civil society, must be more involved in these far-reaching projects. Another point is the investment protection clauses with their out-of-state dispute settlement procedures (ISDS). I take a critical view of them, as they limit the political room for manoeuvre for the future at the expense of their own people. Canada and the EU have a highly developed rule of law and legal culture, and property protection and national equality are sufficiently enshrined in the legal system. At the same time, the arbitration practice of many other investment protection agreements is characterised by intransparency, inefficiency, lack of independence, inconsistency and high costs for taxpayers. What added value can this bring to our society? I reject such a "two-class jurisdiction". The final point is Europe's prosperity, which is also based on high standards in the areas of social affairs, labour, the environment and agriculture. As a trade unionist, I can only say that our standards must be maintained. An agreement that torpedoes these cornerstones of our prosperity cannot be our goal.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I am here the spokesperson for the 150,000 Europeans you are about to deny. Indeed, the arbitration clause caused more than 150,000 Europeans to react in a recent European public consultation. This record turnout proves once again that all the players in society are aware of the toxicity of the TTIP agreement and in particular of the presence of a private arbitration court that would allow multinationals to block public decisions of general interest simply under the pretext of lowering their profits. The Commission, rather than waiting for the analysis of the citizens' consultation on this arbitration court, is trying to impose it on us through a trade agreement other than that with the United States, via the agreement with Canada. The Commission will then have a good game of saying "why refuse this clause in the TTIP, you just voted on it in the Canada text." But we are not fooled and if you, Commissioner, bother to seek the opinion of the citizens, and the experts, the least that can be done would be to take that opinion into account. It is a matter of your credibility in the eyes of European citizens and also in relation to this Parliament.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. " This agreement should have been discussed in this House and it was not. The complete pleading of the Treaty has not yet come into our hands. This agreement, on the other hand, must be ratified by the national states. We will see the room for manoeuvre in relation to a de facto consummate policy where the negotiations were conducted in the utmost secrecy, on the sidelines of this House and the national states. This agreement represents an authentic test flask for TTIP. We see in him the same logic. A hellish logic that places the market above the sovereignty of states and peoples. I would like to draw your attention to the dispute settlement mechanism through which large multinationals will be able to sue any public entity that will take action against their profits. We already have many examples around this world where treaties of this nature are in force. Philip Morris sued the Uruguayan government for its anti-smoking laws. In the face of the protest of many personalities and experts in international law, the Commission decided last January to start a consultation process on this specific aspect. It would be interesting to know the outcome of this query.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D)
text: Writing. I am opposed to the CETA agreement in this form, ostensibly because of the ISDS regime. For it is inconceivable that states will in future be limited in their legislative competence because they will have to fear the millions of claims of large corporations – in sensitive areas such as education, environment and health policy, public and social services, or financial market regulation and tax policy. This would not only disempower the policy itself, but above all disempower the citizens – public welfare objectives could no longer be sufficiently pursued. The right of action for corporations through the path of democratically inlegitimacy of special courts is contrary to all democratic principles. In addition, the various derogations for public services are too vague and imprecise, and legal certainty is no longer available. I am not fundamentally opposed to free trade. But the European Union's internal market is the best example of free trade working differently – without special courts and without undermining social standards.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission's statement on access to life-saving medicines in Europe (2014/2831(RSP)).

name: Connie Hedegaard
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, on behalf of my colleague Commissioner Borg, I would like to think that the Commission shares the general concern regarding the affordability of new medical products and the related risk of inequalities arising in access to care.  The Commission is committed to helping Member States respond to this challenge. This commitment was highlighted in the Commission’s communication of April this year on effective and resilient health systems, which, among other things, focused on increasing accessibility to health systems. The communication stressed the need for improved cooperation, ‘increased transparency and better coordination to minimise any unintended effects that current national pricing systems may have in terms of accessibility throughout the EU’. At the Health Council in June, the French delegation raised the specific issue of the new improved hepatitis C treatments which have recently received marketing authorisation in the European Union, expressing concerns in relation to achieving equitable access to these treatments. Tomorrow Member States’ experts will meet to discuss the new improved hepatitis C treatments. There will be a follow-up meeting with Member States’ competent authorities next month to discuss pricing and reimbursement. Of course, the discussion on the impact of prices on the affordability of medicines for public payers and patients goes far beyond the specific case of hepatitis C treatments. The Commission is therefore looking forward to the debate planned by the Italian Presidency on therapeutic innovation at next week’s informal Council of Health Ministers. The outcome of this debate will help inform the new Commission about the interest of Member States in continuing an EU debate on the affordability of innovative health products. As regards support to research and development, the Commission is hopeful that the ongoing Innovative Medicines Initiative will help speed up the development of better and safer medicines. EU pharmaceutical legislation contains a number of tools to facilitate early access to medicines for patients with unmet medical needs. In addition, in terms of success in helping the development and the placing on the market of medicines for rare and life-threatening diseases, the Commission has already authorised 106 of such innovative treatments. The Commission has, however, no competence to regulate the level of prices of medicinal treatments. These are determined by Member States individually. Thus there can be no price caps imposed by the Commission. However, the Commission can offer help, for example, by pursuing improved exchanges of information among Member States on their pricing policies with a view to minimising negative effects on the accessibility of medicines in the EU. Another way in which the Commission could assist would be by further exploring the use of the joint procurement mechanism to obtain more advantageous price offers from the pharmaceutical industry.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik
text: for the PPE Group. – This debate in plenary in Strasbourg at this late evening should galvany us into a high-quality debate, but above all tangible results. Today, we are talking about a person, a patient who is in great urgent need of his medication. Access to life-saving medicines is, after all, a topic of debate today. The fate of millions of patients, whether in Slovakia, Finland, Ireland, Italy, anywhere, lies at my heart not only because, as a doctor, I have also seen people die and I know from my former medical practice on the life-saving ward of a hospital how important it is to have the necessary quality medicines available and not only in the reanimation unit, but also in all hospital wards and, above all, that the patient with a serious illness has a real , real access to medicines. Medicines that are and will be affordable, in its social situation and income levels, and will also be of high quality and full availability. There is still inequality in access to the necessary medicines, which is partly due to the different levels of health funding in the various Member States, which is then reflected in the price of medicines, to different prices and to the constant increase in pharmaceutical expenditure, and the high price of medicines persists, partly because new technologies are costly. On the other hand, pharmaceutical companies that develop a new drug should not abuse their exclusive position and then drive the price of medicines to intolerable levels. It's unethical and immoral. Between 2000 and 2009, public spending on medicines increased by an average of up to 76% in EU countries. This expenditure on medicines is growing faster than the GDP of the Member States. At the same time, it should be borne in mind that there is an ageing population in the Member States, in other words there are more pensioners and the ever-dwinding price of newly-used medicines. In this context, it should be systemically allowed that the same molecule in the field of generics can be made available to patients as soon as possible and at a disproportionately lower price.

name: Biljana Borzan
text: on behalf of the S&D. Club – Mr. President, with the advancement of medical science, extremely effective and expensive medicines are emerging. When a drug appears on the market that provides a 100% cure, I am sure that there is no doctor who wants to choose between the well-being of the patient and savings in the health budget. If we talk about the cost of health care, in this case an expensive drug that fully treats hepatitis, I ask the question: how much does society cost all hospitalizations that without cure this man will experience, all diagnostics, how much does all therapy cost, absenteeism and of course the most important thing how much does human life cost? It bothers me when billions of euros are spent on bailing out banks, and when it comes to medicine everyone is worried about costs. But on the other hand, I am aware that we need to think responsibly about a sustainable health system. Therefore, one possible solution, when it comes to expensive drugs, is to pay pharmaceutical companies from public funds only when there is a cure.  Furthermore, there is a possibility to shorten the duration of patent rights because when it expires the price of the drug falls rapidly. After all, I must express disappointment that medicines and medical devices in the future Commission will be under the Commissioner for Industry and Entrepreneurship, rather than under the Commissioner for Health. This is a setback and unfortunately a signal that patient safety is losing primacy in front of economic calculations.

name: Beatrix von Storch
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the We are all in favour of protecting human life and, therefore, of the widest possible distribution and access to life-sustaining medicines. With regard to research into these medicines, I would like to make one point with regard to the use of embryonic stem cells: the European Court of Justice took a very important decision of principle on 18 October 2011. The ECJ has found that human life begins to exist with the fusion of egg and sperm. Man is a human being from the fusion of egg and sperm. According to that case-law, all public funds for any interference in that early life, any manipulation and, even more so, any destruction should be deleted. Embryonic stem cell research is therefore inadmissible, and that is exactly what the European Citizens' Initiative One of Us has called for. 1.8 million EU citizens supported this initiative.  Despite these 1.8 million signatures, the European Commission, led by the Christian Democrats, has refused to comment on this issue at all, let alone to take any measures against the destruction of human life for research purposes.  When we talk about the production of medicines, we should bear in mind: let us protect human life by distributing life-sustaining drugs, and stop the destruction of human life for research purposes!

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Mrs Hedegaard, I have listened with as much interest as I would to hear the Commission's statement on access to life-saving medicines. Let me use this area of debate and responsibility which is the European Parliament to bring to the fore the indispensable priority of our work, which is to serve the general interest. What epidemic nature must a pathology acquire in order to be considered a 'public health crisis'? Are the 130 million hepatitis C patients in the world, 10 million of them in the European Union, enough in Spain alone?  Hepatitis C is an infectious disease that, when chronicted, becomes disabling and devastating. It's deadly in half a million cases a year. But now there's a cure. And that cure comes at a price. An unbeatable price of more than 50 000 euros per patient and treatment, fixed by the company that owns the sofosbuvir patent, taking into account only market criteria. Are we going to resign ourselves, again, to making excuses justifying European institutional paralysis? Are we just going to regret the fatality of corporate profit? I don't think so, ladies and gentlemen. I believe that we can act and that there are tools. Member States may implement Article 31 of the 2001 Doha Declaration, promoted by the World Trade Organization; they can issue a compulsory licence for "public health need" and manufacture a generic. They may also legally oppose the patent, as India has already done, as the molecule was previously patented against cancer. Or they can negotiate the joint transfer payment of the patent. Or, of course, choose to form a block and make aggregated public purchases. Egypt today imports the Indian generic sofosbuvir at a price 100 times lower. Another 90 developing countries will also benefit from India's decision. Can the Commission and this House commit themselves to promoting a common position to defend the general interest and compliance with the Treaties? If we have been able in Europe to impose limits on roaming, are we not going to be able to change the pricing model for medicines that save millions of lives?

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, the problem of the over-costing of medicines by pharmaceutical companies, which are intended to make over-profits at the expense of the health of citizens and at the expense of insurance funds, is real. But it's not the only barrier to access to the necessary medications. In fact, the competent bodies of the European Union not only do not care about over-costing, but also consciously promote policies of restrictions on public health spending that make it even more difficult for patients to access medicines. In the worst situation of all, there are countries under a memorandum regime, where the Troika pursues policies of violent poverty, with the result that patients are unable to pay their contribution to pharmaceutical costs and mortality increases. In Greece, deaths from 108 000 in 2009 increased to 117 000 in 2012, precisely as a result of this troika criminal policy. The European Commission ... (The President interrupts the speaker.)

name: Michèle Rivasi
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, we are still in a rather serious situation. I have listened to your proposals, but I find them a little weak. We have learned that 15 states have referred the case to the Commission for this hepatitis C drug, which is sofosbuvir. It should be noted that its cost is in the range of 50,000 to 60,000 euros per patient for a period of twelve weeks. So it's huge compared to the budget. And it affects eight million people in Europe.  At the same time, if it were only for this pharmaceutical company that is releasing this drug, but it is now a lot of drugs to treat breast cancer, kidney cancer. Many states are now playing rationing, that is, on the cost-benefit: if you are too old, you are no longer entitled to it because the social security budget will not be able to meet it. So it's really a public health issue. So why did we get to this point? Some have said earlier that it is a monopoly and patent issue. If these patents are over twenty years and states have too often played on the monopoly, there is an emergency exit which is the compulsory license. We have to tell the states to use this licence because it opens up the market and other laboratories can very well make much cheaper drugs. There is also the problem of research. Look at the Ebola case, the current crisis in West Africa. We have known about this Ebola virus since 1976, but no pharmaceutical company wants to make vaccines and treatments because it is not cost-effective! In other words, we are on a market policy. However, from the moment we put public money, when the European Commission puts public money, it is absolutely necessary to be conditional so that there is no monopoly and no patents. This allows us to have much cheaper drug prices and thus ensure access to medicines and also contribute to innovation because we are in a lack of innovation.

name: Dario Tamburrano
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I welcome this debate with great pleasure, both because I am a dentist and I know the tragedies of hepatitis C and because, in general, we in the 5-Star Movement believe that the ethical principles that should inspire the pharmaceutical world should always win over market logic. The Commission's new portfolios provide for more expertise on medicines for the Commissioner for Industry, while in each Member State the Minister for Health is responsible. How are we going to do the interests of the citizens when DG Industry has competence in this matter rather than the European institution for the protection of public health? How is it possible that in this Parliament, moreover, with a Catholic majority, where references to the values of respect for and protection of life often resonate, no strong action is taken to reduce the costs of essential medicines? Just today, a number of NGOs in the sector wrote alarmed in this regard: 'Is it not the lives of us citizens that are the priority value to be defended?'

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D). -
text: Commissioner, I understand that you have set us the deadlocks on regulating patent prices for medicines and I will try to find ways to make it easier for you to find other solutions, as the TRIPS agreement allows, in cases of medicines, the authorisation of generics. So where human rights take precedence over copyright - and, I wonder, Germany and Italy have been activated on a case-by-case basis - why is the actual cost of investigations carried out by multinational companies not being checked at least with mandatory transparency and then, in cases of obscene profiteering, for patents on medicines to expire in less than 20 years, or for their prices to be rationally rational? The European Union could refuse, in consultation, of course, with the Member States through their public health systems, to receive and buy these medicines at outrageously expensive prices. It could therefore, in cases of obscene profit or in cases where there is a great need for human health, be licensed generics.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR). -
text: It is true that the development of new lifesaving medicines is very costly. However, it is not defensible that the patient does not have the necessary care provided for financial reasons. Every patient in Europe has the right to quality treatment and the availability of medicines.  The principle of fair redistribution of funds must be applied rigorously here. It is unacceptable for such medicinal products to be available only to the privileged and the socially weaker to be excluded from such treatment. Then there are situations where the door to corruption and clientelism opens, which is what we want to combat in Europe.  If we are talking about lifesaving medicines, we should also talk here about situations where the possibilities of actively and fundamentally affecting the prognosis of the disease are exhausted. This is where palliative care should take place. In contrast to common therapies, this offers a higher quality of life even in cases of advanced diseases and in the terminal stages. It is a care that, with full respect for the dignity and rights of a person, ensures quality and comprehensive care for the severely ill or people at the end of their lives.  I presume most politicians know the statement: "Civilisation is so advanced as it cares for its weakest and unassuing members." In my opinion, it is precisely the responsibility of politicians to deliver on this statement in our work. It is shocking that our advanced civilisation, instead of trying to make it easier for the old and terminally ill to provide special care, is increasingly seeking to eradicate them. In the past, they were closed to institutions, today they are being promoted with a financially undemanding solution, namely euthanasia.  Paradox. Europe's maturity and well-being enable us to live with real quality and dignity for everyone, but we are still debating and apologising for getting rid of unprofitable people. The latest terrible example is Belgium, where they have extended euthanasia to children and the mentally ill.  I can't help but be reminded of ancient Sparta, where unsuitable children were killed, or Nazi eugenics, where they removed the unsatisfactory. What does such a view lead to? Society will start getting rid of people with disabilities or those who do not meet our standards. I have to say that in Slovakia, palliative care by the state is not properly devoted....(the speaker has been interrupted)

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE). -
text: Mr President, in the context of access to life-saving medicines in Europe, shortages are caused by a number of factors. They are caused by supply issues, they are caused by production issues and, most certainly, they are caused by affordability issues. I intend to concentrate on the affordability issues. The problem is particularly acute in countries undergoing austerity programmes, largely because of the cuts to public services across the board, which of course limit access to healthcare and life-saving medicines. The Commission itself, in its country-specific recommendations, tells us that limitations on access to healthcare may weigh disproportionately on the more vulnerable sections of society, the people who rely disproportionately on public services. In my own country, Ireland, the cuts in health expenditure between 2009 and 2011 were of the order of 17% and, according to Social Justice Ireland, the cuts in 2013 amounted to 5%. That comes to more than one-fifth of the healthcare budget, and the impact on access to healthcare and life-saving medicines has been huge. Lastly, I want to add my voice to the long list of organisations, including the European consumer organisation AGE Platform, and the Standing Committee of European Doctors, asking Commissioner Juncker to revisit his decision to move medicinal products and health technologies into the portfolio of the Commissioner for the Internal Market. That Commissioner’s mandate, of course, is to promote the competitiveness of the industry, whereas the main driver of EU policies on medicine and health technologies should be the promotion of health and patient safety.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, to have a pharmacist who charges EUR 60 000 or EUR 50 000 for the treatment of a hepatitis C patient for three months is a disgrace. In Portugal, if this medicine were to be applied to all hepatitis C patients, it would mean paying for this medicine the equivalent of the costs of all medicines now spent in hospitals.  What we do know is that patents and patent monopoly, along side austerity, are completely killing health systems. And it is not for the sake of innovation, because only 10 % of the cost that is paid for the medicine is devoted to research. It's not innovation, it's really about profit, shameful profit. If this 10 % were invested in research, states and taxpayers would not be able to pay the 90 % profit.  The Commission says that it cannot do anything about this in relation to prices. You may not do it in relation to prices, but you can do it for patents. It can help to end these monopolies, which are being paid for by states. It can help to end monopolies, so there is political will.

name: Margrete Auken (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mr President! This debate shows that we need to do something if the greed and cynicism of the pharmaceutical industry is completely limitless. And we can do something! I think the Commission is aware that up to 50% of research/development costs are paid by the public sector, after which we let the industry plunder us. That is exactly where we need to address now. Of course, we should not move the pharmaceutical industry to the Enterprise DG. It's a very, very cynical idea. But we also really need to look at the whole way this is knitted together. We are plundering the countries, we are letting people die, and we can react. What is lacking here is a tiny little insight, and then there is political will. As the economist Mariana Mazzucato said: "We have socialised the risks and privatised profits with this system." So we should do the opposite.

name: Γιώργος Γραμματικάκης (S&D). -
text: Mr President, there have been significant shortages of medicines in Greece in recent years. There he led an explosive mix of factors directly related to the economic crisis and the harsh and absurd memoranda imposed on the country. As part of a rationalisation of pharmaceutical expenditure, drug prices have fallen sharply. But they also created significant side effects. Various pharmaceutical companies have reduced the quantities of imports or stopped them completely. Parallel exports of medicines to European Union countries where prices are higher have forced the National Medicines Agency to proceed with a series of bans.  A small country like Greece does not have the means to resist the cessation or reduction of imports of pharmaceutical companies. A new European framework is therefore necessary to introduce an obligation for companies to provide their products to countries in financial difficulties. When the health of our fellow citizens is threatened there are no delays that ... (The President interrupts the speaker.)

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, in Europe and the United States medicines are the third leading cause of death, following cancer and heart disease: it is clear that greater control of the drugs marketed is needed. Some 170 million people have hepatitis C worldwide and some 800,000 people in Spain; conventional treatment achieves about 70% healings, but has a high number of serious side effects, so many patients cannot initiate it. Recently new drugs have appeared that manage to cure the vast majority of treated patients, 95%, without major side effects, but their price is extraordinarily high, which makes individual acquisition inaccessible for most people who need it and makes it difficult for public health systems to be treated, given that dozens of people need to be treated. It is unacceptable to set such high prices for medicines so necessary. We call for a decrease in the price of these medicines that makes treatment possible. We cannot be silent witnesses to the progressive deterioration and death of these patients when there are effective and safe treatments.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D). -
text: Mr President, the European Medicines Agency approved sofosbuvir a few months ago, which eradicates hepatitis C in 90% of cases and costs at least EUR 60 000 per treatment. The first thing the European Medicines Agency should do is investigate a possible case of abuse, especially when the company that manufactures it negotiates with companies in India to sell its technology to produce generics at a cost of 1,400 euros. On the other hand, it is high time that the necessary reform of the 1988 Directive on transparency in the pricing of medicinal products and their reimbursement should finally be unlocked and measures are taken to ensure the sustainability of different national health systems. Ladies and gentlemen, purchasing power cannot be discriminatory for access to life-saving medicines, as is the case or that of anticancers. Health care is not the responsibility of the European Union, but it is the internal market, competition or intellectual property rights and research. Therefore, let us not allow health to be marketed.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, the Commission is coming here today to make a statement to us on access to vital medicines in Europe. The issue lends itself, of course, to pious and kind-hearted statements, and the Commission says it is concerned about the costs and difficulty of accessto various medicines and, surprisingly, the inequality in that access, and wants to help Member States in this area. The European Commission, the same Commission as part of the troika, the same troika which, for example, in Portugal, and illegitimately imposed an increase in the price of medicines and a reduction in state contributions, resulting in serious limitations in access to medicines.  Many users, especially older and lower-income users, now have an option: either medicines in the pharmacy or food. Some hospitals have stopped providing medicines to users in hospital pharmacies. It is often said: a lot helps those who do not disturb. Member States are responsible for the organisation of health services, health systems and the resources allocated to them. It is necessary to confront the transnational smeareof the medicine, but we cannot count on this European Commission to do so... (The President withdraws his word to the speaker)

name: Connie Hedegaard
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, you will understand why, at this late hour, I will not go into much detail on what you have been saying. Needless to say, the sense of what you have suggested and reflected on here tonight will be conveyed to Commissioner Borg, who is responsible for this portfolio. He will also have people from his team who are listening to this debate and taking notes. As early as tomorrow, experts from the working group and from the Member States will meet and discuss this, so that could be one opportunity for Member States to try to continue this debate and take it forward. However, I have to say to Mr Ferreira, who in his closing remarks here talked about the pricing of medicine: I am sorry, but I have to restate that the pricing of medicine is not within EU competence. That does not mean that there is nothing we can do at EU level; there are other things, for instance, the exchange of information. There are other things, and as far as I understand it, the informal Health Council will actually have this on their agenda at their next meeting. Thank you very much for the input. As I said, it will be conveyed to Commissioner Borg, who is responsible for this area.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: The debate is closed.
